GAME: Battlestar Galactica: The Board Game
RANK: 59
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This game brings emotion like few others do. Shocking big moves, huge swings, nail-biting tension... So much fun.
This was The Game for a good 5 years.

----
(gift/free/prize)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Despite never having watched a single episode of the show, I took to this right away. It's my current "can't wait to play this again" hotness-of-the-moment game.

Update: I have now started watching the show because I enjoyed the game so much. Now I get what all the hype was about :) Still loving the game, too.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Based on 3 plays.
The rules are pretty hard to get to grips with without someone who knows the game - just so much stuff to grasp.  But after 1 play I think we understand the game.
Worth watching the rules video explanation if you are playing from scratch.
http://www.mevio.com/shows/?sId=15871&mId=6124298

And verdict:  loved it. Can't wait to play again!

After 3 plays still struggling with some of the fiddly bits of the rules.
Starting to think that the game takes too long to play (4 hours last night). Downgraded from 9 to 8.
I find it incredibly tense and traumatic being a human - which is great that a game can generate those feelings....
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
The core mechanics are ok, but nothing to write home about (probably worth a 6 out of 10). However, the presence of a Cylon(s) is what really makes this game shine. There is so much mistrust around and the Cylon players can really influence the game in their favour without necessarily revealing themselves. Great table banter although can be a little long

RATING: 6

RATING: 4
"Going through the motions: the Game"
Everyone says you don't have to know the series to enjoy Galactica. You kinda do.
Otherwise there is neither intuition nor logic behind what happens. 
It drags on forever.

I love deduction, bluffing, negotiation, co-operation in games. Here they do nothing for me. Feels forced, artificial, clunky.

Like an elaborate, too ambitious version of Avalon. Yeah i said it. Suck it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Played this for the first time. It took a while for us to get into a rhythm, rather than referring to the rule book every few minutes (not unexpected). We had quite a bit of fun, although the frequency of the crisis cards led to a depletion of action cards and made it easier for the Cylon player (me) to cause damage. All in all, we had fun and would play this again, but not on a frequent basis --- we felt a need to recover!

RATING: 10
An excellent semi-cooperative, oozing with theme, and full of delicious betrayal & deceit. My one complaint is that the game depends too much on the Crisis deck from my liking - constantly drawing Cylon attacks/no jump cards massively disadvantages the humans, while never drawing a Cylon attack card hurts the Cylon very hard.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
I was exceedingly underwhelmed by this one.  It lasts over 3 hours, and I felt like nothing I did really mattered, the game's pace was ultimately decided by the fate card drawn each turn.  You could easily just turn over the top 10-20 fate cards and figure out if you won or not. There is a lot of theme crammed into it, and a lot of player interaction, but no strategy whatsoever.  It is more like a weak role-playing game than anything.

RATING: 9
Best with 5 players (6, 4 ok, can learn with 3).
Has immense replay value especially with the expansions (you can add just the modules you like). With the expansion you can adjust the game according to the evolution of your group's game play skills.

Get Daybreak for 4-player games, the Cylon Leader Motives really make very interesting games.

RATING: 7.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.9
First off, BIG fan of the show. I was really looking forward to playing this game after a friend bought it. So we've played 2 games of it and though I do enjoy it, there are problems. First problem is with the pilot characters. Once you play a pilot (even a hottie like Boomer), you probably won't want to play that role again. There can be long periods of boredom playing that role and that's not fun gaming. The other problem is play time. This puppy is a long one and I mean 4-6 hours long. Okay, I'm a bit A.D.D. but this game will try anyone's attention span. Now beyond those two issues, there's lots of fun to be had. Trying to ferret out the Cylon player is good detective fun. If you're the Cylon, you get to brush up on your acting skills. As many players have commented, there's plenty of paranoia starting about mid-game. It's juicy fun not knowing what the next crisis might be or if the President is a toaster or not when ugly crisis come back to back. This is the kind of game that can really be enjoyed by the right group (at least 4 players). 

**Update**
Too long. Plenty of thematic play but it just takes forever. I could have easily played 2 other games (to completion) by the time this was over.

WHO just killed the skill check, and is it now obvious who they are at this point?

Fun abounds.

RATING: 10
Another favourite game of mine, where the players slip into the personas of Adama, Starbuck, Apollo and many more. Loyalty cards define if you are a hidden agent of the cylons as there are models now thast look completely human.

The human struggle against crisis hammering on the fleet and dwindling resources require a lot of communication and strategy to be able to overcome the obstacles that are being given each turn.

I think this game would really shine with repeated plays, but I probably will never get to that point.

RATING: 6

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This game can be incredibly punishing at times, but never loses its thematic feel. This should be the golden standard for licensed games, as you really feel, through the character powers/skill checks/locations/crisis cards, like you are on the Battlestar Galactica itself. From behind a facade of tactical combat, this game shows its true self: a bluffing/manipulation exercise. The real difficulty/beauty of this game isn't in blasting the most Cylons, but in deceiving the most players and hiding your true motives. That being said, the game suffers at 4 and, to a lesser degree, 6 players because of lack of balance for the Cylon players, but this is my go-to 5-player game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 1
It does okay at capturing the feel of the early re-imagined series, but game play is dreadful. Too much time between turns, too many random elements that can leave a player with nothing meaningful to do. The admiral gets to make far too many decisions and the other players are bored to tears.

This is the only game I have played that if it were to hit the table again I would leave; just thinking about it elicits such incredible revulsion.

RATING: 4
2 games, played with 5/6 players.
LIKE: Thematic. fighting the ships is fun. Liked the accusation and mystery Cylons.
DISLIKE: Too long, too brutal. I found the "challenge cards" too long to resolve and the consequences too harsh. sometimes you'd even take a penalty if you pass, which I did not like.
OVERALL: pass. it's more fun to be the Cylons.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
The three-pronged approach for determining the Cylon is amazing:
1) The handful of cards and abilities that let you look at someone's loyalty card (Hard, Rare Knowledge)
2) The statistical games you can play with who contributed or didn't contribute various cards to Crises (Less Hard, Frequent Knowledge)
3) Reading people, probing them with questions, and interpreting their reactions (Soft, Constant Knowledge)

There's so much interplay with those three strategies, and they brilliantly culminate in a 15 minute shouting fest about whether or not Uncle Dan is a frakking cylon (spoiler: he is!).

I'm not aware of a better hidden-traitor game. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4.5
With one play under my belt, I'm not terribly willing to play again. I wasn't overly impressed with it, but enjoyed it due to the folks I played with (who love BSG). In our game, we had 3 cylons to deal with at the end, so the humans were just begging for a mercy killing. The game ran long - about 4 hours. Love the theme and the mechanics are surprisingly smart albeit very repetitive. Has nice ebb and flow with cyclons appearing en masse followed by momentary calm after a jump.

All in all, this game is being carried by its theme, the simple fact there are opportunities to be crafty as cylons and obviously fans of the show (or fanboys of FFG) who will crave to play it like a watered down RPG. Others will likely find it only so-so because as a *game* it only serves to carry the accusations of "you're a toaster!".
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Muy buen juego bien ambientado en la serie, sensaciones auténticamente temáticas, como muy pocos juegos consiguen, a mi parecer. Un semi-cooperativo que me ha gustado (porque no es cooperativo puro, al haber cylons ocultos...), y de ocultación de rol inicial. Mucho azar pero también mucha emoción. Las expansiones aportan detalles a tener en cuenta, aunque el juego es ya muy largo de por sí (4h o más), es su mayor "defecto". A 5 jugadores va de maravilla y a 6 yo creo que incluso mejor (3 humanos y 2 cylons + Simpatizante que puede ser de un bando u otro), a otros no lo he probado.
Le veo como punto flaco también, que no está nada compensando, le faltan algunos detallitos para ayudar un pelín más a los humanos ya que el 80% de partidas ganan los Cylon... por ello yo recomendaría jugar sobretodo al principio, con las reglas opcionales (y oficiales del manual) de setup con +2 recursos de cada uno de los 4 a favor de los humanos.

RATING: 7
Wonderful hidden traitor / Asymmetrical Co-Op game. Very easy for beginners to get into and does not feel like it takes three hours to play although most of the time it does. 

My least favorite part of the game however is the nomenclature of the plastic pieces and the combat tables. As someone who has seen the show I know what a Viper is but the rule book is not so forgiving to players who may like this style game but have not indulged in 4 seasons of the show.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Is this the best political game of all? Its hard to tell in really heavy combat, but I'd back it against Rep of Rome. Easily FFG's best in-house design and very nearly their best product ever. Top-quality design. A very fine TV-series-to-boardgame conversion that invites a long hard look at the revered but aged Dune. A genuine co-op game for the co-operators, given that a large proportion of the players ally with the game to beat them. It begins to capture the underlying subtly and sophistication of the power-politics situation as portrayed on TV...as well as everything else, which is remarkable in a game as simple as this. "Whats not to like" is a good question. Cylon rules are questionable. Requires decent gamers [and its interesting how many commentators mention this]. And no Tricia Helfer, not even in delusional form for a cylonic Baltar. Unfair to compare to Shadows as its far too good for that.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Our first game had pretty poorly shuffled cards which made it almost impossible for the humans to win. I won (as a cylon) even though I'm a terrible liar.

RATING: 7
Picked this up to try with our D&D group, and the response has been very positive!  Everyone involved so far has enjoyed playing, and I have to admit that it gives a very unique experience.  Lots of fun when we can get enough people!

Update: Going to have to bump this up to a 9 due to how much fun everyone has when we get it to the table.

Update: Looks like the honeymoon is over!  Can't get this one to the table any more.  Long setup time, tricky to explain the rules to new players, and large player requirement.  Dead of Winter has pretty much replaced it.

RATING: 9
Thrilling, complex, and paranoia-inducing. VERY thematic and detailed. As a longtime fan of the show, I adore this game.

RATING: 4

Someone will be a cylon , everyone will be accused of being a cylon, it will be funny for the first 30 minutes (you can also have this same enjoyment by calling out to players in the game from another table that they are a cylon - no need to even play it)

I prefer The Resistance instead, 20-30 minutes of pure treachery and then the game is over and you can enjoy another round or another game without having to sit through another 2 hours of BSG.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Most games based on TV shows suck, but this one really captures the spirit of the first 3 seasons of BSG.  Lots of cooperation is required to survive while some players are trying to undermine you.  This is one of the most interactive games out there.  And even better, nearly every move and decision has a built in fog of war that creates tension and distrust.  You spend a lot of time trying to explain why you are not a Cylon and rationalize your actions -- which is even more fun when you ARE the Cylon.
The downside is that it takes a big group (5-6) to really make it shine, the game can seem quite repetitive, and it usually goes about 1 hour too long.  I've played both Colonial and Cylon and either side is fun, but it's a lot more fun to be the Cylon.  

I traded my copy because I never got to play it, and when I did, I joined a group at a guy's house and he would set up his copy in advance.

[b]Update:[/b] I decided that this is an awesome game the first couple of times that you play it, but over time, it loses some of its luster because it takes a long time and doesn't have a lot of variety in the cards.  You could buy the expansions, but they cost a lot and the game still takes a long and requires a lot of players, so I choose not to go that route.  For me, it's a "once a year" game: very good, but not great.

[b]Update II:[/b] This one is falling fast.  The mechanics are nothing special and become quite tedious.  The thrill is in the psychological game and the interaction.  Now, too many players have figured out that if you are not the admiral or the president, that you should reveal early.  When that is the case, it becomes a bit dull.  The thrill is gone.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: N/A

I hear many stories that this is not a normal situation, but I'm not really excited about investing time into learning a game that is as swingy as this.  I already know how to play Dead of Winter (aka I've done the investment) so I'd rather play that.  This game felt like much ado about nothing.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
It's reputation is well deserved. It is a game of intrigue that makes it so much more than just a more 'complicated resistance(Another lighter boardgame)'. This is done with the actions and cards one plays and the events that results in many layers of deceit and paranoia. All this also culminates in the theme coming out so much better than resistance. Another plus is the game can work with more passive players as you can passively help or not help with a situation and since most of the time, it is hard to just flat out be sure someone is a Cylon, the passive players can play without too much worry of too much 'attention', unlike Game of Thrones where all eyes are on you the minute you break a promise. 

Downside, it is heavily dependent on the players, as one horror story I heard that someone revealed she is a Cylon on the first turn and ruined the game. Also, the game seems to work best at 5 to 6 players and takes a while to play.

Overall, a fine game I enjoy and even though I love Game of Thrones the boardgame too. I will find this game easier to table as it fits a wider crowd than Game of Thrones for example.

RATING: 9
I HIGHLY recommend the variants/expansion listed here:
http://boardgamegeek.com/thread/399183/

My rating is a 9 with this, lower playing the rules as written.

The variant lowers game length a bit, and greatly improves balance in a number of ways:
Balances human vs cylon win% some.
Balances different #s of players to have closer Cylon win% as each other.
Balances initial cylons vs those who receive the Cylon card in sleeper agents.
Balances the character cards greatly, makes some of them much more interesitng, and adds new and interesting characters as well.
Balances the skill cards some, reducing the importance of this (broken?) Investigative Committee, and making/making the Press Room less of a dominant strategy, and making Engineering cards worthwhile, strengthening blue characters to a reasonable level.

And more...

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Thematic game indeed. Mechanics work well with this storyline that is card driven and provides players with choices. 

The pros, includes event cards that provides options to players but most of them are detrimental towards ending the game.

The multiple character powers are also flavorful. The components are top notch.

The cons.......

The actions are somewhat limited by what the crisis cards does to the game. The whole game is played in accordance to what crisis we passed and which crisis we failed and thus have to react to it. Repairs, shoot down raiders, etc. 

Not a bad thing, but makes you feel that the game is playing you, and you have to stop a time-bomb from happening, which you do not exactly have the option over it. The more players there are just drives the game to such ending that much faster.

The cyclon players just helps the system move a bit faster to the ultimate end. Good, skilled cyclon players just bring the inevitable a turn or two faster to its end.

A good human player, may not necessary be that good but the luck of the crisis cards and the jump cards are just favourable for the game session.

Play the game, guess how many jump cards it takes to end the game, and we are almost there.

Interesting game, up a notch for theme. Arkham horror might be a better bet.

RATING: 7.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.8
Players are divided into 2 groups, humans and cylons.  The identities of the players (humans or cylons) are kept secret unless they are accused by fellow players.

The objectives of the humans are simple.  They need to jump enough distance to reach kobol.  How about the cylons?  They will win by making the humans lose through various ways.  The first way is by attacking Galactica which if Galactica suffers 6 damages at 1 time.  Another way to destroy the humans is by depleting the resources of the humans or let the centurion infiltrate into Galactica successful.

There are 3 kinds of crisis in the game which the humans must handle.  They are cylon attack crises, skill check crises and event crises.

Good points:
Another semi-cooperative game similar to Shadows over Camelot.  I feel that it is more thrilling to be a traitor in Shadows but in Battlestar, it is more fun to be a human than a cylon.  Human players require more thinking to spot the cylons and even if the cylons reveal themselves, they must counter those challenges the cylons provides them with.  It is essential to have cylon players to be in the game to provide the additional challenges.

Bad points:
Cylon players are a little too powerful but a tad too little actions to play with in the game.  If cylon players are stuck in the brig, then they have basically nothing much to play in the game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 5
The Zen Paradox: Why is it that if there is nothing wrong with this game, what is wrong with it is so very wrong?

I had fun playing the game, but the design is inelegant. That die steals so much from it that I want to cry. Whether it was interference from the SciFi Network, a looming deadline, laziness, or ignorance, that single eight-sided die takes what could have been a game like no other and turns it into a completely average thing.

RATING: 5
Brutally tough semi co-op game in the manner of Shadows Over Camelot.

Fits the classic template of emergent crises overcome with cards with one extra wrinkle:

A second set of loyalty cards are dealt at the halfway stage to players, so some previously loyal member of your crew can suddenylt turn evil.

Nasty, fun and captures the feel and tension of the show wonderfully.

A

RATING: 8
Recreates the tension from the series quite well, not to complicated as long as at least one person is familiar with the rules.

Can tend to drag a bit too long for what it is, but as long as everybody contributes to the tension and paranoia the game need for its length, it works great.

House rule: Everybody need to read (or stare at) their role card for at least a minute, so that players not familiar with the cylon special text get a chance to memorize it.

RATING: 9

RATING: 10
A game that is faithful to the show.  It's tough to be a human.  Also, your allegiance can change halfway through the game to become a Cylon.  Great strategy game where the turn of just one card can make the difference in your destiny.  I have only played the basic game so far.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This game is probably the biggest surprise of the year for me. I picked it up through Borders because I had a gift card for the holidays. I rarely shop there and remembered that this game was getting great reviews on BGG. I was skeptical because I had never seen the show and because it seemed like the game would be hinging on the player having done so.

I couldn't have been more wrong. The paranoia and politics of this game are incredible. The traitor (cylon) mechanic is well thought out and made for great gaming experiences. The one piece of advice I have about this game is not to over play when you first get it. You'll want to, but you'll find that it loses some of it's luster through multiple subsequent plays. This could be because of the length and because of it's semi-cooperative nature.

Either way, this is a great game and one that my gaming group has had a lot of fun with.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

A fantastic traitor game! This game shines with 4 or more players and is a blast to have with the right group. Lots of accusations flying back and forth, plus all the drama of the situations themselves. Overall always a great time when it hits the table.

RATING: 9
v
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.9
I have never seen the show and I am not a fan of science fiction. I suspect that if I were (on either or both accounts) my rating would be MUCH higher! As it is, Mr. Konieczka has done such an excellent job at making sure that every possible aspect of the TV show is in this game that it results in a somewhat unwieldy game that could benefit from being simplified just a tad....and maybe with a few less die roll dependent events! Mind you, if it was themed differently (and I hope this happens!) then I would probably be ranting and raving about how glorious it is! The one thing that I have a definite dislike for, though, is the photo art from the TV series pasted all over the place: it just irritates me for some reason, possibly because it reminds me of those dreadful Star Wars boardgames from the late '70's. And the action cards used for skill checks are just way too small for quick ease of reading.
Having said all that, it is a very, very good game if you are fond of (as I am) bluffing in games, and are a good actor. Give it a different theme and larger cards, Mr. Konieczka, and I might have given it a 9....at least!

Pros

- Brings out accusations

Cons
- It can get long and a little straight up whenever the Cylons are known
- Plays best with 5 or 6 (without sympathizer), and doesn't work with the rest
- Longer game to teach
- Most people will not be into it as much if they haven't seen the show
- Revealed cylons don't have much to do in the base game once revealed
- Going through the motions whenever every player is revealed

Sold/Traded because:
- Too long for my group
- Not enough of my friends have seen the show
- Needs 5 or 6 people to play 
- The Resistance does it better, is more accessible, shorter, and scales better. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

my favorite show ever, probably wouldn't work well with just two people though. How I still long for BSG in any form though...

RATING: 4
Meh. 

I love the show and like the basic structure of this game, but the core game-play is just a hastily cobbled together structure upon which the "traitor" mechanic sits. 

This wouldn't be a bad thing, in and of itself, but the game lasts FAR too long for what little enjoyment comes from the psychological metagame (i.e. the fun part). 

A lot rides on the cylon players - if they reveal too soon then the game feels boring. If they play it right then it can be fun for a bit longer, but ultimately only 1 or 2 players gets the "real" fun and the rest are just trying to sniff the baddie out. The Cylon, on the other hand, misses out on the detective game and only gets to mitigate boredom through deception (fun for some, not all). 

Meh.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
3-6(5)

It's long, sometimes drags (depending on Cylon attack distributions), and loses some theme in that it's just a bunch of skill checks. Still, the meat of it (managing resources and a long con of being a Cylon) are tense and intriguing. I've played the Resistance, and liked it a lot for distilling the traitor mechanic into a quick game, while supporting many people, but sometimes the Resistance turns into a "he said, she said" crap shoot, whereas BSG offers more opportunities to actually think out who the traitor is. Still, it's long and feels even longer if there aren't any Cylons on the board (so you're just collecting cards, or something).

It feels like I'd really need to play this with five to completely balance the experience. You don't have a Cylon struggling to sabotage (nor wonky sympathizer balancing), and it sort of justifies the length.

RATING: 10
Simply the best game to play with my group of friends. It's just fun. The base game is perfect, the expansions though I am not a huge fan of.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
When I saw this in stores, I always ignored it, assuming that a game based on a TV show was designed primarily to be fun for fans of the show (which I am not), at the expense of being fun for anyone else (which I am).

I have been pleasantly surprised.

I've only played a few games, but this game's loyalty system blows those in Shadows Over Camelot or Bang! out of the water.  Additionally, there is an interesting mix of character abilities, and the core skill check mechanic is fairly solid.

My complaints are simple and few: there is a disappointing lack of different strategy cards, and there is a significant range of power in the Crisis deck, making the luck-to-strategy ratio a bit high for my taste.

(Update) Unfortunately, going to downgrade this one from an 8 to a 7, as either we're hopelessly terrible at this game (but only some of us, sometimes) or this game is hopelessly imbalanced.  The part of me that likes to win is starting to get excited every time I see a "You are a Cylon" card, since I've basically been assured an easy victory.  However, the part of me that actually likes competitive games is starting to get a bit tired of this game.

(Update Update) We've been playing this with the recommended variant of "Start the humans with 2 more of everything", and it seems to do the trick (Maybe a little too much; we should try "Start the humans with 1 more of everything"). If your group finds that the Cylons win too often for your collective taste, try this.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Love a good game of BSG. Definitely needs a specific type of gaming group, but the banter and intrigue that goes back and forth is really fun and makes the game a true experience.

RATING: 7
Brilliant game mechanics at the heart of it, but I find the game a little too involved and too geeky

RATING: 10

RATING: N/A
Bari
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
The obvious comparison, because of the traitor/cylon mechanism and cooperative play, is with Shadows Over Camelot.  In terms of thematic gameplay and the range of options open to the players, Galactica is a clear advance on Shadows.  

My opinion of Galactica really has yo-yo'ed.  First game, three player, humans quickly lost but it was exciting, immersive and tense.  Second game, six players, similarly engaging, but we abandoned after three hours, only half way to Earth.  Third game, different group of six players, same result and the game play felt a bit flat and samey.  Fourth game, another different group of five players, much paranoia, a knife-edge finish and the most fun I've had with a boardgame in ages.

What do I make of this?  I think that, much like a role playing game, your experience with Galactica will depend a great deal on the other players.  Add to this a rather variable game length; sometimes it will outstay its welcome and/or the time you have available.

Artwork and production quality are up to the usual FFG standards. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 5
OOOOKAY. I really like this game's theme. It perfectly captures the feel of the show for the non-traitors and is full of nostalgic moments, plus playing as the characters from the show with their own special powers is appealing. I also think the game is pretty well balanced. However, the good theme doesn't necessarily make the game fun to play. 

I've played this game in two different groups, both with bad results. One group just dislikes cooperative games in general and didn't have a good time. The other group didn't appreciate the game's length - the game can stretch on for hours. I also feel the rules as written don't adequately explain the mechanic of the cylon reveal which led to some exasperated cylons who didn't understand how to activate.

I'm slightly tempted to consult the community and fill in the gaps, but honestly, I'm not sure I want to bother. I've had a near-universally bad time playing this game and I don't really want to throw good game time after bad.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7

For this type of game I much prefer Resistance, where a similar amount of fun occurs in a much shorter amount of time.

[Updated March 2012]
After having played more of BSG, I think my feelings are largely solidified.  It's not a bad game, and I will play it, and have some fun with it, but there will always be parts of the design that nag me.  On top of this, although I haven't played either expansion, I know what both do, and I feel their systems only serve to irk me more.

RATING: 9
It took a lot to get me watch the remake TV series this game is based on. When I finally got over my prejudice, I couldn't believe what an amazing show it actually was. A few years later I discover there is this board game based on the show. As a gamer, I'm immediately put off because games based TV shows/movies are pretty much always awful. I should have learned my lesson about judging a book by it's cover. When I finally played the game I was amazed at not just how well it captured the feel of the show, but how innovative and compelling the game was in it's own right. It plays best with 5+ players, and avoids feeling bogged down with so many players by being extremely social. It's one of my favorite games of all time.

RATING: 6.5
For fans of the series, there is much that is appealing about the game.  The theme is tightly tied to the storyline.  The characters are meaningful personalities.  If you've never seen the TV show, the game's theme will fall a bit short.  While that may happen, don't confuse the game's theme appeal with the game play.  Theme aside, the game play is quite good.  There's not a lot that's really new (co-op with traitors), but the delayed reveal of the traitor is actually very cool.  The game helps the traitor(s) play convincingly if only because they don't yet know they are the 'baddies'.  The implementation is well done and the components typical of FFG's high standards.

RATING: 9
What can I say, this game is fantastic.
Obviously playtested to death to get the balance just right. The games I played so far had a very close neck-to-neck finale that was both breathtaking and incredibly involving. Mechanicaly this is a very simple straithforward design with my slight worry that the limited variety in the cards (undoubtly fixed by the expansions) might render the game samey in the long run, but so far almost no game comes close of generating such an intensity and interaction bar possibly TI3.
For me my second favorite FFG release and a great
return to form after the weak Tannhauser and Dust.

RATING: 8.5
This game would probably get a 10 from me, but it requires 5 players to really be in it's sweet spot.  As long as there are exactly 5 players though, this is the game I always want to play with a group of that size!  The level of intrigue in this game is amazing and it is always a blast to play!  The game can be a bit long, but if you have players willing to dedicate an evening, it definitely won't disappoint!

Game can be taught within a few minutes.

You don't have to have seen the show to enjoy the game.  I learned the game and was loving it before I had seen it.  However, now that I have seen the show, I do love the references and how the mechanics relate to the characters in the show.

I always have fun with this game!

RATING: 8
Great semi-cooperative thematic game.

Has clever ways of simulating the tension of the show between the humans, the humans that hold powerful offices and are suspected of being cylons and the cylons who are trying to sabotage the human efforts to make the journey to Kobol.

Having said that, the experience of play can vary wildly. I've played some games that ranked among the best gaming experiences I've ever had while others were dull exercises in futility.

RATING: 6
We had quite fun with this on our 2nd play with 4 players, I think that's a minimum, the more the merrier I suspect. It's quite easy to fit 6 people around this game because there's little more then a hand of cards for each player and then a board and components for that. Quite easy to bring in new players because the game is mostly open and straight forward. This game drips with theme and it's more of an experience to play, you don't know what will happen in each game. This feeling is enhanced by the fact that it's a cooperative game but knowing that one or more player might be a cylon, or might become one later, makes the game more fun to play (especially as a cylon). With 4+ players there's a chance of 2 or 3 cylons working together, so you win on loose as a team.

RATING: 6
I've played three games.  One game was an epic experience in intrigue, crisis management, and victory (or defeat) by the slimmest of margins.  Awesome.  One game was a cakewalk for the humans where most people did nothing on their turns but collect cards.  Sucky.  The last game started out as the previous game did, but then 4 Cylon fleets came out in a row and raped every last civilian ship on the board.  There was absolutely no way the humans could have won and the Cylon victory had nothing to do with how they played.  I think this game needs a stacked deck ala Pandemic in order to avoid the above tragedy.  Incidentally, I have never been a Cylon yet.  Boo.

Edit: Lots of plays since then.  The Cylon Fleet board is necessary for this to be a game at all.  It seems like the Cylons have a distinct advantage, but that's not necessarily a bad thing.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
An excellent hidden-traitor game based on the 2004 re-imagining of the classic 70s TV show.

The humans are fleeing the cylons and need to find a safe place before the game-controlled and secret cylons manage to destroy them. Though as in the series, no safe place is safe for long: each box (Base, Pegasus, Exodus and Daybreak) covers each of the four series respectively and each one adds exciting new mechanics into the game.

Highly recommended, though it may take a few games before your players are used to bluffing and spotting bluffs enough.

Be warned though: this game is brutal for the humans. We once played a three-player game where the only cylon card was not drawn and still lost, and a four-player game where the cylon mis-read his card and thought he was human, and we still lost. Out of all my games I have only seen the humans win three times. But we all still love the game and enjoy playing it regardless (and most of us are disappointed when we are cylons).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Once one of my favorite games, unfortunately nowadays mechanics feel quite heavy compared to what the game has to offer.

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
One of the coolest mechanics I've seen in a game. Secretly working against everyone while playing as a Cylon is extremely difficult - you find yourself attempting to reason your way out of situations, frame other players, and perform "good" actions in public just so others don't find you out.

Playing as a human reminds me of the game "Paranoia." You know there's a traitor... and you're PRETTY sure it's everyone around you. You find yourself over-analyzing, and attempting to trap people into making decisions that will reveal themselves.

I tried this game twice. I had never seen the show. After trying the game, my wife and I went out and began watching because the concept was so cool.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Awesome. Played it twice so far. We messed up the loyalty deck in the first game (there were only 2 humans in the end, though I think we would have won it if we had played it out). In the second game, the humans lost after we'd jumped 4 range factors. Our viper patrols were more or less wiped out and we got very few jump cards...awesome but hard!

OK -- so, I've played this one 4 times and 3 times we or I have messed up the loyalty deck...what gives?

This game truly is brilliant. So, in the last game, we've got 8 jump factors and have loads of room on the dials -- looks like a clean human win...within 10 minutes (no exaggeration), the frakkin' toasters have their force pool on the map and have driven our jump prep back to the beginning...they take out about 5 civilian ships on one turn and that's it...humans lose...again! Never seen a human win to this point, but it doesn't matter -- the game is so great!

12 plays and my record... 0-12!! And I've never seen a human victory except the one time I was a Cylon...still, a great, great game!

Finally a victory...on game 15. 1-14...not a great record, but still a great game. Pegasus expansion without the New Caprica board is the way to go forward. Admiral Cain's special power to draw a Kobol card was the decisive move.

Back to form on game 16 - losing with the Cylons this time. And to think, with me being Chief Tyrol going over to the toasters, I was certain that Galactica was doomed...ha!

Game 17 - I'm now 2-15! And as the humans again! A particularly exciting game. Admiral Cain's special power again proves decisive. Pegasus expansion definitely seems to swing the game's dynamic a bit towards the humans. In this game, the Cylons struggled to get their full powers to bear against Galactica. Human solidarity was very strong. Starbuck as Cylon struggled to thwart the humans and the Cylon leader's objective was to help humanity. Still, as is typical of this game, even with these factors, it was a tough run for the humans.

RATING: 5

RATING: 2
I think this game is poorly designed.  There's a hidden player mechanic to it, and it's very difficult to keep hidden.  One example of the difficulty: The player cards that tell you who you are and whether you're a Cylon are smaller than the other cards.  If you are a Cylon, and only if you are a Cylon, you will need to refer to your card during the game. 

There are other mechanics that have issues as well.  I can't see why you would use/do some of the options in the game.  It's a good idea, and uses a world I love, but it's clunky at best.

I think this game could use a second edition to clean up some of the issues with design and mechanics.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
Only one play but the game is fun, tense, every decision is hard. After you jump to hyperspace you get a little leeway from the cylon ships, but due to crisis cards, one minute you're navigating peacefully with no cylon ships around and the next minute a swarm of cylon ships come out of no where (actually come from crisis cards :p ) and problems start again until the fleet can jump again.

Didn't find the game to drag with 3 players.

The game is hard for the humans so I suggest using the variant in the rules that you start with all dials with 2 extra resources.

RATING: 6

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
By far one of the best games ever produced.
This semi-cooperative (traitor) game is full of tension, intrigue and steeped very deeply with plot and story.  Easily one of the best translations of a tv series or movie to a board game.

The game feels like you are actually in the BSG universe.  The designers pegged that feeling dead on.  I forsee this game getting play rotation for quite some time.  It is a timeless game which I think deserves to be in any collection.  Definitely one of my top ten.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.2
What an exceptional game! To have this and Pandemic hit the stores within a 12 month period is has really brightened my entire year. The traitor element allows for some potentially wonderful and subtle 'performances' by players - something that will appeal to both gamers and non-gamers alike. Who wouldn't welcome the chance to play the 'agent provocateur' - pitting the hapless remnants of humanity against themselves in an air of suspicion and half-truths? A remarkably faithful conversion of the TV show to the board capturing much of the shows nuance. Along with Pandemic, my joint favourite games, quite outstanding in their own ways.

RATING: 8
Very nice adaptation of the series (huge fan btw). A bit tough on the humans (as would realistically be), can't say I was overly impressed by the mechanics and my first plays didn't quite click with the group for me to score with confidence. I did enjoy it overall, but need a few more plays to make up my mind.
EDIT:After a few more plays, the rules stick with you, great replayability value, every play is somewhat different and exciting till the very last turn. Quite luck-prone but that is actually a good thing here, to me at least. One of my favorite games.

RATING: 5
Dec-21-2010
I finally came to grips with the fact that I don't enjoy traitor-mechanic driven games.  I grow tired quickly of trying to convince people of who the traitors are.  The game is a good entry for this genre.  Just not my cup of tea.  I sold my copy.
Update Rating: 7 -> 5.

Dec-26-2008
____ First Game with 4 players that took 4 hours (including rule explanation).  It certainly was on the long side but the good thing is that it didn't feel that long.  It could be that I was on vacation so I had a lot of disposable time and that I was also talking to friends in the house that were not playing the game.  The game is pretty simple to play but there are a lot of rules to keep track of.  
____ The game is all about a group of humans in a spaceship trying to find their new home.  However, one or more cylons can be some of the humans, whose sole purpose is to prevent the humans from reaching their new home.  This is what makes the game unique as people work together, there is a lot of second guessing and acusations and sub-optimal play from people that keeps the game from being just as a puzzle since this is a coop game.  I certainly enjoyed my time as everyone was accusing that each one is a cylon.  I think the longer the cylon reveals himself as a cylon the better the game becomes because the whole atmosphere of intrigue is maintained.  This game that we played the cylon revealed himself too soon and us humans were too efficient since we know we can trust ourselves completely.  This also made the game flat.

RATING: 8
Initial Impressions: A very highly thematic game. I can almost hear the theme music in the background (does that make me a cylon?). My favorite aspect of the game is the traitor mechanism. Once the traitor is revealed the tension and pace of the game really ramps up and the game becomes a race to achieve goals the quickest. Playtime is the perfect length for me.

10 Plays: Having played a number of other traitor games, I find the length and cardplay of this game to just the right amount in order to facilitate the buildup of deduction and paranoia. I'm still enjoying this game very much.

RATING: N/A
CSI $38
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
BSG is one of "those" games people will often either love or hate without a whole lot of in between. But another thing I find is that people often decide whether or not they love or hate it based on one experience. The problem with that is that perhaps not unlike other board games, one round of BSG can differ vastly than the next. I like to describe BSG as a game that has provided some of my favorite gaming experiences, (some of the best) & some of my least favorite experiences, (some the worst)!
BSG is a well designed game, but not an easy one. It suffers at times from the fact that many of it's teachers are woefully inadequate at teaching the many rules and intricacies of the game.
This is a difficult cooperative game with a hidden betrayer(s), sometimes the "bad guys" can win by simply not helping much and allowing the game to beat the players or by just giving that extra little push towards oblivion at the end.
You don't need to be a fan of the mini-series to be a fan of the game, in fact I've never seen a single episode of the show. (But I'm sort of interested now as a result of playing the game). 
The game can suffer a little when played with an unbalanced group. I prefer playing with more experienced players but will admit that I am still learning many of the games intricacies.
I also think this game suffers when whoever is teaching it takes an hour or more to teach (I've sat through that and thought I would hate the game as a result). 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
Similar mechanisms to 'Shadows over Camelot' but plays quit differently. First of all it's less abstract - it is still a card managing game but each character and location has different abilities. The skill resolution system, where everybody can secretly support or oppose the skill check, is great. The best thing is probably the 'Cylon Sleeper Agents' rule which causes a lot of additional tension.

RATING: 8
A fantastic 'hardcore' party game. Players assume role of a single person aboard the Galactica. One or more change into Cylons, that try to reduce humans food, sanity, fuel, etc before the humans escape. Highly political, very mature and can be difficult to learn for non seasoned gamers. Components and board: Fantasy Flight quality, as always.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Just an all around fantastic game. I was a bit intimidated at first, as the board looks extremely busy and there are numerous sets of cards, but after a couple of turns everyone picks up the rythm very easily. The design and balance are outstanding. One thing I must say is that very few games will be alike. The last two games we played were polar extremes in outcome. In the second to last, the humans won with little difficulty through a fortunate series of long jumps and almost no Base Star appearances. In the last game, the Galactica, pummeled by two Base Stars and having a Cylon revealing very early to add sabotage to the overall damage, was not even able to make a single jump before being destroyed!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Hard to be objective about this game since it’s my absolute no.1. I love it, I played it dozens of times, there is no other game I like more than this one. Made by one of my favorite game designers, based on one of my favorite TV shows. It’s just great.
That beeing said, the basic game has flaws. And quite a few of them actually. Three to be precise. 
First, I really dislike the sympathizer mechanic. It seems unfair and takes away the fun for one of the players halfway through the game. There is nothing worse than saying „sorry, you don’t play the deception game with us anymore, you are a cylon/human now and we all know about it”.
Second, it is not that interesting to be a revealed cylon. Almost literally nothing to do but the same, one thing over and over again. 
Third, the space combat is very random. There are games that you won’t get even one cylon ship around Galactica during the whole game. You just cruise through the galaxy calmly with a sense of… well, that nothing is happening. Plus, the pilots feel kind of useless when that happens.
I do need to write that all those flaws are beeing „fixed” with the expansions. The first by Daybreak (adding the mutineer instead of the sympathizer) and the last two by Exodus (cylon fleet), making the game perfect.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Took way too long to play. Around 3 hours, but we were all learning. The humans won.

RATING: 10
What else can be said about this game other then a pure gem! Granted, it can and sometimes will take a while to play the game but the investment can be worth it. People have said that games like the Resistance and others have made Battlestar obsolete, but I say NEH! Sure, those game can give you a traitor feel in a short amount of time, but with the added time in Battlestar your are more invested into the game and the loyalties of the people. The betrayals are more soul crushing and the victories are more grandiose.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Hard to know where to start on this one. I purposely have avoided this one for most of its life until now. but I have wanted to make a run of it. I am so glad to have had the chance. If you are a fan of the show, this will put you over the top, if you are not you may want to go and check it out. Do yourself a favor and just play another round of this, After you watch the miniseries, all of what transpires after will pale in comparison to your own tormented time in the universe. The tension can be really high, and the mechanic of knowing that there is a traitor or two in the mix is brilliant. The fact that this one leans so heavily on the group playing it for timbre is in itself remarkable, and that it puts you through the grinder is also. Play it, if you are a fan of or hate or have never seen, the series upon which this game is based, play it. everyone in that group will love it, only set aside hours and hours for it, you will not be sorry!

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Complicated to explain and difficult to get the hang of on the first play, but with a dedicated group this game explodes with awesomeness. The mechanics of the game are actually remarkably simple, but the traitor aspect colours every other part of the game and makes it a big, fun paranoia-fest. The fact that it's based on one of the best sci-fi TV shows ever made is icing on the cake. The length of the game is the main downside, and though the ending will often be tense and dramatic, it can sometimes be a big letdown if the good guys are looking hosed or the cylons handled their hidden role badly. It's tempting to recommend shorter hidden-role games like Avalon or One-Night Werewolf in BSG's place, but nothing quite matches BSG for epicness when it works. As a sidenote, I can't see myself ever needing an expansion, as it feels complete as is and definitely doesn't need to run any longer. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
One of the few Co-Op & traitor games I don't mind playing, though the game is damned hard even if you have clueless cylons.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Long and heavy, but it's the BEST game ever! The Pegasus and Exodus are "must have" expansions to BSG.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.8
Very well themed semi coop game. The infiltrated cylon mechanism creates an aura of paranoia around every action which feels right for this game. Solid gameplay with enough variety to keep things interesting for all players. Bad point is the Sympathizer rule used for 4 and 6 player games. Someone needs to come up with a good variant here as the original rules can be easily manipulated to greatly favour the humans. Plus it is no fun to become a sympathizer if it would actually happen. Also as in most FFG rules from this era it's almost impossible to find stuff. Bad index and sub optimal layout are the main causes.

Have the first two expansions which add some fun modules to the game which I would never play without. But also a lot which I will never ever use.  It also adds some nice bling to the game. Man do I love those basestars.

Gameplay: :star::star::star::halfstar::nostar:
Replayability: :star::star::star::star::halfstar:
Fun/Social: :star::star::star::star::halfstar:
Components: :star::star::star::star::halfstar:
Rules: :star::star::halfstar::nostar::nostar:

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
I have been forced to play Galactica twice this last Saturday and hated it: I ain’t interested in the new series, so I guess I lack the necessary identification with the characters, which is mandatory to fully understand the complex game mechanics and its theme.

My first run was pretty short: I happened to be a cylon and was immediately discovered in the first turn by the player after myself, who used her character’s special ability to check my alignment and give an executive order to another player, whose special ability was to shoot any player. I was shot and in less than a couple of minutes after the game started I found myself a cylon with almost nothing to do hence.
The second (forced) run was a better experience for I was human, yet I had little to do all the time, except for drawing some cards and giving executive orders to the other players when my turns came: it was a pretty boring play.

Nonetheless, what I disliked the most about this game is that «French Revolution atmosphere» it creates: Galactica should be a cooperative game, yet nobody can trust his fellow players for anybody could be an infiltrator. So you play in an atmosphere of suspicion, distrusting everyone and inciting others to do your bidding: this way all of the game’s dynamics come down to a «do this or else you’re a cylon» statement by the more experienced or motivated players.

All in all, you have to really like the series in order to enjoy (and understand) this game.
I surely didn’t.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 4.25
I have a strange relationship to this game. I played it and loved it, and playing it made me want to watch the series. Since watching the first season, I haven't wanted to play the game again.

RATING: 8

However, for those who are familiar with the show, this does SUCH a good job of capturing the feel of the characters and interactions. =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
As far as coop games go, Shadows Over Camelot is better.  I was very disappointed in this game.  The traitor mechanic in BSG is good, but other than that, after 4 hours of playing, we lost and realized that there was nothing we could have done differently to change the outcome.  Our Crisis cards came up midway through the game in this order:  Water shortage, Food Shortage, Food Shortage, Water Shortage.  Then a few turns later, another Food Shortage finished us off.  Since there is absolutely NO way of getting more food and no way of preventing the loss of food, there was no change in strategy or gameplay decision that anyone could have made to change the outcome.  Someone said, "well, that's in the spirit of the show."  Perhaps that's true, except that doesn't make a fun game.  4 hours lost.

In Shadows over Camelot, yes, you might get slammed with a lot of mean cards all at once, but at least there is always SOMETHING you can do about it.  You can combat any loss, mitigate any mishap, prevent a catastrophe. Not so in BSG.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Recommended to everyone.

RATING: 6
That was probably the most memorable board game that I have ever played!  The accusations and crazy logic was flying every which way... My newly acquired sleeper cylon status had my head swimming with schemes and looking forward to every new crisis card... And when the second cylon was finally revealed after our success, it was completely awesome!  Oh, what a great night!  But, playing this game with strangers would be dry and nerve-wracking... Even with good friends I kept worrying about feelings getting hurt.  This is one of those "games" where the machinations are just there to encourage the experience, and if all of the player's don't make their best effort to enhance the experience the machinations by themselves won't make for a fun time.

RATING: N/A
I really enjoy this, and I'll happily play it, but having played it a fair bit, there are a couple of things that can grate a bit. I don't like playing with someone who's aggressive in trying to convince people that someone's a Cylon - it feels like it can cross the line into intimidation. I also think the game only really works at its best with 6 people - with 4, it's extremely difficult for the Cylon to win, particularly if they don't learn they're a Cylon until after the midpoint. With 5, it's very difficult for the humans to win, particularly if the Cylons can reveal early. 6 feels very much like the sweet spot for this.

When the game runs well, with a nice group of people, I love it as much as I do Stone Age and Arkham Horror.

RATING: 10
This is the best game with a traitor element I know. The tension about the identity of the cylon just sits over the table; I've never been less than fully engaged in a game of Battlestar. I am a fan of the show and I don't know how one can fully appreciate the game without a familiarity with the show (though some who haven't seen it claim to love the game). That said, the game is so good that it's worth making time to see an episode or two just to gain access to the drama the game can provide.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
What I Like:
The tension is unbeatable in a close game. It is as advertised. I enjoy the closeness the game keeps to it's theme. And I REALLY enjoy team games, traitor or not. The rules are simple enough to teach as you play, and nd there are plenty of surprises along the way.

What I Don't Like:
Play time. It's hard to get in under 3 hours, especially with new players. While I feel that there is little downtime between turns, the game seems a bit long for it's complexity level. 

I's starting to feel the weight of the game in the play time. While I overlooked it early on, it's now a bigger factor than I previously rated. In many ways, it's a game that prevents itself from being played due to it's playtime, which is unfortunate. 

Why I still own it:
It's an experience, like a murder mystery. Everyone leaves the table with a narrative.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This is the first game that I've felt I should rate a 10.  Yet the odd thing about it is that most of makes it deserving of a 10 isn't due to what is in the box, but rather what you bring to it.  The amount of fun you have with it will come from the group you play it with.  My group accuses each other of being cylons in real life, so you can see where we might have a field day with this game.  The mechanics themselves are rather simple, and not all that exciting on paper, but are necessary to leave the room needed to make this game what it is.

If played with the right players, who can pull of a little bit of drama, the paranoid atmosphere is really incredible.  This is the sort of game that makes me appreciate why I play board games.

Edit-Lowering this to a 9.  Playing with the same group sort limits just how repayable it is, but it's still fun.

RATING: 7
Finally got to play this game. The TV series was one of the first series that got me binge watching until deep in the night on working days, so I really wanted to try this one.

My first play was with five players and I chose Gaius Baltar. Right of the bat I got the two Ceylon cards and to make matters worse, two players got to filter crisis cards, to skip over the worst ones during the game. An uphill battle for sure, but I got enough confusion in to stretch the game to three hours. I did lose though, as jump cards with high numbers were drawn. Came still pretty close.

This is certainly not a game to play every week, but once in a while I think it's a very enjoyable experience, especially if you were a fan of the series remake. You do have to have the right crowd, because of the role playing aspect. The game thrives when people are busy scheming and accusing each other. It's still a bit long for a hidden traitor game and therefore probably not for everyone.

Provisional rating at 7 until I get a few more plays in.

RATING: 9.5
I folded and bought this.  Guess I could not hold out as well as I thought!
Ran my first play of this, liked what I saw.  I do believe that the players have a huge impact on how much people enjoy this game.  With players that get into their roles it's going to be fantastic!

Interesting, I've been putting a considerable amount of idle time towards thinking about this game.  That bodes well for it, as it's been a long time since a game grabbed me that way!

I'm just loving the paranoia and player interaction of this game.  Creating suspicion amongst the players is great fun, and I really enjoy the back and forth with the other players!!  Amazing game, and it only gets better with more players!

Feb 15, 2010 -- Dropped to a 9.  Note that my rating on this game is for the five player game only, with is 90%+ of my plays.  With a number of players != 5 the game is lower. likely 1 7.5 to 8.0.

As much as I enjoyed this game, space considerations and desire to play sent it to a new owner.  I'd still play with the right group though!

RATING: 9

RATING: 10
I can't get enough of this game and can't find enough people to play it. I find it really easy to get my family into playing it whenever we gather though. It usually gets derogatory comments the first time I bust it out but by the time it ends they want more.

8-27 : 5 player. Roslin, Starbuck, Admiral Adama, Baltar & Helo, Roslin cylon before sleeper, Starbuck (myself) cylon after sleeper. Both got good reveals off. Humans lost from running out of fuel at 5 on the track to Kobol. Had a 3 jump but insufficient fuel.

PBF Game: http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/839765/bsg-295-a-disease-of-hoping

9-2 : 5 player. Roslin, Tigh, Baltar, Apollo (newbie), Chief (newbie). Both of the newbies got cylon cards at the sleeper phase. They both got successful reveals off but only because a brig check failed. They successfully briged me after I declared Martial Law but it was after we had already gone the 8 distance so Admiral was pretty useless at that point. They had convinced Roslin that I was a cylon after the martial law. Resources were all in the red but we got the jump off after the 8 distance and Humans won.

3-3 : 6 player w/ expansions. To Kobol, no Conflicted Loyalties but had Final Five cards. Played as Cally, others were Anders, Roslin, Zarek, Dee, and Bill Adama. Used my OPG to execute Dee turns out she was Cylon. I was Human Final Five. Humans won with only 1 population left. Raiders took out 6 civilian ships on the last turn right before we jumped to the victory.

RATING: 9.5
I never really get tired of this game.  One of the few where I can lose horribly and still have a great time every play.

To me, this game has perfected the hidden traitor mechanic.  It gives plenty of options for players to subtly sabotage their "teammates" without having to give up their identity as a traitor.  There are even plenty of mechanics to allow you to attempt to "frame" another player, or to provide limited access to incriminating information.

Amazing.

RATING: 6

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
A cooperative game that actually works and a franchise tie-in that doesn't suck! Surprising on a number of levels, this game is very thematic, plays smoothly, maintains tension throughout, and is absorbing and fun to play. On the negative side, it can be repetitive and long. If you are enjoying the overall experience however, this is not necessarily a bad thing (and if you were a fan you will enjoy this) owing to its marvelous capturing of the theme of a "rag-tag human fleet fleeing from the relentless Cylons bent on their destruction."

The sequence of events can spell the difference between victory for the humans or their annihilation at the hands of the Cylons, but clever and cooperative play can give them a fighting chance. This game lends itself more than many to a spirit of role-playing that adds an extra layer to the whole experience - but that could be predicated on players who were really "into" the TV series.

I'm impressed after two plays!
++++++
Back to the game after quite an interval. I was struck by the re-immersion in the theme which is captured so very well but; on the other hand, if you weren't a big fan of the series this may mean little and the long(ish) repetitive nature of the game might detract. Thus perhaps not a game for everyone - but so far, in my book, it is the best "cooperative" game system out there!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Never seen the series, but from the spirit of mistrust and "forced co-operation" it must be an interesting one. A fun game if players can stand some false accusion and treason. Clever game mechanics make it work out that you never really know whom to trust.

RATING: 7
Hated it first time - I don't watch the TV series and missed all the references.  "Who's that...what does she do...I thought they were called 'Cyclons'...I thought Starbuck was a bloke" and so on.  So I sent the first and second games in a state of ignorance (thank heaven I wasn't a Cylon).  Last play was much better when I managed to separate the mechanics from the fiction. =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
As a fan of the (new) series this is a '10' for me, it's great, bit of role-play, bit of paranoia and mind games and you get to play BattleStar Galactica.

If you don't know the series, it's not going to be such a great experience as you'll have less of a hook to the theme and the images and quotes on the card won't mean anything.

Game play, variable - experience depends entirely on the players, with some groups this could be a total nightmare of long drawn out tedium - but with the right group it shines.

You need to realise it is a team game (rather than co-op) and it's an experience game, if you go in with the mindset you want to just optimise your play to 'win' it's going to fall flat.

But I love it ...

*** update, 10 plays later, still love it :)

*** 2nd Update, played this over and over since getting it (12 plays now) and still love it. Made me want to go and rewatch the tv series again. Seems Cylons have the easier time of it, but that is because it's harder to play the humans. 

Humans can win, but they need to use executive orders (so doubling the actions players are doing) and pick and choose which crisis to try to pass. Also helps to weed out the cylons quickly, or at least have the cylons running scared so they actually help in an attempt to remain hidden.

*** 3rd Update

Lost count of plays, still love it - BUT it depends massively on the group playing, with the wrong group this can bomb massively.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I've found that I don't seem to enjoy co-op games very much, but I did enjoy this game.  Would play again, but probably wouldn't buy.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Really cool suspenseful game.  You don't know it but half of you are traitors and then again maybe not quite.

This is one of the most interesting designs I have epxeriences in a game.

I am not convinced that the game is properly balanced yet at the way it plays out seems lop sided to the Cylon side however there is enough entertainment value to continue to play 5-10 more times to earnestly figure it out.  I suggest adding some additional room to each of the four dials for players to have some padding on a failed game(from the humans point of view...)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4.3
First game was thematic and intense - would rate a 7.  Second game was downright boring.  We breezed through the first half of the game with little tension, then in the second half four out of five players spent most of their time in the Brig.  If you don't know the game, being in the Brig essentially stops time in the game (no Crises card is drawn).  With only one jump needed to win, a series of Crises cards activating the Cylon fleet destroys about five civilian ships and loses the game for the humans.  Most players felt they had spent nearly three hours having no effect on the game.  Second game rating: 2.  So I think I have seen the best and worst this game has to offer.  Much like in Knizia's Lord of the Rings encounter tiles,  if the Crises cards are stacked against you, you will lose.  If the bad Crises cards are spread out, you may have a chance.  Is it worth risking 2.5 hours of game time in what might feel like a futile exercise?  Maybe.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Like Shadows Over Camelot in a Sci-Fi setting.  Game is very tense.  Theme adds something, but isn't necessary for enjoyment (unless you include the expansions).

Biggest complaints are length and difficulty... it seems that if you have one newbie on the human side (playing Admiral or President), the humans are doomed to lose.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A very interesting co-op game with a traitor element done right.  I would rate this higher but the game really drags with 5 or 6 players.  Our last 6p game went 4 hours and that's just 1.5 hours too many.  This game can be brilliant but you really have to have the right group dynamic for it to work.


*edit*  With a few more games under our collective belts, the playtime has dropped to 3 hours or less.  This has done a lot to increase our enjoyment of the game.  Certain aspects of the game are brilliant (rooting out the Cylons for instance) but a weak Cylon player can make the game too easy for the Humans.  A really good co-op that we'll play happily on occation but it dosen't overthrow Arkham Horror and it's very dependant on having the right group.  In other words, I wouldn't play this with strangers.  For now I'm keeping my 6.5 rating.

RATING: 7
Excellent game, fun for human or cylon. I agree with other posters that it's more of a team game than a cooperative game; that's not a criticism, just an observation for folks who think they're getting a themed version of Pandemic or something. The biggest downside is the long playing time: 2-3 hours. It's a fun 2-3 hours for the participants, but makes coordinating game days difficult.

Recently, I've been playing shorter games like The Resistance to scratch the team/treachery itch. The theme on this is very good, though, so I've kept it around.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Juego ambientado en la serie. Admite hasta seis jugadores. Todos los jugadores deben cooperar para sobrevivir y sobreponerse a los sucesos que van ocurriendo. Cada jugador lleva un personaje que tiene ciertas características. En su turno coge cartas según esas características y escoge una acción (según las cartas o la ubicación que escoja). Al final del turno hay que desvelar una carta de crisis que supone problemas para los humanos. Los retos se resuelven por votación oculta. Cada uno contribuye positiva o negativamente a los test de habilidad que dirimen todos los conflictos. Entre los jugadores hay algún traidor (según el número de jugadores puede  ser 1 o 2 cylon).  Los humanos ganan si consiguen llevar la nave a kobol, después de su octavo salto. Los Cylon ganan si los humanos no lo consiguen, o si la nave es destruida, alguno de los marcadores de los humanos llega a cero, o la nave es invadida.
Está entretenido. Gana si conoces la serie. Hay que leer bastante. Lo mejor del juego es la existencia oculta de un traidor, que da lugar a muchas situaciones. Es un buen juego.

Subida la nota de 7.5 a 8 tras mi segunda partida, esta vez, con bastante conocimiento de la serie (a mitad de la tercera temporada). Si eres jugón y te gustó la serie, este es un juego imprescindible.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Even less likely to play this now I've got Dead of Winter.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A good hidden role game with the extra element of not totally knowing which side you're on until halfway through the game.

Humans have a difficult time winning in the beginning, usually due to over-compensating on skill checks when they don't have to.  With practice, I believe that skill checks will get closer and thus put the humans in better stead.

The Sympathizer card is fine the way it is. Leave it alone.

RATING: 9
[Bought 2nd hand from Doomfarer:bradspel.net 2011-09-06]
Played with three players and it was a blast.
A constant foreboding about that something bad is going to happen.
Really like the feeling that you coplayers are all cylon.
The accusations, suspicion and threats make you always to be on your edge. Because you don't know what crazy things your human players will do to you on their way to find the cylon player.
Paranoia level is often going through the roof.

--- update ---
Played a game with 4 players and the game gets even better with more players. The cards you have on hand are fever and it's always a tough decision if you should support on a crisis card or use the cards on other important tasks.
Can see that the game will really shine with 6 players.

RATING: 8.5
This is one I wish I could get to the table more often for sure! My core group of friends and I are all huge BSG fans, but some of the people we game with have never seen the show or dont care to and as such are thrown off by the theme. The game provides a great sense of paranoia as you're trying to figure out who you can trust and who you can't, and it all works together very well. Space combat is a lot of fun, and the political aspect of the game provides some unique choices. Would highly recommend to any BSG or sci-fi fan!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Didn't care for the series on tv at all, but game play is engaging with all players involved most of the time. If not playing skill checks on other player's turns, you are watching the current player's actions to find some clue to his loyalty. Tense game for the humans, fending off cylon ships between jumps, with resources dwindling toward the end. Each turn offers a variety of action choices, with the several ship stations, character abilities, and skill cards. This continues even toward the end of the game. The mechanic of secretly adding skill cards with the two destiny cards thrown in provides for some fun speculations. Rated for the five player game. Fun coop game, with much suspicion and accusation, but you need the right crowd.
Donated to the Dallas Gamers Marathon library. 
UPDATE: Owned again after playing recently and hoping for further plays. Great game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.6
Juego semicooperativo de 1 a 8 personas y unas tres horas y media de duración. 
Es actualmente el juego que más se ajusta a mis preferencias.:

 Es un juego semicoopertivo, con "infiltrado/s", lo que permite mucha interacción, mucha diplomacia, votaciones, muchas opciones sobre qué hacer y cuando...

Lamentablemente, a pesar de que a mi me gusta, tiene varias cosas en contra:
Es un juego que exige que haya un mínimo de 4 jugadores.
Es un juego que requiere disponer de 4 horas (por si acaso).
No ha calado en mi grupo habitual de jugadores.

RATING: 6
Not bad for a semi-cooperative game with hidden identity deduction. Based on one game. It was a tad long for what it is. 1.5 hours would be okay. Not double that. In my one game, the president and the admiral and the sympathizer were cylons from the beginning and it was just too powerful for the humans to have a reasonable chance. It just became a long drawn out defeat.

Second game still dragged. Six player game again that lasted 3.5 hours. Double the ideal playing time for this type of game. I do like the paranoia that the game creates. Also like that for a co-operative, players make independent choices without one person telling everyone else what to do.

Update: the game has been made redundant by The Resistance.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.3
Rating only applies in conjunction with the Valley of Darkness variant here on the Geek.

With the variant: An excellent attempt to cpature the feel of the show. There is a real tension in trying to uncover the hidden cylons and it's great to play either as a human or a cylon. Unlike other games with traitor mechanisms (Shadows over Camelot, we're looking at you) in BSG the cylons can actually do real perceptible harm without being discovered.

Without the variant: Another flawed implementation of a great idea from FFG. The game contains degenreate strategies for the humans, the sympathiser creates an ugly metagame for the humans and some of the characters are either too good or too bad.

RATING: 8.5
