=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
I can't really tell why but I like Dead of Winter more...

So, after my second game in which I was a Zylon after the second loyalty card I guess I can describe better what kills the game for me (in the first we used the Pegasus and in the second the Pegasus and the Exodus expansion)

The first negative is the downtime. You can't do much on you turn, just one action and then the waiting begins. Yes, you are involved in the crisis cards but that isn't enough, for me this is still downtime.
The second point is that the game becomes a pretty dull mixture of mechanics if you aren't familiar with the TV-series.
And the last complaint is about being a Zylon. Once you reveal yourself you are limited to just a few actions and aren't allowed to use card effects. Yes you have your super-special-crisis-cards but they aren't as bad as you expect them to be. So you spend a turn to draw one and a second turn to play it. But that is everything you have done in these two rounds. You don't draw crisis cards while you are revealed so combined with all of the other penalties you have to suffer there is no real reason to reveal yourself. So you just stay hidden and hope that you don't get blown out in the Airlock.

And that in a 4 hour game.
Sorry but that is just boring. I could have played a 4-player game of Twilight Imperium 3 in the same time the 4-player game of BSG took.

Dead of Winter does the traitor/exiled thing much better.
Now after my second game of BSG I have not a single reason to play that game again.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
About as good as it gets..
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Love this game.   Of course, I'm a BSG fan, but the game itself is fantastic.  Love the paranoia and interesting strategies that can be made.   As much a game of politicing and twisting other players minds as it is anything else.  Few games can invoke the player interaction, frustration, scheming, lynching and accusing that this one can.   

I suspect the thing with this game though is it all depends on your group and the personalities involved.  It would likely not work well with a bunch of quiet/reserved people or a bunch of people who are afraid or unable to lie and misdirect.  Our group seems to be filled with enough liers and backstabbers to work perfectly with this game.

One of my favorite games.

Edit Jan 2011:  After a couple of so-so games, enthusiasm is dropping a bit.   Down to an 8.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
As a fan of the TV series I was skeptical of this game. How could it be anything but a hopeless cash-in like some many TV/Film-2-boardgames before it? Boy was I wrong. This is an excellent co-op/traitor game in the spirit of Resistance and others. You struggle to trust your shipmates and guide the fleet through Cylon attack and worse, all the time seeking the unearth the traitors among you before they doom you all. If you're fan of the series there is lots of flavour here to enjoy but the game never puts fan-service ahead of mechanics and solid playability. I defy anyone to not like this game (unless you're a frakkin toaster that is....).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

What a great game. Finally got to play it a couple of time back-to-back and had a blast. Nail-biting finishes and with the right group an absolute blast. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
The first time I played [b]Battlestar Galactica[/b], I was human.  However, my fellow humans acted like Cylons and basically sabotaged the game.  (They said that they were just trying to confuse everyone as to their true identity.  Mission accomplished.  Everyone thought you were Cylons.)  The second time I played this game I was a Cylon.  But it became painfully obvious who was the other Cylon because he kept looking at his loyalty card to read his special ability.  Both games were not very fun for me. 

BG is innovative with its traitor game mechanic, but it can take several games before a new player can properly play their roles.  This game is best played with experienced players.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Very fun, very cleverly designed game. We had a rough time with it the first time around because one of the Cylon players gave themselves away before their first turn, but we still had a good time. I think five players is ideal, because with four, a full half of the players end up as Cylons and the game slows to an agonizing crawl as the humans inevitably fail every skill check and the Cylons are unable to summon a base ship on their turns. I'd like to try one of the expansions to see if they fix some of these problems (by adding more possibilities for ship combat, for example).

RATING: 5

One of my issues is that, as a revealed cylon, the decisions are too obvious and there is little to do.

Played with a really good group, and we played with 5, which I'm told is the right number of players.  I just didn't like it.

Love co-op play in PC and video games, don't like it in boardgames.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
I've had to drop my rating a point on this one, just because it's so !@$#ing long. The 5-hour play time is a complete back-breaker, given the limited range of the game itself.  5 hours for Titan, OK, 5 hours for the very repetitive and uneven BSG, not so much. There is a fair amount of good stuff in here, but it is absolutely killed by the time required to play it. Mike Siggins called it criminally overlong, and that might be an understatement.
---
Played this once and actually rather enjoyed it. But it is a bit of an overchromed monstrosity, not helped by the fact that a few critical references (mostly having to do with die rolls) that should have been on the board are not and have to be looked up, and also by the fact that too much import detail is in tiny type on the board that you have to get up next to and squint at. They had plenty of space to work with, the tiny type and missed references on the board really are almost unforgivable in a game of this complexity.

Underneath the overchromed monstrosity though are a number of good ideas trying to get out. The jumps are a great way to manage tension and ensure the semi-regular restart so the players don't get into a death spiral. The hidden loyalties are well-executed for the most part and also add a lot of good tension. The game is faithful to the good parts of the show, which is good, because I don't think you want to be faithful to all of that show, which has its own set of issues.

Where BSG struggles, though, is with pacing. The game is just too long and gets repetitive before the end, has too many moving parts, and is too much at the mercy of the draw deck for its tension. Some jumps will be great as Cylon raiders pile into the Galactica in waves. Some not so much, as you spend half an hour dealing with relatively uninteresting crises while waiting to jump (the crises themselves aren't that interesting; things only really get fun when you have bad guys swarming too). In general, there are just too many moving parts which are not tight enough. The players manage many more resources than they do in Lord of the Rings, and yet somehow end up with many fewer tough and interesting choices. I can't help but think this game could be much improved if it were the euro that in its heart of heart it really is, and wasn't trying to be the overwrought super-themey sort of thing FFG specializes in (which always delivers a boatload of rules but doesn't always deliver plausible theme). Usually more is less, and this applies to theme as much as anything else.  Here as much as anywhere, a tighter, tenser game would be thematically far stronger than this kind of kitchen sink game.

Final thought: it's been said that a revealed Cylon may be too strong - with not really enough incentive to remain hidden - and I can see the strength of that argument. I'm not sure it's entirely convincing, but it's definitely a worry, since the position of a revealed Cylon is also not a terribly interesting one to actually play.
---
Oh yeah, and one other thing, one of the reason that the show ultimately turned me off was its one-note tone: dark. It had no emotional range and just got boring. Real people are sometimes funny and crack jokes when they're under stress. BSG characters always take themselves so excruciatingly, painfully seriously. I mention this only because playing BSG the boardgame was a rich mine of humor, and if only the show had been able to capture some of the humor we found in the game, maybe it wouldn't suck.
---
Looking forward to playing this quite a bit actually, but I'm worried about two things: first, balance, at which FFG is notoriously inept but which is important to this sort of game. Second, it's got the same phoney and unworkable player communication rules that Shadows over Camelot had. It seems a little less egregious here, but it's still a little unfortunate - if you can't make a straightforward rule, it's not a good sign.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
Very cool traitor game. I really enjoyed the two rounds of identity assignment in that someone who is a human during the first of the game can become a cylon in the second half. Definitely an interesting dynamic compared to other traitor games where the traitor is usually set from the beginning. I also really enjoyed the fact that each character not only has a special ability but also a one-time super ability and a flaw that causes each player to be worse at something than others. It helped make each character much more unique. Looking forward to playing more of BSG even though I've never watched the show.

If you're a fan of the show you will fall in love with the game, and even if you're not you will still have a blast due to the addictive and immersive gameplay.  

A real gem that will stand the test of time despite its flaws.

RATING: 5.5

My enthusiasam about the game was hampered even more as I was thrown in the brig before my second turn (though I have to say that I had some extreme bad luck, as I would only be accused if two red cards turned up from the destiny deck which was statistically highly unlikely – guess what happened... Despite all of this I found the game to be okay, and it definitely has the potential for a higher rating. We were 6 players (2 newcomers) and it took 4½ hours which is too much! 2 hour would be perfect.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
BSG does a pretty decent job at emulating the paranoia and suspicion that went with the first two seasons of the show.  If you were a fan of the gritty, post-apocalyptic, survivalist, military sci-fi of seasons 1 and 2 (and Razer) then you'll probably enjoy this game.

Players take on the roll of characters from the show working together to save humanity -- or so they think.  Some of the players may secretly be Cylons, and be actively working to sabotage humanity.

The game rewards careful thought and the ability to read people.  It's also an excuse to call your friends and family "Fraking Toasters!"

Gameplay feels very stacked against the humans; in all the games I've played the humans have only won once.

For non-fans of the show the game might feel slightly less approachable.  As the years go on and people forget the details of the show it may become easier to introduce new people to it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
Battlestar Galactica is THE game for the hidden traitor mechanic.  I was a huge fan of Shadows Over Camelot, but BSG has supplanted it.  It is a bit complicated (I'd say it takes 15 minutes to learn), but overall, a great game.

There is no better moment in board gaming than flipping over that traitor card... it makes the entire game far more fun.

I played the game before I watched the TV show.  Now that I've seen the show, this is a near-perfect rendition.

RATING: 8.5
Love this game! I was a big fan of the series and it is remarkable how events in the game play out like certain events in the show. That is - alert vipers are essential to protecting citizens - characters can be thrown into the brig - new elections can determine the President, etc.

I also like how the Admiral and President are given special role powers, and how these powers can be usurped by other players.

The fact that some players thinking they are human - but later finding out they are cylon - is also a very awesome attribute of this game.

The only bad thing I can say about it is that it requires a lot of explanation to new players. Also, some players may be turned off by the long playing time.

Find a group that loves these types of games and can handle the time commitment and you will have a great time!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

The crisis deck can be very unforgiving, but the game's fun factor much overshadows the game play RNG since even losing is a good time.

RATING: 6.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
This is a difficult game to rate, as it has a number of clear strengths and a few key drawbacks.

Strengths--man, I love the theme. If I had to choose strong mechanics vs. strong theme, I'd choose the former. But BSG has theme in spades. I love games with hidden roles, and the fact that cylon role cards are introduced midway through the game keeps the tension high (which, is a clear strength over Shadows over Camelot). Although there are a number of moving parts, all of it makes sense.

Cons--the playing time. If I plan on spending 3 hours on a game, it has to be something special. BSG is on the cusp... but I need another play before I can say definitively that it delivers for the whole duration. Turn order is ssllllloooowwww. I think I waited 15 minutes between turns at one point. Yes, it depends on the players. But a game that encourages tabletalk like this does not play quickly. Fortunately, the skills checks help to keep everyone involved.

I played this with the Pegasus and another expansion, and I'd like to try this again with the base game only. That might help to keep things a bit more lean. As a gamer that tends to gravitate toward Euros more than heavy Ameritrash, I'm not an audience for the expansions. But the base game has a lot of intriguing elements in it.

Update: a 2nd game with only the base game, and my original comments still seem pretty accurate. Thematically rich, mechanically slick, and probably one hour too long. However, I've probably played it with six players both times, and I'd be curious trying it again with five or four.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I only played this once, but I enjoyed it.  Knowledge of the TV series is not required to play the game, though I'm sure it probably helps with the enjoyment.  This is a semi-cooperative style game, where all players are seemingly on the same side, but some are secretly working against the group.

RATING: 8.5
Excellent game. Captures the flavour of the show and still remains fun to play. Can be a bit too long, and hard to wrap your head around all the things that are going on. Takes a couple of plays to make sure you're doing everything right.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
This game has dropped in the past two years.  It is too long for what it is, a bit too tricky to play, and definitely too rules intensive for casual family gatherings.  It's a bit like the series that way.  When it was great it was great, and then it dropped like a stone.

-------

For fans of the show this game can be fantastic fun.  The trash talk, the accusations, the intrigue of trying to figure out who is a cylon.

In most of my games, I've been a sleeper cylon, and I suspect that's the most interesting role.  You learn you're one of the bad guys half way through the game, now how are you going to betray the others without being found out?

I would only caution that the game can be long, 3 -4 hours is not uncommon, and the cylons tend to win ... I'm not sure why this is the case and if it's a trend.  Seems more of an issue with 6.  In addition, the role of Sympathizer is unsatisfying for most who get it, consider either (a) reaching Kobol with some resource in the red (so the Sympathizer is just another human) or (b) playing with the official FFG variant in which the sympathizer is removed.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I have rarely had as much fun playing a board game as when I played BSG.  My friends, including some non-gamers,loved it too.  The theme really gets people who are fans of the show involved.  I also think that the traitor mechanic works better in this game than in Shadows over Camelot, which I could never particularly get into.

Highly recommended.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Luckily I haven't played this so many times that I have "grokked" it and still take much enjoyment in not realising what all the cards and abilities can do.

The traitor mechanism is brilliant. But one downside to it: everyone wants to be a cylon! This means that if you are NOT a cylon, it's a tiny bit of a let down when you flip the cards over - strange eh?

But this is a fun game that I have had many many a jolly arument about. This is one of the games that I have played that has the MOST amount of post-game analysis. That is a good thing. It is fun :)

Another good point; it mimics the TV program SO accurately. I love that the feeling of depression and hopelessness that the cast experience in the series is exactly the same how you experience it in the boardgame.

A bad point: I do not like feeling depressed and hopeless! 

I like how each character has a very specific role that they excel in and that the team can come together fantastically (only to be torn apart internally).

Would rate an 8 but must rate it a 7 due to the amount of numbing despair.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
The television show has become painful to watch.  It had so much promise...and the miniseries was really captivating, then it all went to hell. It turned into this soap opera where the characters were written different every episode and all this false drama.

The good news is that it all spawned this great hunt-the-traitor(s) game!

I've only played once so far, but it was thematic, tense, humorous and fun. The cylons won narrowly.  We had 6 players and lots of close calls. There was a lot of movie/TV quoting going on.  One guy talked like Colonel Tye the whole time. That alone is worth a full ratings point.

I thought the game worked pretty well, and can't really think of any specific criticisms. I think maybe it kind of wore out its welcome at the end, but not too much, and we had several new players so that is probably more the group.

I'm not sure it will hold its charm for me with too many repeat playings, but I'd like to play again a few more times.

RATING: 7.5
I like this game a lot, but everyone else I know refuses to play it now.

The problem is the huge amount of rules that no one can remember (even the person who owns the game), which turns the game into a grueling 5 hour match between, ultimately, the wrong amount of cylons vs human players. It is pretty frustrating, and has happened 3/3 times I have played this game.

However, I think the play is pretty fun otherwise, and I like the intrigue (until I find the game was set up incorrectly and the match was unbalanced). But I can not stand for a game that lasts 5 hours, that is too much for me. However, where everyone else refuses to touch the game again, for me, hope springs eternal that I will one day play a smoothly run, correctly set-up game of BSG.

7.5/10 for "good lord, that took all day and we didn't even play it right"

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Finally a cooperative game worth playing
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
A stunning disappointment after all the positive reviews. The gameplay is highly repetitive with the core mechanism being relentless card-play 'skill checks' conducted for very little actaul game effect beyond decreasing abstract dials representing key resources. After four hours of play I knew something wasn't right when I was actually hoping the cylon player would blow up Galactica to avoid enduring yet another jump sequence... 

I really wanted to LOVE this game. The production values are great and any fans of the TV show (like me) will appreciate the way the game evokes the series. The 'hidden' traitor mechanic is also a really exciting game idea and clearly has worked well for many other players. But in my experience with the game its impact can vary wildly depending on when this happens and how adept the player is at disguising their identity. 

Please note my impression is based on playing with 4 players only and know that the recommendation is for 5 - but it's difficult to see how more players can address the core emptiness of the game. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
One of my favorite hidden role games AS WELL AS favorite cooperative games. Just an excellent blend of both genres, super intense and really engaging no matter who's turn.

Will say, it is EXTREMELY hard for human players to win, even with no Cylons in play. This might turn certain people off if you're really just interested in winning or if your group doesn't like to lose two or three times in a row, but it is very possible to win.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
 BattleStar Galactica was nominated for our game of the year for countless reasons. It's incredibly fun to play, easy to learn, and there is nothing more satisfying than throwing your friends in the brig. This board game does more than bring the TV series to life, it puts the players into an intense situation of survival, struggles, teamwork, sabotage, subterfuge, and betrayal. This game is at it's best when the Cylon players are still a mystery and the frustration comes when accusations land on innocent humans. Often an innocent human can feel cornered when they realize they've said something that could condemn themselves.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Keep

11/11/12 - Really enjoyed this one - particularly with the theme (I love the TV series). 

We only just won as the humans and that was after the game was 'rebalanced' in favour of the humans. I have read and heard that the game is unbalanced towards the cylon players. I would like to play again using the standard rules to test this further. We won as humans but it was close (and if we were playing the default starting conditions we would have lost). It didn't help our cause that I let the cylon out of the brig, and I think our victory would have been more comfortable if I had left him there (or alternatively executed him). 

16/2/2013 - Played this as a 5 player and I was a cylon. The humans only just won in a marathon (almost 5 hour) game. My mistake in retrospect was revealing as a cylon too early, even though it was relatively late in the game. I should have used the move to accuse someone else. I could have tried to sow some doubt, rather than reveal as my once off cylon power was quite weak given chief tyrol was in play. Was a great game that came down to the wire. 

24/8/2013 - Played a 5 player again, and was a human (cylons won). Played this with two eurogamers who didn't really get into it. This game is better with others who enjoy this genre. 

This game is somewhat long and for this reason it doesn't rate higher than 8.5. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7

Like all such games it needs a right group. The game seems to favor the cylon team.

RATING: 6
Feb. 10, 2009 -- After two plays of this, I think the game has a few flaws, but with the right people it can be a lot of fun. The people actually seem to make the game, whereas the game itself sometimes just doesn't feel like it has enough options on certain turns.

It would be nice if there was some way to move the jump point along. Sometimes turns taken feel like they're wasted because there's nothing really to do that can help the humans win the game. On the other hand, though, the Cylons are a lot of fun to play once they're out in the open. 6/10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I'm giving this an initial rating of 8 after my first (5-player) learning game. Lots of fun, lots of choices... and although we'd only barely sensed the strategies possible in the game, everyone had a great time. There was much discussion after the game and everyone is looking forward to the next play. It's interesting to note that of the group of five, only one player had ever seen the show (not a fan, but had seen several episodes). I don't think that fact hindered our enjoyment in the least. Your mileage may vary, but Battlestar Galactica seems a perfect fit for my game group.

Update: Simply HAD to bump up my initial rating. At present, it's almost a foregone conclusion that this will hit the table over almost anything else in my collection. It's a great game with a deeply immersive theme... it accommodates varied play styles/personalities... and it never fails to engage all of us in not only a compelling narrative, but - most importantly -  a raucously entertaining couple of hours of sheer fun!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This game is pretty good with four players but much better with more. The sympathizer card strikes me as a necessary but somewhat forced mechanic. Once players start getting close to the halfway point (where the sympathizer card will be dealt out) they start considering whether they want to intentionally lose enough resources to get into the red in order to avoid there being two Cylon players (instead of one). That detracts from the mood a little in my opinion, but unfortunately it's a rational consideration.

I think the theme works fabulously for a co-op, however, and I enjoy it in spite of any "metagaming" flaws.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7

RATING: 7
Frakkin' toasters! The gameplay fits perfectly with the BSG setting and is evocative of the show's key premise.  It can overstay its welcome and be difficult to teach.  The game initially seems way more complicated than it is by a fairly obtuse rule book.  It's fun to be the traitors secretly bringing down the ship from the inside and also rewarding to make it through as the meatbags trying to deduce who the toasters are. Very neat is the dealing of loyalty cards a second time midway through the game- so your loyalty may switch and you end up being a toaster all along!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Just lots of fun running around, flying and blowing up ships.

RATING: N/A
Opponents
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Epic Game, my favorite semi-coop!

Pros:
-Games tend to be tense and close until the very end
-Depth of play: interesting variety of actions available
-Diversity: due to the sheer number of crisis cards, characters and modules, every game played will be different. With expansions, the possibilities are almost endless.
-Traitor element: interesting possibilities as a traitor. The traitor can't ruin the game in just 1 blow (like in Dead of Winter), and doesn't have his hands tied (like in Shadows of Camelot). Traitors have interesting actions and possibilities. Revealing early to be all-out at opposing the players, waiting for a golden opportunity, insidiously taking control of key positions, etc.
At 5 players, there will be 2 traitors, which makes it more interesting for the traitors. It's the best traitor mechanism as of yet.

Cons:
-Difficult to teach casual gamers. The game takes a 1-3 tries before you begin the see the depth and potential.

Great game, not liked by my group :(

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
I really enjoyed this game in the early days, with newer players. It tended to take a really long time, but I figured that would tighten up with experience.

Then I played a game or two with more experienced players, and much of the fun vanished - their knowledge  was such that even slightly sub-optimal plays were instantly noted and called out. This left the Cylons no room for subtle sabotage - only a single well-timed moment of betrayal - and turned the deduction from subtle clues into something I didn't like nearly as much. (It also acted as the co-op alpha-player problem, only with "...and if you don't do X, you must be a Cylon" as a stick.)

RATING: 8
American
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
Components: Cool spaceships and character pawns. The board is fun, but having all the text face one direction for a multi-player game with secret roles is a big mistake, as it could be quite obvious that a player is trying just a little too hard to read the cylon actions from upside down. Very important information is either in small print (like on the character card, which need only be referenced if the player remembers to check for special powers), or hiding in the rule book (like the Cylon ships' attack behavior).

Experience: First, the game is very fiddly. I suspect a designer could cut the game in half (complexity and length) and still have a good BSG system.

Second, the game is too long for what it delivers. Every round felt pretty much like the previous rounds: attack the ships if there are any, otherwise do something else.

Third, the theme isn't working for me. The game has way more theme than most games, and does evoke many elements of the show, but I think the fiddliness really gets in the way of me feeling like we were each a unique character with a distinct personality. We could all pretty much do the same stuff. Gaius manning the guns or Starbuck becoming President just doesn't make sense, at least not without a handicap commensurate with their relative experience at the task. Also, and this is important (and I'm drawing only from the first two seasons that I've seen), I don't think the Cylon paranoia in the show reached the same levels as in the game. In the show, there are hundreds and hundreds of personnel, only eight of which could be Cylons (since Adama recognizes one of the templates from the very beginning). So the crew might not know who the other eight or so traitors are, but they can be sure that most people aren't traitors. In a three player game, half of my crew are traitors. In a six player game, a third of the crew are traitors. That's way more like Werewolf than like BSG.

Fourth, it's not very interesting. There are actually a lot of different actions a player may take on their turn, but they all felt the same and inconsequential to me. It would be much more interesting if I could string together several actions, such that doing things in a certain sequence made sense. But with only one action on my turn, I either roll dice to hit the bad guys, draw a card, play a card with fairly predictable results, etc. There are enough different types of actions, but they need to each be more interesting, and interact with each other in more interesting ways (i.e. someone who has just come from sickbay is too weak to move to a different ship; a player may fire Galactica's canons multiple times, but at an increasing cost of fuel; spend food to increase morale; move ships farther than one space, but the baddies get a free attack as the ships pass by; etc.). It's not that it was always obvious what to do, but that whatever action I took seemed slightly boring.

Fifth, the deception is not to my liking. I especially don't want to be a Cylon and have to lie for most of the game. There's just no delight in being sneaky if I can't celebrate it until much later in the game. And it's super stressful. And it's too long a game to keep up such a pretense. But even as a human, I dislike having to distrust the other players so much. Without knowing a single person who is definitely with me, I must assume everyone is against me, which is the case in most competitive games, but at least there it's all on the level. And I don't mind secret deduction games (like Mr. Jack), because they are just asymmetrical win conditions for openly declared enemies. But to have to rake my teammates through the coals before I'm satisfied they are pure enough to be trusted is like TSA treating everyone at the airport like a terrorist: we're all safer, but now nobody enjoys flying anymore.

I had heard so much about this game. After an aborted attempt at playing it a year ago, further hype made me think I just hadn't given the game long enough to develop. Now I feel just as jaded about the game as I do about the show, like it has abused me. There are many suggestions that the box's required number of players is too low, that it should only be played with 5+, but I have very little interest to discover how that adds anything other than giving each player even less control over the outcome.

Last Played: 2011-10-16
Eagerness to Play Again: No Desire

Plays (1):
3 players: 1

RATING: 9
An evening of Cylon accusations and dwindling resources.  Great fun.  However, if you approach this thinking "the humans may win this" you are sorely mistaken.  It should have the subtitle "the Cylons are going to win".  It's good fun being a Cylon to be honest - you really don't have to try too hard at deceit - literally do everything you can to help and get out of whichever crises is punishing the doomed humans.  It's teasing really - you get that "You Are A Cylon" card and it may as well be "congratulations - you've won without trying".  Regardless, I have a lot of fun playing it.  It's all about the group really.  But the Humans will lose.

RATING: 7.5
It's probably a little bloated, a little long, a little heavy on the rules overhead, a little unbalanced in favor of the Cylons, and little overly reliant on Executive Order cards. Also, BSG rules.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
This game is quite Ameritrashy with random Crisis draws, Skill card draws, Destination draws, and Destiny draws.  Not to mention the dice rolls for combat and the luck-of-the-draw as to who becomes a Cylon. Independently, these are okay, but when combined, these elements mean a luck component underlies much of what occurs in the game.

Nonetheless, the uncertainty behind who may become a Cylon is part of the game's appeal, both thematically and from a game-mechanic perspective (because it adds tension).  Trickery also has to be employed to help conceal your identity.  Perhaps being a Cylon is more engaging?     

The biggest problem with this game is its 180 minute length.  Does anyone want to co-op for that long?

I enjoyed the game of deduction and evaluating our resources as a group was fun.

Cylons won. The ending wasn't climactic - more a victory of attrition than of any particular treachery/attack/move. 

Cylons being able to 'masquerade' as human, even when we knew without doubt who they were, seemed thematically wrong.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
One of my favorite licensed games.

Fantasy Flight nailed the theme and tension of the show, and have provided fans with one of the best "traitor" games available. The variability between sessions (different characters and roles) keeps the game very enjoyable.

There are issues though:
* Doesn't really scale well for different sized groups of players.
* Simply too long. Every game I've seen where humans win or come close has run longer than it really should. By the end, some people may lose interest.
* Relies on having active, involved players. When you've got one or more people who "check out" and stop caring about what happens, it really hurts the gameplay.

Because of those problems, this is a game where you have to pick and choose when it comes out. Still a winner though.

Expansions are interesting. Some parts add to the game nicely, other parts feel tacked on or slightly boring. Being able to pick and choose how much of an expansion will be used is a nice addition, although I'm not sure they are worth the price of admission.

===

Edit: Rating dropped because it's just too hard to get on a table. This remains a very good game *if you have a group interested in taking the time to play*.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
One of the few board games that consistently manages to create suspense with every new play.  It can be hard for new players to take on the role of the cylons, but with the right group, this game really shines.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
If you have a good group of people to play this game with, it can be one of the best experiences a table-top game has to offer.  You KNOW someone is going to be a Cylon, but you don't know WHEN they will be a Cylon, or WHO is a Cylon.  

The only pitfall is that I am disappointed when I don't get to be a Cylon, because I feel like that is what makes the game EXTREMELY fun--trying to figure out how to disrupt and sow dissent without giving away your motives.

The only downfall is that this game does take a healthy chunk of time, but it is such a fun and social game that it doesn't really feel like a long game.  But for those times where you don't have an entire evening, it won't be able to make its way to the table.  But when it does, everyone is in for a good ol' backstabbing time!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Excellent Ameritrash game that minimizes the use of dice!  Great mechanics of having all players draw more Loyalty cards (to determine Human or Cylon) halfway through the game.  You can start out as a Human, and then later become a Cylon.  Also great politics with each player being able to secretly affect other player's strength checks.  I love the suspicion of other players in this game.  Evokes the feel superbly!

Certainly a lot of replayability and a fun game that has everyone discussing afterwards.

I wasn't crazy about the acting in the first season, but I'm on season 3 now, and the story more than makes up for the dull characters.

Notes from a BGG user (a1bert) about playing as the Humans:
The main strategies with the base game are: a) scout a lot, mostly the crisis deck to prevent the Cylon Attack Crisis cards from coming into play, b) move civilians ahead of the raiders and try to jump away as soon as possible, c) if that does not help, shoot down the raiders, d) use Investigative Committee to help passing checks without wasting cards. (And e) learn to decide which skill checks to tank - i.e. purposefully lose.)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Theme meets Mechanisms

Fans of the show can appreciate how the semi-cooperative betrayal mechanism matches the intellectual property that the game is based on.

Pros: Components are good and theme works really well with mechanisms. Even if you are not a fan of the show the art and cards carry the theme through.

Cons: Rather long slog through space while you deduce, accuse, or fool your fellow players.

I initially rated this game much higher since I thought the show was okay at least in early seasons until I dropped it. There definitely seems to be a lot of places in the game where everyone can contribute something useful or find times to hinder the group per the semi-cooperative nature of the game. But I find the game drags on too long for what it is especially if players are slow to commit cards and negotiate while they do so. Adding and resolving the destiny cards just lengthens the process. The ship (game) doesn't move that fast towards the end destination either.

After a few plays I found my dislike for the mechanism plus the length overcoming the initial shine of the game. If anything, this game is so good that I liked negotiation for just a little while.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This is a cooperative game, in which players try to root out the Cylon in their midst and defeat the oncoming threats.

I have not seen the series, so much of the experience was lost on me and it is an experience game. I've also only played once. I am a fan of cooperative games, in general, though.

They use a simple, but clever, hidden traitor mechanic, in which players all potentially submit cards face-down to defeat threats, the cards are shuffled, and then players find out if they defeat the challenge. This is nice, because the Cylon player can throw a wrench in the works, without being spotted. Unless, of course, only two people put cards in and some are negatives...

I feel like the game suffers because some players won't want to be the Cylon (and it is random), because they don't have a good pokerface or don't want to be "the bad guy". Also, there are two Cylons one in the first half of the game and one in the second. The problem here, potentially, is that you could be the good guy the first half and develop a nice, healthy hatred for the Cylons and then be forced to be one for the rest of the game!

The first half of the game, I didn't really enjoy at all. I felt the mechanics were somewhat uninspired, other than the one I mentioned previously, and that many of us had very little real impact on the outcome of the game.

The second half of the game, paranoia broke out big-time, with accusations flying and people being sent to the brig. Everyone's every move was being scrutinized and second-guessed. This seems to be the real strength of this game. Even though I eventually came around, I think your enjoyment of this game will be directly proportional to the interest-level of the group you play with.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
A long social deduction game, designed to leave humans struggling to hold on the entire time while including a traitor to tip them over the edge when they get close to losing.

Good stuff.

RATING: 8
An excellent experience in board gaming! Because of the length of the game, I wouldn't recommend this for new gamers, unless they were already fans of the TV show.

For BSG fans, it's an AMAZING experience. The theme immerses you into the game so easily, and knowledge of the show only helps ease into playing. The mechanics aren't the smoothest in the world, and there are other games on the market that emulate the play of this game in less time, but jumping into the mythos is so much fun. The fact that there WILL be a Cylon thrown into the mix makes for some good table banter, and because player interaction helps elevate the play of most any game, BSG works really well in this regard.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Perhaps the best (in my mind) "traitor-element" game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.8
[2010-07-26 Rating: n.a. -> 7.8]
Summary:
------------

Battlestar Galactica (BSG) is a semi cooperative game based on the new version of the tv series. The human players try to reach Kobol to win BSG, while the game "attacks" them with ships and crises which can destroy the human resources, if you don't manage to deal with them. 
The nice twist (and in my opinion the real game) is that some of the human players are actually Cylons trying to mess with the human efforts. If they manage to make the human players lose, they win. Because of the secret assignment of the Cylons, you can never be sure who is on your side and who isn't.

Comments:
--------------
* The game is a blast when you're trying to figure out who the bad guys are. It's quite reminiscent of Werewolf in this regard.

* I guess, without the Cylons the game would be rather dull. In order to prevent the negative effects of a crisis you have to play some of your cards and check whether you have reached enough points. This is not very exciting once you know who the Cylons are. In the two games I've played, BSG lost a lot of it's appeal once we knew who the Cylon player was.

* The threads that the game throws at you don't really seem to be balanced. We had a lot of turns where nothing happened on the board and therefore the crises weren't to hard to deal with. On the other hand, I guess you can get unlucky and draw a lot of attack cards (can't remember their real name) and be swarmed with enemy ships.

* Maybe the game is little too long, repetitive and luck-driven. Our second game lasted four hours and we lost because of a bad die roll. Otherwise we would have won. I had the feeling, that this one little die roll was too significant for the time we invested in the game. But maybe it was the Cylon player who didn't have enough experience with the game and therefore didn't bring us down fast enough.

* Like most Fantasy Flight Games there seems to be a little too much chrome. I guess, the game could have been streamlined a little more without reducing the fun. All the extra cards make this game look more complicated than it really is.

* All in all, I'm looking forward to my next game as I think there are still a lot of things to discover.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
For Trade
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A

RATING: 3

The fate deck needlessly confuses identifying the cylon and the "sleeper phase" ugh what a horrible mechanic. The game boils down to you must play to kinda lose so that when you become a cylon later you can help insure the loss. Terrible boring unfun long game. Perhaps the expansions improve it, but I don't care to find out.

RATING: 7
I've thought a lot about how to rate this game and ultimately have settled on a "7." There are moments in this game of sheer brilliance, but they're surrounded by large swaths of uninteresting play. Ultimately, there aren't enough of those great moments in the overly long play time. There's also a dose of randomness in whether the game is going to be good or bad. When it's good, the game is a 9 (it's still too long), when it's not it's a 5. So, I'll split the difference and rate this a 7. Too bad, because I loved the TV show and the theme: a tightened up version of this would be a winner. If there was ever a game calling out for a second edition, this is it.

RATING: 7
Bought 2010-08-07.

Finally got to play it. Not underwhelmed but certainly not over exited either. A game that is fun once or twice a year but more than that and it would get stale very quickly.

I like several parts of this game, such as you never know if you'll turn out to be a cylon later on so don't make things go too well for the humans and so on. The accusations and paranoia before all the cylons are revealed is great fun, but the moment you know who is who the game get much less interesting. Just rinse and repeat until end of game. If it had been playable in half the time it would have been much better as well.

RATING: 10
Nothing surpasses Battlestar for me for a fully and totally immersive gaming experience, where in game decisions have weight and consequence in a way that supports the game's imaginative and storytelling potential, tapping into the world of the tv show in a way that no game previously or since has come close to for me.

No matter how many games I play, each is a completely new experience for me, depending on characters, players, loyalties and crisis deck.    

Virtually no other games I've played have even come close to inspiring this kind of appreciation.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

The game can bog down when players get so into chatting that they forget they have to take their turns.  This seems fun until you realize it's 2 hours in and you're not half finished.  If you can keep it moving, it's a winner.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Players are characters from the TV series, trying to either get the humans to Kobol, or prevent it happening.  Cooperative game where players are either human or cylon, a fact that's gradually revealed during the game via either deduction or via declaration.  Players take turns, and during a turn they draw new skill cards (currency to fight off crises), move around the ships, take an action, then advance the cylon cause by triggering events and ship combat.  Humans win if they can "jump" eight units of distance and jump again to Kobol, the Cylons win if they drain the humans of resources, or blow up/board the Galactica.  Very nicely designed cooperative game, that plays cleanly.  It's very long - 3-4 hours looks typical, probably best with 4-5 players, thus won't get played much because of that.  Still, if you're a fan of the show, and don't mind a long sitting, go for it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Haven't made up my mind about BSG yet. The theme is AMAZING, but I'm still not entirely sold on the gameplay. It's a good set up and all, I'm just not sure it's for me.

Edit 21MAR2013: Honestly, I haven't changed my opinion much about this game since I first wrote about it in 2011. The theme is excellent. The gameplay is ok. I like the atmospher of second guessing, and it is well tuned to almost always seem like it comes down to the wire. But there's not a lot of choice for each player (especially if you're not Admiral, President, or CAG) and turns can sometimes take forever. I like BSG, but the excellent atmosphere it creates doesn't fully conceal it's few (but significant) flaws.

Also, I get it, it's funny to call everyone a cylon for any reason (or lack thereof) whatsoever. Can we please stop making that joke every five minutes??

RATING: 4
I had high hopes that this co-operative game would de-throne Pandemic or Shadows over Camelot. It is a sort of fun experience, but there just aren't enough moving cogs and levers to keep me coming back for more. I'll concede that FFG is improving their track record: components, proofreading, design, and (especially) playtesting are all getting better. Another base hit, but no home runs.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Idea:
Try to defend Galactica while jump engines prepare. Try to complete enough jumps before population/fuel/morale falls to 0 and cylons win.

Mechanism:
One player is secretly cylon and tries subtly sabotage and play to cylons bag without being detected. Each player does two actions per round and then 'encounter' happens which either brings more units or disaster that has certain number which must be beaten by discarding cards (1-5 points each) so that others dont know value but amount. Thus cylon tries to play negative and others positive cards.

to whom:
best played with 4-6 players, takes maybe 2-3 hours, pretty easy mechanism but has some nice interaction.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
DEAL-BREAKER: Gameplay seems too plodding.  A bit too many mechanisms, each of them rather uninteresting on their own.

I like my for my co-op games to not exceed a certain rules complexity.  This is so that the game can thrive on the player "social" interaction rather than worrying about parsing the rules.  I think that Lord of the Rings and Pandemic both get the rules depth about right.  I think that both Shadows Over Camelot, and to a greater extent, BSG, start to really push up against the rules complexity that I'm comfortable with for this type of game.  However, that being said, I think that BSG is still on the proper side of the line, and all the game's systems serve the goal of giving the players some interesting things to base their actions around.  

So far, I've played twice, both times with the same 4 players, and both times the Cylon gave herself away very early, which I think severely hampered the game.  Also, I'm not a fan on the Sympathizer rules, which are both too fiddly and not much fun for the person who draws that card.  I think next time I'll try to find more players or try the "no sympathizer" variant.  

I am eager to try this again, and I want to be a Cylon!

UPDATE:
Okay,I got my wish and got to be a Cylon.  This happened a little past the halfway point when the revealed Cylon pushed his other card to me.  Despite that, I was able to avoid being pegged as toaster until the turn I revealed during the run to the last jump.

I think the game does a great job of setting the atmosphere and creating tension, but I find the gameplay to be too ponderous.  I think I'm changing my opinion that this game was on the good side of the complexity line.  It's actually not so much the complexity as the plodding pace it had for us as we went though every step, shuffle, and math at each turn.  I had assumed that the game would smooth out a bit with more play, but it hasn't.  After tonight's game, I don't know that I would choose to play this again over something else.  Just too long.  

I also am terrible at remembering to use the characters' negative abilities. 

I think maybe Shadows Over Camelot has the better approach.  Overall, Shadows is certainly less thematic, but it still gives a good measure of the hidden traitor vibe, and more importantly the mechanisms are simple enough that they get out of the way of enjoyment of that aspect.

I can see why some people love this game, but for the life of me I can't imagine wanting to add more baggage to it with the expansions.

Overall, I would be very happy to play someone else's copy of this, but I don't see myself teaching and leading a group through it again.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9.5
A wonderful, involved, intense, semi-cooperative game whether you enjoy coop games or the show or neither.  Your actions essentially boil down to putting out fires on the ship, but the suspicion that one of your fellow players is a traitor make the "game hates you" aspect that much more intense.  This is a great social game, and I have seen players of all levels make impacts for good or for bad, always in entertaining ways.  Relatively easy to play, complicated by side rules and addendums, ultimately extremely satisfying.

RATING: 8
Michael Barnes Cracked LCD Review:

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
One of the more tense and frantic feeling long games I've played. From the first moment onward you're hemorrhaging resources and can't deal with everything. As a result every conflict feels a little impersonal.

Compared to Dead of Winter, this feels a little more bloated, but with a lot less room to breathe. It also necessitates a high level of play, since a successful cylon can bring down the whole ship with just mildly suboptimal choices.

Hard to get into, hard to deal with emotionally. Excellent if you're in a position to do both.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
The traitor mechanics here are absolutely top notch, no game has ever made me go from just meeting someone at my local game store to staring them in the face and calling them a lying piece of shit in a shorter amount of time. If you buy this game, buy it for that. The rest of the game though is mediocre at best, so if the traitor is discovered to early the game kinda falls really flat. There are definitely better games on the market, but this is still a solid pick up.

RATING: 6
Good co-op game, and I don't generally like co-op games.   The primary innovation is the skill check mechanic, where players can secretly contribute positive or negative cards towards the result.  You don't need to know the show, but I'm certain it's a better game if you do.   It can be very random, and you can win thru no fault of your own, so I'm not sure it should be taken very seriously, which is a bit unfortunate given the game's length.  Heavy on theme, so I give it props for that.   It's a good choice for a large group of players looking for a co-op experience and should appeal highly to RPGers also.

RATING: 10
All character cards laminated; all ships custom painted; all cards have premium sleeves
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
[b]Thank you Secret Santa 2010![/b]

Very fun game, just make [b] absolutely positively sure[/b] you play it with the right people. 

On its own merits, the game is a decent (although very repetitive) strategy game that does a fan-fucking-tastic job at porting over its theme into the look, feel and mechanics of the game. Really, it absolutely feels like (the first couple seasons) of BSG. 

However, as just a strategy game it is a little long and a little boring for what it is, although still alright. Where the game positively shines is when it's played with a group of people who are willing to embrace their characters, and yell at each other repeatedly, accusing each other of being dirty Frakking Toasters, and by the Cylons secretly sowing sabotage and discord in the fleet. This game needs that 'above the table' element more than almost any other out there - which in my experience often doesn't happen with the people I know, unfortunately. Without that element, after a few plays it becomes "Oh look, another water shortage. Yawn..." 

It also absolutely needs 5 or 6 people, probably with the No Sympathesizer variant. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
I know, for many people, that Dead of Winter 'replaces' BSG, but I couldn't disagree more. For one, as a fan of the BSG series, I love how much BSG simulates the feel of the struggle against the Cylons (and other humans!) In contrast, I couldn't be less interested in The Walking Dead - while not the direct theme of Dead of Winter, fans of the popular zombie series will find parallels that will appeal to them.

I also prefer BSG's traitor system - no 'secondary objectives,' just a team with a traitor working against them, with the Destiny Deck being sufficient for introducing doubt. The second-phase of the traitors, where someone may discover they're a Cylon, is perhaps of my favorite moments in any board game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 4

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4.75
It's very complex for what it is.  You're trying to run a deduction game to figure out what the other players' loyalties are.  But wrapped around this is a hand management game, a resource/risk management game, a space combat game, and so on.  Parts of this are interesting &/or fun to me, others are not.

The difficulty can be very random, like most co-ps.  With the attack cards spread throughout the deck, the pilots may be scrambling to fend off enemy ships, or sitting around with nothing to do.  You could get a series of brutal crises that target one resource, or a bunch of less difficult and less focused ones.  A lot depends on whether you get 2, 1, or 0 cylon cards randomly dealt out at the start.  If they stay in the deck till the sleeper phase, the human players have a much better chance.  

There are a lot of things that feel like odd choices or rough edges.  The game can be tough enough (see above) that you can be well on your way to losing even if everyone at the table is loyal.  I'm not entirely convinced that the cylon players shouldn't just reveal early and start throwing a wrench in things rather than pretending to help.  It doesn't seem possible that the players could make progress in a tug of war between 3 of them and 2 enemies who have the game's entropy on their side.  I guess that's a lot of the strategy.  You know you're going to deplete resources either quickly or slowly, it's just a question of whether you'll run out before limping across the finish line.
You can play loyal for half the game, then suddenly switch sides (without any choice in the matter).  Some players might even try to avoid helping too much in the first half, just in case they have to undo that work in the second.  
In this version, there's also a very forced kind of decision where, with some player counts, one person is a cylon sympathizer.  They'll join whichever team is doing the worst.  Practically speaking, this means that you want to do well in the first half, but not too well.  You need to ensure that one of the resources reaches the red before the sleeper phase, or the odds shift dramatically against you.
The secrecy rules, even once clarified in the errata, are still somewhat ambiguous.  The game's problem is that it gives you a decent amount of information, but there's too much for even an experienced player to keep track of.  Who put how many cards into which check, who draws what colors, what off-color cards showed up, who has access to colors outside their skill set, and that's just the beginning.  You'd have to have a mind like a steel trap to track all these variables.  That's what makes it so frustrating.  I feel like I almost could track it, but the process would be too taxing.  I'd either have to take notes (which I've never seen anyone do), or insist that the game be played at a pace that allows for such calculation.  Many of the people around here are actually quite good about keeping information open (declaring how many cards you're putting into a check, etc.), but every time you miss something or it isn't said, that's a delay when you've got to stop and ask them, and the game takes long enough already.  
Add in the fact that I don't think people (esp. as the human team) really play that well a lot of the time, and it can get more frustrating still.  There are a number of actions that people seem to consistently undervalue, and giving fellow players an opportunity to prove their loyalty (or an opening to sabotage while you're keeping tabs on them) seems under-used as well.  As an example of the kind of tactics that are overlooked, consider the once-per-game abilities.  I've always advocated for using them at the right time in the first half of the game.  People have the tendency to try and save them for the perfect time, instead of using them at a merely very good time.  It's very easy to forget what your own super move is and when's the best time to pull it off, let alone the other 5 at the table.  This gives the cylons excellent cover to 'forget' to use theirs, and when a time comes up that they can use the ability harmfully rather than helpfully, they'll do so.  If you use these them before the halfway point, you won't be losing the ones from players who turn against you in the sleeper phase, and they wont have them to use harmfully.

So, the whole experience is kind of schizophrenic.  It's stuck somewhere between a strategy game and a deduction game.  It's nice that it's a real game you're playing, and not just 2 people going back and forth ("You're lying!"  "No, you're lying!").  The fact that there's some actual meat on the bones makes me more inclined to play than a lot of the other social games.  But at the same time, the game isn't that interesting without the team element.  And the signal to noise ratio in deducing who's on what team is way too low.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7.66
The best coop/traitor game there is. The best feature of BSG is that players always have something to do and are focused all the time so there is virtually no downtime between turns (Especially with Executive Order card).
And the fact that goes so much well with the theme puts it even higher on the list of my favourite board games.
It is much more fun when you role play the characters from the series. I love to play Zarek and bring the confusion to the Galactica even as a human just because humans can't be trusted when given the privileges.

[b]Update:[/b] Expansions add more characters and crisis cards but they add so much more in modules and bits that the game gets pretty watered down. After playing few games with all expansions I kinda wanted to play base game only from then on.
[b]Update:[/b] Rating dropped from 8.5 to 8.4 due to the lack of interest.
[b]Update:[/b] Rating modified according to a custom rating system.

Have a lot of unrecorded vanilla games.

[b]Favorite mechanism:[/b] Crisis phase which happens after each player's turn and demands for undivided attention from every player in the shroud of total paranoia rendering downtime virtually non existent.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
This game is something else.  If you're a fan of the show, you'll love it to pieces, but if you've never seen a single episode, it doesn't matter.

BSG has everything in it - solid mechanics and social interaction.  The traitor mechanic works wonderfully and a lot of thought went into helping those Cylons stay hidden.  In contrast, a game like Resistance has similar elements, but it's much easier to sniff out the traitor and keep them out of the game.  Here, even if the Cylons are revealed, they can still wreak havoc for the humans and it's just so beautifully weighted.  Up until that moment, enjoy the little looks, winks, and nods as people try to suss out just who at the table is working against them.

The meat of the game is voting.  Sure, there's a bunch of ship combat that keeps tension taut, but what really drives the game is, like Resistance, secret votes to prevent disaster for the fleet.  Cylons will have ample opportunity to swing those votes, but if you're paying careful attention, you might be able to figure out who's doing it just by observing the cards that are laid out.

The diamond to be found, however, is really how many paranoid people you can sit at the table and have a good time.  Wild accusations, finger pointing, and acting upon hunches by locking up the innocent in the brig or firing them out the airlock is what makes this game a blast to play.  If you prefer multiplayer solitaire, move along and pretend you didn't read any of this.  If you're looking for a good time with friends, this is the one to bring to the table.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9.5

I guess you need to be more prudent when you send someone to the brig. We got our asses whoop a whole lot more than the first game. The 2 cyclons cards were out right from the start. The sympathizer was on the cyclons side. The two cyclons players played very well their role.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Great!  A shoo-in for Ameritrash Game of the Year 2008, and already shaping up to be a modern classic.

Like many great AT games, the rules are solid enough to provide a structural framework, while still allowing for emergent narratives and meta-strategy.  I like games with hidden traitors but they can be hard to get right -- Bang! and Shadows Over Camelot each fall short in a variety of ways.

BSG nails it thematically and mechanically ... almost perfectly.  It's not a pure negotiation game like Diplomacy, nor a pure exercise in mechanics like Puerto Rico, but somewhere nicely in between -- you negotiate over what the optimal mechanical choice actually is, and then try to navigate the in-game consequences people who disagree can inflict on you.

One minor quibble is that I think the game might be better without the Sleeper Agent Phase.  While it is true to the source material (some characters don't find out that they're Cylons until a ways into the series) it produces odd mechanical effects that are at odds with the theme.  E.g., if you're human at the start, it is counterproductive for you to try to do as best as possible, because if you draw a Cylon card, you're now facing an uphill battle against your own prior progress.  So you try to barely squeak by, just in case.  But there's no way (in the show) that any of the main characters would have not fought all out for what they believed -- so the optimal strategy is anti-thematic.  And if you're not playing this game for the theme, why bother?

For the same reason, ditch the sympathizer and play with the No Sympathizer variant from the official FAQ.

However, I criticize because I love.  This is otherwise a stellar achievement.  Best game I've played in 2008 and on my Top 10 list for all time.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

April 13-Dinged .5 for the fact that the classes can be too narrow re: 'best' things to do (i.e. president sit and draw quorum cards) and if you don't do those things it's immediate suspicion from the other players.

RATING: 6
UPDATE: Sold in an auction. My gaming group doesn't really like the hidden traitor games as much so it was destined to not get a lot of play. If I were to own one "hidden traitor" game though, this would be the one.

UPDATE: I still like it, but I tend to prefer co-op games where everyone is cooperating, like Pandemic.

Initial impressions are very positive. It's like someone looked at Shadows Over Camelot and fixed most of my major issues with it. I feel that I'm really doing something as opposed to the SoC "I'll fight off the invaders by...laying down a straight." I'm a fan of the show, so I feel that BSG takes a lot of the tension from the show and makes it a very interesting game. I am hoping to play it with a larger group than the three players I tried it with the first two times.

The rulebook is much better than the typical coop game rulebook (Lord of the Rings and Ghost Stories, I'm looking at you).

Sold.

RATING: 6.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
There are so many great things to say about BSG. Let me say that Battlestar Galactica is the pinnacle of a thematic game experience and the mechanisms of the game are heavily intertwined to this theme which is great considering I'm a fan of the source material. I challenge that this game can't be played without the players saying Frak, Toaster, or Skinjob during a game.  People call this a co-op but it's more a team-based game with the 'good guys' not knowing who the bad guys are until a point in the game when they've been caught or they reveal themselves at a critical time to cause harm. It's even worse because in the beginning of the game everyone could be a good guy and then switch to 'bad guys' at the halfway point of the game. You also have to consider that in every game there are two important titles (The Admiral and The President) that are controlled by people in the game. Are they good guys? Are they bad guys? If you try to change who controls these roles, what is the motive?

BSG is more than simply a game, it's a social experience of lies, paranoia, subterfuge and desperation.  Not only is there a game, but often a meta-game: every game but one (7/8) my girlfriend at the time has been a Cylon and I've been Human every game.  My friend Chris has been a Cylon every game he's played so far which has been about 4 or 5.  This makes you automatically assume things and point fingers earlier than usual.  It really makes the game interesting.  I can also revise my statement in that it's probably as fun being Human as Cylon and now that our group has more experience it's more balanced than I thought, maybe even skewed more towards the Humans, especially when you play with the Pegasus expansion.

I'm typically not the biggest Fantasy Flight Games fan but when they make a game that I like, I tend to really like it. It's long (about 2 1/2 hours) but I don't find it's Arkham Horror/Descent/Android long.  There isn't as much set-up and breakdown time in this game which is lovely.  

"In 7 - 10 games, if I still feel the way I do now about it, Battlestar Galactica will be upgraded to a 10 and will be my favorite board game."

Is what I said when I revamped my comments on this game.  This is a 10 and it is my favorite board game.

~-~-~-~-~-~-~-~-~-~-~-~-~-~-~-~-~-~-~-~-~-~-~-~-~

Previously rated a 7 & Previous Comments: "My initial impression is that the theme and mechanisms of the game are heavily intertwined which is great considering I'm a big fan of the source material.  This game has a traitor mechanism similar to Shadows over Camelot, unlike it's predecessor, you may or may not start as a traitor but also have the potential to become one later in the game.  The game is not perfect however since the balance of power using the standard rules seem to heavily favor a Cylon victory, though some might enjoy the challenge as Humans.  I personally feel being a Cylon would be more fun to play and since the game seems to favor their victory most of the time just seems a bit overkill."

So, still my favourite, but I understand this wouldn't be for everyone!

RATING: 8
Can be a spectacular game when everyone knows the rules and are fans of the show. The game is quite deep and includes a ton of player interaction which is one of my favorite elements in any game. It's one flaw comes when introducing the game to new players, and particularly players unfamiliar with the show. As a theme game, a lot of the driving force, in game jokes and so forth are generated by knowing the show. The game is also very complex. When playing with new players, it will be a lot harder to distinguish a player playing poorly on purpose because they are a cylon, or by accident because they have no idea what they are doing.

RATING: 8
[Shared ownership.]

1 play: it definitely has potential for me to really like it.

3 plays: it's starting to feel like there was a good game here, but they lost it among all the tedious card mechanics...

10 plays: i guess if this game was for me, i'd know by now.  Will only play when avid fans are around.

12 plays: still can't tell if i like this game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
A great implementation of the hidden identity mechanism interwoven with a boardgame. The skill check mechanism is a brilliant way to drive the game forward and add a deductive element. I find there's a bit of a barrier-to-entry with the game in that you need experienced players to provide the savvy required, otherwise things can go off the rails, especially for the hew-mons, er humans, (I'm not a Cylon, I swear). With an experienced group, however, the paranoia can create a truly sublime experience that is similar to but different from its cousin game, Werewolf (of which I'm a big fan). Plus, you don't need as many people for this one as you do for WW. 

My caveats are that it's not a short game, plan on 4 hours, and that it's hard for the hew-mons to win until you get some experienced players who can pick up on the subtleties. But if your group is willing to put in some investment plays, the payoff is a truly unique, challenging, and tense experience. I'd also like to note that I finally got around to watching the BSG series and was only mildly entertainted by it, so affinity with it is no prerequisite for liking the game. If you like WW, Resistance, etc., this is a must try for you.

Note on suggested expansion mix:

Base Game + Pegasus (- New Caprica) + Exodus +Cylon Fleet option (-Ionian Nebula, -Conflicted Loyalties) + Daybreak (-Search for Home Option, -Demetrius)

RATING: 8
Hidden traitor game  w/out hidden movement mechanics.  Everyone is aware what you are doing but nearly every decision has negative results so is all about convincing others the alternative was worse.

Cleaner and easier to most one verses all game. Rules have enough depth to make and interesting game that will play out differently each time however they are clear enough to avoid distracting from the theme and gameplay.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.9
What a well-thought out game!  I'm not a fan of the new Battlestar Galactica show, but that has little to do with how well this game plays.

The game starts off with a cooperative feel, similar to Shadows Over Camelot, with that nagging knowledge that somebody (or somebodies) are hidden cylons secretly ploying against you!

I've played seven games (once as Baltar and once as Boomer, each of which have a higher chance to get a cylon loyalty card) and I've always been a loyal human!  My catch-phrase is that my loyalty is "unimpeachable".  :)

The best part of the game is all of the social interaction after the first "bad deed" is detected by the players, and then the accusations fly.  It's scrumptuous to have close friends (even husbands/wives) second guessing each other and listening to the rationalization.

The only downside is that the game can take a bit of time.  Be ready for 3 hours or more.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Nostalgia keeps me from panning this game. Its criticisms are warranted: It's too long, it's not terribly balanced and the social dynamics don't always work as intended (plus, player awareness is so vital). But I've had so much fun sweating over my cylon-ness or second-guessing everyone at the table for hours. And a human victory produces such ecstatic joy that it should be illegal. It was one of FF's first well-produced big-box games at a reasonable price (they didn't overdo it with the minis but the quality is still top-notch). Worth getting if your group is sick of The Resistance and getting into more gamey games.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 4
It doesn't seem fair to rate this low, but I was completely not engaged with the theme. I'm not a fan of BG, my friends were and loved the game, especially the possible traitor. To my experience, this was another Shadows Over Camelot, with much more limited activity. The fort is beseiged, but unless you're a pilot, you don't really get to do much. Reading actions off a text box on the board? Not my idea of fun.

So here's the thing. The game failed to engage me at all. If it had something beyond the theme, then it should have. If you love BG, you'll thrill to this. Me? Left cold, which means the game failed.  *** I played this again (to oblige), played a pilot, and I was a Cylon from the start. Again, the other players had a blast, really enjoyed the experience. Again, I was left stone cold. There just isn't any significant choice for player action. It's not even that you choose the optimal thing to do. You just have to do the most obvious, because the other options are so weak. If you loved the new series of BG, you will really enjoy this game, it drips with theme. If you are just after a good traitor game, there are better ones on the market, much better.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Though the idea of playing a game based off a sci-fi TV series may be off-putting to a large number of people, I can safely say that despite no one in my groups every having watched a single episode of this great show (except for myself), it has always been a lot of intense and paranoid fun for all.  The core of the game is that you and your fellow crew members are fighting for your survival against a seemingly endless onslaught of robotic Cylons, but one (or more) of you is secretly a traitor, deliberately sabotaging your plans and card skills.

The game is pretty intense even without the traitor, but the paranoia and finger pointing after each failed skill check is quite enjoyable, both during and after play.  Sometimes the game can be a bit too unforgiving, and the Cylon Sympathizer rules are a bit lame IMO (we tend to not play with them), but otherwise this is a favorite of mine, if we can get enough people to play a quality game - you definitely need 5 or 6 players to get the most out of it.  It can be a bit confusing and intimidating for new players, and it, like all Fantasy Flight games, can seem to have an over-reliance of dice rolling and card draws, but the atmosphere of a game of Battlestar Galactica is hard to match.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5.8
5 of us played for 2 1/2 hrs and were less than half way through the game.  The Cylon was discovered early and he sat there with very little participation in the game.  The other  of us easily defeated any adverse events.  Just not much happened in these 2 1/2 hours and the Cylon was bored silly.  I much prefer Red November and Pandemic.  Both are much shorter games with much more action and harder to beat.

The possible Cylon(s) & sympathizer mid-game really changed the game the second time I played--we all enjoyed it very much.

3rd game-I hated it.  Never play with 4--always .  So boring.

RATING: 10
