=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Wonderful paranoia until a moment of revelation starts a concerted effort to make the final jumps.  Since the Cylons do have a favorable position because the more the humans bicker, the less efficiently they work together.  And the humans must play perfectly together to even hope of winning.  The Cylons have it easy if they can stay under the radar long enough, but at some point they must come out and start pummelling the ship.  I think the best opportunity is when distrust amongst the players is at its highest with hopefully an innocent human already in the brig.  This game has a wonderful atmosphere but it must be played swiftly; I wouldn't sit down for this one with AP players.  That is what likely ruined it for a lot of complaints of long playing times.  My first game took 2h30 including explanations, which I found perfect for this type of game.  The crux of this game is crisis resolution.  Last I checked, the crew didn't have endless thinking time to resolve them...

RATING: 8.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Best traitor style game I've played

Pros
-Very involved, as players must focus on survival (or destruction) and deducing/maintaining the secret identities of the opposing players
-Regular votes, events with choices (with real impact on your chances of survival), the ability to have titles/roles (like admiral) all add to the game
-Clever use of Destiny deck which adds unpredictability to votes AND hides cylon players
-A player that is caught is not eliminated in the game but rather gains new options to do other things (not just a few lame options)
-The game is highly thematic and accurate depicts both the atmosphere, and the contents of the source material

Cons
-Another long game (3+ hours)
-Difficult to play with people that are not good at games involving a traitor/hidden identities
-Cylon invasions depend on drawing from a deck (changed in one of the expansions). There may be no invasions for awhile, leading to boring and uneven situations (for the cylon players)
-Lacking miniatures for some components (improved upon in expansions)
-Somewhat questionable expansions add-ons
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
The traitor mechanic is brilliant, and I like the character specific strengths and weaknesses as well as the mechanical emphasis on trust (Executive Orders, Investigative Committees, Scouting, etc). I haven't seen the TV series, but this game makes me interested.

However the game is too long and there are too many decisions that don't matter. Skill checks take too long, are too frequent, and don't matter until the end. This game would be great cut in half.

Many roles suffer high downtime and low involvement; whether the game is exciting or not comes down to the card draws.

RATING: 10
Based on seven plays in a 4/5 player games.

Still a great game with an almost perfect blend into the series. I've been a cyclon about 60% of the time.

From my first game:

5 player game: I was Baltar and a (eventually) revealed cylon. The President (sitting to my right) was found to be an unrevealed cylon and aided the cylon cause greatly with the President's special ability (drawing 2 Crisis cards and selecting one for play).

It came down to my attack of 3 cylon raiders against 2 civilian ships protected by 1 piloted fighter with population at but 2. I rolled an 8 on my first roll, eliminating the fighter leaving the civilian ships to destruction by the other 2 raiders. Each was a population loss, giving the win to the cylons.

The next human player could have made the final jump to Earth.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
For some reason I just don't see the tension building up in this game. And without tension, it just falls flat. The game ended on one unlucky card draw and... well... that was it! The actions you take every turn seem pointless, nothing you do can really turn the game in a different direction. The card game to counter bad events (and the associated deduction) is the only good thing, but it's not enough. Finally, the game becomes even more boring when you're a disclosed cylon. I would say: stay away unless you're a big fan of the show and can bring in your own fun.

UPDATE: Rating went up 2 points. With the right group this game can actually be fun. The mechanics work to create all kind of suspicious situations. It's still very long for what it is, especially since you can get in a very boring situation: lonely Cylon, late-game Cylon, Sympathizer, stuck in the brig, etc. But still, not as bad as I first thought it was.

RATING: 4
I played this only once so my impressions are perhaps too heavily skewed from this one experience - but that one experience left me uninterested in playing again. Why? Because it was very depressing. I was accused of being the bad guy - it turned out I wasn't and nothing I could say or do convinced anyone otherwise. So we all died a slow death because of this. I wouldn't mind so much if the game lasted 30-60 minutes but I ended up spending our entire gaming session of I think 3 hours suffering through this slow death.

I play games to have fun. This was not fun. The rules purposely pit people against each other in an atmosphere of distrust and intrigue. Not for me.

The reason I didn't rate it lower than a 4 was because it was original, well themed, and the mechanics truly did achieve the intended atmosphere.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
I understand the allure of the game, the small mindgames that can be played when trying to figure out the cylons, and I don't mind a 3 hour game, but this game just doesn't do it for me. In my opinion the cylon players are really the only ones who get to make interesting decisions, while everyone else just goes through the motions. It basically comes down to 3 hours I would rather spend playing something else.

The thing about co-op games are the person/people who have played the most always tell the others what to do on their turn. Maybe that isn't the case when all the players have played multiple times, but in the couple of games I have played this was what happened. In this game, unless you want to be accused of being a cylon you just let others play your turn for you.

RATING: 5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Battlestar Galactica is sort of a more elaborate implementation of the idea behind Werewolves/Mafia. Its biggest improvement (and likewise also its biggest shortcoming, depending on how you look at it) is that it adds a fairly rigid set of rules. The effect is that the game becomes much more complex, and longer, but it also means that there is palpable evidence for whether a player is a human or a cylon.

The process to get there is, of course, rather involved but it is just so much more satisfying to execute someone because of what he (supposedly) did or didn't do than just because he "looked like he did it". That the cylons aren't out of the game just because they've been found out is just another bonus.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I really enjoy Battlestar. Sad it doesn't get to the table much.

RATING: 6
This is a great game to get people who are mildly interested in board games, to play something. It looks really appealing, it's easy to get the hang of it, and it is very social.
On the other hand, if I gave a rating based on how I feel towards this game, it would probably be around 4. I do not feel as if there are any hard decisions to make, most of the time finding the optimal action is simple. For me it feels like a variant of werewolf, where most of the additional rules just provide a frame. This would not be a problem, but I think that a lot of in-game interaction got lost somewhere.
I give this a 6, because the first two plays were fun, and because I consider it to be a good gateway-game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Battlestar Galactica is a solid card driven co-operative game, with good mechanics, and with the right group of people, it's great fun to play. In fact, it’s probably the best TV series theme game that I have ever run across. So what's not to like? Well, all that being said, it definitely shows signs of being a rushed production. For example: there are 5 skill decks of about 20 cards each, but each skill deck only has 2 different events. Why? Or again, the Cylons can board Galatica, but once there all they do is move up a generic track. Why couldn’t they have taken over different parts of the ship? Or the combat: the Vipers roll an 8 sided die and either kill a Cylon raider or not. And once the main ships jump all the small Vipers do too. Why not add some tension with the Vipers being possibly lost or damaged if they fail to return on time? Or the rules booklet: the rules seem all to be there but trying to find them when you need them is a chore. Organizationally they need plenty of work. Or the crisis deck: each crisis - and there are an awful lot of them - doesn’t seem particularly crisis-filled. In a 4 hour or so game (with 6 players), a typical crisis would have you lose one population, or one fuel, food or morale point. But as you start with about 10 points worth of each of the different supplies - 40+ in total - the first hour or more is not that dramatic. In other words, why give up obvious chances to add tension and interesting details to the game? Yes, it would make a long game longer and I know that euro-based game designers worry about creating long playing games but as Battlestar Galactica ends at an arbitrary 8 jumps, it seems to me easy enough to have made  it an arbitrary 6 or even 5 jumps instead and pack it with tension. The bottom line is that Fantasy Flight Games missed a golden opportunity to publish a superb product. Its skeleton is there, but the accompanying muscles are not. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9.5
This is one game that looks a lot more complicated that it is!

One might be forgiving for feeling overwhelmed by the sheer number of things to do, but everyone I have taught, even those without much Boardgame experience, has really come round to understand it.

Some might not favor its complexity but I love it! Complexity does allow the "traitor" players (Cylons) to craft very very devious plans, and when it all comes together it is very very satisfying. Other social deduction games like Bang or Resistance lack that extra layer to afford the truly devious/shrewd players the extra burst of gameplay that brings the experience to a higher level.

If I had anything bad to say, it is that the Base Game alone does lack quite a bit. Pilots aren't quite as useful. Cylon attacks too random. And oh, sympathiser I do so detest thee. But with the expansions (and your choice of addons from them) I'll say this is pretty much the most entertaining board game I own.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 4
Second play: used MasterDinadan's ultra-short variant.  It drastically improved the game.  You can find it here:

[filepage=53543][/filepage]

----

Rated 4 after one play.  

The game is far too long and repetitive and starts feeling even longer and more repetitive after all the Cylons are revealed.

It is fun, but it is criminally overlong....  Fun-per-minute is incredibly low.  

The fun part is the uncertainty associated with not knowing of who is on which team.  Once that is removed, you're turning the crank for far, far too long.

The game needs a sudden-death provision that is triggered by the revelation of all Cylons, or at least needs a "speed up" mechanism that kicks in from that point forward.  The problem is that the reverse happens, the game bogs down...

RATING: 7.75
Terrific game.  The number of characters to choose from plus "Who's a Cylon this time?" plus the way the crises play out make for a lot of replayability.  Be forewarned, though, that your first games will take well over the two hours suggested on the box, and if you're playing it with several folks who are new to both this game and games of medium complexity or above, you're looking at well over thirty minutes of rules explanation before you can get going.  The fiddliness was necessary to get the TV show's flavor down so well but man, is it ever fiddly.  I mean, Agricola is easier to teach.  Just the same, I won't be surprised if my rating of BSG keeps inching up; Nov. 2008--8; May 2009--8.25.

RATING: 6

I'm sure I'll play more in the future because most people I game with still like this, but it's probably no longer one I'll suggest.

RATING: 9
Simply put: a superb game. The awesome feeling that comes when the game is on the line, you know one of your fellow shipmates is a dastardly Cylon and you have to make a call. Who do you trust? That tension filled moment, with your cylon buddy trying to stay calm and cool under pressure; your human pal desperately trying to convince you that [i]he's[/i] innocent. Who do you trust? No matter your choice, that moment, and the big reveal to follow, will be remembered for many game sessions to come. Awesome in it's purest form.

The little to no downtime is also a really nice feature for a game that can take a few hours.

The only downside is it's best with 5 players and my group usually tops out at 4. Still, it's a lot of fun.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
There's nothing particularly interesting about the core game mechanics in [b][i]Battlestar Galactica[/b][/i]. Without the traitor mechanism, this would probably be a pretty boring game. For example a critical game aspect is the skill check where you turn over a card and then, as a group, play cards that equal or exceed a listed number with some extra cards thrown in for randomness--not terribly exciting on its own. But saying BSG is boring without traitors is like saying an omelette wouldn't be filling without the eggs. The addition of cylons (hidden traitors) takes this game to a great place because the simple skill check, for example, becomes a weighted probabilistic loyalty test: Is this check important enough that a cylon will try to sabotage it? Who is in position to betray? Two pilot cards were revealed, are these the extras or is our pilot against us? Hidden traitors, combined with how easy it is for the humans to lose the game, make decisions feel important.  These elements combine to turn a game of BSG into the tensest most paranoia-filled 2 hours in all of board game-dom. 

Being a fan of the series (or at least of science fiction) definitely helps. If you cannot role play your character to some amount and instead choose to focus on the game play separate from the theme you might be underwhelmed. This isn't to say that there aren't interesting choices outside of the theme (there's enough probability and hidden information to keep anyone busy), but the game is strongest when you, for example, call Lt. Valerii a frakking toaster.

◊s◊

RATING: 8
I have a soft spot for games that encourage deceit; BSG does not disappoint.  Some interesting thematic elements that appeal to fans of the show, but it's a solid game even without exposure to the TV series.

Game times can, unfortunately, vary quite a bit.  An efficient game might clock in around three hours, but a game with lots of cylon combat and a bit of AP can stretch out beyond four hours.

The Cylon Sympathizer is not a terribly fun balancing mechanism.  I plan to try the official "No Sympathizer" variant the next time we have 4 or 6 at the table.

The Pegasus expansion has gone over pretty well with my group. We exclude all the "New Caprica" rules, which add unnecessary complexity.

RATING: 8

RATING: 7.5
After many more plays, I've raised my rating on this. It really has a great theme, and both fans of the show and those unfamiliar with it enjoy themselves.
I've taught it to non-gamers, and they've had fun (although one was overwhelmed). The gameplay starts slow but gets faster. We've played 3 and 4 player games in about 1 and a half hours, without ending early.
It's just a lot of fun. Try it out!

Update:
I like the game, although the expansions are a mixed bag. I feel they mostly add unneeded chrome, when really the game is about pretty simple mechanics and fun social interaction. It's still a fun ride, though.

RATING: 8.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.8
This is a great game! It is a solid coop game to begin with, but the traitor element is implemented excellently and tension builds quickly as soon as people start making decisions.
My last 5 player game, I was convinced that 2 of my fellow humans were cylons, and it turns out I was dead wrong. Myself and another human player nearly released the cylon from the brig! Luckily, the other two humans stopped us (which further convinced us of their cylonic nature) and all the while we are all trying to escape before the board controlled cylons take out the Galactica. 
This is a good example of the zany confusion that can occur, and the game does an excellent...maybe perfect...job of allowing these kinds of interactions to take place. 

The game does have a couple downsides.
1: Its long. I like to pretend it will only take a couple hours, but it usually takes upwards of 3. That's not bad in our group, but for some it may be too much.
2: It most definitely works best with 3 and 5 players. For balance purposes, in a 4 player game there is 1 cylon and 1 cylon supporter. The cylon supporter is essentially 1/2 of a cylon. You don't get all the cylon abilities, but you have to reveal immediately and get the negatives. If you're unlucky enough to be the supporter, it kind of sucks (unless I'm missing something.) In a 3 and 5 player game, you have 1 cylon and 2 cylons respectively...no supporters = more fun for all.
Also, while on the subject of number of players, I actually find this game quite entertaining with just 3 players, which is a rarity for bluffing/social deduction games.

TL;DR
This is a great game with 3 or 5 players if you like making crazy unfounded (or well founded) accusations about loyalties all the while trying to either destroy or save the BSG as it journeys to its new home. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Blends the basic concept of Shadows Over Camalot traitor wonderfully into the theme of BSG. But BSG supports this much better than Shadows and adds a lot more depth to game with the various multiple actions beyond intrigue and quests. Also once the traitor is discovered here they have much still to do, which I don't feel you do in Shadows.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This is a great game.  It plays smoothly and while perhaps a tad too long, the metagame is wonderful.  The game is incredibly tense and are usually close, almost always going down to the last jump in my experience.  I have had some of the most hilarious, table pounding fun times playing this game.  Pure genius.  It is well designed and totally self contained.  On some level, I cannot imagine playing an expansion to this as it is perfect how it is.

Of late, I've been finding that it goes a little too long which knocks off points.  It could stand to be calibrated for 3 jumps of length.

The game is a tough one the first time you play it with inexperienced players, especially if they are dealt a Cylon.  If there were some way to guarantee that 1st time players were not dealt Cylon, that would be great in terms of gameplay.  But, of course, that would ruin the game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
One of my favourite games, yet it needs to be played with the right group of people.

The game is designed with an engine that would possibly defeat the players on the long run. However, players have a bunch of very effective options to win. But... surprise! Some of them are (or become) Cylons, human-looking evil robots trying to defeat humanities. 

The group needs to find out the traitors between its ranks, and jail or execute them.

The game is quite long compared to other traitor games (Shadows over Camelot, The Resistance), but if you have the time (120-200 minutes) and a dedicated group, you are in for a hardly forgettable experience.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Very good game in its genre. But of course it has flaws typical of its genre, i.e. lots of rules and text, huge downtime, long game. On the other hand pretending to be a human (while you are a cylon) or guessing who is a cylon - these are really great aspects of the game. To sum up - I can play it from time to time.

RATING: 10
The best traitor game I've played. The most thematic game ever and also very fun, I like that you can play half of the game without a traitor. My one play of it was far too long though, over 5 hours, but we were 5 and only one had played before. I'm sure the downtime can be cut down considerably.

EDIT: After playing with 4 experience players and 1 new, once again for 5 hours, I think I can say that this is simply a long game. It did take over 1 of those hours to explain and refresh rules, compounded by the poorly laid out rulebook. It's definitely worth those hours, though. Although it felt rather slow at times when playing, I couldn't stop thinking about the game for hours after and that is a sign of a good game.

EDIT: After my third play, with Daybreak, we managed to reduce the time to 3h + rules, this time with 2 new players. I can definitely see the game getting more fun and quicker, so with my main downside getting better, I increased my rating.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Feels a lot like Shadows Over Camelot, but I like the traitor mechanism and traitor protections in BSG better.

The "half-cylon" solution of a sympathizer bothers me a little, since you can game the system by deliberately breaking the ship, but I can't think of a better solution. For that reason I think it works best with five players.

Be warned, the playing time estimate is flaky. Like Werewolf, if players get really into discussing who the traitor is the game can get a lot longer. Just running the mechanics might be able to finish in two hours, but I've seen most games last at least three.

It's a good game even if you're not a fan of the show (I'm not).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Clever two sided game pretending to be a "co-operation game".
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Set in space, players are either humans trying to accomplish a mission and travel to Cobol or trying make them fail. What role you are is not revealed at the start of the game. Therefore it is a game of treachery by sabotaging without it being obvious or trying to beat the game.

My opinion is not affected by the TV-series since I haven’t seen it, but I am intrigued with the theme and how it seems to be executed. I find the traitor mechanic work really well where there is a fine balance for the cylons before revealing. Despite its archaic mechanics, I find that it is usually very tense. I appreciate the game more after playing it a few times as you get into the system and understand what cards are good or not.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
The best coop around
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Easy game to learn and play, but it's all about those little things that happen during the game that can make the difference between win or lose.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5.5
eh
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Played with 4; unlikely to get more players in the near future.  I liked how the Crises mechanism got all the players involved (as opposed to solo quests in "Shadows Over Camelot").  On the other hand, having a "guaranteed" Cylon was less appealing than the random Traitor in SOC.  Want to get more table time before making a firm decision on this rating.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
One play with five. When you're fighting off raiders and everything is going haywire, it's quite exciting. I assume that the hidden traitor element is going to be a lot of fun as well, though that didn't work out in a satisfying way in our particular game. The "jump" mechanism is also very cool, giving the game an interesting rhythm. The negative is that it's a long game and there's a fair amount of down time. In particular, things can get pretty dull for a Cylon player who has been exposed.

Also, I think it's kind of a cop-out when a special ability in a cooperative game is to give your actions away to someone else. How is that fun?
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Good but short of great. Maybe a bit better than Shadows Over Camelot but I like the theme a bit less, so it is a wash.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.8
2 caveats to start; 1) I only played a partial game and 2) I have not seen the show.  That said, this game had a great feel, and some fun mechanics. I can see how fans of the show would absolutely love this game. In the meantime, I'd definitely play again and will likely look into watching the series...
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Rating after one 5pl and one 4pl game. Most cooperative games fail with me as they don't offer any interesting decisions to take. This one is different. Table talk is important and unlike Shadows over Camelot, in BG it's useful to reveal the traitor/Cylons. Here you must work together and not like in SoC just send one player there and the other overthere. Clearly superior in terms of "working togehter". However, being suspected being a Cylon, then being thrown into the brig but you are human hurts a bit... just like in real life. Not all characters are equal fun to be played. Winning is very hard because of fuel shortage. I wished that the skill cards offered a bit more distinct actions, as the ones on the board are very limited. The game is fun but can also drag a bit.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Box D

I absolutely loved this TV series, so i don't see how i can possibly dislike the board game.  Some of the guys in my group are attempting to watch the series and don't want to play it until then.  Man, if they'd just watch the movie they'd be hooked.

RATING: 6
Can be really long (hours).
I found the game quite interesting. Complicated enough to give nice choices.
It can be, however, frustrating a little for revealed Cylons, and very frustrating for accused innocent humans.
Quite difficult to keep track of what's going on precisely. Especially if unrevealed Cylons act smart and are convincing at the same time.

RATING: 8
the core of the game isn't in its mechanics, its in the sheer interaction between players, both cylons and humans trying to convince the others to meet their own agenda.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Long game. Things are interesting until the cylons are hidden and as they reveal all the shit hits the fan. 
Then it is a slow slow death...

I found actions a little repetitive and the decision making tough but not excruciatingly so, as I would have expected instead. Finally I have some concerns on the balance of the game. We won in our game, but only because the cylon players were being good sports, otherwise we wouldn't have had a chance. I doubt that with competitive players playing the cylons the humans really con make it. 

Finally, the Italian edition of the game is a monument to what you should not do in the business. Give Editrice Giochi the edition of any game! The map has typos and outright mistakes, the cards have mistakes. It looks more like a playtest game with all the editing in progress still there, instead of a finished game!

Overall I wasn't impressed.

RATING: 7
Gets a good rating because it's the only thematic game my wife will play and she loves it. While I can already see limitations in the choices available to players this is a hugely enjoyable social game that has brought a number of old gaming friends back to our table and hungry for more and we've had some very tense and exciting games. It's a great favourite that's seeing a lot of play.

RATING: 8
I have only played the game once, but I was noticeably swept away by it. 4 hours went in the blink of an eye. Even though we lost to the Cylon traitor, I can't help but look back fondly on the experience. The pieces are beautiful, the theme is perfect, and the mechanics make sure that everyone is continually guessing who the Cylon is (even though our Cylon was obvious about it...we didn't want to get him any more angry at us). Definitely want to add a copy to my collection, but there aren't enough people in my group who would be interested in playing.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
The best adaptation of any screen (large or small) story to a board game that I have ever experienced.

It masterfully recreates the looming tension of the series in a 3+ hour game between players. I will never forget the first time I played trying to convince (truthfully) my fellow players that I was not a Cylon (ironically, my character was Boomer). The witch hunt nearly killed me.

In the second half of the game, I found myself accusing another player of being a Cylon with such vigor that I used Boomer's miracle token (we were playing with all expansions) to airlock/space Adama. I was convinced he was a Cylon.

Nope.

What I did have, though, was blood on my virtual hands, and the irony of that in contrast to my tearful pleas for mercy in the first half sold me on this game as a concept.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

i only want this game for its  components , mostly the plastic ships , and a few of the crew cards to use for a different game .

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Are you a Cylon?  Am I a Cylon?  Half way through this game you'll think you know who the Cylon is, and then another set of traitor cards will be dealt out and your confidence goes right out the window with it.  Sometimes you'll run out of fuel and lose, sometimes you'll run out of morale and lose and sometimes you'll lose all your population and lose.  If you're really lucky you'll have a massive space battle and the Galactica will be blown up.  Sometimes, you'll even manage to win - but probably only because you were a Cylon.  All this means that on the rare occasion you do win as a loyal human it's a special day.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
Gold Star
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
For straight-up co-op play, there's Pandemic and Lord of the Rings. Honestly, I don't think any game will replace Lord of the Rings in my affections.

But Battlestar Galactica isn't straight-up co-op play. And I *love* it. Paranoia, tension, treachery, massive dogfights against insurmountable odds...it's wonderful!

My only concern is that BSG can take too long, which makes it more of an "event" game and less of a "hey, wanna play BSG?"
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Had a very fun first play as Starbuck.  I didn't get out into space as often as would be thematic, but I think that was more due to the lay of the cards

My cylon compatriot had no idea I was a cylon and used his power to send me to the sickbay.  I would have more sense to send the President, but he must have thought he was the other cylon.  Galactica had 4 damage at this point and I was about to reveal and damage 2 more areas (special ability), and blow up the ship!  D'oh!  I guess that means I was playing "human" pretty well and just waiting for the right time to do my sabotage.  Unfortunately, my team bungled it up and nixed my ability.  It was still good fun.  The humans were having too easy a time of it until the end.  It didn't become a nail biter until then.  I'm looking forward to trying it again.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
This is a coop game that makes you hate everyone you're playing with. The game is nicely designed and balanced, but the atmosphere is oppresive and eventually the players are paralyzed by how difficult it is to pass the endless series of skill checks. Regardless of whether the cylons win or lose (again, it's well balanced), the game starts well and ends with a big groan. Definitely needs 5+ players.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I really enjoyed this.  It has everything I like about Shadows Over Camelot, except the theme is much more interesting and intense, and is better integrated.  Instead of fighting the black knight in a tournament or worrying about a despair card coming out, you're fighting enemy ships and trying to prevent your people from starving.

RATING: N/A
[b]You will love this game if you like[/b]:
Paranoia
Coop-play - in a sense
To beat the crap out of your fellow players
Secrecy
Paranoia
Being the focus of, or the instigator of, suspicion
Paranoia
To discuss, and present your case
Social experiences before rules

[b]You will hate this game if you like[/b]
To finish games in under three hours
To have everything be apparent for every player
Play your own game, keeping to yourself
Elegant mechanics

RATING: 6
I was only able to play half a game, but what I saw was very interesting. It's very similar to Shadows Over Camelot (which is not necessarily a good thing). I love the show, so the theme made a big difference to me. I don't think it would be as fun for someone who is not a fan, but I could be wrong. Need a full play to give a solid rating, but starting at 7.

UPDATE: After another play (sadly aborted before the end), I still like it. It seemed overly complex and took way too long, but I think both of those aspects would be reduced by more familiarity with the game. Staying at 7 for now.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Loving this so far, but definitely with 5 rather than 6. Downtime with 6 seems a bit too much (particularly for revealed cylon players, who have a relatively short turn) and if there is a 3rd cylon it seems a bit too difficult for the humans.

With 5 it seems tense and a close game, although I imagine it is dependent on who you are playing with. If there is a lot of talk about who is a cylon that is where the fun is. Otherwise I can imagine it reverts to a normal cooperative game with one or two players dominating the decisions.

RATING: 8
A Christmas ('08) gift.

My initial impressions of this are very positive.  The game does a very credible job of invoking the tension that was always present in the source material.  So far, unfortunately, I haven't managed to get a complete game played.  

I'm going to score this an "8" right now, because that rating does accurately reflect how I feel about it at the moment, but that is [i]highly[/i] subject to change.

Edit:  After finally getting in a complete game, my initial opinion is largely unchanged.  I do wonder how much staying power this one is going to have.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I usually am not that interested in hidden role games, but I love this game anyway. The mechanics are all fairly simple and intuitive yet there's tons going on, near-constant decision making, and lots of ways to play. Every playthrough is a different story and will have heroes, villains and unfortunate victims. Downsides: it can be tough to get on the table, it may start some arguments and/or hurt feelings, and the sympathizer rule is atrocious, but none of those problems are big enough for me to bump it down from a 10.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Foul, spectacular fun.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Goes on a little long for what it is... the many skill checks involved, as important as they are at times, can kind of make it drag.  But that notwithstanding, this is a terrific game.  Some will prefer Shadows Over Camelot for its relative simplicity, and I still like Shadows quite a lot for what it is, but this has a lot more "chrome" and doesn't just tack it on, it's all integral to the theme and the gameplay.  There are a lot of great decisions to make throughout the game, and a lot of important interaction and interpersonal dynamics.  Some games can be kind of boring if enough Cylon Attack cards don't come out at times that matter, but some of the great games are truly intense, so I'm happy that this swings for the fences and often hits home runs, even if it strikes out now and then.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
What to say, brilliant, intriguing...I love it.

Usually if mine play group play something during the week and the next day is a working day we call it a night at round midnight. when I first got the game we finished our first game at about half past midnight and people were all standing up from their chairs. Once it was finished we all looked at each other, looked at the clock and everyone agreed "well we will all be really tired tomorrow at work because we are going to play another game now!"

In mine opinion it gets a bit old after couple of plays but luckily there are 2 large expansions in witch you can mix and match deferent expansion options so it will keep you hanging on for quite a while.

Enjoy

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
For a "gaming experience" it's hard to top this one.  It captures the theme of the show really well and the tension is high.

Unfortunately it takes a long time to play and you don't have very much control.  There's also luck, luck luck in here so go in with the right expectations.  Thinking of this as a social game is probably the right way to go.

Update 1/9/11

Played a few times now and the cylons always seem to win.  Not sure whats going on.  Again, the long playtime makes it pretty challenging to get this one to the table.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Ok, so a geekbuddy asked why I had played it so much and not had made a comment on the game yet.

Well, what more needs to say.  Everyone loves it.  I'm just not sure it's a 'Top 20' game.  Heck, I'm not even sure it's a Top 100 or even 200 game.  It's fun, but I'm not sure it's enduring.

It's a bit long for a 'blind bidding' game.  But, the player interaction within that bidding game is interesting.

I do think it's somewhat well balanced.  I enjoy the Sympathizer mechanism.

The main positive is that it's fairly easy to teach and it's well received even among players that aren't fans of the show.

I'm still not sure about this game as far as a 'top notch' game, but with over 50 logged plays now I still enjoy playing it 'most' the time.  It really shines with the right crew.

I did not enjoy the addition of Pegasus, but Exodus has reinvigorated it.

smell: -------:what:-------

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Ez kérem ki van találva
Az eddig próbált árulós-kooperatív játékok közül a legjobb! Mindenképpen érdemes a sorozatot is megnézni, mert így a játékélmény még jobb, de az azt nem ismerők is belevághatnak (sokat segít ezen, ha a szabálymagyarázás közben a sorozatot ismerő pár színesítő infót bedob).
A szabályokat könnyen el lehet sajátítani, azonban minél többet játszottál már vele, annál jobb az élmény. Minél tapasztaltabbak a humánok és a cylonok, annál jobb lesz játszani és újra elő-elővenni. Bár lassan 10 éves a játék, nem sikerült a témát és a mechanizmust jobban kidolgozni. Egyelőre klasszikusnak tűnik! Próbáld ki, ha tudod!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Simply amazing.  A wonderful thematic game.  BSG fans, rejoice!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Always played with expansion and 6 players. Board looks great. Only a few players (the president for example) get to do anything in this game, the rest of the time, you are shuffling some cards and let people who know the game choose actions for you. 
Very very long and tedious. In short, not fun. If it played under an hour, maybe it would be fun. As it is, you need a really good group of friends to play this. Not a pick up and play game.

RATING: 7
I started watching the series shortly before playing this game and found that thematically, this game is excellent. The game was quite difficult for the human players, but even in defeat it felt good to be one of the good guys - this game definitely has the potential to make you temporarily hate your friends. Overall, the game is quite fun, although it seems to be unbalanced. In all games I played where humans won, the card draws were stacked in their favor. Additionally, in 3 and 5 player games it becomes almost unfair for humans, while in a 4 player game the cylon player usually has slightly less than even odds against the humans. I have not yet played a game with more than 5 people.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Rubric:
*Components (1-5) - 4 (Cardboard battlestars could easily have been plastic)
*Artwork (1-5) - 4 (Screenshots from the show are thematic but original artwork for ships and backgrounds are not fluid in transition)
*Intuitiveness & Replay-ability (1-10) - 9 (Player phases are simple and straightforward. There is a learning curve for new players so I would not immediately teach this as a gateway game.)
*Strategy & Choices (1-10) - 7 (Much of the strategy is decided before the game begins based on character choice of the group. If a key member of the group becomes a Cylon, your choices become limited and tip in the favor of the Cylon player(s). There is an element of luck as you handle crisis and jump cards but hopefully you trust your team to support you)
*Game Experience (1-10) - 8 (Fun every time it hits the table. I have played as Human and Cylon and Cylon Leader characters. I have used none, one and both expansions. I would highly recommend Pegasus over Exodus. Some turns drag, as each player preforms their actions while the others wait. That said, everyone has a change to contribute to the crisis on every turn so you are still actively contributing to the game on each turn.)
*Elegance (1-10) - 8 (This game has been flushed out and simplified for players. Unfortunately one expansion had much more playtesting than the other.)
-------------
Total: [40] x2 = 80
Grade: B

RATING: 9.5
Consensus among my playgroup is that the game itself should never get more than 6-7 on the merits of how good it is in vacuum. It's just that with a good group the playing is so much fun, it would really make no sense giving anything less than 9 to this masterpiece! It doesn't matter if you know anything about the TV series, but if you do, it will give you some extra kicks. The mechanics fit the show better than I could have ever guessed.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Excellent cooperative game.  Best traitor mechanism I've ever seen.  Kicks the ass off of ghost stories and other recent cooperative games.  Reminds me of Arkham, but the system is stripped down and you have the cylons to worry about instead- which makes for a shorter, simpler, but more fun game.  Your individual turn/action is usually not that interesting but the long term group planning (we need to get some pilots out, you should take engineering skills because I think our engineer is a cylon, etc.) is pretty interesting.  The guess the traitor metagame is fantastic.  The ship combat is simple but provides some tension.  The skill resolution, which is a sort of hidden bidding mechanism, is really clever.  The variable player power characters are very different and playing each one will be a totally new experience.  The components are great, rules were well written with the exception of one typo (nukes).  It needed a player aid with the battle chart, but its on the back of the rules.

Overall this is a fantastic co-op game that FF thankfully didn't overchrome.  The theme is great and shines through the entire game, but you don't get bogged down in rules exceptions and card text.  

UPDATE: climbing my ratings, this is great fun and very replayable.  The humans really have to have their shit together to win, especially if the president or admiral become cylons.  

UPDATE: Humans have won!  Awesome game, its a different ride every time.  Sometimes its easier for the humans, sometimes for the cylons, but you always have a great story to tell after the game.

The balance is really effected by the players themselves.  Our group seems to have caught on to the cylon strategies easily but we aren't the most effective humans.  We may start turning the resource dials up until the humans start winning more often.  GREAT GAME.  This is one of my favorite games of all time, ranking up there with Titan.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.25
Hard to rate this game: I like the tv-series (as entertainment), and the game replicates quite well the overall feeling and dynamics of the series. That is definitely a positive thing in a game based on a television series.

The gameplay itself is not actually bad per se, but little bit uninspired combination of communal skill checks, light hand management and some suspension from figuring out identities of the cylon agents.

If you like the series, playing this few times is probably a positive experience. But not a very good game mechanismwise in my book, and probably not replay value for 10+ games.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
It was fun, but awfully long. I don't see a very good way to shorten it either. I think you'll just have to play a different hidden role negotiation type game if you don't have the 3+ hours. The characters work well to feel very different from each other, but the general mechanics of the game aren't anything special. The real fun is in the paranoia. Because it's so dependent on the players being deceptive to work, there's really no reason you couldn't just play another (shorter) game with similar mechanics. Even so, it does create some good “remember that one time” stories, which I think is why the Ameritrash crowd finds it so appealing.
UPDATE: Now that The Resistance has come out, providing a structured hidden traitor experience in such a short time, there really isn't much reason to pull this one out other than the theme. Battlestar Galactica now feels to me like playing a game of The Resistance and Pandemic at the same time, but going on much longer. I wish the designers had realized that the real strength of this game lies in the deception and analysis of the actions the other players take, not in managing the food, fuel, and population dials.

RATING: 7.5
Really interesting mechanics. Haven't played it enough to get full use out of the expansion, but it's neat.

What is really great about this game is that everybody does indeed suspect everybody else of being a Cylon. Accusations flying back and forth, and skill checks being sabotaged not because the Cylon actually does something, but because the others refuse to cooperate with who they think is a Cylon.

It's all in the metagame, and this game enables that perfectly.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
BSG can be fiddly and clunky. It doesn't always satisfy. But when it [i]does[/i] work it is very hard to beat. In those high moments, following comment applies: BSG is a game of mind games. Cylons sabotage the humans not only be being unhelpful, but also by persuading them to make less than helpful moves when the pressure is high and mistakes are costly. Humans need to keep focused on doing the best thing to survive, figure out fast who the cylons are, and deflect suspicion and criticism more effectively than the cylons do. All this adds up to a diffcult metagame that offers many avenues for misdirection and for manipulating ambiguity.  

But BSG is a fragile game. People need to be prepared for the possibility that they will be subjected to a one-sidedly brutal defeat. I've decided, furthermore, that I don't like the game if I play with people who don't pay attention. In that context the game drags, the intensity lessens, and a 3-hour game drags into a 5-6 hour bleary-eyed ordeal. 
 
EXPANSIONS:
I don't play regularly enough to keep on top of all the extra rules added by the expansions. In general, I find the expansions add more overhead and complications with little payoff in terms of gameplay. But there are one or two cool things that I'll want to keep. To avoid the bloat, next time I'm going to: 

-From Pegasus, ditch 'reckless' skill cards (except I'll keep the Investigative Committee)

-From Pegasus, ditch any quorum, super crisis, you are a cylon cards that refer to treachery

-From Exodus, ditch crisis cards and skill cards with 'consequence' symbol.

-Keep cylon fleet board, pegasus cylon locations, pegasus board, but ditch all other expansion features (new caprica, conflicted loyalties, cylon leaders, etc)

NOTE ABOUT PLAYS:

My plays for the Pegasus and Exodus expansion are rolled into my stats for the BSG base game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Get ready to be immersed in this theme heavy coop game where you are sure at least one of your shipmates is a Cylon!

It is a risk and resource management game, which is fairly easy to play, and where the action takes place during the Crisis Resolution step at the tail end of every player's turn.  Most of the time, players will get to "vote" (using their action cards) on the crisis at hand.

WARNING: As with most games, it can be quite boring when played with the wrong type of players.  Even more so with this one.  Table talk is a large part of the game, so if you don't like Co-Op games or dislike the theme, stay away.

Following a jump, there will be a few duller moments.  This is the time when you will want to pick up additional cards or use Recon Patrol to help with the next jump or ensure nothing really nasty is waiting for you with the next Crisis card.

NEGATIVE ASPECT: Can be long if you're not into this type of game or dislike the theme.

The Skill cards are too small (standard sized cards would have been better, IMHO)

A die would have been better when rolling to damage the Galactica (location) and/or Cylon BaseStar, instead of having to shuffle a pile of tokens.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Fantastic game, but you need the right group of people to play with.

RATING: 9.5
Played once. Absolutely loved it. Very loyal theme.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Despite the large manual, the game is quite easy to pick up.

The game definitely recreates some of the atmosphere of the show (or at least the atmosphere of watching the show). Ingeniously, you may know or have a strong idea of who the Cylon may be, but you won't be able to prove it until they reveal themselves, or you break the rules. 

Even if you are allowed to look a the cards, you cannot show anybody - thus you may have the proof you need, but nobody may believe you!

Unfortunately, once the Cylon is revealed, a lot of the tension is dispelled, and it turns into a roll-the-dice-and-move kind of game, though using "jump" icons on cards, instead of pips on a die. And the skill cards, are very limiting, I'm not sure if this improves with the expansions, but I was definitely fed up of some of them by the end.

The more people you can get to play the better I'd imagine, though our first 4 3 player game lasted 4 hours, so beware.

RATING: 10
I only play a house-ruled shortened version. Distance 4, lower ressources, less vipers/raptors/nukes, halve the deck etc. And it works like a charm.
I can send you the exact configuration if you pm me. 

Then you have a tense 100 minute game that is perfect. (Otherwise it drags on for just too long!)

This game is theme through & through.. if you're a human you really wanna protect the galactica, if you're a cylon you really wanna destroy it.
The traitor mechanic is implemented perfectly.. it builds a tension of doubt and mistrust, but at the same time you have to work together.. these naging doubts & accusations.. a true classic!

RATING: 3

Before you buy check the theme out,

RATING: 9
9-21-11
Updating my rating from an 8 to a 9.  Since my previous comment where I had not yet been a Cylon, I've had a few more plays of this game.

I still have similar complaints.  Among them, is the time it takes to play the game, the difficulty of learning to get new players to try it, and that ultimately you are pushing skill cards around for a few hours.

The brilliance shines through the interaction though.  The constant fear of backstabbing, challenged motives, card analysis, and risk taking has a great balance.  Definitely helps that the group I play it with knows each other fairly well so the table talk is a lot of fun.  Only one game has truly been sour - where the Cylons had us held in the brig indefinitely until we called it a wash after they were done torturing us.  The rest have been enjoyable to play through, if not easy.

That's my final complaint.  If the cylon(s) are new players who don't really know how to utilize their options, the game might turn out pretty biased to the humans' favor.  The right balance of player skill can mar the experience a little if not found.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
Deeply immersive theme that is faithful to the series in terms of suspense and suspicion. However, like most cooperative games I've played so far, this game drags with a bunch of newbies to four hours with six players, despite the very limited set of actions a player can take: "Move your token, and take an action--play a card or do what the space says to do." And the actions themselves are too simple for my tastes--Starbuck: roll a 4+ on d8 to destroy a Cylon Raider in combat; if you get hit, you end up in Sick Bay; rinse and repeat. As Baltar, I was thrown into the Brig, and could not get out for the lack of cards--I kept on playing one card on my turn, what fun is that? Near the end of the game, the pace picked up, and the humans lost by 2 points in the skill check cards to prevent our last morale point disappearing before we could make the final jump to Earth. Still, slow play like this is unforgivable. I'm not sure when I will play this again. Initial rating: '6'.

Update (06/18/10): Haven't played it since. Don't think I ever will again. Downing to '5'.

Update (08/17/10): In hindsight, the reason this is probably so popular is that it provides a very good template for role-playing, and in that regard succeeds; as a game of in itself, meh.

Update (10/01/11): I am a big fan of the new BSG series, as well as the old one. Still, familiarity is not enough to have me consciously want to play this cardboard-bloated, mind-numbing time waster. Due to the cooperative nature, some alpha-male will always take over the game, although the secret Cylon element should keep it interesting. I now feel about this game like I feel about Arkham Horror. I simply don't care to play this ever again. Down to '2'.

Update (10/30/2014): Played [thing=159503][/thing], which is faster, more intense, and more fluid than BSG:TBG. With tongue-in-cheek references to Star Trek, TCID is a [i]far superior[/i]--in terms of game mechanics--more accessible cooperative that plays in 60-75 minutes. 

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I'm very torn on this game. On the one hand it has given me some of my favorite gaming memories. On the other, there are times where I have never been more bored playing a game.

In essence BSG is a complicated game of Mafia -- it's a team play game with "moles" who are trying to sabotage the players' success. It's up to the "good" players to figure out who the moles are and convince others around the table to agree with them and take the moles out. As such, the fun level of this game is HIGHLY dependent on who you play with. The psychological aspect and bantering is what makes this game fun, so if you don't have people who can do that, don't bother playing it. Furthermore, the game is really only fun if there are two Cylons (moles), so don't bother playing if you don't have 5 or 6 players (this can make it hard to find people to play). 

The interesting thing with this game is how quickly the pace can change. Many turns can go by where you're basically sitting there not doing much, and then all of a sudden a Cylon fleet will jump in and all hell will break loose. This can make for uneven (and sometimes boring) gameplay, but I think it's an essential part of this game. This unevenness captures the feeling of the show better than any other branded game I've played. It really does make you feel like you're a sad bunch of humans wandering through space. 

At the price for this game you would expect a nice board and some nice pieces. Well, they're definitely "good enough", but not exceptional.

So in summary: this game captures the feeling of show VERY well. It's also given me some of my best gaming memories. For these reasons I give it the 8 that I did. However, if you have a crappy group of friends, I can see this game feeling like a 2.

New in Shrink
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Preliminary rating after a single 4p game.  I don't believe the potential was fully realized with this one play, and have doubts about the game with only four.  Current rating based on projected potential.  I have high hopes, but we'll see...

[q="HiveGod"]Some games require you to bring more to the table than others—the best games are far more than the sum of their parts, and contain possibilities that are not spelled out in the rulebook, or even hinted at.  They must be invented by the players.  "Experience" games, especially, demand much of the players.  [i]BSG[/i] is guilty of this in spades.  It's intimately tied to the show, requiring that you watched it, liked it, and are willing to engage in role-playing the paranoia and terror of tooth-and-nail survival and religious genocide.  The rules and mechanics serve merely as a foundation for this play—dumping cards into a skill check is boring.  Paying attention to who is dumping cards and how many, who is abstaining and why, demanding explanations for a player's behavior during that check [i]is[/i] the game.  That's where facial expressions, body language, and too-passionate denials trip up the wolves and damn the innocent.

The mechanics of [i]BSG[/i] are not, in and of themselves, sufficiently interesting to entertain for more than 15 minutes.  They are indeed "boring, fiddly and repetitive".  But as a foundation to support the emergent play of like minds, it's pretty damn fantastic.

So...  is [i]BSG[/i] a good game?  It all depends on who you have to play it with.[/q]
UPDATE:  After a 6p game, this locks in at a solid 8.  The mechanical aspects of what's happening [i]on[/i] the table are nothing compared to what's happening [i]at[/i] the table.  If you sit down to this game thinking you'll be playing out tactical space battles and puzzling to solve sci-fi crises co-op style, you'll be bitterly disappointed.  Oh, sure, you'll be doing those things in a small way—but really, they are only there so you can watch how enthusiastically and competently (or not) people work to handle them...  The real game lies in the social interaction of wolves slinking among sheep while bleating helplessly.  It's all about poker faces, plausible deniability and hiding in plain sight.  It's playing on emotions, constructing compelling arguments, and working at the chinks in others'.  It's pure sociopolitics, more RPG than board game—it's [i]Werewolf[/i] with a sci-fi theme and more moving parts.

PS.  With the right people, it's a hoot!

UP-UPDATE:  Bumping this up to a well-deserved 9.  Now that we have the rules down to the point where the mechanics fade into the background, [i]BSG[/i]'s true potential shines through.  An incredible experience!

RATING: 10
After several plays (including an AMAZING pbf session), I have to actually enter comments on this awesome game.  BSG can be a very tense and exciting game.  I have only had one session that was a little dry, and that was when it was being played as a 2 player game using an official variant.  If BSG has a flaw, it is that it is at its best the more people that play it.  A 3 player game is good.  4 is better.  5 or 6 is outstanding!  I don't have an issue with the Sympathizer as some folks do, although, it would irritate me if my group wanted to "game" the system in order to cope with the Sympathizer by intentionally knocking a resource into the red pre-sleeper phase.  Even people that I introduced the game to who have not seen the show have loved it.  It truly transcends the typical "licensing tie-in" genre and shines as an outstanding example of paranoia and distrust made fun!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Spend a long time doing very little.

Whenever I play this game it takes forever - I usually play in a large group of 6 or more people.

The game is too long, you could start the humans right before the half-way mark when the psilon sympathizers have to pick sides.  Otherwise you spend a long time getting there and not much happens.  When all the psilons leave the ship and try to destroy you is when it gets interesting (although usually hopeless for the humans).

The exciting and fun game elements seems to be buried in a lot of trivial non-sense.  The president of the colony has cards that are marginally helpful and they waste time reading them but often never use them.

There needs to be a third type of player (not sympathizer) but a psilon that is trying to remain with the humans and help them win.

If you could play this game in 30 minutes, 45 max I would have given it a 6 or 7, considering it takes 2 or more hours to get the 30-45 minutes of fun makes this game one I don't plan on playing again.

Fantasy Flight continues to have extremely high quality boards, cards, and production values overall.  Fantasy Flight also keeps true to its form over substance game offerings.  They like to sell a lot of pretty games, but not really good games.  I wonder if they refuse to make any game that doesn't have the option for expansions.

A well designed Euro-style game can't be expanded over and over again, FF wants to put out new content for a game every quarter or put it out of print.

RATING: 10
I love the mechanism of this group game! I can play this game again and again, it never gets boring!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
This a difficult and lengthy cooperative game which isn't a necessarily a negative in itself. But mix grinding elements with surefire traitors and the result is a draining 3+ hours experience. Unlike other cooperative games, there is no way to improve the situation. Every turn is weathering crisis after crisis and hoping the 'jump' clock will bloody advance. After a few hours of play, Galactica will be in poor shape, limping into the next jump before running out of suppliers / morale / what-not.

There is no way to grow in strength, move the clock forward or tip the scales. Just another "Kill me now" groan for every new crisis without a jump clock. Towards the end, the morale dial becomes misleading because the players on the human side actually lost the will to live several turns ago.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
Paranoia. As the humans, you feel it.  As the Cylon(s), you create it.  While everyone seems to be rushing about from location to location, trying to help, there is at least one person who is secretly sabotaging your efforts and driving wedges in between players.  Skill checks are made by playing cards face down that are either negative or positive, then shuffled together with 2 random "fate" cards thrown in to ensure anonymity.  Meanwhile, raiders attack, boarders move up, and resources dwindle while someone aboard contemplates the perfect moment to reveal themselves and seal the fate of the ship.

RATING: 9.5

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Co-op games with traitors aren't really my thing although I do feel like playing this every now & then with the right group.  It's a good way to spend time with friends.

Things I like: 

* The way traitors sabotage with wrong coloured cards in the skill checks.  I think it's a good mechanic.
* How additional loyalty cards are received halfway through the game.  It freshens the game up when it might otherwise start to drag.
* The multiple variable player powers.
* The social/psychological aspect of the traitor(s) can be great with the right group.  It's great fun to find out how & why players played the way they did.

Things I don't like: 

* I don't like being a traitor (I'm happy to be evil but this type of duplicity is against my nature).  
* The order the crisis cards arrive is a bit too random for me - it's hard to plan for them & it can be boring when there are no enemy ships for long periods.
* Occasionally there's not much to do on your turn & the game loses a bit of tension.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This is the best traitor-based game out there.  Playing this game is so good that it makes several other games look completely outdated.

RATING: 7
Co-ops won't ever be my favourite type of game, but this is above average for the genre. As with Shadows over Camelot it's the dark atmosphere produced by the constant suspicion of a traitor that makes the game, although Cylons are perhaps a bit too easy for the President to reveal. Variable pacing, some jumps are just swarming with enemy fighters, others provide little to do but kick your heels for a while. There is some die rolling, but its influence on the game is kept reasonable. In all, this, like SoC is an over-produced 'experience' game, but good for a change of pace.

RATING: 4

However, the much larger problem is the gameplay. There were times when there were no cylon ships, and not really a lot for the human players to do with their actions. This was made all the worse by a distinct lack of variety on the cards, and each player normally only drawing from 2 or 3 of the 5 decks (meaning they saw even less variety). The cylon players also had little of interest to do. Also, I find the idea of changing sides mid-game rather off-putting.

RATING: N/A
Buen juego de coop-op con sistema de traidor oculto. Lleva camino de convertirse en un clásico moderno. Puntos fuertes: resolución de crisis (una especie de pujas en subasta oculta con cartas) que es el pilar del juego. Cada personaje es único con puntos fuertes y débiles. El traidor descubierto aún está en el juego pudiendo hacer varias acciones. Pegas: los humanos lo tienen dificil para ganar. Partidas largas (3-4 horas). La suerte influye en varias ocasiones más que tu habilidad para lidiar con una crisis. Me gusta la variedad de cartas que hay y la pacífica quietud del espacio profundo que se forma tras hacer un salto para evitar un ataque cylon.

RATING: 2
--Nov 6, 2012--
I'm not familiar with the show, and I'm not a huge fan of games where you spend the whole time trying to mindscrew everybody at the table. Overall a very average game that I would play again (and probably enjoy it well enough for the duration), but I wouldn't ever request.

--May 24, 2013--
Played it again. Will no longer play it again. The game itself is minimal. You spend the entire game playing cards from your hand in response to randomly selected crisis cards at the end of each turn. You can do almost nothing on your turn except draw your complement of cards. Nothing happens on the board. Why does the board even exist? Make the game simpler and pare it down to the cards and the mind screw. People who like this game seem to really just want the people-playing factor. Get rid of the rest of the crap that make this game take way too long and be way too boring. Aaaahhghgghgghghhh I'm ranting again. Oops.

In summary. Yuck. Yuckyuckyuck.

RATING: 8.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
First played September 16th, 2009. It takes about 20 minutes to teach and setp (if at the same time) and about 2 hours to play for a group of 6 players. This has a lot of luck to it and a bit of strategy. The Humans seem at a disavantage. Everyone choses a character and gets 3 resources based on their character. There are 5 types of resources, however each character is limited to the resource types they can get. A president and admiral are declared based on ranking of characters chosen. Then each player takes a turn gathering 5 resources (based on your character) and takes two actions. Actions can be repair damage, fight Cylons, move ship, put someone in the brig, etc. After actions you draw a senerio card and decided what action to take. Senerios typically have two options and both are usually bad. You can lose fuel, food, moral, colonies. Cylon ships and bases appear. Colony ships or fighters also appear. This is a great game for those of you who like co-op games. I don't like the secret Cylons so much however. I recommend you give it a try if you know someone who has it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Fantastic social deduction game. I've never played a game that was not super tense and nailbiting.

RATING: 8.2
I would probably say that it is decent game which may hit the table about three, maybe four times a year, with the ugliest FFG minis ever (if you live in Poland you might find the Raiders strangely similar to crappy plastic soldiers sold in bags in the 90's) if not for the traitor element which makes the game pretty much in-sane! =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4.5
Jan09: Well, in some ways it's awesome.  The situations are dynamic and the tension is pretty high.  The mechanics match the theme pretty darn well.

But it still takes a long time to play.  A quick loss still took a couple hours, and I just don't see it going a lot quicker.

The rules are a bit of a hurdle to get up and going, however they do make a lot of sense once you play.  I didn't have to look back into the rules too often.

If you're a fan of the show, or a fan of FFG big boxes, I recommend you look into it.

For me, I still actually think I like Lord of the Rings the best of all the coops.  The tension and game length is just right in LotR.

Update: So, I've played BSG twice now. I think I'm pretty much done. In the first game, I won as a Cylon. Why did I win? Because the FTL track got moved back 3 spaces while there were 2 base stars present. Was I responsible for that? Not really.

In the second game I lost as a human. Why did I lose? Because I didn't get somebody out of the brig. Why didn't I? Because it was boomer right after the sleeper phase. I had no information to go on other than a "please let me out". The odds said she was a cylon, so I didn't. Turns out she was a human and we proceeded to fail the next 3 important skill checks because the cylons were running loose. Was that my fault? Not really.

So for me, it's sort of an experience game. I don't really have control over winning or losing. I just go along with it. That's okay for a shorter game, but 3 hours of just sort of going along with what happens is too much for me.

I will say it captures the theme well. There's plenty of distrust and the humans are going to take a beating. However, I already traded off my copy.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
[3-6p,B5][age 10+]
I am a BSG(reimagining) TV fan.
BSG board game has strong theme, but bad game mechanic.
12 months after I first played BSG, 4 games later and after the TV hype wear off... I am so glad that I didn't buy this game.

With 6 players, it seems to take forever between your turns.

Unless you plays the President or Admiralal, you are just waiting to collect your cards, then been told to chip in # of color card that you have in crisis resolution.

If you are new and happen to be Cylon, the other players (human/unrevealed Cylon) cannot help you, So you are going to waste 2~3 hours on a lossing battle.

There are better games (co-op/spy) available.

RATING: 8
Don't let the comments deter you, what most people fail to realise is this is a bluffing game - a talent that most groups clearly lack from the explanations about bored cylons who are discovered early.

Also, ignore anyone who says this is easy and that there is no tension. My games are wrought with tension because once you master the rules the game becomes vastly more difficult because it's the little one line addendum that ramp up the difficulty for the survivors. The action is constant, the tension is high and the length is at the top end but not outrageous.

You must try this.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
OWNED SINCE 2012
This game does a great job creating a "who is the traitor"  environment and involving everyone in the theme. Every one I play with gets excited over the traitors. Besides the traitor mechanics, the game is a solid co-op game. One of my favorites. It is definitely best with a minimum of 4 players. My kids 7 and up enjoy playing this one. Even the smaller kids, who don't fully understand the mechanics, understand the theme and can follow the direction of other players (when they are not the traitor and are on your side) allowing them to be effective team mates. When my kids are traitors, they can effectively sabotage things and then reveal themselves; so they can play this game well regardless of age. I don't think my board game collection would be complete with out it. After playing many other Co-op games, I come to appreciate BSG even more because it does not suffer as much as other Co-op games from one player "leading" and "helping" others during their turn. No one person takes control of everyone else's decision or pressures them to make certain choices. I think this might be form each player's character having its own strengths and abilities, also a lot of a player's options are hidden from other players? Still a great game, even after all these years. My only complaint is that my kids (game group) are no longer interested in the "game" part, they play to be the traitor. If they do not get to be the traitor there attention drops . . .. and the game suffers. So, because of the current game group I have it does not see much play. Also, I have several of the expansions and feel that the base game is best. The expansions are too pricey for what you actually used. You really only need to buy them if your a completest (like I am) or fan of the show. Truth is, the game did not age well. I had great mechanics for its day, but compared to the newer mechanics of games, it feels a bit slow and long.  I would wait for a Second edition to stream line it before buying. Still glad I have my copy.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This is my favorite game.

It’s easy to see similarities to Shadows Over Camelot.  Both allow one action and a progression of evil phase.  In both, a player can (potentially in SOC’s case) be playing against the others as a traitor.  Playing both of them feel completely different.  In Battlestar, knowing that in fact there is (will be) a traitor means you do not want to play a game perfectly for the good side because you could find out mid-game you were the traitor all along.

The tension in Battlestar can really mount as resources fall and do feel like you are making the better of the two equally bad options.  Shadows Over Camelot is an enjoyable game, but I would choose this over SOC every time.
