=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Cooperative game based on the TV series that tries to reproduce the survival of the human race as well as the intrigues surrounding the cylon infiltration in the ship.
The best thing of the game is how thematic it is, it is impossible to play a game without pointing fingers to everybody at some point time shouting "cylon". Exactly as in the series! In addition to that, even with a full crew of humans, the game would be very difficult as you always barely arrive to Kobold. One of the issues, but probably it doesn't have to do with the game, is that the cylon (or cylons) should be players that have played it before, to maximize the impact of their sabotages. A new player may think that the sooner the better, and being caught right at the beginning instead of waiting for the perfect moment. There is another situation that I do not really like and it is why I was thinking of rating the game with a lower number but, as it doesn't have to do with the game, I have put a 7, and it is the "general factor". If there is one player that things that his/her opinion is better than the rest of the players and that the plan has to be doing A, then B, then... you will spend 3 hours just playing the cards that another player is indicating. I would recommend to play this game half-cooperative. We all have to push in the same direction but, please, we are individuals, I am not here to follow orders, that is what I do from Monday to Friday. But that depends on the flexibility of every player. This factor is why I do not play this game, but if your group doesn't have that role, you will have a great time
Positive:
1. How thematic it is
2. Easy to play
3. The game is difficult even without cylons
4. The sleeping agents mechanic is brilliant, even though that simple
5. Can be played with non-gamers
Negative:
1. If there is one "general" type of player, the game can be boring
2. The cylon(s) need to know when to do its move
3. May be too long. Easily it may extend over 3 hours
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Great game, one of the better semi-coops/coops with a traitor out there... Climate of paranoia, suspicions and mutual accusations is a ground on which traitor(s) should thrive...  So many options and so many subtle actions a traitor can excercise...

But you need proper company (preferaby people you know and prone to lively discussions) and MOST importantly - people who play _fast_, because otherwise the game has tendency to drag and drag forever... (unfulfilling experience then).

EDIT: After several plays I have enough.  The base game alone became repetitive and the charm is gone too.

Sold.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Initial rating

I'm more than a little torn on this game. Note I never watched the new series but seen the old one and movie. Note also I very much enjoy Werewolf and hidden role games.  

So I love that they mostly made a "game" around all this hidden role goodness but I did think the game was just too long unfortunately overall for what it offers in total. The game reminded me of Dune actually in some ways especially the epic "feel" of the game and that it is an "experience game". (also its a lengthy game, based on a show and very closely mimics it {so I'm told!} & built around the theme and the in-game rulebook look-up).  Like Dune when I played this I was awfully glad we had an experienced player running it and even he had to look up some rules during play (esp with exp) so it is a little over wrought and that is a detractor along with the length. 

One thing I noticed is it seems there is not that much incentive for a Cylon to stay hidden as they have some better stuff to do once revealed. Of course once revealed that whole tension and accusation part of the game falls flat. I also thought the Cylon choices in general were quite limited overall and if you played cards to hurt the humans due to the colour scheme it could sometimes be narrowed down to only a couple of players who the Cylon is so hard to be productive AND stay hidden. I also seen some pretty non-productive human turns with some decisions being too obvious, I think the expansion does help here but not completely. 

So in one sense I love the game and actually the board is pretty cool because you have a real threat with the Cylon ships attacking and it seems to give you some options to choose from etc (not just a card game with a board because the board does add here) but it seems there are a fair number of rules to keep track of (esp with expansion) and the game does seem too long. If a game could take 2 hours TOPS or under I think it would have been a great hidden role game as the concepts are awesome but running to 3 and more it just feels like it is starting to drag out more and more and just unnecessarily so.  

Note that the expansion adds quite a bit to this BUT I think it also adds more time, see my comments there. This game really would have been much higher rated by many many people and myself if it was just an hour shorter and if there were fewer "non-turns". It actually would have become a favourite for me I think in general if shorter, more streamlined but also a few more options on turns. So close to greatness yet so far too.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
A good cooperative survival game with a bit deduction and "politics" (each players tries to make other players to trust him)
 
Hard to rank as this game is very situationaly.
Note: can be overwhelming to new players. 

Contra:  
- very long
- can have bigger downtime - there are times you cannot do nothing, times when the best play is to "give" your turn to fellow player, etc.
- unbalanced "roles", characters and actions
- very luck dependant (expansions try to fix this)

Pro:
- very thematic
- enough variety to have different experiences (enough roles, cards, etc.)
- very thematic
- with imagination it plays out like a "movie"  
- can raise different emotions during one session (if you get involed enough) 
- sessions can be exciting and provide talk material after it

If you like longer thematic games this is one of the best (I would rate it 9 in that case).

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Lots of fun.  Everyone are humans on the Battlestar Galactica, trying to reach Earth.  But 2-3 are actually Cylons trying to sabotage the rest!  Each turn there is a crisis to be surmounted, provided by a crisis card and usually solved by a simple choice or by playing in colored cards that either add or subtract to a needed total.  But secretly so the Cylons can get insidious.  Every turn lots of options as one can play a card, move to a ship location that provides an action, use a special character power, or fly around and shoot Cylon raiders!  Very challenging even without the Cylon saboteurs.  Lots of wonderful paranoia and fingerpointing if you have players that get into the spirit of it.  A bit long though.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8

RATING: 8.75
"That's exactly what a cylon would say!" -Everyone who has ever played this game.

The most tense, paranoia filled gaming experience I've ever had and I loved every excruciating minute of it. While some friendships may be tried, the atmosphere of this semi co-op/hidden traitor game is unrivaled and easily it's biggest strength.

For fans of the show, it captures all of the tension and impossible decisions that made the show so much fun to watch. For those who haven't/refused to watch, don't let the theme keep you away from a great game.

The mechanics aren't as simple as say The Resistance, with much more to worry about besides just who the traitor is and that can turn people off. In addition, the playing time can get to be a bit much for those who aren't willing to invest a couple hours.

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
With insert from The Broken Token.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
An absolutely fantastic game - one of my all-time favorites.  From a Battlestar Galactica standpoint, this game is dripping with theme.  It immerses you into one of the personas of the show and never falters in thematic gameplay. If you play Starbuck, Baltar, Boomer, or any of your favorite characters, the powers and weaknesses give you the feel of being that person.  The tense game environment of mistrust among each other mixed with the constant struggle for eking out a victory, and simply trying to survive really brings out the perpetual theme from the show, and creates a great game experience.

From a game perspective, Corey Konieczka, famed game designer, has created a well-balanced, punishing, yet rewarding, game.  There are many components that come with the game, so it may appear daunting to newcomers.  After some familiarization with what the different icons or components signify, the game play is fairly simple.  The constant decision-making and balance of threats keeps the player on his or her toes, therefor leaving no down time and zero dull moments.  The game is definitely challenging, and at times crushing (that depends on the Cylon[s]), but it is not impossibly difficult (like Ghost Stories, or Yggdrasil).  In addition, any escape from such situations, or victories, will result in a sense of incredible accomplishment and gratification, which mirrors the feel of the Galactica's sense of accomplishment in the show.

Going back to one of my favorite aspects of the game, there will be a traitor amongst the players.  One of the players will be a Cylon infiltrator and will be working against the Human goals (unless you involve expansions, then there may be various Cylon agendas).  What makes this game mechanic much different than, say, Shadows Over Camelot is that there may not be a Cylon in play the first half of the game, yet suspicions and doubt are still sewn amongst players.  "Why would you do that action instead of this?!"  There is a genius and very thematic "Sleeper Agent Phase" that adds additional "Loyalty" cards midway through the game, which further adds doubt and intrigue.  "Who ruined this skill check with red cards?!  Dave! Dave draws red cards!"

Another great mechanic is the "Destiny Deck" which is a stack of randomly-assorted cards that are added to skill checks.  What this does is it will add possible good or bad cards to a skill check to help hide any possible Cylons, or cause doubt and sew paranoia amongst players, even with no Cylon.

Everything about this game is excellent - the component quality is superb (as is standard with Fantasy Flight), the design and functionality is well-balanced and very tight, the theme is ever-present, it poses a great challenge that feels rewarding if conquered, and if not, it always creates fond memories of spectacular losses and intense game play.

Fans and newcomers alike, I simply cannot recommend this game enough!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This is a great game. It has a great traitor mechanic, and has little downtime. Everybody can be involved during other player's turns.

I'm a little woried about game lenth though, it took us 4 hours, and we were about halfway through.  For sure we are gonna bring the playtime down with experience, but playing under 3 hours seems a little optimistic.

RATING: 6
Well-made experience game. Lots of decisions to be made, lots of potential for paranoia, and lots of excitement thanks to the constant addition of new crises. Theme/mechanics integration is excellent - this really is a game *about* BSG, rather than a game with a BSG theme pasted on.

I have played a couple of games, and like it so far. Both games have been with 6 players, and while that allows group dynamics to flourish, it does mean massive downtime between your turns. On the plus side, one is involved in the game even outside one's turn, but there is no denying that actually getting to *do* something is a rare occurence.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Yet another reason to love FFG.  Based on the popular series, players cooperate to evade the Cylon fleet and reach their destination, Kobol.  However, in each game at least one player will secretly be a Cylon, working against the others to eliminate the humans.  Uses a very clever card-based system to allow the Cylon(s) to hide their true intentions, which causes paranoia and distrust amongst all players.

2011-06-12 

Initial Rating: 10.0 (July 2010)

I love BSG, maybe I´m a little biased here as I´m a big fan of the series too. I think this is an EXTREMELY fun game, it has been a hit every time I have played it. I just love the way the game lets you manipulate other players and the surprise (and hurt) you see in their faces when you reveal yourself as a Cylon. Great GREAT game, I totally recommend it. It has a long play time but I´m ok with it.  

Current Rating: 9.5
[hr]
2013-09-02

I still love BSG, however today I removed it from my top ten of favorite games, it was replaced by Android: Netrunner. I also downgrading its rating so it matches my feelings for the game with the BGG rating system.

Still a great game and a must buy for me.

Current Rating: 8.5
[hr]
2014-09-16

Battlestar Galactica is my favorite hidden roles game (and hidden roles is my favorite game mechanic :D). The Resistance comes close but BSG has an epicness to it unmatched by any other game so far (I haven’t played Dead of Winter).

At first I was wary of playing it as I thought it would be a bad port from the series, but gladly I was wrong. As it has a long playtime, it doesn’t come often at our table, but when it does it is a blast. There are a lot of interesting actions/decisions as a Human or as a Cylon. Perhaps the Cylons players have more fun than the Humans but there is fun for everyone.

I’m worried about possible balance issues. Of all my plays, only once the humans have won, so perhaps the Cylons have the upper hand, however most of my games have been close. I need to play more to see if this is an issue for me. I also dislike the “sympathizer card” so I avoid playing with 6 players. BSG is one of the few games that is best with 5 players. Also it depends a lot on the game group, you need the right crowd to enjoy the game, many friends dislike it so try it before you buy it.

Hugely thematic semi Co-Op game. I love it and I want to play with some expansions. 

Current Rating : 8.5
[hr]
2015-09-15

I played Dead of Winter (a HUGE disappointment) so BSG is still king for me in the hidden roles department.

Current Rating: 8.5
[hr]
2016-12-20

This past year, I have been drifting away from most Ameritrash games. I still love Battlestar Galactica but I prefer to play many Euro Games over it. I won’t ever get rid of the game but getting it to the table is harder these days. My desire to play the game diminished, thus the new rating.

Current Rating: 7.5

One of 2008´s favorites.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
After one play, seems like the best (semi-)cooperative game I've ever played.  3.5 hours flew by in an instant as we got more and more immersed in this fantastic title.  Components are reminiscent of TI:3 and avoid my major quibble with plastic parts in that the plastic pieces are very easy to tell apart.  As for gameplay, there is a lot of tension, especially right after the sleeper agents are assigned.  The characters are specialized, which makes me want to play the game multiple times to try out all characters.  In fact, I want to play again right now.

In my opinion this is better than Shadows over Camelot in all respects except two:  the longer playtime (if not a negative exactly, does make it harder to schedule a game of BSG) and the lost opportunity to make lame Monty Python cracks.

Maybe one in eight games will be a dreadfully boring affair, with either the human or cylon side playing incompetently and the winning team crushing the other.  The other seven games more than make up for it.

Updated 5/09:  20 plays in and I'm still addicted.  If I could give one game an "11" rating this would be it...and that's coming from a heavy economic/Euro/civ gamer.

RATING: 8.5
I gave overall rating 8, but game is easily better than that with good companions, I´d say even 9. Co-op gameplay is fun and challenging, there`s always lots to do and with crisis cards theres nice spacing from still and safe moments to hectic chaos moments where everything goes wrong. Theres also clever traitor mechanism, and over half of the games greatness depends how well the Cylon side players can hide themselves and cause disasters behind the scenes, and manipulate human side players to suspect and blame others. Game is also hard on human side, but thats good imo. Some people find that one game takes too long, but at least there isnt many dull moments.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Similar to Shadows of Camelot, but better.  I used to love SoC, but BSG is simply that much better,  I don't see myself EVER playing SoC again.

Great semi-cooperation game that has a player or two (depending on the # of players) helping the board win.

After 20+ plays, the game GENERALLY is a blast!  The tension created by the players trying to learn who the cylon is great.  Many games maintain this tension until the reveal(s) when it becomes a dogfight between humans and cylons for the win.  These games are amazing and fly by, but..........unfortunately, there are games that lead to an early cylon reveal eliminating the tension.  Then the game turns into a simple exercise of performing your actions.  And because the game generally lasts 3 hours, it drags and drags.

Initially, I rated the game an 8, but now lowered it to 7 because those bad games are frequent enough to make the game hit and miss.

RATING: 10
A must have, especially if you watched the 2004 TV series. At the beginning of the game each player receive a loyalty card, specifying if you're human or Cylon. Nobody knows who's on what side though all pretend to be human and helping Galactica to escape the Cylons. At half time of the game, a new set of loyalty cards is drafted: each player is given a new card and some human will turn into Cylon and change their game behaviour... but not too much or they'll be send to the brig. You must try this game

RATING: 8
This is after one play, so we'll see how my opinion changes... This is a really great, thematic game. Everyone who says it captures the feel of the show is dead on. It's really intense, with some great, tough decisions to be made. =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Game mechanics are clunky but the meta game that takes place makes it a fun event.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
I'm torn on Galactica.  As a pure game, it isn't that great.  Mechanically, there just doesn't seem to be all that much going on.  Because of the way skill checks work, players put in a lot of work resolving even simple issues.  It just feels clunky.  At the same time, sometimes turns and turns go by without any appearance of the Cylon fleet, leaving those who have chosen pilots to circle the Galactica aimlessly.  You almost need to have five people.  Aside from the hated Sympathizer mechanic, there ends up being a lot of down time with six players.

That said, Galactica isn't leaving my collection any time soon.  With the right group of fans, it becomes more of a social experience than a game.  Players quote their favorite lines from the show, and vehemently declare themselves to be human while accusing once-trusted allies of treachery.  It is a lot of fun!  As a pure game, I'm giving BSG a generous six.  Even so, I still enjoy gearing up for a five player game from time to time, and I don't see that changing.

UPDATE:  There have been a lot of advances in the state of the art since BSG was released.  While BSG was an OK system to build on, it's showing its age now, and I got rid of it without remorse.  There are better, quicker, easier co-op/hidden traitor games on the market now.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I am in on this when it hits the table. Hidden traitor is done well here. Really enjoy this one.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A great game that captures the atmosphere and theme of the show perfectly. There's the feeling of desperation and paranoia for the human players, and triumph as they jump closer and closer to escape. I must say I enjoyed playing the cylon more, messing with people's minds and then revealing myself to devastating consequences. Mwahahaha!!

The components and cards are beautifully made and look great, although the skill cards are small and can be a bit fiddly. My only other qualm with the game is that it can tend to go on just that little bit too long. This is a game I'll be happy to play whenever I get the chance.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
Based on 1 play.

This session was with 5 players and clocked in at roughly 4.5 hours. Now I heard that the game plays in 3-4 hours so this this isn't bad with two newbies. The real problem is that there isn't enough game here to justify spending that much time at the table with it. If it played in 60-90 minutes it might be okay.

Turns are straight forward you move and take an action. Yes plenty of games have that mechanic. What I'm looking for in games are interesting decisions to be made an the opportunities for a clever play. Unfortunately, I didn't see that here. Now I must state that I wasn't a Cylon and they have to figure out how to keep conning us. But as a human you are looking out for the best interest of the ship which means doing what's best, yawn. Some cards allow you to pass an action to another player or have crisis resolution played face up or make blue cards positive and if you're the human it is in the groups best interest to do so. 

The crisis cards are what move the game along allowing the Galactica to "jump" and the Cylons to attack. They also have pass/fail items that the group must decide on and then play cards to influence the outcome. It's a nice idea but the outcomes don't leave much to discuss. We never saw a card that as humans you would argue passing vs failing. So if we were okay with a fail we allowed it to happen and if we wanted a pass we played cards. If we wanted to force the pass we played the card that made all offerings to influence face up.

As someone who hasn't seen the show there was no more theme to me than playing checkers. I don't need theme if the game is good but for those of you that do then beware.

As the president I started in a separate ship where I could collect Quorum cards. At the end of 4.5 hours I was still in the same room, yep I never moved. My turns consisted of either drawing cards or allowing someone else to take an action on my turn. 

The game ended with us looking to make our final jump. On a roll of 7 or 8 we win if not we lose. The die came up 4, we lost. Thankfully the game was over. I'm not sure who rejoiced more the Cylons or the humans.

Was that fun you ask. No, no it wasn't fun. 


=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Adaption from a TV show to a board game done right. But even if you haven't watched the show this is a superb game. The struggle for survival and traitor mechanics inject so much tension into this game that it becomes a thrill to play.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
MG
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
BSG is a "team" game. Ostensibly, players play cooperatively to beat the Cylons, but some players are cylons in disguise and try to secretly sabotage the efforts of the humans. The humans win if they meet their goal (Jump a distance of at least 8 units and then jump one last time) and the cylons win if they stop the humans from reaching that goal. There are some interesting mechanics that enable the cylons to work against the humans without making their identities obvious. Good 'ol deception is still a big part of the game, so your behavior at the table is critical, but at least the mechanics won't blow your cover by themselves.

I'm a bigger fan of team/secret identity games than I am of straight co-ops and this is a good one. At the very least, this has to be the best board game based on a television property. Do note, the game takes a long time to teach and a long time to play. It features the usual FFG rules bloat.

Update: Dead of Winter accomplishes a lot of what BSG does and does it more efficiently in a more playable time frame and format. I've downgraded my score of BSG from an 8 to a 7 simply because Dead of Winter highlights just how ridiculous the rules bloat and intricate mechanics truly are on this one. However, to be fair, Dead of Winter probably wouldn't exist if BSG had not preceded it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 5
So after a few plays I think this is a pretty good co-op game. 

PROS: Compared with the LOTR and Shadows, BSG is more thematic, has more tension, is harder to win (if human), and has better catch phrases like "frakin' toaster".

CONS: The game is easily 3 hours and waiting for those crisis cards with the FTL jump symbols feels gamey and annoying. I think a quorum card that allowed you to advance the jump marker at some risk similar to the food and moral cards could easily fix this without making it too easy.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4.2
Great implementation of theme and mechanics, this was apparent even for someone like me who’s never seen the show.  Beautifully produced.  Really feels like an epic adventure, at 3 hours playtime (for 4 of us).  However, it was verging on a little too much downtime, and it dragged at times.  One drawback is that just by sheer luck one (non-cylon) player can be sent to the brig for several turns (as the sympathizer) and also get a lot of sickbay cards.  As a first-time player and being that one unlucky player it got a bit frustrating to get my one special power taken away upon going to the brig, and with all the additional downtime, since each round of turns took so long to get through anyway.
I liked the variety of crisis cards, and the calm peace of empty black space right after jumping away from a cylon attack.

Bottom line is, I play games to have fun, and simulating sitting in a brig, however thematic it might be, is not fun :-)  I get that it's all about social dynamics and the co-op aspect, but I just don't enjoy it.  As co-ops with traitor elements go, I much prefer Shadows Over Camelot.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I've immensely enjoyed the entire series, so I was very curious about this game. I love it! This is my favorite traitor-based cooperative game. The ruleset seems skinny, but allows a lot of freedom for player-interaction. I think it's amazing how the mechanics and card-texts can cause a real sense of paranoia and dread. In some cases the game can last too long. The Resistance is a good replacement for need of a shorter game, but when there's time to build up a story, then BSG is the way to go. Maybe BSG Express can combine the best of both games: a great story in a more playable timespan.

Houserule: remove the value "1" Kobol cards. Decreases downtime and doesn't impact the experience for my and my friends.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
Played our first game last night. 3-player game.  Fantastic!!! Blind accusations and mistrust galore. I played Tom Zarack(?) and fought with Lee Adama all night over the Presidency.  Had him thrown in the brig for taking my 'president' status and giving it to someone else.  He had me put in sick bay.  Got the 'presidency' back and then the Cylons turned up in force.  We all pulled together to fight them off and then it was back to our infighting.  Hilarious stuff!  We all marvelled at how true to the series our game played out. It turned out that no-one was a Cylon till mid-game but we might as well have been.  Probably better with 5 or 6 players.  More mayhem, accusations and suspicion to go round.

Gameboard, photos and playing pieces are excellent quality and very appealing.  We all enjoyed handling the components.  Rules are easy once learned and combat is simple - which is good because when your being swamped with Cylons the game doesn't get bogged down.  We found that we had to 'jump' the more we got swamped as we couldn't fight them all off. Just like the TV series. Great stuff!  Can't wait to play more.

31 May 2009 Update - Have played a total of 4 times now.  The more players the more fun.  A real blast. Our gaming group loves it. There's a bit of something for everyone. Combat, passing Crisis tests, accusing others of being a Cylon.  This would actually play great solitaire too.  You would just play hard when you took a Cylon turn. The Sympathizer card is actually very clever.  It balances the game.  The card comes out mid-game.  If the humans are doing too well the Sympathizer becomes a Cylon and helps the other Cylon/s.  If the Cylons are caning the humans, the Sympathiser simply goes to the brig but remains human.

18th Jan 2010 Update - Still great fun.  Played a four player.  Somehow, the cylon player had myself and another human player convinced each other was a cylon.  We accused each other all game until toward the end when the cylon player revealed himself.  We couldn't believe it! Humans lost...just.

6 Oct 13 Update - Changed rating to a 6. Will play it but it takes so long and the shine has worn off. Not hitting the table because of length of play.  

July 17 - Oh dear. This one had finally died for our group I think. The accusations are still fun but it doesn't kind of matter that players are cylons. They reveal themselves at some point and disappear to the resurrection ships and then play havoc with the humans. But it's the same dance that has occurred every game. I'd rather play Resistance for my hidden spies fix I think. We're also bored with the crisis cards every player turn. You bust a gut to pass with no benefit - just the benefit of not suffering the consequence. It would be better if you were rewarded with finding a water/fuel/food supply or an early jump or something, just not nothing all the time.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I like the theme/concept of this game a lot. The idea that there is a hidden traitor in your midst creates a wonderful gameplay experience. The paranoia in this game is really high and it makes for a very unique cooperative game. I'm not very good at figuring out who the Cylons are, but I always have fune nonetheless. However, there are a couple downsides to note: First, pilots are boring. If I wanted to spend this much time in sickbay, I would eat my mom's cooking. Second, the game is clearly unbalanced. Unless the Toaster is a frakkin' moron, the humans don't stand much of a chance. Their own paranoia often causes them to do more harm to each other than the Cylons. However, I like how this unbalance fits thematically. So say we all!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
My first hidden traitor game and based on the IP that ushered me into the golden age of television. BSG hits the sweet spot of theme and game mechanics that is hard to outmatch. I generally enjoy it with several expansion modules these days but the original game is still the complete package.

There are a couple of small problems with the base game being limited fun things to do for pilots and the boring sympathizer mechanic. The former was to me and my group rectified by the great Cylon Fleet Board from Exodus and the latter by the official "no sympathizer" variant.

RATING: 6
Not having watched the TV show, there's not as much to connect with, but I can see how it would really enhance the game for those that have.

I was pleasantly surprised with the game, as I was not a fan of Shadows Over Camelot.  I think what really sets this game apart is the general sense of paranoia about who may or may not be a cylon.  I'm not that experienced with SoC, but it feels quite different than the speculation about the trader.

My main concern is game length - at 90 minutes I would be happy to play this at about anytime, but over 2 hours is really too much for what will probably become repetitive with more plays.

Update, 3/15: No desire to play, completely replaced by Resistance. This is just too long. If I was a BSG fan, maybe, but as it is, no.

RATING: 6

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Learning Curve: 8/10

Strategic Balance: 2/10

Player Interaction: 8/10

Thematic Direction: 8/10

Replay Addiction: 6/10

Additional Information
Enjoyable game with the right crowd. There needs to be accusations and trickery thrown left and right. Passive players make the game mundane. Actions are simple enough to jump right into the game so it's beginner friendly. 

However, the mechanic relies a bit [b]too much on luck of the draw[/b]. Cylons are crippled if they don't get the right timing of cylon fleets. The main element is that if 1 Cylon player gets all of Cylon cards (Sympathizer + 2 Cylons), the cylons are sure to lose. It takes too long to pass cylon cards to other players and its far too inefficient to play mind games by passing "You are not a cylon" cards to other players. This should be a free action.

Also, the decks are too small (in size and number) which requires constant reshuffling.

If these factors were fixed, I'd have no hesitation to rate this game perfectly. Still, it's amazing that BGG produced [b]a quality release for a very reasonable price[/b].
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This is a great hidden traitor game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
An excellent, extremely tense, easy-to-learn co-op game. It is based on the BSG universe, so players who are more familiar with the universe might enjoy it more.

Gameplay is simple compared to other FFG games. No player aid required. What I like most is how the game manages to create a very intense feel of survival. Players get very involved with solving problems and trying to see the BSG to Kobol.

Its not perfect however. The game takes a bit too long. The loyalty system can be a bit problematic. And the components are a tad too small to be easily moved around.

RATING: 6
A game that integrates its theme very well and seemingly does several things right that Shadows over Camelot did wrong. However, the balancing system has been said to be clunky and in my game it was so: when the third player turned against the humans, none of our plans mattered any more because there was just no way to go on. Sure, the reveal was something of a bang (spending actions and resources to boost the sympathetic Cylon because it seemed like the best way to win, then bam! O, the irony) and the Cylon players rejoiced, but if the game was going to be cut short in that fashion it could have happened a good hour sooner. Apparently works better with five, which would also give each player more screen time.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Excellent game, in my opinion. If you don't like the series, avoid this one. You'll be bored by the repetitive skill checks and rather slow gameplay. And the Cylons have the advantage. :) BUT, if you're a fan of the series, like our group, this is the game to get. The strength of the game is not the game itself, but the meta-game that goes on inside the main game. The suspicions and overall paranoia deliver the MAIN POWER to the gameplay, and make you forget about the downtime, and overall length of the game. Some characters are more useful than others, but I consider that a strength too. Are the humans on equal ground with the toasters in the series? NO... Frakking good... Best co-op so far, for me, that is. ;) UPDATE 29.9.09 The gameplay starts to feel a bit repetitive. Pegasus Expansion to the rescue!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Pretty fun game. I'd suggest playing it with confident players though. What do I mean? Well, gameplay is fast and rather simple on a turn by turn basis, with the complexity coming from player interaction. So people constantly hesitating on their moves or being overwhelmed by other (louder) players really slows it down.

I like some of the expansions. I think... Daybreak added the Treachery deck? Very nice addition.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Well, OK, a few caveats. I have never finished a game. The one time I did play we made it as far as our second loyalty card. But I can kind of see where it was going, and I don't particularly think the game is worth the money you'd spend on it. While some might have fun trying to guess whether there's a Cylon in their midst, the game makes actually being a Cylon so meaningless as to make what could have been the game's best mechanic into an appendage to a passable space game. Some characters are far worse than others (paging Helo to the Galactica... Also, why is he out of the game for the first round? Shouldn't that be, um, Anders?) 

There are also fairly silly strictures on what you can and cannot say at the table. (This is my new pet peeve. You can tell me the rules, but do not tell me how to handle in-game chatter.) Players are encouraged to tout others as "the Cylon," but there's no real in-game reason to bother. 

And then there's the cards you use for skill checks. What, they couldn't come up with more than two card ideas per skill? I found myself discarding certain types of card over and over again because all you really need is one of each type going into each round - you can't use more than one skill card anyway, so having only a few card types per skill is a pretty serious flaw. Also, we always ended up with more skill cards than we needed - they just weren't scarce as they should be.

I dunno... I think this is the most overhyped game I've played recently, and while I'd love to give it another shot, so far it seems DOA.

---------------------

Update: While I still think this game consists of pulling crisis cards and trying to mitigate their effects, which is not very much fun, it's also the kind of game that's probably more fun to lose than to win. After a game that I ruined by undercutting my fellow players on a skill check despite being a human myself, I realized that the atmosphere and paranoia are as essential to gameplay as they are destructive to your actual chances of winning, since the more time you spend ferreting out cylons, the less time you have to do other, more important things. On one hand, I feel like the best strategy is to simply overpower the cylon by spending skill cards freely on skill checks and using every opportunity to get as big a hand of cards as possible (when you're not repairing, piloting, etc.). But on the other hand, that strategy ignores the traitor half of the game, and may be unsustainable when there's more than one cylon. 

I don't really like this as much as my friends do, but it does exert a strange and inexplicable power over me, sort of like the TV series, which I liked for 2 seasons, but spent the rest of the show yelling at the screen. I'll play it again, and have upgraded it to a 6 from a 4.5, but I remain suspicious. I'd like to see what they do with expansions that take the game past season 1. Maybe they can adapt Mammoth Hunters for the final expansion!

---

Update 3:

Have upgraded to an 8. I still think there are serious problems with this game, the foremost being the inertia of the "take a handful of cards, take another card, play the handful... or don't" system. 

That said, there's an undeniably amazing soft game here. The stuff on the board is the tip of the iceberg.

DO NOT play this with people who: are boring, stupid, uptight, easily annoyed, untalkative, unsubtle, bad liars, people who cheat, people who haven't seen the show, or people with no sense of humor; MOST of all, don't play it with people who refuse to follow the rules.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
Was very positively surprised about this game. I only watched the crappy old series as a child and the only thing i remembered about Battlestar Galactica was that it was something about fighting evil robots. 
But the game has some really well thought out mechanics and the theme is very well integrated. While you work together against the evil Cylons you have traitors in your group, and the game does a very good job at creating an atmosphere where you can't trust anyone while you still have to work together to survive. You might even be the traitor yourself but only get to know this later in the game.
Never experienced any other game that manages to create such a dense atmosphere in a very short time.

RATING: 7
1 partida.

Está muy logrado el juego respecto a lo que ocurre en la serie. Se trata de un juego a caballo entre lo colaborativo y los roles ocultos, con sus correspondiente faroleo para tratar de que no descubran a los que les haya tocado ser Cylon (los malos).

Sin duda, lo más divertido es ese suspense de no saber quien es quien y tener qué cosas hacer, con la incógnita de si te van a sabotear las votaciones o no.

En cuanto al desarrollo del juego en sí, llegas a temer por tus recursos y tu nave, cuando ves que rápidamente se pueden llegar a acumular muchas flotas Cylon a tu alrededor, pero consigues hacer "saltar" la nave y, de repente, todo despejado... o no! (igual saltas a otro lugar con más naves).

Me ha gustado más de lo que esperaba, porque era de las primeras veces que jugaba a un juego tan largo y, además, pensaba que sería mucho más complicado. Si te lo explican y tienes a alguien que sabe jugar no es difícil, aunque tiene pinta de ser una dura labor enseñarse a jugar de cero.

No le pongo más nota por la duración de las partidas y porque, por consiguiente, no es un juego que se preste a jugarlo continuamente, ni con toda clase de personas.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Not merely the best semi-cooperative game made yet to date, one of the best games of any type. It is one of a very few games that do a fantastic job of marrying theme to mechanics, yet ensure that a new player need neither know the theme to understand the game, nor make the mechanics so cumbersome that they detract from the thematic enjoyment. Unlike some co-operative games (even others with traitor elements), this one is not a puzzle in which one or two players direct the action for everyone else. All players must genuinely make their own choices, and not every choice will be what the other players want - even those on your own team. 

Box says 2-3 hours and this is just about dead-on accurate (though figure in an extra 1/2 hour if you're teaching new players). Designed for 3-6 players, but best balanced for 5. Still a very good and enjoyable game for 4 or 6. 3 is playable, but it seems like there needs to be some variants or adjustments for 3 players to give it the same tension and fun as with more players. 

Well worth the bucks.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Game play is a little long for my liking.

RATING: 7

It sucks to be the sympathizer (not a real Cylon, after all), so we simply sent the sympathizer to the brig and then let them resume play as a human. It also sucks that the Cylon is only fun before it gets revealed. When the paranoia stops, so does most of the fun. We also tended to find it hard for the humans to win, so we sometimes used the variation that increased their starting resources. Ultimately got rid of it because I felt like there was too much down-time on other players' turns.

RATING: 9
One of the best team-play board game I've played so far. It's not about long-term strategy or character developing. It's more about fast thinking, paranoia and acting skills :)

We've played too much of it in a first month, so little bit a burn out right now. Nevertheless, it's a lot of fun to throw a new people on Battlestar Galactica, and observe how they evolve :)

3-6
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Battlestar Galactica is a partially cooperative board game which follows  very tight narrative and can be extremely immersive. The mechanisms, individually, are not particularly clever nor streamlined, and the game is quite luck driven, but the paranoia that builds during the sessions is brutal. All the game is about telling apart the Cylon from the humans (even if you are Cylon, as you want to know who your partner is to maximize damage).

Most of the game revolves around the action cards: they have a number, which serves to complete (or frustrate) events that will be popping up, and an action, which gives you some sort of bonus. So a key part is handling your actions, as you will want them for both uses, but once a card is played, is gone. Events will be popping up, with players adding action cards face down to try to amass a certain score by adding the values displayed on the cards. The tricky part is that cards are colour coded, and only some colours add to the score: the rest subtract. And if the required score isn't met, something nasty happens, to the amusement of the Cylon players. As two extra are added from a neutral deck, players never really know if who, if anyone, is hijacking.

Aside from the action cards, the players can move around the ship to use the FTL control, fire the cannons or to go to the docking bay, jump into a fighter and take the fight a bit more personally, amongst other things. This helps with immersion greatly and is a key part for surviving (as a human). Also, if you believe that a player is a Cylon you can try to send him to prison, but... Is the accused truly a Cylon and not the accuser who is trying to frame everybody? Almost everything that a player does can have a double meaning, because what might seem a direct threat for one player, other can see it as something less urgent to deal with.

The main problem of this title is that it's quite possible to come to stagnant situations were the game does not progress. Worst cases of this can happen if several characters are in prison or when playing with three or four players. The first usually means the cylons have won, but when a player is in prison no crisis card is drawn. So basically, human players do not do anything meaningful but not enough bad things happen for cylons to end the game soon. The "no crisis card drawn while in prison" rule probably is to balance things out, but I personally prefer a more brutal game than one with deadlock issues. Regarding the four player games, whoever is the cylon is alone, which can easily get boring, as you usually cannot do enough damage to pull a win, but are also annoying enough to slow the human players.

All in all, BSG is a very narrative game based on a very popular license. I must admit that I do not like the TV show, so being an avid fan of it is definitely not mandatory. Having said that, watching at least the pilot episode is recommended to know what is going on.

Rating: :star::star::star::nostar::nostar:
Optimal number of players:
:thumbsup:5
:thumbsdown:3~4

[i]To have more information on how I rate games, [geekurl=/user/Kodeir]go to my profile[/geekurl][/i]

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Very good semi-cooperative deduction game. The paranoia and mistrust, the wild accussations, the incredible difficulty for the humans, the tension ... it feels just like the TV series. Great adaptation to an interesting boardgame and an excellent cooperative game without the domination of a single player as found in most of the other games of this type. The traitor mechanism for the cyclons actually works. *** Four plays: 1x Baltar/human - humans lost, 1x Chief Tyrol/human - humans won (but very close!), 1x Roslin/human - humans lost, 1x Chief Tyrol/cylon - cylons won.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
A perfect translation from the TV series. Skill checks mechanic really makes all players involved & constantly guessing about other players' motive. Crisis deck perfectly simulates the events in the series with all those encounters with cylons or other life threatening incidents across the fleet. This one, for me, is the best coop game ever !

RATING: 6.6
Fun sabotage game, one or more members of your starship crew "COULD BE" an enemy(Cylon).  But know one knows for sure.  
Your ship jumps through hyper space from location to location, as you are trying to get to your home planet.  Your resources are low, and stuff keeps happening to lower it even further, on top of that, someone might be sabotaging it to get it down even more!
Trust no one, and watch everyone closely...
Even worse...  Half way through the game, someone that was a "good guy" could become a saboteur...

This is a great game, but those who don't follow the TV Series it's based on, might not enjoy the game to it's fullest degree

RATING: 4
I really don't get why people like this one.  I assume is Battlestar Galactica fanboyism.  It is a cooperative game where you are secretly in competition with n other players (where n = 0, 1, 2 in the first half, and n = 2 in the second half).  For all that, the game seems utterly dominated by the luck of what space battle (or whatever) comes up.  That said, the folks I was playing with who had watched the show seemed really into it.  So, YMMV. I could be talked into this again, I suppose.

RATING: 8.3
My first game was a bit dull to be honest but the second one, when everyone was already acquinted with the game,  was definitely better. It's like The Resistance mixed with Space Alert (but no real time action). Thematically it is very strong and the gameplay is quite smooth. I think there should be more variety in cards though (can be added with expansions). I would also like there to be more combat with spaceships. In our plays there were only a couple of combat dice rolls because there are so few cylon fleet cards and when you do the FTL jump, the cylon fleet will stay behind. The enjoyment of BSG is probably largely dependent on your gaming group style (I think the game suffers if everyone is very conservative and only tries to keep track of cards rather than play the social game - similarly to The Resistance).

RATING: N/A
Battlestar Galactica: The Board Game is a semi-cooperative game for 3-6 players ages 10 and up that can be played in 2-3 hours. Players choose from pilots, political leaders, military leaders, or engineers to crew Galactica. They are also dealt a loyalty card at the start of the game to determine if they are a human or Cylon along with an assortment of skill cards based on their characters abilities. Players then can move and take actions either on Galactica, on Colonial 1, or in a Viper. They need to collect skill cards, fend off Cylon ships, and keep Galactica and the fleet jumping. Each turn also brings a Crisis Card, various tasks that players must overcome. Players need to play matching skill cards to fend off the problems; skill cards that don't match hinder the players success. Fate could be working against the crew, or there could be a traitorous Cylon! As players get closer and closer towards reaching their Earth, another round of loyalty cards are passed out and more Cylons may turn up. If players can keep their up their food stores, fuel levels, ship morale, and population, and they can keep Galactica in one piece long enough to make it to Earth, the Humans win the game. But if the Cylon players reveal themselves at the right moment and bring down Galactica, the Humans have lost.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
One of [b][i]the[/i][/b] most thematic board games, considering how detailed this game handles and respects the source material of the TV show, but this aspect comes with certain pros and cons (see below).

I am very late to the party when it comes to this board game and the TV show of 2004. The first time I played this game in 2015, I had not watched a single episode of the show, but still immensely enjoyed this game and understood why it is so popular. Coming back to the game after having watched the first two seasons of the show, the experience was obviously even more enjoyable and immersive, as every little thematic detail and game design decision now made perfectly sense.

One thing I never liked about [b]Battlestar Galactica[/b] was the possibility that people can start loyal and become traitors later on during the game by a random card draw. Yes, this is again a very thematic design decision, but it always felt strange to me in terms of gameplay, making the game too random in this very critical aspect of the game. Additionally, paying close attention to what each player does makes less (to almost none) sense because of this delayed possible introduction of an additional traitor.

Another problem people can undeniably have is the game's length. This is one of those games spanning several hours that requires you and your board game group to plan ahead and schedule a certain time frame, depending on the number of players.

This game for sure would have been ranked higher by me (especially back when it came out and was new), but since [b]Dead of Winter[/b] was released in 2014 (which was obviously influenced by [b]Battlestar Galactica[/b], which again was influenced by [b]Shadows over Camelot[/b]), I always prefer bringing the cold zombie apocalypse of [b]Dead of Winter[/b] to the table, as it refined the mechanisms, streamlined the flow, has a shorter playtime and higher replay value, high-quality hand-drawn art and the right amount of humour.

If I wanted to sound harsh here, I could objectively say that the game is in comparison outdated.

[b]Closing words:[/b] The game is absolutely solid and good enough to be very enjoyable for people who never watched the TV show (like myself, see above). Having said that, if you have watched the first few episodes, the game's theme will really unfold for the players and make them realise just how well it is implemented, and I am sure that a lot of ratings and reviews are influenced by this factor of personal relation -- arguably rightfully so.

I would have objectively rated this game an 8/10 (or even subjectively higher as a fan of the TV series now), but since similar and more refined games have been released by now, I have to adjust it to a 7/10, which obviously still is a very high and well-deserved rating for this game. If only all movie-based and TV series-based board games would have this level of quality...
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Very good collaborative game that plays extemely well with the traitor mechanic. The rules are easy and intuitive, harder to explain than to understand after seeing them working. 

If its mark is not higher is because it needs the right group of people to play. I have played with two different groups, and, being a total blast for the first one, it turn out to be a bad experience in the second. More than for the game features, this fact depends of the tastes of every player.

BSG focuses on player interaction, forces players to be suspicious and to discuss every move in a desesperate atempt to catch cylon players (the traitors) before they can harm the human fleet enough to make the whole mission fail.  

To summarise, having a good experience playing BSG is closely related to playing with the appropriate group of people. If your grup doesn't like collaborative games with the traitor element, or simply they dislike having to discuss the moves of every player as the game goes by, you should avoid this game. Otherwise, it is probably the best amongst its kind. I would recomend it with no hesitation.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
I think I would need to play more if I want to know if I really enjoy this game. There are a lot of interesting mechanics to make sure  there can be sabotage and traitors in the crew without anybody knowing. The admiral and president mechanics are nice.

The only problem is that I did not feels like I had a control over the game. I also did not have the feeling of really beign on a space ship fulfilling jobs here and there.

First, there is so few actions you can do in a turn ( 1 action), and there is so many things happening in a complete turn. I would have made sure you could at least perform a location action and a card action. Second, you always have not enough cards in your hand. Since I was the last player, almost the whole first turn I got stock with no cards in my hand.

So I don't feel like I have really the power to help other crew members. Like "OK, we have this crisis, we lack of vipers and there is a base star ahead, what should I do. What are the priorities." There is no dressing a list of priorities and try to solve the problems.

I don't feel also that there is that much negotiation to do. There is a few, but I think there could be more.

So I don't know, I think I would have to play it again.

I played a second game, it could be summarized as thie: Great idea, bad implementation.

I strongly suggest you take a look at BSG Express because their core mechanic is much more better than this game.

RATING: 10

RATING: 4.5
My particular game group loves this game.  We tend to really enjoy co-ops (myself excluded) and many of us are self-identified as "geeky", so the theme is appealing.  Unfortunately I do not love most co-ops and I am not a BSG fan.  However, this is a fun co-op game that involves "dirty" players, which always makes co-ops more fun.  My only complaint about this game is turns can take a long time and, thus, the game plays over a long time.  For me, if a game is long, the turns best be short, or vice versa.

RATING: 8
This is the game I wish The Resistance was a lot of the time. The traitor mechanic is well-executed, and the turns actually flow fairly quickly, though there can be a fair number of them. The only place I get bogged down is when dealing with what the Sympathizer card actually means; its variable meaning depending on the player who gets it has made it confusing every time it's come up, and the fact that the card doesn't make it 100% clear what you're supposed to be doing now has caused more than one player to vapor-lock. Other than that, I highly recommend this to anyone who loves traitor mechanics or semi-cooperative play. (People who are obsessive about BSG canon should steer clear, though; this game does not attempt to be 100% accurate about who is a Cylon.)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
While the cylon having to balance sabotaging everyone's plans while remaining discreet is neat and there's some cool battle mechanisms, the hand management of placing cards to avert crises isn't that thematic to someone not into the Battlestar universe, and once the cylons have revealed themselves their options feel limited.

EDIT: I like the crisis cards more having finally played this game again. While I don't like that the game's length came be extended or shortened significantly based on how many warp symbols show up, The fact that they aren't always Dead of Winter's add cards to a pile but have some e.g. president choice too helps mix them up, and even when they are add cards to the pile the reveal cards that are played, change so that this color now counts etc. possible modifiers mixes things up. Also like that you just draw cards instead of having to spend half your actions searching like in Dead of Winter. 

However I am not a fan of the cylon attacks, as it requires significant amount of time rolling dice to see what gets hit, while not being a particularly unique form of combat. Also I feel knowing what is good to do is more opaque than Dead of Winter, where it is always good to search for items, which I think makes it optimally require all players be on a similar level of play (also if someone gets thrown in the brig).

The cylon mechanism I think works except I don't like how you can turn sides with no prior indication halfway through. Still think your options are a little bit more limited as a cylon.

This game I played took less than 2 hours and at that length it was enjoyable, but if was 3 as seems to be typical it would be too long for what it gives.

RATING: 9
This is hands down, my favorite immersive thematic game. When you're playing BSG, you feel like you're actually a human fighting for your survival or a cylon trying to make them suffer. Everything, from combat to the characters to the crisis, is plucked straight from the show. And you can't just rely on seer views to determine who is evil. You have to fully get into character and assess whether or not the decisions people made were best for the fleet.

Also, I like the Cylon Fleet Board now.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
Wow.  Love it, love it, love it.  First game tonight - a friend's copy.  First round was slow as we worked through the rules (and socialized, some non-hardcore gamers with us).  Game picked up quickly after Turn 1.  Hidden Traitor (or two) is so fun.  Bluffing and card counting for card players.  Much Paranoia for those familiar with the Paranoica RPG.  Dissent and accusations abound.  GREAT fun for a group of poker players.  Many of the same strategies w/bluffing, etc., but implemented in a fun new way.  Everyone who played is stoked for another go!

RATING: 9.5
[microbadge=419][microbadge=5792][microbadge=5389]

Battlestar Galactica is exciting.  Every turn is just another exercise of how much can be risked and who can be trusted, and the first time that more than two bad cards show up in a skill test, you just can't rely on anyone anymore.  (Unless you're the Cylon.  Then you're just a frakking skinjob who needs to save his ass before he's thrown in the Brig...)  Highly thematic and prone to series in-jokes while playing, the game actually works exactly as well with those who have never seen the show.  With fewer players, characters are more pressed to deal with the priority things happening, so some of the game's chrome, like piloting or using the Quorum, don't shine as well, so keep that in mind.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This is a magnificent piece of adaptation. What's most impressive about it is that it finds a way to make almost every significant plot element of the first few seasons of the show, from the food shortages to the vulnerability of raptors, and from Starbuck's bad temper to the President's illness relevant to gameplay. Because of this, even though it's extremely complex and fiddly, it's also remarkably easy to learn if you're already a fan of BG. Its one (very minor) shortcoming is that for the sake of fidelity to the plot, the designer has built it so that single, more or less random events can turn the tide of the game very quickly, in ways that players can't really do anything about. This makes it better suited for people who like their games to tell stories than it is for those who prefer a test of their strategic or tactical wherewithal.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
I am told that my one play so far was an oddity in that nothing happened in the first half of this game.  The human characters went here and there around the ship waiting for enemies to show up, and when some finally did, the ship made a jump before any real harm came to pass.  The 2nd half showed a lot more promise as the tension ratcheted up, and I would definitely give this another try based on that.

RATING: 8.5
Rules Complexity: :star::star::halfstar::nostar::nostar:     
Strategic Depth: :star::star::halfstar::nostar::nostar:    
Luck Factor: :star::star::star::star::nostar:
Negotiation Factor: :star::star::star::star::nostar:   
Amount of Downtime: :nostar::nostar::nostar::nostar::nostar:      
Fiddliness: :star::star::halfstar::nostar::nostar:     
Replayability: :star::star::star::halfstar::nostar:    
Component Quality: :star::star::star::nostar::nostar:     
Player Interaction: :star::star::star::star::star:     
"Take That" Conflict:  :star::star::star::star::star:    
Theme Integration: :star::star::star::star::star:

Playtime:   90 minutes – 3 hours

Hands down the best game released at GenCon and probably the best game released this year.  This game captures the feel of the series like no other game does for it's subject matter.  It feels like your playing thru the episode named "33".  I was lucky enough to be like the 10th person in line to get a copy of this.  

If you only played the demo and didn't get a copy to play a full game then you have not seen even half of the game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
The game is a cooperative game with a traitor.  An event comes up each turn with the players and the players spend cards of various types to address those issues.  There is a usually a success and failure condition on an event.  

I own just the base game and there are some problems with the actions available to the Cylons.  It also really is optimized for 5 players.  4 player or less is too easy for the Cylons and 6 is too easy for the humans.  It can run very long with AP prone players and it will not typically finish in under 3 hours.  

It is a pretty great game is you can find gamers willing to put in the time to play it.  


=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
What a game! Deception, trickery, manipulation and cunning all play their part in this fantastic game. This game really plays out the theme of BSG in an incredibly accurate way. Great components and artwork too. Although it greatly increases the length of the game, it definitely plays better with more as the accusations fly. Try to avoid playing this game with people that get easily distracted or people that are prone to analysis paralysis. The turns are meant to be thick and fast, and if you end up with an AP sufferer on your hands the game can take up to 5 hours which drags.

RATING: 6
Overly complex and elaborate game of social interaction, where one or more players may be spies working against the group. The game's mechanics keep the pace brisk and flowing, and if you are not a spy from the start, you may still become one later in the game.
Cool idea, but, as I said, overly complex. The game is generally very slow to set up and play, but fun once you get confident with it.

RATING: 8
Who is the traitor?
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
$40 at Borders w/o discount.

PROS:
-- Great interaction element
-- This review (http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/413645/a-perspective-from-someone-who-hasnt-seen-a-minute) although I cannot see when it would get played given the "CONS"
-- $24 at Borders w/40% discount applied!!
-- Fantastically recreates the feeling of the show
-- LOTS of tension and suspense as you are constantly analyzing who might be a cylon (see Tom Vasel's review)

CONS:
-- Very Long Game (2-3 hrs and sometimes longer). This is the killer UNLESS playing with people who are committed to a long game (maybe with older kids who have seen the show and WANT the full gaming experience in length and depth)
-- Boring board
-- Requires a high degree of commitment to being secretive about one's role
-- Not worth playing with less than 4 (http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/520506/dont-buy-this-game-if-7-battlestar-galactica)

Positive Review: http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/340367/review-after-three-plays-
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
11/2010 Seems like a good game if you're familiar with the Battlestar Galactica series. If not, you're left with playing the game mechanics.  It's a collaborative game with a (potential) saboteur.  In our 4 player game it was easy to spot the saboteur after a few rounds observation, though not very much to do about it.

3/2012 Was lured into another game and, again, it just doesn't get me. Plain booring, lots of down time with pointing fingers and shouting "cylon".  And once the cylons are revealed there's really not very much to do about it.  Actually, the players havn't realy that much influence on the game at all.  The "Crisis" cards drive the game and you're just tagging along. Rating down 5 -> 3, sorry.

RATING: 10
This is a hugely entertaining game of hidden identities that does a very good job of evoking the theme of the television series, and I've had a lot of fun particularly playing as a cylon. Still talk about some of the moments the game has produced for us *years* after they happened. One of my all-time favourites, though I haven't played it for some time now. I like the fact that the game is usually very difficult but not impossible to win as the humans, because that does a great job of recreating the tense atmosphere of the series on which it is based, and any victory you do manage as the humans is all the more memorable as a result.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
I went to college with Corey Konieczka, the game's designer, so I may be biased, but I think this game is great. However, this is a bit like a role-playing game, in that it requires the players to immerse themselves in the the theme/story of the game. If played as an abstract, without the metagame of guessing the cylon, the game falls utterly flat. Fortunately, for our group, that doesn't happen.

RATING: 9
(Commande avec [url=http://sportscardcorner.com]Rami[/url], 2012-09-07)

BSG is a great thematic cooperative game with hidden identity, suspense, and backstabbing. Players must work together trying to pass critical crisis cards, save skill cards for later use, and try to determine which one of them is a traitor. One of the best TV-show adaptations to game, BSG truly translates all important aspects of the show to the game making it a very enjoyable experience.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Gameplay:
+ simple, but solid mechanics
+ high level of tension and suspicion due to unknown traitors/cylons
+ randomized events
+ apealing mechanics for resource management and FTL jumps
+ very thematic; this game really captures what BSG is all about
+ simple rule variants are offered out of the box to adjust difficulty

- there could have been more choices of actions
- if not using the variants to adjust difficulty, the game favors the cylons; it is hard (but not impossible) for human players to win

Components:
+ very high quality components

- the game uses pictures from the TV-series; I personally would have preferred some nice artwork instead

RATING: 7
One of the best implemented themes in a board game ever. If you've watched the first season of the series, this game feels exactly like that. There is constant pressure of food, water or fuel running out and the baddies are on your tail constantly. Add to that the traitor mechanism and you have a very exciting game.

They did mess up some things about the Cylons, though: apparently the Cylon player should reveal himself immediately to have the best chance of winning. Also, playing a revealed Cylon is very dull.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Bon jeu coopératif, sur le thème de la série.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Battlestar Galactica: The Board Game is an exciting game of mistrust, intrigue, and the struggle for survival. Based on the epic and widely-acclaimed Sci Fi Channel series, Battlestar Galactica: The Board Game puts players in the role of one of ten of their favorite characters from the show. Each playable character has their own abilities and weaknesses, and must all work together in order for humanity to have any hope of survival. However, one or more players in every game secretly side with the Cylons. Players must attempt to expose the traitor while fuel shortages, food contaminations, and political unrest threatens to tear the fleet apart.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Wonderfully rendered background. Not perfectly balanced for "human" players.

RATING: 9.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Købt 2010
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I'm skeptical to franchise-based games, but I've found this one to be fun and, in addition, that the gameplay cleverly evoke the feel of the television series.

The rules are somewhat complex but easy to get into. We were all able to make wellfounded decisions one round into the game, and in that first uninformed round it didn't seem like we could mess up to badly. Two of us had read the rules beforhand, four had not.

For me the collaboration and traitor mechanics work better in this one than in Shadows over Camelot. One of the traitor-players felt, however, that once he was revealed his options were a little less fun.

The time estimates are lies, of course, at least in regard to my friends: Our first game (six players) lasted for five hours, and then I don't count the rules explanation or the lunch break.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Not much into Co-op but his one is just O.K.
RPGers might like it more than a Eurogamer.

IMO, 5P is sweet spot, 6P gets somewhat long.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
One of my favorite games.  The best betrayal game out there in my opinion.  I love the mechanics of the hidden Cylon agent, secretly working against the rest of the crew of the Galatica and "twist" part way through the game where a human player finds out they were a secret Cylon.

The dynamics of trying to figure out who the Cylon and eventual Cylons are, all while trying to ensure the Galactica isn't destroyed and makes it to Earth is just fantastic.  Some of my fondest gaming memories are with this game and either convincing my friends I was on their side, all the while working against them and destroying the Galactica or being a member of the crew, figuring out who the Cyclon was and airlocking them.

The game throws a lot at the crew too, there's a crisis to deal with every round and they are legit crises, not bumps in the road.

It leads to a hectically fun, chaotically social gaming experience.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: N/A
This game was a blast. I immediately wanted to play again. I love the theme, and trying to discover who is the Cylon adds an incredible level of tension and excitement. It was a little difficult to teach from the rulebook (none of had played before).  Also, I think that being a fan of the show adds to the enjoyment. However, it really seems like you need the right group of people. If people aren't getting into the spirit of the game, then it is hard to have an awesome experience.

RATING: 9

Although I don't see myself tiring of the game as long as I enjoy the people I play with (since it's the social aspect that makes the game), it doesn't get played with quite the frequency as before--I think the expansion will breathe a little more novelty into the game.

It's one problem is the running time. Unfortunately (unlike most games), I've found playing time doesn't drop with experience--sure people don't get fouled in mechanics, but debate fills up any time gained.

RATING: 8

Can occasionally drag on at the end, if a clear winner has made him- or herself known.  Also, could afford to be a little shorter.

RATING: 9
What an amazing game ! One of my favorites since 30 years of playing !
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
A truly epic game! For a game that originates from a TV show, this game succeeds amazingly. Each game is tense and exciting, and each game experience is not only unforgettable, but a whole story in itself. Every character has a role to fulfill and does not feel like it's being added without reason. At its core, it is a game of interaction with lots of politics, betraying and surviving in order to achieve the end goal on each side. It does need the right gaming group to get the most fun out of it. But from all the buzz that it garnered since its launch, the game proves that it works for all types of gamers. For fans of the TV show, this is a no-brainer. Just get it and experience all 5 seasons of excitement in a 3-hour game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Painted
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
This game wasn't for us for a lot of reasons. We primarily play two-player games, and this requires three minimum, but doesn't play well at that number. I think it needs a bigger group to shine.

It's too long for what it is. After two hours, the mechanics start to feel repetitive and fiddly, and the game still goes for an hour (or two!) beyond that. (I don't mind long games, but I do mind long, repetitive games.)

Overall, for the people I usually play with, it was going to be impossible for me to convince a big enough group to spend three to four hours playing a game about Battlestar Galactica. Even though I'm a huge fan of the show, that wasn't even enough for me to want to play the game. If I'm going to devote that much time to a game, there are other games I'd rather play.

RATING: 9
A deserved classic. We must have played this game well over a hundred times and never got bored. For a while we played it weekly with some friends. Personally I like it best with exactly five players as it's a straight up three humans vs two hidden cylons split, no faff with other types of character, but the balance created by those extra rules means it's a smashing game no matter what number of players you have. Except three. Three can get... nasty.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This is a fantastic, sumptuous, involved game. It's lengthy without being long, and the way its interlocking mechanics combine to make it feel like the show -- right down to the bizarre situations (Lee, who is the President and the Admiral, gets thrown in the brig as Cylon sympathizer -- totally consistent, and happened in our first game) and the arc the humans follow (limping across the finish line, tossed from crisis to crisis) -- is sublime.

BSG isn't complex, but there is a TON going on at any one time, and a lot to keep track of. The banter around who is or might be a Cylon is delicious, and our first play cemented this one as a solid game.

---

This never hits the table, so it left my collection. Sold.

Box Insert: OK... lets get this, out of the way... so Fanstay Flight... you guys only know how to make one box insert for your full games... and even most expansions. one deep well which doesn't really hold the cards and two flapable wings to hide components isn't exactly a one size fits all solution. Battlestar is one of the most wounded by this. SO MANY PIECES, and nearly no sealable bags to put these components into.
