=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Similar in it's basic idea to a game called Shadows over Camelot, Battlestar Galactica is a game wherein up to six players supposedly work together towards the salvation of the remnants of humanity, all the while knowing that there is at least one traitor amongst them.
The game is heavily themed and will appeal a lot more to fans of the series, but I've found that it still works wonderfully with people who know nothing of the Battlestar Galactica setting.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Played once with six players. This games keeps you on you toes because you never know what is going to happen.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
5 / 5 - Great

Very good game, which I found thoroughly immersive in spite of no being a fan of the TV show. Reading the rules - and the session reports - would seem to indicate this as a largely psychological game, but it isn't. There's a good amount of strategy for both sides to explore as well. So, tense, tactically challenging, highly interactive, very social .. what's not to like? Well, the rather repetitive nature of the skills checks and the fact that the game becomes rather less interesting once the cylons are revealed. The 100% co-op and solo variants from the publisher aren't great - don't buy the game on the strength of these alone.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6
I could see this rating going up with more plays, but my first session wasn't stellar. I was Starbuck and a Cylon from the beginning, but wasn't able to sabotage the humans much because of her limited ability to acquire green/yellow cards. All of the crisis cards for the first half of the game were green/yellow/blue crises, so since I could only draw one of those per turn, I could only plausibly play one card per round of play without giving myself away. I managed to stay out of the brig, revealed myself at the half-way point of the game and danced around the cylon spaces until, with the help of my cylon buddy, the Galactica ran out of fuel. At least for now I think this game would be much more enjoyable as a human because then you feel the tension of not knowing who the cylons are. As a cylon there is no mystery, all you have to do is lay low until the time is right.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
In short, this is a beast. It's really hard to get to the table often and tough to teach new players what to do in their first game, so often the first game has to be carefully planned to avoid ruining the experience. I find Shadows over Camelot to be more forgiving.

With players who all know what they are doing this is a hard game to beat.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
I love the theme and mechanics of this game!  It is so very immersive  and paranoia inducing.  The tension is palpable right from the start as you try to figure out who the traitorous cylon(s) hiding amongst the humans is/are.  Every move every player makes is under heavy scrutiny.  If you're a human you feel like you must defend every decision you make and if you're a cylon you feel like everyone must know.  The game is fantastic in these regards.

Where the game comes off the rails for me is the incredible amount of time it takes to play through.  Games I've played run into the 5 to 6 hour range.  This is almost the length of a workday!  I don't play games to go to work, I play to have fun and move on to the next thing.  So, as much as I love the theme and appreciate the mechanics I can't bear to play this game again. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Do I even have to say anything about this awesome game. You have it all, intrigue, resourse management, team play, every game is different. If you have not purchased this game you should buy it NOW.. Two thumbs-up.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Very long and heavy (always play with short game variant found on variant forums!!! otherwise it's way too heavy - unless uou are able to plan whole Saturday/Sunday around this game, then go wild), but otherwise seems to improve the traitor aspect of Shadows over Camelot. Days of Wonder does great components but so does FFG, and come on, it's BSG. It's so heavy though. For traitor element only, Resistance is the better choice, but Battlestar Galactica is a lot deeper experience (even if you haven't seen the show, if you have it becomes the best tie-in game you've ever seen!) where being a traitor matters more.

2-Player Comment:
*Variant forums has decent 2p variant. But it's really missing the most fun part of the game, so it's mostly good for learning or if you are HUGE BSG fans and can't get more. Don't buy if you want a 2p or 3p game! 4p can be good with cylon leaders but 5 is where it becomes great

Expansions: 
+Battlestar Galactica: Pegasus Expansion
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Interestingly I was not a BG fan until my game group insisted I watch just enough episodes so I would have the background on this game. I watched the first three episodes and then we played. This is now one of my favorite games. It requires team work and sometimes keeping a poker face when you are a cylon and don't want anyone to know. The one drawback to this game is that it takes a lot of time to play. Our group has to be ready for an early start to our game playing when we are planning to play BG.

Variantes à tester : 

Préparer le paquet crises "à la Pandémie". Mettre 2/3 des attaques cylons de côté, mélanger le 1/3 restant avec les crises. Faire des paquets de taille équivalente (autant que d'attaques mises de côté), et mélanger 1 carte attaque dans chaque. Empiler le tout.

Un cylon qui se révèle (et seulement à ce moment là) choisit sa carte super crise parmi 2 piochées au hasard.

Un effet qui dit d'endommager le Galactica ne peut pas cibler le Pegasus. Quand un basestar attaque, il tire 2x. Une fois sur le Galactica puis une fois sur le Pegasus.

RATING: 6
Good: 
Hidden role traitor game in a Battlestar Galactica setting. 

The game uses screen grabs of characters, scenes and objects from the show, which looks good and works really well for the theme. 

Bad: 
This game is way too slow and way too long for my tastes. 

The card-play (main gameplay mechanic) just isn't engaging. 

The difficulty to win/lose is greatly influenced by the luck of the draw. It feels very lame to get a few crappy drafts toward the end of the game and have it suddenly swing to being unrecoverable due to that.

RATING: 8.5
I have played this game a number of times and feel a rating of 8.5 is well deserved. You don't have to be a fan of the TV series to enjoy this game (I've never seen a single episode!) and there is enough in the text and story during game-play to get engrossed in it's world and characters. I enjoy the co-operative nature of play with the other players while you struggle to make decisions to protect your ship and eventually get you home. There is a lot of player interaction (from sniffing out cylon sympathisers, voting on tests and co-ordinating attacks) and intrigue that goes on that is a much as part of the game as the cards and dice-rolling. Definitely give it a try!

RATING: 9
After reading about gameplay, I am dead sure that this will be a nine or even ten in my ratings.
(FFG really should raise Corey K's salary, I think) :)

A first playtest in Essen plus a play later confirms my initial high rating of 9.5 (well, almost).
I have to subtract 0.25 because of the damage table just being in the rules and the texts on the board just being in one direction (why not writing them twice in both directions, why not adding the table twice on the board?). The sympathizer mechanic with 4 or 6 players sometimes may be a bit boring for the sympathizer - another .25 have to go. Still a strong game I want to play again as soon as possible.

Own German copy, previously owned English copy(ies)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Sweet semi-cooperative game, although I've also found it to be punishingly difficult for the humans most of the time. The entire concept works better than I thought it would, and it's ultra faithful to the spirit of the show. Looking for the traitor(s) is exciting and the paranoia that the game creates is very real. There comes a point where you feel you need to rely on your co-players but the reality sets in that you really can't count on them to help you win the game when they start to act suspiciously.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
The one problem I have with this game is that if players don't know in advance about the importance of fuel, that decides the game all by itself, which is annoying. There's basically enough fuel for the humans to EXACTLY finish the game; if the humans pick "lose fuel" on an choose-your-fate event even once, their odds of winning are about one in four. That's just stupid.

The only other issue is that the number of players makes for a dramatically different game. The four-player game (where two people are almost always Cylons) and six-player (where three people are almost always Cylons) is dramatically different from the five (where humans have an advantage in numbers every time).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

I like it, except the cylon mechanic can be extremely frustrating. You can spend half the game unable to do anything if everyone at the table thinks you're a cylon.

RATING: 7.7
Rarely Play
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.4
Our houserules:

Shorter Game Variant:
Sleeper Phase at 2, Final Jump ready at 6. 
(9 Pop, 7 Morale, 7 Food, 7 Fuel)
6 damage to destroy BSG.
Can't lose by running out of raptors

Sympathizer Variant (4 and 6 player games):
Remove sympathizer role;
4 player game: 2 cylons (1 in sleeper phase).
6 player game: 3 cylons (1 or 2 in sleeper phase).
Double the value of the highest matching skill card in each check. 
Last cylon has NO option to reveal.

Revealed Cylon Variant:
No Cylon Reveals before sleeper phase.
When a Cylon reveals, discard to 3 skill cards and take an extra "Not a Cylon Card" loyalty card (to use with the ressurection ship).
Revealed Cylons draw ONE skill card each turn and can not play special abilities from cards or from their character sheet.
A player in a viper or raptor can reveal as a Cylon to attack friendly ships but the Cylon card ability can not be used for the rest of the game. The BSG is considered a basestar if attacked this way. If shot down, you go to the ressurection ship instead of sickbay.

Increased Cylon Attack Variant:
Randomly remove 7 regular skill check cards from the crysis deck for more cylon attacks.

At the final jump phase, spawn the following:
Sector 1: 1 Basestars, 4 raiders
Sector 2: 1 civ ship
Sector 3: 1 civ ship
Sector 4: 2 Heavy Raiders
Sector 5: 1 civ ship
Sector 6: 1 civ ship

FTL Jump Variant: 
For early jumps, the admiral only chooses the top destination card (-1 destination card). He may still jump to a destination from a pilot's reconnaissance mission. 

Damaged FTL drive:
If the FTL drive is damaged, BSG may not jump. If the marker reaches autojump, it remains there but no jump is made.

Scout Card Variant: 
- becomes "recon mission" no need to roll

Raptor variant:  
Any card or action that says "Viper" also refers to a "Raptor".

Raptor Abilities:
Recon Mission (Action - Manned Raptors):
Draw the top destination card and keep in your hand (secretly). When the next jump occurs, a pilot with a destination card can suggest a card to jump to. If the admiral trusts the pilot, the BSG jumps to this destination and the destination card is revealed. After a jump, the recon cards are reshuffled into the deck.

Jamming Signals:
Each friendly raptor gives a defensive reroll for the human side in their sector.

FTL Drives:
Raptors have their own FTL drives and can jump for recon missions and can jump along with the BSG. When the BSG jumps, clear the board but keep the raptors in space.

Combat:
(Defense)
Damaged on 5-7, Destroyed on 8. (same as vipers but vipers are attacked first)
(Offense)
Unmanned: Can not attack
Manned: Hits anything on a 6-8

Additional Houserules:
Civ ships are flipped (public knowledge)
Civ ships with no resources cause BSG to lose -1 morale

Changes to Cylon Locations:
Human Fleet: steal 2 cards instead of 1
Ressurection Ship: Give ONE of your loyalty cards to another player (can't be used during final jump phase - distance 6+).

Notes: 
A damaged basestar can be replaced by a new one if there are no more in the supply.
The skill card discard pile is facedown.
The command location can be used to activate 1 viper/raptor two times.
A pilot in space can be sent to the brig unless they are a revealed Cylon.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
A favorite with our gaming group. While not a huge fan of the expansions, I love the base game simply because it has great mechanics and gameplay. Huge amount of Euro tropes (worker placement, auctioning, etc) but also dice rolling (space combat, weapon firing, FTL use, diplomacy, speech-giving). Add in the hidden traitor elements and to me you have a perfect game. Who cares that it takes two hours?

RATING: 7
A well-designed game with solid mechanics and a few really neat ideas, and everything is excellently melded to the theme. With the right group, the table talk can be really fantastic, and so the game can be a great social experience.

I can't say that it's a [i]great [/i]game. It's longish and getting tossed in the brig is a potential fun-killer. I'm also not a big fan of the television show, and it can get repetitive. The lack of variety in the cards is a sticking point. But it's definitely good to very good and worth replaying several times as different characters.

I've never been a Cylon, so I can't speak to the funishness of that, and I've never played with an expansion. Boomer is the best character to play. Don't argue with me on that one.

RATING: 10
Battlestar has yet to lose any of its luster after quite a few games of playing, and its basic incarnation (without Pegasus) is so well put-together we have friends begging to play at times.  I have never played a game that captures the feel of a TV show (or movie) as well as this one.  Paranoia and conflict abound with punctuated moments of respite fed by a near-constant feeling that you've nearly lost the game.  The traitor mechanic is also very well thought out and adds a ton of replay to this game.  In its basic (non-Pegasus) form it is the absolute best semi-co-op game I've ever played.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5.5
The theme is pulled off extraordinarily well and the designers used the BSG license to it's fullest.  It's Cylons versus humans but the Cylons are initially hidden within the human population.  Table-talk and play that inspires trust but leads to accusation, second-guessing and poor decisions is going to help the Cylons undermine the human efforts from within their ranks. 

The game relies on an engine to help keep the balance between the two sides.  A fluky disaster card-draw or even an early-guessed reveal can throw off this balance.  Like most cooperative games there isn't a lot ONE person can do on their turn.  So you'll need to really help everyone with the decisions presented to them each turn.  This can be frustrating for a revealed Cylon player who at times is going at it alone with not many choices ahead of him.  For me BSG only seems to have about 5 plays in it before it becomes too samey.  Perhaps this can be changed by bringing different personalities to the table.  If you're like me, not much of a table-talker and even less a manipulator you're probably going to be a generally weak player compared to others.

UPDATE: knocked down a half point because it seems to be either too hard or too easy.  Additionally the 3-4 hour play time is 1-2 hours too long for such a repetitive game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This game never plays twice the same way. Players have chances to interact with the game, and each other, outside of their turn. The traitor mechanic really ties it all together.

RATING: 9
likely very group dependant, but i think this is a very well done "co-op" with a traitor(s).  i have not seen an episode of the tv show and had no trouble picking up the gist.  does a stellar job of pacing (sometimes slow, sometimes frantic, sometimes back to slow, and it does reach a crescendo) and creating intrigue (better than Shadows unless you play with the 0-2 traitor variants with 6 or 7 people).  great experience and leads itself to retelling stories of games down the road.

needs at least 4, and shines with 5.  would not ever play with the sympathizer and prefer the official variants.

RATING: 5

Interesting enough twist on the co-op genre, although perhaps too limiting in the actions one can perform within a given role - even though there are a  lot of options, I didn't feel like I had a lot of options. In the right circumstances, I'd play again.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I felt that this game was just a bit too long. Early on things progress along at a reasonable rate but then as the cylons are revealed less crisis cards are drawn and so the movement of things like the jump track slow down. For my view we'd got to the point where the chance of human survival was very low but the final knock-out blow took such long time to be delivered that it just seemed that we were going through the motions. We still weren't certain goners but it did feel that it took too long to find out if we'd pulled one out of the bag or if the cylons would have their way.

However the traitor mechanic does work very well in this game with the paranoia ramping up as players can't work out who the cylon is but suspected various other players. Is the player denying vociferously doing so because they are actually a human or because they are only trying to convince you that they are human? Did that player do that because they really thought it would be the best move or were they hoping that the dice would help the cylon cause?
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 5.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
Draft actions and pass cooperative skill checks to save humanity from the cylons/destroy humanity.

Plays: 1.
Type: Thematic cooperative game – a theme-driven game where you play together against the game.
Complexity: Heavy cooperative game.
# of players: See BGG.
Playing time: See BGG.
Player interaction: Cooperation. Misdirection. Some targeting of other players.
Randomness: High – dice and card draw with high impact and little control.

Replayability: Not so high. It’s a long and very random game. Your actions have little impact. The outcome mostly depends on how many cylons there are and what crisis cards are drawn, which is entirely random. I guess you don’t play this game to win, but to enjoy the ride. Those that enjoy the ride will probably want to play again.
Fun: Not so much. The urgent sense of inevitable doom can be fun. Destroying cylon ships with nukes and in space combat is fun. Figuring out who is a cylon sounds like fun, but this was the biggest let-down for me. The cylons played exactly like humans until they could get a big pay-off from revealing themselves and then did. There was no sense of increasing paranoia, just a “ok, so he’s a cylon”. Meh. 
Memorability: High. This creates a story about humans and cylons. You’re playing your opponents as well as the board, which increases memorability.

Thematic integration: Very good. This is designed theme first. The theme is very cheesy, which I guess can act as a deterrent to trying the game.
Components: Good. A quality game.

Who will like this: Gamers that like the theme and play for the experience more than for the outcome.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Oh, BSG. As a fan of the show, I enjoy you very much. As a guy who wants to play more than one game in an evening, you frustrate me. This remains my favorite hidden traitor game, and with the right group this game is an unforgettable evening. However, it can be overwhelming to non-gamers, and unfortunately it really only takes one player not buying into the game to derail it. Still a favorite, but one I'm becoming more hesitant about. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

You could easily rate this game a 4 if you spend it all in the brig. The game can be a walk in the parc for the humans if no Basestars show up before other launches.

Beginners are definitely at a disadvantage, since you can't ask some questions (for example if a player asks "how do you declare yourself a Cylon" you can guess he is probably a Cylon).

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Can go on a little long but the social interaction is great and it's fun to play a saboteur.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Bought ding n' dent from CSI at Gen Con for $31. Kat bought this, I bought Pegasus.

This game is a blast with a good group of players. Distrust, deception and betrayal are heavy themes in the game. Some metagaming is inevitable with this game, and the worse the group is about metagaming the more the game suffers in my opinion. For example, if you're a cylon you need to be careful about how long you look at your loyalty card and make sure not check it again later, because if you're checking your loyalty card, it obviously says more than "You are not a cylon."

With a good group, it's an enjoyable way to spend 2-3 hours. Playing as a cylon (which I've done in 4 of my first 5 plays) is challenging and enjoyable.

I was already getting diminishing returns from Shadows Over Camelot, and I think BSG has made that game obsolete. In the rare instance that I have the proper players and time, I can't see picking Shadows over BSG.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.8
Love, love, love this game and wish I got to play it more.

RATING: 7
11/7/09: I'm torn.... On the one hand, I love the political interaction of this game.  Just today, the action of checking out a player's loyalty cards (as Baltar), seeing that he's Cylon, and then trying to convince the others --- it's just wonderful.  On the other hand, I've played three times, and each time the humans have lost in a long, drawn out, and seemingly inevitable assault by Cylon forces.  The player interaction is great; the endgame less so.

RATING: 8.5
So much more psychologically intense than Shadows Over Camelot. For some reason I always end up a cylon.

My ONLY concern is that of the five games I have clocked, the humans have NEVER won (possible game balance issues?)

Favorite character to play: Chief Tyrol! (who is also my favorite character on the show.)

Edit: Humans won today, and with me as the Chief! It was excruciatingly close, and the cylon player did the best double-cross backstab I've seen in the game so far. Updated rating of this game to nine. I am at a point now where, if we have exactly five, I almost prefer this to any other game.

This game coined a new phrase in our gaming group: "evilgasm." As in, "Convincing you to executive order me so I could reveal myself as a cylon, blow up half of Galactica, and cause you guys to lose the game just game me a massive evilgasm."

------------

RATING: 9
Excellent game that in truth is held together by it's cylon edge. Highly recommended for 4-5 players. I used this game to convert non gamers who now always want to be invited to games nights. We allow secret messages to be sent (to only 1 person) at the end of each round. It's funny to read them after the game ends and the whole note passing thing adds to the paranoia. Only problem we have with the game is the sleeper agent (2nd cylon). The rules are a bit awkward on this point and it can make the game nigh on impossible for the crew to win. To be fair to it this games not about winning or losing, it's about the great talking point's you will laugh about for a long time afterwards. Great game.

RATING: 8
Based on 3 plays.  So far Cylons have won every game.  It is fairly fun if you are a Cylon, as long as you're not revealed too early.  But otherwise I'm not sure what makes it such a great game.  Nothing incredibly novel about the mechanics.  But overall I've had fun with it.  Most of the tension is around the question of Cylon or not.  It does go a little long, but if it's a tense game you don't mind too much.

After 5 plays.  It's wearing a little thin with me.  The last two times I was a Cylon and we lost, probably because I tried to stay unrevealed too long.  It's just that it's kind of boring if you're a cylon.  It seems you can win too easily just by revealing and playing bad stuff.  But there's almost nothing for you to do between turns.  Lame.  I think it's a much more interesting game if you're a human.  But if you're not then you just have to wait out a longish 3 hour game which means you can't play other games you might have enjoyed more.  The next couple plays will probably keep me interested in a game now and then, or turn me away for good.  If I become a cylon, and can find a more interesting way to play it, or if I become a human and feel like I have a fighting chance.

RATING: 8
Excellent game with shades of Diplomacy-meets-Red November.

The BSG theme is thoroughly integrated throughout, but the game is involving and well-explained enough that players need not have seen the TV series. Players who have, however, will better appreciate some of the flavour text.

The box suggests '3-6 players', but I would not recommend playing with fewer than 4.

RATING: 4
Yet another co-op game with tons of theme but a game mechanism that is either brutally agressive (when Cylon battlestars are present or Cylons have revealed themselves) or plain boring (when none of the above is happening). Tons of possibilities and different cards tend to slow down the game and in the end you wonder if your choices really do influence the outcome.

One positive note on the voting mechanism which is really fun and has a lot of tension but after laying down cards for the X-th time, this also looses its tension.

Fun if you are a fan of Battlestar Galactica, might be fun if you are a co-op fan. Otherwise don't bother.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
Yet another boring co-op. I wanted to like this game, but it suffers from all the same issues as most co-op games. Primarily, playing a co-op board game feels like trying to paint a portrait by committee. Deciding things in a game by group discussion is as boring as sitting through a meeting at work. The decisions are either blatantly obvious, or a crap shoot with regard to outcome. Either way, I don't feel like I have any skin in the game, and I quickly become bored. The traitor mechanic is a nice try, but all it does is turn it into a guessing game, which is just yet another game mechanic that bores me silly. The only time I enjoy guessing and trying to read my opponents is when it's distilled down to a fast-playing filler game like Skull, Liar's Dice, or better yet, Coup. [Update: Reverse that order. Coup sucks. Skull rocks. And Liar's Dice is still the boring middle.] Anything longer than that, and guessing just becomes a tiresome chore. I could easily cut and paste this comment and apply it to several dozen other co-op games with traitor mechanics, but I'm putting this here only because I actually own a copy of BSG.

Update: Sold.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
Battlestar Galactica ist eine einzigartgie Spielerfahrung. Auch wenn die Spieler zusammen arbeiten müssen, herrscht ein ständiges Misstrauen untereinander. Die Thematiken der Serie z.B. die einzelnen Charaktere wurden perfekt in das Brettspiel integriert. Aber selbst wenn man die Vorlage nicht kennt, ist Battlestar Galactica ein unglaublich tolles Spiel. Wie schon gesagt ist es ein Semi-Kooperatives Spiel, denn es kann einen Zylonen in den Reihen der Spieler geben. Anders als in anderen Spielen mit einer "Verräter"-Mechanik, kann der Zylonenspieler manipulieren und sabotieren und trotzdem sehr lange unentdeckt bleiben (zumindest wenn er klug spielt). Dann aber entstehen unglaublich spannende Partien, die im Gedächnis bleiben. Battlestar Galactica muss man gespielt haben!

RATING: 8

RATING: 10
Egy ízig-vérig 'ameri' játék: a sorozat hangulata, eseményei, főbb szereplők és azok jelleme tökéletesen átjön a játékból, a pedig kocka rendkívül fontos eleme a játéknak.
Az első pár játékban csak sodródtunk az eseményekkel, szükséges, hogy alaposan megismerjük a helyszínek akcióit, a szakértelem kártyát akcióit, de ugyanilyen fontos, hogy tudjuk, mit veszthetünk egy-egy ugrásnál az uticél pakli miatt. Ez miatt kell egy kis kitartás, hogy megkapjuk a játéktól a sikerélményt.
A partik általában lassan indulnak be, de kb. a felétől nagyon felpörög a játék, onnantól lesz valódi küzdelem, vádaskodásokkal, stratégiák ki- és átgondolásával.  
Pár játék az alapjátékkal és jöhetnek a kiegek: az Áruláspakli, a meglévő szakértelempaklik kiegészítései, az új kiegészítőtáblák, az új karakterek mind mind - a sorozat tematikáját megtartva - mind-mind hozzátesznek a játékélményhez. Az egyes kiegészítő dobozok a sorozat egyes évadaihoz kapcsolódó lehetőségeket hoznak a játékba,.Mindegyikkel kapunk egy-egy, az adott évadhoz kapcsolódó végjátékot is, kinek melyik tetszik.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
BSG? Stands for Boring, Shallow Game.

Draw some coloured cards, play some coloured cards, sit and watch everyone else do it for 20 minutes whilst blindly hurling accusations of betrayal for every action they make. Repeat. Carry on for 3-4 hours.

I go in really hoping to get to play that amazing "Best Coop game ever" that the 17 pages of 10 raters seem to be playing, but it's just not there.

It's dull, painfully long, repetative and just not very interesting. Without knowledge of the TV show this is just a wishy washy sci-fi non-gamers game. Be warned however that BSG fans will remain completely oblivious to this fact and act like it's the best thing since sliced bread.

RATING: 8
The designer has done a great job of capturing the essence of the re-imagined TV series.

A non-stop onslaught of ill fortune, foreboding and "who did that?" like predicaments that you face alongside your fellow players.  It Provides an interesting juxtaposition whereby the game has you playing a highly immersive co-operative game, while at the same time being unable to fully trust or rely on anybody but yourself...assuming you are playing as a human that is.


=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A great Co-Op game with traitor, this is a long game (2-3 hours) and super complex for beginners. Once you have a grasp of the game mechanics however it's a surprisingly fun game. My only gripe with this game is that it can feel a little dull when you are not being attacked by Cylons. The flip side to this is that its very chaotic for the Humans once the Cylons are ousted and openly attacking you.

RATING: 9
Brilliant capturing of the theme.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Konieczka's best game to date, though that's not saying all that much.  As usual a license game as FFG makes, it feels like a solid, individual design.  Neither WK or SC:tbg felt that way to me.  There's a lot to like, but in my first game the actions felt a tad meaningless.  Great, we've avoided the crisis for the turn, and we are closer to auto-jumping.  Now what?  I admit it's exhilerating to be battling the Cylons and to jump just as they produce more raiders, but very often they were back next turn, just as before.

Regarding the Cylons, our game-long traitor finally managed to search for enough long-distance planets to run us out of fuel.  Pardon me if that sounds like a less than thrilling denoument.  I'm also not a fan of the last half Cylons.  Those players work half the game to make things work right, and then they must start anew sabotaging things.  Feels very gamey to me.  Sadly, we didn't get to see the exposed Cylons in action, nor was anyone put in the brig.

As President, I felt I had far too many things to do (good!) with too few actions in which to do them (bad!).  Also, I made liberal use of leadership actions, which meant that I was forfeiting my own turn to allow another player to make a super-move.  And nothing says fun like not taking a turn!

Like AH, this will be more of an experience than a game, and I want more game.  But I certainly can respect Konieczka for the innovative design and the very particular tone the game evokes.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
The most thematic game I've ever played.  It has its flaws (needs 5 or 6 to play well, 3+ hours to play), but it so wonderfully recreates the sense of paranoia and mistrust from the show.

RATING: 8
I own this and all the expansions. This is a great game of coop with a traitor. It has the feel of the TV series, and yet does not require you to know the TV series to play it. RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
All the games I've played of BSG have been a lot of fun. There's been plenty of tension, paranoia, panic and laughs at the same time. 

Game length is 3+ hours, which flies by for the most part, although the denouement can occasionally feel a bit drawn out and boring for the side that sometimes has no chance of winning. 

The game requires social skills like bluff and accusation. Creating uncertainty and distrust is the Cylon's main job in the early to middle game to ensure that the real humans fail to cooperate effectively. Then, during the 3rd quarter of the game, the Cylon's should start to expose themselves when the humans are running down their capacity to deal with events and BSG has a few holes in it, at which time the Cylons reveal while applying the crippling blow to BSG and/or team members. 

I've heard BSG can die if everyone isn't into using some social skills and playing up people's perceptions.   Fortunately I haven't faced that problem. I think BSG will frustrate most eurogamers or light gamers because of the need to manipulate perceptions, but its huge fun with a crowd of roleplayers, ameritrashers or BSG fans. Just wish I could play it more often!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.6
As a fan of the re-boot TV series I was hoping that this game carried the theme though (having been disappointed by Firefly board game) but this time I was not disappointed! As not only do the characters interact as they did in the series but the suspicion over who is a Cylon adds superb level of tension and mistrust.
A TRULY FANTASTIC GAME!

RATING: 6

So although this game works fine with our game group, I can't see it working to well with casual gamers.  Also takes us a solid 3 hours to play.  Which is an hour longer than I care to play this game.  Once you are revealed as a cylon the game for the cylon gets a bit boring.

Although it may not be the popular consensus, I'd rather play Shadows over Camelot.  Easier rules, quicker play time, and more fun with a theme that has wider appeal to casual gamers IMHO.

RATING: 3
I enjoyed both Avalon and Dead of Winter and want to see how this cooperation with hidden agenda game plays in comparison.

After first play: I'm confused. Why is this so highly rated? Repetitive gameplay where you only play cards of certain colors and numbers and then draw new cards. Dead of Winter's individual objectives offer much more tension and the zombie threat feels more imminent than the cylon ships. Avalon's streamlined voting mechanisms offer faster gameplay and more intense arguing. So why play Battlestar Galactica?

RATING: 10

- Hate the Tv show
- Don't like long games (such as Brass or Power Grid)
- Don't like Co-op games
- Don't like Traitor games (such as Shadows over Cammelot)
You'll hate this game... Other than that you'll most likly LOVE this.
You'll like this game just as mutch as you liked the TV shows, it recreates the state you where in the entire series, don't knowing who's a cylon or who could be trusted to accusate other.
I do have to say that the game takes quite a while, last time I played it it took 4:00 hours, however I only realized that when the game ended, because during the game I was having so much fun (and getting so tense) that didn't mind the game ending 2:00 AM and having to work the next day... (And I would have played it again were it not for a friend who had to woke up 6 AM).

-Reviewed
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
A cooperative game based on the latest Battlestar Galactica TV series, where one is secretly either a human or a cylon. Each turn, a player must deal with a  crisis, simulated by playing cards face  down out of everyone's hands to beat a total. Negative values can also be played. The humans win by jumping Galactica 8 spaces, then one final jump, while the Cylons win by running down one of fuel, moral, population or food. The Cylons also win by having a boarding party advance four spaces on Galactica. 

It's got pretty good theme and a fun experience, but be prepared to spend three hours on it. There's also a good deal of luck involved, when you roll dice during combat. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
hmm ok
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Highly amusing, but somewhat fiddly.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.4
This game, Battlestar Galactica, and Descent would all get .5 to 1 score higher with me if you use clever streamlined mechanics so that a timer for each turn is actually part of the game and at least one person knows the rules so well that he doesn't have to check rulebook ever and other people know the rules at least fairly well on top of that.

Like BSG, Descent, etc. This game doesn't provide a natural incentive to move swiftly and yet, I've discovered that it's MUCH MUCH more fun when it's played quickly since it is an action--real time game simulation after all. I strongly recommend a system using timers where every player has a 1-3 minute timer which doesn't limit their entire turn but how long to take major decisions (they can still execute decisions after timer) this really speeds things up and makes things feel fun, exciting, and tense rather than just stressful, daunting, or overly drawn out. You can impose different reward/punishment incentives with health and ammo in subtle ways from the beginning so that there's incentive to move quickly but your not horribly punished if you occasionally go over.

This game, Battlestar Galactica, and Descent would all get .5 to 1 score higher with me if you use clever streamlined mechanics so that a timer for each turn is actually part of the game and at least one person knows the rules so well that he doesn't have to check rulebook ever and other people know the rules at least fairly well on top of that.

I really feel that if the pace and sense of speed was increased it would make the daunting overwhelming stress that this game has when it stretches to 4 hours turn into pure tense fun excitement played in 3 or less.

RATING: 5.5
Played this once at a meetup. I think I'd like it more if I watched the show and got the references, but alas...

The gameplay was pretty decent. It was neat all the stuff that was happening and the crises were interesting. The traitor aspect was cool, trying to detect the evil guy/s, and I liked how I didn't feel like there was that much downtime with the constant talking and crises.

I guess I didn't like the ship combat as that was a bit confusing (would probably improve on later plays), and I dont know how much I like Co-ops in general as they generally seem to beat down on the players with trouble after trouble. I also think this game was a bit difficult for beginners, though I understood after a bit. This was also a bit longer than I liked. The theme was meh to me as well (not a sci-fi fan and not crazy about space), but overall solid traitor game.

Played again, and it was meh, taking way longer than it should have. Ive also just found traitor based co ops like this and DoW and even SoC to an extent to be flawed. The balance is off, downtime is high in these games, and the arguments and suspicions arent enjoyable for me.

Plays: 2

RATING: 9
I like traitorous cooperative games.  They're not truly cooperative.  More like ferreting out the bad guy.  I love these element almost as much as I love being the traitor.  BSG offers this up.  The game is very long; however, this can be mitigated by players planning ahead so that they know what they will be doing when it is their turn.  If they don't, then the game may very well drag.  Plan some time for this game.  It's fun.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.3
One of my absolute favorite hidden-loyalty games. It's a coop game, honest! 40% of the group isn't trying to sabotage everyone, really! Has many ways to lose the game, which provides the saboteurs with multiple avenues of attack.

Expansions provide multiple new optional rules and play modes that completely change the game for increased replayability.

The game has some clear downsides though. It takes a long time to play, and it's fairly complex. It takes a while to explain and has the issue of having to explain both sides to new players well enough that they don't have questions that will reveal their loyalty. The game often feels unbalanced, though sometimes it's one way and sometimes it's the other.

And lastly, with extremely competitive, aggressive, and hostile gamers, the game is an abysmal and stressful mess. But, that's a social problem and not a problem with the game. It just suffers from players like that far moreso than other games, so I have to be careful whom I play with at conventions and game nights. Just, be aware that the game includes stressful and accusational situations as part of the gameplay already, so don't play it with people who create those situations in other social manipulation games like Settlers of Catan or Bonanza.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Even though I have never seen the show, I've enjoyed the many plays of this we've had. The game system is a little fiddly, but once you have someone in the group that knows it well, the speed of play increases greatly. The expansion is great to have, but not necessary.

everything you do,everything that happens is supposed to be this way (I can only imagine).

RATING: 7.5

I've played a 4p and a 6p, both have been enjoyable, especially the latter one.  However, there's many little rules you want to keep track of and please, don't make a mistake handling the loyalty cards, they ARE the core of the game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Battlestar Galactica is semi-cooperative, difficult to win, but functionally easy to play. The complexity of the game is in deciding which is the most pressing crisis that you need to address, oh, and discovering which of your fellow players is an enemy in disguise.

But... if you were not a fan of the TV show the characters and crises will have no emotional/nostalgic connection. The limited number of actions that each turn consists of (draw cards, move, do 1 thing) isn't very engaging. Yes, players do get a hand of cards, but there is very little variation in those cards, which leaves every player feeling like they are completely interchangeable and are all doing the same thing.

The cards in the Skills decks are too small. Granted, the decks are smallish stacks and table space is at a premium with this game, but the discard value of the cards is so important, it would have been nice if they had been easier to read.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Patryk
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Previous copy posted to Hammond with Pegasus expansion, new one secured!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Epic game where players are formed into two groups, cylons & humans, secretly dealt out at the beginning and mid-point of the game.  There is a chance that you become cylon mid-point through the game because of this mechanic.

While the humans are trying to pilot their ship back to earth the cylons are trying to stop them.  The trick here is they have to try and stop them without giving away the fact that they are a cylon or else you will be brigged and proven ineffective for awhile.  Secrets, intrigue, subterfuge, compiled with co-operation makes this game very fun and epic, every game you play.  

Out of all of the different games I have played, it's this one that you can always look back on and remember details of every game you played.  You can do this due to the secrets, manipulation, arguments, and sometimes cooperation, that all form to make this game the truly epic experience it is.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4.5
I'm a fan of the show, so I dig the theme, and the theme's integrated well. I'm usually not a fan of space combat, but despite the title, there's not very much of it, and/or it's resolved so quickly that it seems like a trivial part of the game. But, it's not that much fun. There's not much you do in each turn. And, if you get a string of crisis cards that don't advance the FTL counter, humans aren't going to win. So much seems to hinge on which crisis cards are drawn that the game ends up becoming a game of chance with odds favoring Cylons. Also, to have half the group in a 6er be traitors seems way unbalanced. I've heard that humans seldom win this game, and in our game turns out they really didn't have a shot. The theme helps the game out a lot, but I don't find it particularly to be a game of skill; for me it gets some points for being a social game but loses more for not amounting to much: not much of significance you can do on your turn, just waiting to see which crisis card is chosen and if it features raider combat/FTL jump. I'd probably play again based on the theme, but this is severely overranked at #22 overall in board games.
---
3 years on, gave it another shot, it still sucks
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Wow, the Ameritrash co-op game we've been waiting for.  And boy, does FFG mesh the theme with the mechanics here.  Most games I've played have been very even, nail-biting affairs.  Great for huge groups who aren't burnt out by co-op games.  This should be a side-by-side comparison with Android and a lesson in how theme can be integrated into a game without breaking it.

People who complain about the constant repetition of core game mechanics, in my opinion, are missing the real fun.  It's the same mechanics over and over, sure, but like poker the mechanics aren't the game -- the people are the game, because the game is won or lost by the human's ability to ferret out the toasters.  Humanity is a much more interesting game platform than efficiency engines.  This game keeps getting better with age, even with the same group of people; it forces the wily to play wilier, it forces humanity to get more clever, it forces everyone to step up their respective games.  And isn't that what you look for when you play?  Yes.  Yes, it is.  I am sad that I can only give this game a 10.

That being said, if your first move is throwing someone out the airlock, the problem isn't that the game is broken.  The problem is you.

2017 UPDATE: I don't play BSG as much as I used to.  But every game I play, I love.

RATING: 9.5
Fantastic semi-co-operative game which produces more war stories than any other three games put together. At its best when paranoia and mistrust is ramped up!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
I think the secret alliance cards really work. Since you only know that there will be a certain number of Cylons out during the game, you are never sure when they appear. I also like the secret voting on all of the checks, that way people can sabotage without revealing themselves. The different strengths are also good, since different players can affect different win conditions. A better co-op game than any I have so far played.

The more I play, the more I feel that sometimes the win comes down to a die roll. I understand that alot leads up to that point, but it still feels anticlimactic. This is more prominent in a game with all revealed Cylons, once everyone is known, the game becomes much more manageable for both sides. Luck plays a much larger role at that point.

After further plays, I've come to the conclusion that the game is only enjoyable if I'm a cylon. Otherwise, what you have to do is pretty much scripted. That just makes for a long boring game. At least with LotR I can choose to be Sauron.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
First impression (4 players): A cooperation game with Battlestar Galactiga theme. The game mechanics borrow from Shadows of the Camelot and Lord of the Rings cooperation games but the combination feels fresh. There is Cylon(s) on board and the good guys must be able to make enough hyperjumps to get Kobol.

There were couple issues in the game. First of all it seems that after hyperjump sometimes there might long time without any Cylon space activity. This way it feels a bit too easy. On the other hand with four players there might be balancing issues with the Cylon sympathizer. If he is a Cylon then it's 2 vs. 2 and Cylons have almost guaranteed victory. If not then 3 vs 1 is quite sure loss for Cylons. Because of this it might be that game is really interesting only with 5 players. But it felt good and I'm eager to try it again before final judgment.

The second session had an uninteresting beginning, was utterly hilarious around the two-hour mark, and then started to drag towards the end. I'd say you need one or two playings for all players before the game really starts getting interesting.

RATING: 7.5
Non amo i cooperativi ma tra quelli che ho provato (Pandemic, Shadows over Camelot, Panic Station, Alcatraz...) Battlestar Galattica è a mio avviso il migliore. Anche se più articolato e avvincente ricorda The Resistance e Lupus in Tabula, anche qui infatti ci troviamo di fronte a due fazioni (umani e cylon) con ruoli non rivelati ad inizio partita. Il gioco rende con almeno 5 giocatori. Specifico che i frequenti lanci dei dadi (più che la pesca delle carte) rendono le partite molto influenzabili dal caso, ma il tutto non stona visto che il gioco più che sul lato strategico si basa su una costante valutazione del rischio, con frequenti possibilità di migliorare il lancio dei dadi con carte speciali. Penso che con giocatori inesperti i Cylon siano lievemente favoriti. Ricordo che la prima partita che ho disputato si è conclusa con un tiro di dado: da 1 a 4 avrebbe vinto uno schieramento e da 5 a 8 l'altro. Questo mi conferma la forte incidenza dalla fortuna (risolvere 3 ore di partita con un lancio di dadi potrebbe far inca**are) ma anche il fatto che tutto sommato il gioco è ben bilanciato. Trovo la durata delle partite (specie con qualche giocatore inesperto) un po' troppo lunga. L'edizione EG della versione italiana, secondo me fondamentale per chi non padroneggia l'inglese, ha diversi errori di traduzione sia sul tabellone che sulle carte. Dopo ogni partita mi viene voglia di vedere la Serie TV. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
I don't ever underestimate games with overchrome - and BSG has a HELLUVA lot of overchrome. Even to someone, like me, who has never seen a minute of the series, it is completely immersive and engaging. A proper Geekfest for the addict, I'm sure.

But the game underneath? Little more than a weakened version of Shadows Over Camelot. There's no real way of actively counterpointing a Cylon - the day that a game like this finds a mechanic that will let you do this without revealing your allegiance will be significant. And no real hand-management, as your card turnover is way too quick and driven by others.

RATING: 8
Rated after 2 solo plays. Even without the intrigue I'm told about in the multiplayer, the solo game is a brilliant abstraction of the show's dynamic, pacing, and tension. Played multi now. It is better multi, but a bit longer than solo. I do recommend this for both modes of play. Playing a Cylon well is hard.

RATING: 10
Comment after over 50 plays.
The game has original mechanics and a very strong setting. It is half RPG and half party game (Junta-style) and it requires that players enter the setting's idea and know it a little bit.
It is pleasant and playing with experienced players makes the game long but very interesting. Every game is different!
Even though sometimes there are periods of time without any cylon ship on the board, the presence of cylons players still makes the game go on.

Its only problem are unexperienced players, which can be fooled too easily.

RATING: 10
I love this game! Though, it does have some weak spots: small variety of skill cards; the sympathizer doesn't work for our group, pilots are weaker than leaders.

UPDATE 01/2011
I finally realize that this game fulfills the role that 'Catan: Cities and Knights' occupied in the late 90's/early 2000's : A game everybody is always willing to play, a game full of excitement, interaction and a narrative theme. I have played this more often than any other "big" game within the last 2 years. 

So, I suppose is's a 10, right? 

RECOMMENDED TWEAKS: Sharon is put into sick bay, not the brig. Don't use the sympathiser, but an additional cylon card and add resources (alternatively; add a human card and reduce resources).

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I have a beat up copy that I'm willing to trade, and would like to trade for a new or almost new copy. 

I've played this over 30 times now (Jan 2010). Update: 145 plays (Sep 2013).

BSG can run long sometimes (3.5 hours), but is usually 2 - 2.5 hours (2hr 15 is typical). It's not too complicated or too simple for it's length. I don't normally like random dice and event cards in my games, but for some reason it doesn't bother me here.

This is a great game partly because it is so different to most other games*, but also because it is well designed. Innovative mechanics include the skill checks (inc. the destiny deck), the sleeper phase, the cylon ship activation symbols, the crisis cards that give one player a choice between A.) discarding personal cards (hidden info, these are a resource only to that player - but they could be cashed in to either help the humans OR sabotage the humans) or B.) losing a (collective) resource such as food.


* The only similar games I know of are Shadows of Camelot (not as good), Werewolf and Saboteur (good for what they are, but at 20-30 mins too short and simple for a full game session). 

It is quite hard for the humans to win, but that's not a bad thing. I think playing as a Cylon is more fun - but only slightly. 

I think there's a nice progression of tension on most jump cycles.

Usually by the time you jump some Cylon ships have shown up and are threatening civilian ships or to board Galactica. Sometimes you get a breather, when you can focus on other important actions like fixing vipers, quoruming, etc. Other times things spiral out of control, with the tension rising to a crescendo as someone hits the FTL button to jump ASAP.

By the time you have an idea of who the Cylons are (if any), another batch of loyalty cards comes out. Also as resources dwindle the tension mounts, as each skill check becomes more and more important, and resources are stretched thinner by the Cylons.

A great game. And I watched the TV show because of it, not the other way around. It's great TV too (or at least the first 2 seasons are - start with the Miniseries http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battlestar_Galactica_%28TV_miniseries%29).

Bought Dec 2008

RATING: 6
The best part of BSG is talking about playing BSG...then you're five hours into the game and all of that joy is gone, stolen by this game. People who love this game really, REALLY love it. Someone sold it to me as Resistance with action spaces and I was happy to go along with that comparison. But then I realize that a whole game of Avalon can only take up to thirty minutes and BSG is minimum of four hours. I wouldn't be complaining of the run time if it was worth it but I believe BSG is overcomplicated for what it wants to accomplish. Thankfully, there is a faster version of this that still feels like BSG. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I may not be the stingiest reviewer, but I try to be so with my 10 ratings. The original, unexpanded version of BSG is beautifully designed and evocative of the one-of-a-kind tv series (the reboot). I cannot think of a better match of theme and mechanics in my experience gaming with titles based on existing genre properties. This has seen countless plays at our table. Putting aside my love of the BSG-reboot universe, it's a game that works well even for non-fans who could care less about BSG. It perfectly captures the paranoia of a cooperative game with at least one traitor in the midst (who may not even know he or she is such early on). A classic.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
A really great game. Always in demand in the group. The game system ensures a tight finish most of the time and strong replayability.

We tend to play games 6-8 handed (with extra loyalty cards). Lots of fun.

Despite the discussion from some on BGG regarding bias towards on side or the other we have pretty well maintained a 50/50 split of wins between humans and cylons right from our initial games and still sustained that with more than 20 games played.

update March 2010 - still hitting the tables regularly. Lots of interests from our regulars and part timers. Fun, popular and strong replayability.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
One plays this for the theme and to enjoy the meta-game (ie gaming the other players). There's enough mechanism to provide interest if you do, but not enough for 3 hours if you don't. I've got a lot of value out of this, enjoying each ride that it's taken me on. The story builds nicely, everyone starting as a human, but anyone could be cylon, and accusation builds on accusation, based on alleged incompetence in options chosen and who has secretly played dud cards into skill checks that should have reached the safe tally otherwise. Drama builds as players get chucked into the Brig, but was it erroneously, and should cards be spent to retrieve them so they can assist against the Cylons. Or are they Cylon? Eventually the Cylons feel they can do more damage revealed, and they then concentrate on pounding the Galactica with raiders, centurions, and so on, forcing the humans into a running fight to limit the damage before enough jump cycles have completed to win the game. Always fun and there's a story to tell afterwards.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Clever game.

RATING: 9
Great Game! Actually, the play length (3-4 hours) can be a little too long but I've really enjoyed this game every time I've played it. The 'hidden traitor' mechanic is where Battlestar Galactica shines. It really captures the essence of the source material in a way that no other board game has been able to do. Without the traitor, it's probably an average game but the suspicion and accusations and second-guessing really make this a tense ride.

RATING: 6
"I have only played the official pure co-op variant, with 2 players. It works fine, but it was obvious that we were leaving out a significant part of the game, and it runs long. As a pure co-op I rate it a 6. As a traitor game I would rate it a 2, since the length would amplify my dislike of traitor games."

What I like:
- Nice theme, and decent components
- Multi-use cards are always fun
- Some interesting decisions

What I don't like:
- I don't like traitors, but the game is bland as a pure co-op
- It felt about twice as long as necessary (at 2.5 to 4 hours)
- There are so many "least evil" choices

I would put the weight around 2.8 as a pure co-op. I can imagine it would be deeper with traitors, which might explain the higher BGG-voted weight.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
5-6 Players

Have the Exodus expansion



*****Shorter Game Variant*****

No distance, just have to complete 3 jumps to win.

Starting resources 6/5/6/7
Begin with 6 vipers and 3 raptors.

4 or 6 players, use the Personal Goal Cards. Play with 1 or 2 cylon cards, depending on whether there are 4 or 6 players. However, everyone will draw an additional card during the sleeper phase (Plan the deck size to accomodate this). This means that the humans will have a lot more Personal Goal cards, to balance the fact that they get an extra player on their team.

When you jump...
1 distance: ships are not removed from the board, advance pursuit track by 1 space
2 distance: play as normal
3 distance: admiral adds 1 to any resource, and jump track advances one extra space

Take out Legendary Discovery Card

After the first jump, deal out the sleeper cards and send Boomer to the brig.

After choosing a destination on the third jump, the humans win unless the destination reduced a resource to 0.

Whenever a cylon reveals before the second jump, he immediately passes his other loyalty cards to another player.

Five damage tokens are required to destroy Galactica.
The board party track is shortened by one space.



Cylon Fleet Board

-Cylon symbols add ships to the fleet board, even if the appropriate ship type is already on the main board. However, the pursuit track only advances if there is no appropriate ship on the main board.
-When a basestar symbol is drawn and both basestars are on the fleet board, remove all basestar damage tokens.
-When a 1 distance is resolved, keep all cylon ships on the main board and advance the pursuit track by one space.
-base stars cannot both be in the same space. Reroll.

Conflicted Loyalties:
-If there is a cylon card in the loyalty deck at the end of the game, reduce all resources by one.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.8
I think the rules on this one can be a bit fiddly at times - it takes a while to get clarification in the manual. The game also depends a lot on who gets the Cylon card. First of all, they need to have some idea as to what they are going to do, and they need quite a bit of game knowledge to be really effective. Then, they need to be a good bluffer. But it always gets an emotional response and leaves us with a story to tell :)

The big downer for me is that sometimes it it your turn but there is nothing that you really want to do. Compare that to Dead of Winter where there are too many cool things to do!

RATING: 9.5
The mechanic of having possible dormant Cylon's present is very well done and adds confusion to the game (in a good way). At first, the Cylon players must keep secret, which makes it hard to effect the gameplay, but the game is long enough and the mechanics are so that subtle sabotages are possible while still being hidden and then in the second half, more obvious and even open attacks are possible. The destiny deck (where two random cards are added to the skill check) make this game work so well and all the mechanics fit well, while still giving the feel of the show. I must for any gamer who likes discussion, secrecy and fun!

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
Il gioco ha l'eccellenza grafica della Fantasy Flight Games e il mio personale appoggio di fan della serie. Ed è per questo che la delusione è più alta. 
Il tabellone, gli indicatori con le risorse, i modellini di Viper, di Raptor e di caccia Cylon servono a riempire una scatola che fa da accompagnamento a un interminabile e pallosissimo gioco di carte.
Già, le carte. Dimenticabile fuffa con citazioni dalla serie, dove quel che conta è il colore e il numero scritto sopra. Alla faccia del detto "i giochi tedeschi sono astratti con uno spruzzo di tema sopra". Vale lo stesso discorso di quel capolavoro di Marvel Heroes: non bastano i cartoncini con le astronavi aerografate sopra per rendere un gioco "calato nell'ambientazione".
Aggiungi personaggi sbilanciati tra di loro, il traditore Cylon che non si capisce bene se fa più danni rivelato o infiltrato, una piattezza di gioco che si ripete, senza un sussulto, turno dopo turno per ore. Le meccaniche si risolvono in 1) "Estrarre la carta Crisi" e 2) "Giocare carte Skill". Da questo sforzo creativo mi aspettavo (e probabilmente avrei più apprezzato) un gioco di carte da mezz'ora.
Le restanti quaranta pagine di manuale - immancabile la sua presenza quando si gioca, impossibile farlo senza - sono un inutile esercizio di gratuita complessità, che serve a mascherare quella che forse era l'idea di base: una specie di briscola con le astronavi.
La montagna ha partorito un topolino: gioco pessimo che non merita lo spazio che occupa nello scaffale.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Johns
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Battlestar Galactica is a hidden team game--players get role cards telling them whether they're human or cylon.  The players then work "together" to overcome a number of challenges, which the cylon players can try to sabotage--but they risk revealing their identity if the humans can logic out who did it.  Additionally, a second round of role cards is passed out at mid-game, so players that thought they were on the human team might actually be on the cylon team.  The game, unfortunately, invokes one of my least favorite mechanics--arguing.  Additionally, the game isn't particularly well-balanced--the cylon team is far more likely to win, even if they don't do anything particularly nasty.

(5+ plays)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This game is a mixed bag of fun for me. There are times when it's absolutely brilliant and I feel like everything is moving along at a good pace, the cylons are giving it their all and the humans are pushing the jumps. Other times, you can get brigged and just want the game to be fucking over. You sit there and literally do nothing. I'm also not a fan of the pilot role. There never seems to be anything to do or if there is, but your attention is needed elsewhere, you get labeled a cylon for something that is just as critical. Ugh.

This game was overplayed for me, but if I get it to the table once every 3-6 months, I'm more than happy to play it again. At one point, it's literally all our group wanted to play and I grew very tired of it. It's also a lot more fun if you can actually read the cards flavor text.

I'm also undecided on how I feel about the expansions. I like bits and pieces from them, but when it comes down to it, I think I just like the base game best. Everything else just seems to add unnecessary complexity to a game that at it's core, is pretty simple and should probably stay that way. The pegasus board needs a house rule to fix it from being a damage sponge and the fleet board feels far too gamey. I like the extra action cards, but once you start to add in the brown treachery cards, it's just too much. Not to mention New Caprica and the other mini game they added in those expansions. Blech.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8

Multiple special abilities and drawbacks for each character, space combat, boarders, random event draws, etc. It all just gets in the way a little too often. Plus, Cylons revealing themselves takes all of the tension out of the game, yet is a very tempting move because you become very powerful and untouchable. Needs more focus.

Edit,April 2014: this game gets more fun every time I play it.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
An exceptional semi-cooperative thematic experience. It helps to have seen the series, but it isn't necessary. Half the people I've played with have never seen the show and still end up enjoying the game. 

The game isn't very complex, but it can be hard for new players to play Cylons effectively. So it's good to have some player reference printed out. 

The tension, stress, paranoia and agonizing decisions, combined with the meta-game of the Cylon traitors, makes for an awesome gaming experience like nothing else I've played.

The exodus expansion pushed this to a 10 for me. I don't think I'll be playing without it anytime soon. 

Also remember it's important to always call all the other players "Frakin Cylon toasters".

edit: I regret selling this. Also need to check out Dead of Winter to see how it compares.

edit: Sad that the license has been lost for this game. I was hoping to pick it up again now that I have a gaming group that I can count on to play it. This is still one of my top 10 games after all this time despite some of its weaknesses. Still need to see if Dead of Winter can replace this for me. (however I like this game more thematically. Dead of Winter zombie theme is less appealing.)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I bought this game immediately after reading the rules. The games with a decent politics aspect are few. I knew nothing about the series, which was shame since the knowledge just enhances the experience.
Anyway, the game is great even without knowing anything about the series. The problem is that if you are interested in the show, some potential spoilers are included (wish I'd knew this...).

The game is at its best with 5 people. With 3 it's just a stripped game with only mechanics left (good for studying the rules), with 4 and 6 there is a sympathiser-problem (unbalanced imho). With 5 players there are two cylons and three humans. Perfect.

The board itself is big enough and clear. There is plenty of room in the space but still it may all be in use at some point! Resource disks are a bit lame, but do their job fine. The plastic miniatures are just embarrassingly bad quality but this doesn't bother me since the game was cheap. I've used to those small skill cards so they don't bother me either. The problem with the skill cards is that they lack the variety. There are only two types of skills in every pile. Bleh. Well, waiting for an expansion.

It is clear that this game needs a proper group to be fun. Dare to go politic, unreliable, hysteric and finally, dare to betray everyone!

RATING: 6.5
Fun Factor: 4 (I have fun, but I also seem to get very emotionally bent out of shape... unfortunately this usually collides with my fun and creates a large explosion.)
Components: 6 (Cards too small, board a bit flimsy, small)
Theme: 10 (Almost perfectly represents BSG.)
Mechanics: 7 (Too much down time between turns.)
Theme + Mechanics: 10 (Mechanics really support the theme in a good way)
Replay Value: 9 (Every game IS different.)
Scaling/Players: 3 (Doesn't scale well. Definitely seems to have an optimum player #...)
Subjective: -0.50 (Revealed Cylon downtime horrible.  Playing against the humans from the start is the best option for any player, just in case you end up a traitor and have to take the humans down.  Metagame poor.)  Additionally, the paranoic and deceptive metagame is very hard on my psyche, so the game personally wears me down spiritually.

RATING: N/A
This is the yardstick for all semi-co-operative 'traitor' games. It is best played with some but not all elements taken from the various expansions. With the base game and all three expansions, you have a choice of characters that seems greater than the total number of actual characters you can remember from the TV series. The cleverest device in the game is the fact that, as in the TV series, you could find you are a Cylon when you previously thought you were human. 

I succumbed to temptation and picked up the Broken Token organiser for this game. Implausible as it sounds, it really does enable you to fit everything from all the expansions into the main box, even with the cards all sleeved and with the stands added for all the ships.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
It is great to see such a great game developed as a tv show tie in! The mechanics are great and really give the feeling of desperation you are fleeing from attacking cylons while supplies are dwindling. (And my rating is all based on a solo run through, so there was no hidden traitor playing. I can imagine that my rating will go higher once I get a chance to play in a group setting.) 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Fun and exciting game of hidden roles.
Being a cylon rules!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Update:  I am surprised to find that we actually have friends who will play this with us now.  The rules are a bit fiddly, although we're getting the hang of it, but the mechanics are so very good.  I do think that having a sympathizer with only 4 players is a bit too much though.

Old: A lot of potential for greatness.  We'll have to try the 2 player to see if it will get much use in our collection.  I'm concerned that we may not have a group to really play this with.  On the other hand, I was really mentally fatigued when I learned it, so maybe I am overestimating it's difficulty.

RATING: 8
(1 play)  The single play was with 7 players using the Pegasus Expansion and the 7th player optional rule at the end of the rule book.  I was the Cylon Leader and the game was so dramatic.  The Cylon Leader has a completely secret wild card objective, and mine was that the humans needed to win, but one of three dials had to be 2 or below, so the humans had to be beaten down before the end.  The game was coming to a rapid close, and the dials were in good shape, so I was an obvious and overt player against the humans for most of the game.  Finally, Morale was down to 2, so I made an immediate about-face, trying to help the humans escape New Caprica any way I could.  In the end, I was able to make a final move to betray my two revealed Cylon brethren, giving two of the humans a clutch win, and leaving two stragglers to be executed on New Caprica.  I managed to orchestrate a position where the Admiral could win the game along with one human counterpart, or surely lose as the two revealed Cylons were next and the situation was DIRE.  One Cylon Leader and two Humans win, while two Cylons and two Humans lose - not an outcome anyone expected.  It took over 3 hours to play, but with that much drama and betrayal, time spent was not a problem for me.  I would love to play again.

RATING: 4
Hate is a strong word, but I hate this game.

Social deduction is so group dependent, and most don't make it exciting. Even so, this game is wayyyyyyy too long for a social deduction game. Also, way too much luck involved in fuel and cards that get added for a crisis. Just feel like if the wrong colors were neutral instead of negative, or if the values didn't go all the way up to 5 (like a separate deck that is only 1's and 2's, making failing with large numbers more noticeable).

Also, needs more variety in card powers. Only 2 per color?

RATING: 5

This makes it feel very tedious, and you wish that you didn't know who the cylon was again.  The actions the Cylons can take when revealed are not very exciting either, and it basically becomes a game of attrition which, while thematic, is very dull.

RATING: 8
Has a good traitor aspect to it, that is made all the worse by the fact that every person needs to make several agonizing decisions each turn. Make a wrong or unpopular decision and you'll be pegged as the traitor. Nice tension by making the game hard to beat, even if the skill checks can be a fairly dry core mechanism. Surprisingly, it's the meta-game that is the best part of the experience.

RATING: N/A
Wiederspielwert bei komplexer Science Fiction
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
The traitor mechanic on this game is at the core of everything. Getting the humans to win seems to be a fool's errand, but when accomplished, so satisfactory. It was a bit troublesome for me to trick my own kids into getting mom put on the brig, but that was what I was supposed to do. The only drawback for big fans of the series is going to be probably that you actually try and avoid space combat if you can, so pilots and attack oriented people may feel there is not enough action. This is a social game, in my opinion. The coop part of getting the humans to win is necessary, but the seed of distrust that exists in the early and middle game stages makes it hard for the humans to progress. Once the traitor or traitors have been revealed, it is an all out "let's get out of here" attitude. I can see this game go bad with the wrong set of people, so have that in mind. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Very good game, I really enjoy playing it. Get into the role of your chosen character and winning or losing doesn't really matter. Ofcourse winning makes it even better. Play with advanced gamers, stay focused on the game and avoid downtime.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Incredible game. Not only did they capture the feel of the licensed property but they did it well.

My one complaint (and it's minor at this point) concerns the number of Cylons in the game. Specifically, the number is fixed: 1 for a 3 player game, 1.5 for a 4 player game, 2 for a 5 player game, and 2.5 for a 6 player game. One of my favorite aspects of the game is the pervading notion that you never really know who is us and who is them. With a fixed number of Cylon players, the Cylon suspicion continues until all the Cylons are unmasked and then it immediately becomes "us vs them." I don't think there is a way to "fix" it and keep the came relatively fair.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Too much time, too little payoff.  Not worth the trouble.

RATING: 4
Not a good first impression. Game play strongly influenced by how many aliens come out (first round had all humans which made for boring play with no traitors). Second round had two come out of course but time was running out. Long downtime between turns is a big turnoff. Twice I went to fight outside the ship as a pilot, once we jumped the other time I got shot, effectively losing not only that turn but also the next one drawing only one card in sick bay. A third time I was in a part of the ship that got blown up so I went to sick bay. when the time between plays is so long and you can get taken out by events out of your control that cannot be mitigated, not a big fan.
