RATING: 5
Warning! Do not be fooled by fans of the show telling you that you do not need to watch the show to enjoy this game! Die hard fans want to play this game so bad that they will suck anyone in with this line.

Played a 6 player (3 newbs and 3 vets) 3 1/2 hour game. I was the Admiral, so there was nothing for me to do for the first turn (30 minutes, who designed this thing!), except crack jokes about the Admiral being in the bathroom and such. Once I was in the game (turn two) things went faster, barely! Now I was getting a turn every 10-15 minutes.Whoopie! By a turn I mean drawing cards and then passing my one action that I waited 10-15 minutes for, onto another player. Even though I wasn't a Cylon, I wanted the humans to die at about the one hour mark.

I have to say that I am being selfish here. As boring as things were for me, I had it good compared to the first Cylon revealed. His character had very little to do once he was revealed, poor guy!   

Don't get me wrong, there are some neat mechanics in this game, but the mechanics become repetitious and boring very quickly.

By the way, the Cylons won and I cheered for them because they finally put me out of my misery. My only wish is that they could have done it sooner!

RATING: 8.5
I don't consider this one a cooperative game, it's a team game - and for me it's better. However it's a very good game, highly thematic. A must for the series' fans.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Shadows over Caprica. 
If you liked the ideas behind Shadows over Camelot, you will very much enjoy this game.

The game is thematic to the show. Its game play better supports the theme than Shadows over Camelot did. However, like its predecessor being the traitor is much more fun than the regular folks. The Pilot role looks to be distinctly less interesting.

The common skill check provides a much better mechanism for cooperation, along with a better opportunity for the traitor to sabotage the communal effort (remember be subtle).
The two tier traitor deals (one at the beginning and one at mid game) nicely catches the "sleeper agent" aspect of the show.
The Cylons are constantly battering at the gates - so much time is spent just trying to fend them off.

The downside is there is a lot of card fiddling during the game - you go though a LOT of skill cards - but again I think it is necessary to mask the traitor.

During the show (as in the game) I would laugh that the Colonials were in search of Cobol (excuse me Kobol). Where is Capt Grace Hopper when you need her?

RATING: 8
Wow, that game is great! It has it all for me. The tension not knowing who the cylon is, the blind accusation, the power struggles, and in all of that, a fleet to guide to Kobol. If you have a good cylon player, it makes the game very tensed. The key, and what is realy tough being a cylon, is knowing when to revele yourself. So it can be realy fun to be the cylon player. The main advantage about the game is that there is no down time. You participate to the discussions about the decisions and help (or not) when there is a crisis for the other players turn. So you are always in the game. The material is superb. The rulebook is superb but the rules are arsh to read the first time and you will need a couple of games before mastering them all. The only down points would be the relative low choice of action at your turn sometime and the play time of the first few games. The theme is realy well exploited in the game. I will never turn down a game BSG except for time considerations.
Update: Lower the score from 9.5 to 8 because I feel that the game is more a rôle game. If people are not playing the roles or only one player is taking the whole field not leaving any place for the other player to get in the game, it can be quite boring then.

Wow, ce jeu a tous! Le fait de ne pas savoir qui est le cylon, les accusations sans fondement, les luttes de pouvoir, et dans tout ça, une flotte a mener jusqu'à Kobol. Si vous avez un bon joueur cylon, le jeu peut être très tendu. La clé pour le joueur cylon, et ce qui es vraiment difficile, est de savoir quand se révéler. Jouer le cylon peut être très intéressant. L'avantage de ce jeu est qu'il n'y a pas de temps mort. Vous participez toujours aux discussions et aidez lors des résolutions de crises. Vous êtes donc toujours dans la partie. Le matériel est superbe. Le livre de règles est superbe mais les règles sont un peu difficile à lire et vous aurez besoin de quelques parties afin de bien maîtriser celles-ci. Les seuls points négatif seraient le choix restraint des actions certains tours et le temps de jeu des première parties. Le thème de BSG est rendu à merveille par le jeu. Je ne dirai jamais non à une partie de BSG, sauf pour une question de temps.

Mise à jour. J'ai descendu la note de 9.5 èa 8 de ce jeu car je me rend compte qu'il s'agit d'un jeu de rôle et que lorsque les joueurs n'embarquent pas ou lorsqu'un joueur prend le contrôle de la partie et que les autres joueurs ne peuvent jouer leur rôle et embarquer dans la partie, le jeu peut être assez plate.

RATING: 8
Like Mafia/werewolf, but with team objectives. Looking forward to this one.

EDIT: One play, was very tense and a good overall experience. The rules were tough to get a handle on for the two players who don't play games but love the show. It took forever to get the basic flow of gameplay down, but when we did, things got going fairly well. This game would likely benefit from a few more plays.

Tentative rating: 8/10.

Edit: After the second play, the game flowed more naturally and took less time, but the Cylons made some key errors halfway through the game that made it somewhat inevitable that the humans would win (and everyone pretty much knew it for the entire final hour of the game). I kind of don't want to hold that against the game because if all players are playing at a high level, that problem goes away, but for a game aimed at fans of the show who don't usually play complex games like this, it was a bit disappointing to see their lack of rules understanding ruin their chances completely. It's still good, but realistically only great with a higher-level group.

RATING: 10
This is the first semi-cooperative game I played and I enjoyed it very much. Great mechanics and lots of variety in possible strategies, both for the good and evil players. There are a few reasons why this is not a 10 to me. 1: The Theme, I am not a Sci-Fi fan and never saw a single BG episode, so it does not add or take anything for me. If anything, it makes the game harder to relate to. 2: The game encourages social gaming, a lot ! So if you are playing with people who are not into that, the game loses lots of its appeal. Also, the is a lot of accusing, nastyness and betrayal going on, which can be fun, but some people may not like that sort of interaction. 3.) Experienced players have an advantage over newbies. Other than that, Amazing game.#

EDIT: I would rathe this a 10 for the game that takes place before the Cylon(s) is revealed, it becomes less exciting and rather anticlimactic afterwards.

EDIT: Played Shadows over Camelot for the first 2 times today and must say that it is the superior 'traitor' game, not by much but still. I prefer the theme, playing time and nature of the climax.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
Very repetitive.

Straightforward combat mechanism. Specified colours, or suits, of cards count towards fighting a particular crisis, other suits count against. Cards also double as special-action cards; each suit has a different selection of actions, which contributes greatly to the theme. All players contribute cards to resolve a crisis, but no one knows for sure who played what card.

This is the main mechanism of the game. However, this mechanism never changes, or develops, at all -- it changes a bit when Cylons use their "special" crisis cards, but other than that, every fight against a crisis feels the same -- each player has a maximum of 10 skill cards to fight against any given crisis, and the nature of those skill cards never change throughout the game -- you can't invest in any accumulative powers that would enable you to defeat crises in a more efficient way -- nor do crises steadily become more difficult.

One more issue: With any direct conflict game in which players must defeat each other, it should ideally end as soon as players recognize who's the strongest and who's the weakest. However, if you have a case where the players discover who the Cylons are and manage to send them to the brig, then those poor Cylons must wait quite a long time for the rest of the humans to finish the game -- there is simply no way to quicken the end conditions of the game.

As for my tastes, multi-player direct conflict games must have a theme I find interesting. Unfortunately, I have no interest in science fiction; I had to rely on my other opponents to give me a basic rundown of the TV show on which this game is based.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Tough game to rate (especially on 1 play).
On the one hand, it has quality bits & a unique combination of mechanics, which I appreciate.
On the other hand, it is so complicated that it requires a pretty thorough understanding of the entire game before you can even make any meaningful decisions/strategy. It is therefore highly susceptible to the "dominant players decide group actions" (moreso than Arkham Horror, SoC, Pandemic, & LotR put together) on 1st plays.
In all those games, you can cover the basics and start playing, and people can learn as they go. Not so with BG - almost everything is public information (and heroes can MAKE the skill checks public if they want) so you've got to know the game inside and out to even play a Cyclon or your actions are transparently reverse-deducible.
Once everyone memorized the rules/goals (I'm not kidding - there is almost zero on-board indicators about how things work), the strategic element of this game would improve dramatically.
However, by that point I'd venture to guess that the absurd amount of randomness might start grating on people - similar to Arkham Horror, this game is utterly dependent on card draws and dice rolls - you can work for 5 turns and not accomplish anything, and then 1 turn when the right card comes up you get more done thatn all 5 previous turns. 
Did the designers REALLY need the basestars to have to roll a 4-8 on a D8 to do damage to the Galactica? That leads to the situation where they can completely whiff, even if a perfect storm of events is pointing towards basestars attacking. It's almost like the designers took out auto-effect mechanics and figured "Hey, let's make it a roll! Everyone likes those!" and forgot to factor in the aggregate unbalancing impact if all that randomness - as people have pointed out, many games are either landslide Cylon or human victories.
I don't think SoC has THIS amount of overwhelming randomness (but I'm still testing that opinion).
I'd put BG in the same group as Tomb and Arkham Horror in this regard - too long of games (3 hours), that require strategy but make mockeries of it.

Like LotR, BG almost requires players to be knowledgeable of and enjoy the theme.
Do NOT play this with non-gamers expecting for them to come around to the concept of boardgaming.  WAY too fiddly, complex, and long for that.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I like this game for many reasons. You have a very detailed character system. Each person has an ability, a once-per-game power move and a weakness. They also draw different sets of cards. And there are 10 of them. The game system is also relatively easy to follow, I personally use the DMAC system: D-raw, M-ove, A-ction and C-risis. The crisis cards are pretty interesting and as a fan of the series, I appreciate that they used images from the show. I often remember where certain events happened. It even has 2 status titles, the Presidency and the Admiral.

But then wait...

There's this whole traitor system as well. This is really, really brilliant. Traitors not only have an effect when they reveal themselves, but they also have interesting choices they can make on their turns, rather than do some boring crap like in Shadows over Camelot. If they pretend to be human, they can also do sniveling things as well such as screwing up with skill checks.

BUT...

The game is pretty long. 3-4 hours is just too much sometimes. The game also has too many side rules that make it feel messy and poorly designed. People's natural tendency is to reveal themselves as the traitor whenever they want to, but you actually have to have an action to do so. When doing skill checks, you can't say what will put in, you can only say "a lot" or "a little". They could have cut some more things out of the game to make it smoother for new players such as making the skill cards a bit simpler, making crisis cards happen less often (but have a bigger impact), etc.

This game is a good one and has a good overall concept. I just feel that the premise isn't too hard, but that there is too much detail for the average player. I mean you have 10 characters, but then the new player has to then go over each of their abilities and weaknesses. You have skill cards, but then you have a range of 5 numbers and colors, plus you have 2 abilities on each. You have destinations, but then you have a range of 3 numbers, plus a ton of different outcomes. It's a good game, but it's a nightmare for people who want to memorize everything. The value of the game isn't that any one thing is particularly deep, but that there is just so much content that gets flung at you that you just can't recognize much at all. To make a comparison, Go is the complete opposite: the content is easily absorbed and understood, yet the depth comes from the analysis of the board state and player interaction.

With that said though, a person who has a general sense of the game and knows all of most of the content will appreciate the game more than someone who is completely lost. It takes a while to get over this hump and being 3-4 hours long does not make it easy to do so. However, the game is probably one of the best games that mix traitor elements with an actual game. It is miles better than Shadows over Camelot.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
It's a pretty good game.  The people I play with are getting a little tired of me accusing them of being cylons before the loyalty deck is dealt, but it's a good game that will probably continue to hit the table for some time.

The first game I played took six hours and we didn't even finish it because it took  too long to fight our way through the rules.  The rules desperately need an index.

RATING: 9
Component Quality:
Excellent. My only complaints would be that there's sometimes too many cards to keep track of and the board is hard to store with the spinners attached. Otherwise it captures the spirit of the show perfectly. My copy has seen dozens of plays and the components are holding strong.

Gameplay:
Perfect blend of a variety of mechanics. The game forces players to make a lot of tough choices which makes figuring out the cylon player a blast every time. Best traitor mechanics i've seen in a game. This is probably the only game I could play over and over again without growing tired of.

RATING: 8.5
The updated edgier version of the series in a box. 

My only complaint is that sometimes the game can go on for much longer than is necessary. My longest game that I played in went on for 5 and a 1/2 hours. At around the 4 hour mark, the Humans (of which I was one) were looking like we were going to win; around 5 hours in, one of the Cylon players screamed, "Ohmygod! I am SO bored!", before she burst out in hysterical laughter, causing me to also laugh with her.

Like any other game of the similar ilk, players need to moderate the game with regards to time taken to reach a decision [Crisis cards] to keep a good flow and tension.

I really, really do enjoy BSG with a good group.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.2
Absolutely the best game I have played. The game mechanics are good, the blending of the tv-series with a boardgame is done very nicely and the interaction with your fellow humans(?) is sublime.

The only drawback is your fellow gamers. When you play the game with people who doe not have a pokerface or know a subtle way to mislead his fellow gamers it's a frustrating game (for the have-no-way-to-conceal-my-darkest-secrets-people).

Why didn't I rated this game with a ten. Well, there are some game mechanics that are in some situations very frustrating. Like when humans(?) are suspecting an other player to be a cylon they have the option to throw that player in the brig. Except when this player is very lucky, or convince the other players that he is a human, he will sit in the brig for the remainder of the game (sometimes up to 3 hours).

Next to the game mechanics there is a very small problem with the gamepieces. Overall it is fantastic. I have never seen a game that is so greatly styled and crafted. The little miniatures are beautiful, the gameboard is of great quality and alle the cards have exiting flavor text that give a wonderfull flavor to the game. And of-course we have the basestars, who are not..... that great. Except of being nicely crafted miniatures they are tiles. In a normal game it would not be a problem, but with this game where there has gone so much time and effort in the "look and feel" of the game it is just a bloody shame. 

Fortunately the Pegasus expansion resolves all problems. The game mechanics are corrected and the expansion have two nicely crafted miniatures of the basestars, but to be fair the problems shouldn't be in the game first place.

I seem to be harsh in this review. The reason for this is a bit of frustration. The game is really wonderfull and it could have been a rating of 10. But these silly errors has dropped the rating, and I feel bad for Fantasy Flight..... because this could have been a perfect game.

RATING: 8
This is a rating on one play, so I'll likely have to revise it again later. If you like the theme great, but ignoring that (I've never seen the new series) this is basically Shadows over Camelot 2nd Edition. Some-one sat down looked at where that game was limited and how they could fix it. And on the traitor mechanism they scored big time. Replacing the accuse action with the Brig was a stroke of brilliance and the more obvious second deal of loyalty cards was clever. Over-all a very good game, and a nice addition to the co-operative (with traitor) games.

:star::star::star::star::nostar: Easy to learn
:star::star::star::star::nostar: Fun factor
:star::star::halfstar::nostar::nostar:   Replay-ability

why this game stays in my collection?
The mechanics with the voting on decisions can feel repetitive and some turns you can find yourself with very little to do.
But the whole traitor role mechanic, with other players possibly being a cylon or sympathiser can make this one of the most socially orientated and entertaining games.

RATING: 7
Very good, very tense game. It really captures the essence of the first season: Frantic attempts to escape the superior Cylon forces, never knowing whether the latest disaster was an accident or sabotage, and trying to figure out which your friends aren't who they seem. All the mechanics of the game work together to perfectly capture the theme. The only downside to the game is its length: At about 3 hours per game, it's not going to hit the table with my group nearly as much as I'd like.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
(08/20/09) - Despite needing at least 4 to really get the most out of this experience, I have faith that I will either find enough to enjoy it or will make it work with just 3!

(05/22/13) - [7.5] - After three plays of BSG (with a range of three to five players), I am assigning a 7.5 rating. As one of my playing partners described it: "there's a lot of noise while you play, but not a lot of action". The base game seems to devolve into skill check after skill check, and it is hard to immerse yourself when the goal becomes diluted down to "we need X green and yellow", repeated dozens of times. The Cylon aspect is very enjoyable, but with only three or four players it turns into the Cylon laying as low as possible for the majority of the game. A more active traitor makes for a more exciting game, but it is simply too easy to deduce the Cylon during skill checks with less than five players.

SOLD (04/14/2017) - I'd love to think that one day I will find a consistent group of 4 other players to enjoy this title with, but it hasn't happened in ~9 years, with not much chance of that changing. The theme adds another obstacle to introducing new groups as well.

RATING: 8
Such a good game.

Apart from that, I always signed up for games when giving the option. The traitor mechanic works beautifully and it is always a very difficult battle to win the game!

An absolute gem!

RATING: 7
rating after 1 play (5pl) - NA

got a major rule wrong regarding population loss so game was odd cos so bad for humans from start 2 cylons (inc self) felt little need to detrimentally interject which led to little suspicion so times between battles felt a little flat - will reserve judgements till next play but have some doubts...

rating after 2plays (5pl) - 8/9

we didnt shuffle crisis cards properly so was AGES before they came up and then all came up together. also our 1st crisis card failed and meant noone cld look at any loyalty cards for rest of game which was odd but either way was a lot of fun. more plays will reward cos of knowledge of decks which is key eg if ur trying to decide if admiral is good or not u need to know what the range of jump cards is

rating after 4 plays - all 5pl - 7ish

got the chance to play a couple of games in quick sucession and i really dont know about this game - it takes 4+ hours BUT never feels like it drags but i dont think it needs to be that long - 3+ wld be much better. the suspiscion element is nice but there just isnt enuff to do - new players constantly ask what they are supposed to be doing when theyre are no cylon ships on the board and i never know what to say to them cos there is v little to do. also there is a LOT of dice rolling and this will prob decide the game, either im missing something or there is no real game here - having said that cos of the theme its somehow fun to play but im yet to be convinced y this is so loved 

(btw i really like saboteur and shadows over camelot and BG the tv series so this SHOULD be perfect for me)

WEIGHT
rules - 3/4 - quite tricky to teach
play - 3
master - 3/4 ttricky to rate this cos is all about playing the opponents which is as deep as it gets btu is v random
= 10/3 = 3.33

RATING: 6
Secret Santa Gift which was perfect for me as I was curious about the game but unlikely to get it myself.  

I like cooperative, thematic games such as this and Arkham Horror.  For some reason, Shadows over Camelot never really appealed to me.  (I suspect the skill checks - sets of cards didn't quite work there for me.)  Back to BSG - this game shines with 5 or 6 players.

With more players, skill cards become more critical as they can run out before you can draw more.  A full game (humans reaching earth) isn't that long - about 3 hours, so a game that is easily played in an evening even with 6 players.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Not my type of game: (1) I'm not so into cooperative/team games. (2) There's no real planning, just reacting to a long series of random events that lasted way too long in the slow group I played with. (3) Lots of discussion about who might be a Cylon, acting/roleplay to look innocent and cast suspicion on others, voting/debating about other issues, etc which is hard for me in Polish... 

But I was glad to try it to see what it's like, as it's quite popular and clearly has some clever ideas. The card play system is a good elegant variation of the failure cards from Kill Dr. Lucky, and it works well. The basic mechanics are simple and ultimately not so interesting - the point of the game is the suspicion and negotiation and paranoia and discussion. I would probably enjoy it a lot more if (1) I played in English or Esperanto instead of Polish and (2) all players were faster and more focused. My first game lasted roughly 5 hours, and that's just too long for this.

To enjoy the core experience (secret traitors thwarting the shared goal), I recommend the much shorter card game [url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/boardgame/9220/saboteur]Saboteur[/url] - it's small, easy to teach, and lasts a half hour instead many hours.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Wow!  Very faithful to the show, still enjoyable if you know nothing about the show, very atmospheric and lots of interaction.  Seems to scale well to various numbers of players, though I haven't played enough to know for sure.  The main downside is game length.  Three hours is a long time, especially against those with AP.  If there were a way to shorten this to two hours consistently, it would see a lot more of table time.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
I really enjoy this game. I do. It's only problem is it's too complex for most. The game just has so much going on that it offers many problems.

1. Lack of attention. I hate it when people don't pay attention during games. Texting, talking about something other than the game, or just not paying attention in general. But in this game it bothers me more than anything else. Why is that? Because this is a game that thrives on table talk about the game. 

2. Lack of caring. If someone doesn't care about a game and how they do, it doesn't matter usually. I can play a game of Race for the Galaxy against someone who really doesn't care about the game that much and doesn't try and still get enjoyment out of it. But in this game, if one or two players just don't care, the game falls apart.

Enjoyment in this game is heavily weighed on the players and their attitude. 

I wish I could get this to the table more.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
(2 plays) At the moment, I'm still enjoying playing it a lot. I'm worried, though, by its tendency to fall into lulls without much action (e.g. when there are no Cyclon ships on the board) and everyone is basically sitting around waiting for either the jump counter to progress or (if they are Cyclons) for a Cyclo ship to show up, both of which are out of their control.  If games with lots of these lulls prove more common than not, my rating could drop substantially.

RATING: 4
--Nov2008-- (After one play.)  My colleagues tell me that the game is very thematic.  Yet as I'm not a fan of the series (either old or new), I couldn't tell. =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
While I enjoy cooperative games, I am too competetive to feel like playing them a lot.  With the recent crop of popular Co-op games, i didn't expect to particularly enjoy this one. 

What a surprise.  I really feel like this is the best marriage of theme and game play that I have seen in a co-op. The other co-ops are great, don't get me wrong, but;
•Pandemic can turn to shit on you with a simgle card draw, and the theme isn't very deep.
•Ghost Stories is also a little abstract and the win condition just makes it feel like a hyped up tic-tac-toe.
•Shadow over Camelot is entirely too scripted and 
•Lord of the Rings is good, but not too thematically deep.

Battlestar Galactica is VERY thematic, (so if you havn't seen the series, your going to be a bit lost.) I also think that the traitor mechanic in this one is particularly clever...  one player, if smart, can effectively screw with the game the entire time, making an already hard to win game nearly impossible unless the other players can thwart him/her.

The Crisis card give this a massive amount of replayability.

Great game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A game based on the TV-series that Sheldon like most... The story happens in the future, when the earth dies and the last humans escapes into the space. However, the aliens find them and are about to give them the last blow. All players shall cooperate with each other and stop the aliens ('The Cylon', said Sheldon). The meat of the game is that there is one player acting as a Cylon (a spy, but no one knows he is), and, in the middle of the game, another player will become a Cylon, too! (Gene mutation or whatsoever) It adds conspiracy into the pure cooperation. Unfortunately I have no interest in sci-fic, so sorry for the low rating.

RATING: 8
Not sure how much of my like for this title is due to my fanboy status.  Ah well.  Frak the toasters, anyway!  First time we played, after about 7 turns with successive jump-prep conclusions, I muttered something like "Wow we must be missing something" or "Jeez, this game seems kinda...easy."  Little did I know we were just getting very lucky cards, because suddenly we were getting boarded tagged and bombarded from all sides, couldn't jump, couldn't repair, a Cylon revealed himself and left the ship to wreak further havoc and we were trying to figure out which horrible loss was more likely to allow us to just last long enough to jump one more time.  I haven't stopped thinking about this game for the 3 days since we played it!

RATING: 8
The great thing about this co-op game is that not everyone is working together. This changes the game from a solitaire experience to a trust game. For the best experience players need to realize that it doesn't always benefit them to help in the beginning half of the game, because they may become a cylon in the latter half. Otherwise, I find the humans will usually win.

RATING: 6.75
The system in this game, in which you play cards secretly into a pool to affect the result while trying to also be subtle and avoid detection, is neat, but feels like the activity of an hour rather than the hours-long game that it was.  I found that most turns were not very interesting, as the course of action was clear (move to the room to advance the current goal of the team), and the card-playing event was the only interesting bit.  Over so many rounds, it didn't remain very exciting.  However, I'd like to try this game at least once more.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I shouldn't like this game: I don't like co-ops or team games, don't like games that play longer than 2 hours and don't like variable player powers. And yet, I've really enjoyed this game almost every time I've played. 

It's biggest downside for me is that, because of the high level of interaction and communication, some players outright ruin the game. Teaching takes a long time because of all the hidden information and mistakes made by new players often throw off the balance, but that seems thematic at least. There are however certain players who are too dominating or critical or analytical who I simply won't play with, and has led to me playing this much less.

RATING: 8.5
This one really depends on the players. You need people who are willing to enter into the accusation-counter-accusation spirit of the game. Perferably those who've seen the series.

That said, I do think that the mechanics are a little pedestrian for actual gameplay, and it's one of the few games where I feel the expansion actively detracts from many of the game's strengths. The game tends to drag towards the end, unless a very smart Cylon player is keeping things interesting. 

As a result, the game can be great, but it relies entirely on this social aspect to get the game going - which to me means that it must be remembered though it can be an amazingly fun game... so can munchkin...
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
More than any other, this is the game that led me to fall in love with board games (thanks Spoony).

The hidden loyalties are so tense and thematic, and games usually feel on a knife's edge right until the end -- pretty impressive with so many moving parts. The expansions were expensive and only add complexity but the better modules are (probably) worth it.

This is my "event" game. It runs long and will take a while before your group can speed through it.

RATING: 7.5
So glad that our friends' picked this up.  It's a great game, fun and tense with rules that seem to run supa-smooth. =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
The best execution of a theme in any game I've played.

Everything in this game feels like Battlestar Galactica; the tension, the Cylon ships appearing, the slow loss of resources, and of course the paranoia of who is a Cylon agent. The implementation of the sleeper agents is also ingenious, you start to dread: 'Am I actually a Cylon'.

This does not mean the game relies on just fans. I've played this game mostly with people who have never seen the series - and it goes down very well - the mechanics and tension are appreciated on their own.

The rule book is not the best, it is actually fairly annoying when you are learning the game or checking up a rule. Saying that all of the rules themselves (once you learn/find them) make sense and there is very little 'what happens now'-situations.

It is a long game, but it is meant to, rarely do we have a game when you feel like it should have ended a lot earlier.

Not sure on how balanced it is, as I don't really keep count of who wins and I think in a game like this it doesn't really matter, the only thing that matters is what you felt when you played it and if you have a story afterwards. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8.5
French
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Never have I been so conflicted in my opinion of a game. We played two back-to-back games with the same six people—no one was the same character and we swapped out seats.

There’s a LOT of good stuff here. 

The theme is well done. The characters are very distinct. Each one has a special power, a once-a-game bigger power, and a weakness. So Roslin can look at the top two cards of the Crisis Deck (Bad Things) and decide which to implement and which to put on the bottom. Her weakness is that she’s “sick,” so has to discard two cards to activate a space. Tighe’s weakness is Alcoholism, so if he ever only has one card in his hand, he has to discard that one, too. So the people have specific traits that fit them—though very abstracted. 

You face some of the same challenges that they face in the show: food shortages, attacks, Cylons boarding the ship. You’re trying to jump away from the Cylons, so cards slowly allow the FTL drive to ramp up, and when it’s far enough along you can attempt to jump early--but at the risk of losing population because you leave ships behind. Or you can wait a bit longer and auto-jump. But the longer you wait the more you’re getting beat up by Cylon ships. It’s a cool gamble. Our second game came down to one die roll. The humans were down to 3 population, but really had no choice but to try to jump early. They rolled a D8, and on a 1-6 they’ll lose 3 population (and thus the game). If they roll a 7 or 8 they don’t lose any pop and win the game. They rolled an 8 and went NUTS. It was a great gaming moment (even though I was a Cylon and lost).

The Loyalty idea is cool--particularly the fact that a new set is dealt out halfway through the game. In our first game, no one was a Cylon until the second half; then we had two. In the second game there was one from the beginning, one at the halfway, and then I was a Sympathizer halfway, and since the humans were winning I became a revealed Cylon. As in most games of this type, being the traitor is fun. 

I have never felt such a sense of paranoia as in this game. Part of it was that our group really knows each other well, so there was a lot of smack-talk and goofing around. But everything is scrutinized, and there’s a lot of opportunity for sabotage. You can throw bad cards into skill checks to hose the deal, and people can’t be sure who did it because there are two random cards thrown in that could be any color, and all cards are shuffled before you look at them. And you can start throwing blame around: “Hey, that blue card really hurt us. And so-and-so is the only person who draws blue cards...” No one trusted anyone--it was [i]awesome[/i]!

But the bad:

First, it’s long. Way too long. Each of our two games took around 3 hours--with fast players. This might be forgivable if there was more to do when it’s not your turn, but there’s a lot of downtime. This would obviously be different with fewer players, but I wonder how in the world you’d pass some of those skill checks with only 3 people...especially with one person being a Cylon.

The cards are pretty boring. There are only a couple variations in each color, but much of the time they weren’t interesting enough to use (other than reroll cards, and help-pass-a-skill-check ones). I also thought the action spaces were pretty boring. “Well, there are no Cylon ships right now, and we’re not damaged. I guess I’ll move here and draw another card.” Yawn. 

I think the game is skewed toward the Cylons. They won in 3 of the 4 games last night, and there was a 75% chance they win in the fourth one, too. Since each person has a specific skill set, it could be that both your pilots in the game end up being Cylons. The humans are screwed if something like that happens. 

I know the ultimate question is whether it was fun, and I have to say: sometimes. Most turns were pretty dang boring. It was more interesting once I found out I was a Cylon, and then when the game moved into the End Phase we were all pretty involved. But that was after two-and-a-half hours of not-exciting gameplay (but way fun paranoia and finger-pointing). 

Before I played I thought I’d probably end up buying this. Now I know I won’t. I’ll play someone else’s copy, but it would have to be with the right group--and I’d have to be prepared for 3 hours of one okay game. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Battlestar Galactica is the only game I have ever played for four straight hours without once feeling bored. At the beginning of the game, everyone is on edge because some players might be cylons, and by the point the cylons reveal themselves, everyone is so invested in the game that outcome is crucially important. The skill checks do an excellent job of providing information about possible cylons as well as keeping all players engaged even on off turns.

A couple of the mechanics have minor issues. The crisis deck has a great deal of variability in the level of damage it can do to the humans' cause. Cards that cause ships to be put out are particularly annoying to deal with, and very large or very small concentration of those at any point in the game can be enough to decide the winning team. Generally, when I play a game, I never want to feel like I won or lost because of random card draws, so this is a problem.

Another small problem with the game is the sympathizer identity card. The card only affects one person, but it kind of sucks the fun out of the game for that person. Therefore I always try to play Battlestar with exactly five people, which significantly reduces the number of plays it would get if I felt it worked well with four or six.

This is also a game that requires a fairly experienced group of players. It can be difficult to play as a cylon your first game, so it's best to have players who have played other hidden role games and are comfortable with bluffing.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Only had the chance to play once and it wasn't as big a hit with that group as it was with me. I think this might get a higher rating if I got a chance to play it more.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I adore this game. One of the best I've ever played. The only (very valid) complaints that I'd like to echo are that the game is much easier for the cylons than for the hoomans, and that at an average 3-ish hours, you have to be prepared for a long night.
As usual, the instructions leave a lot of be desired. There are some great videos out there explaining play that I preferred to learn from. I'm a visual learner, so that may be the main issue.
Otherwise, once you become an experienced player, and have an experienced group, this can be a ton of fun. The adherence to theme in the game is one of the best I've ever seen, to the point that I can't help quoting the show while playing. But I suppose that's the same as everybody else, right?

RATING: 7.5
Nice semi-cooperative game. As someone who watched and liked the show, it's fairly easy to get into. Deceit, bad faith and roleplay are mandatory to make the game fun, otherwise it falls flat on its face. I wouldn't play it with anyone.
In the long run, the pace of the game is very random. The game can drag for an hour without anything interesting happening (aka "The Love Boat") and suddenly go super hectic (aka "Titanic"), or vice versa. Some games are very funny, others are utterly boring. For a game this long, this is a problem.

RATING: 10
[imageid=752292medium]
This is my favorite of the hidden loyalties genre, as it strikes the best balance between free-form deduction and game-mechanical structure (since Werewolf-style free form can often go too out of hand and depend on the play group). Battlestar Galactica is my favorite TV show, and the board game does more than justice by conveying the tension, paranoia and gritty atmosphere, in addition to porting key events in the show through event cards. Is this the first ever game that does justice to its license? There's Dune, but this might be the first that captures the spirit of a TV show so well.

The weakness with hidden loyalties is the game can get boring or drawn out once you are exposed (hence it's better for the game to be short). BSG runs against type by offering >3 hours playtime, and can be subject to this, but combats it by offering many choices, and the innovative Destiny Deck mechanism. There are many ways to frak with the other side and sow confusion, many opportunities to interpret signals, many ways to frak with them mentally and spitefully, and many things still to do once your mind is somewhat made up.

The gameplay can definitely feel a little rote if the loyalties are revealed early. But the strongly integrated theme allows me to overlook this, and nearly every deficiency with this game.

Now that the arc is likely complete, the Base Game remains at a 9 due to lack of variety and some 'solvability', but the entire series is a definite, true 10, capped by the amazing Daybreak expansion. There are so many options and sandbox-element cards that no two plays will ever feel the same again.

[u]My 2 recommendations[/u]
[b]1. Beginner:[/b] Destination = Earth, Cylon Attack Cards (after removing 21 non-CAC Crisis Cards), no Battlestar Pegasus, no Exodus Loyalty +1 (and therefore no Conflicted Loyalties, and none of the modules from Exodus). Guaranteed 2 cylons. No Pegasus in order to get rid of Airlock and to give cylons an advantage after taking away the CFB. The thematic bonus of no Pegasus going to Earth is just gravy.

[b]2. Expert:[/b] Destination = Ionian Nebula, every single module. No guarantee of 2 cylons, but maximum ability to cycle the Loyalty Deck (via Airlock, Personal Goals, disaster tokens and executions with Nebula etc).

3. Intermediate: (because everybody insists on the CFB but isn't experienced enough for the Nebula...) Destination = Kobol, every module, but Conflicted Loyalties and Loyalty +1 are optional. Recommend CL for 6er Mutineer (a little harder to let the cylon be the last card, + make it a little harder for humans). Recommend doing Loyalty +1 pre-sleeper if not using.

Also, Beginner is more suitable for 5-player while Expert is more suitable for 6-player (where Treachery/Mutiny kicks into overdrive, there is rule complexity from the Mutineer/Cylon Leader, and you need 4 potential human turns in between the 2 Basestar Bridge turns). And consider banning Political Prowess for Expert (due to Airlock availability) but not Beginner.

[u]House-Rule Considerations[/u] (in decreasing order of priority)
1. [b]Ban Cain[/b] aka Scout + Blind Jump cheese. C'mon, she was only in like 2 episodes. Added bonus of actually giving a reason to pick Adama. Negotiable if going to Earth.
2. [b]Ban Cally[/b]. Nobody else has that good a combo of ability + miracle, and her presence makes the game less fun for everybody (totally disrupting unrevealed-cylon strategy).
3. [b]Protect unrevealed cylons from disasters[/b] with Ionian Nebula. Just ruins it for everybody when an unrevealed cylon trips the mine, especially if through no fault of his own. Favor letting humans and unrevealed simply toss disasters away (HARDENED) when they draw them or shuffle and draw an extra Loyalty Card.
4. [b]Tory's ability requires Consolidate Power[/b]. Else her power is out of whack compared to other card-draw characters.
5. For Crossroads, [b]don't eliminate, just execute[/b] (and don't shuffle an extra card into Loyalty). For revealed cylon, this additionally means dropping his/her Super Crisis Card(s).

Political Prowess isn't so bad when Pegasus is often destroyed (so no Airlock), and the new Treachery/Mutiny makes people come in and out of the Brig so much that the one skill check it's used on becomes less pivotal. Plus Change of Plans.

Who I've played in Base-only:

Zarek - 1

Roslin - 1

Base: 5+3
Pegasus: 3+4
Exodus: 2+3
Daybreak: 5+5

g{[b]Favorite 5-player Long[/b]}g
g{[b]Favorite 6-player Long[/b]}g (with Daybreak expansion)

RATING: 9
Does a truly amazing job of capturing the gist and psychology of the TV series with a relatively slim rule set. A game that doesn't try to club you in the head with clever innovative mechanics, but rather pushes things forward along the social axis. The strengths aren't really in the game per se, but in the stories it tells and the interesting social situations it creates.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This game is absolutely amazing. The expansions somehow manage to add even more depth, intrigue, manipulation, and suspense to a game that is already chock-full of all of this. The Cylon mechanic is particularly amazing.

I highly recommend playing the game with at least the Cylon Basestar expansion from Exodus and the Pegasus ship from the Pegasus expansion. Otherwise, the game can get a little bit boring for Cylon players (once revealed) and they can feel 'left out'. Humans win about 15-20% of the time, and games have taken anywhere from 2.75 hours to up to 6 hours.

I have not played with the Cylon Leaders mechanic, but am looking forward to adding that in to the mix as well.

RATING: 1
Brainless game of cooperative play, tons and tons of randomness, and talking; there's no long term strategy or thinking involved. The game also completely lacks balance - roles are either very strong or very weak, so for the good guys 1-2 people play the game and the rest executive-order them because that's best for the team; playing a cylon, after discovery, feels completely disconnected from the good guys' play - you might as well be playing alone against an automaton. One time I won as cylon leader by sitting around in jail 80% of the game doing petty things, because my victory condition was for one side to win while I am in jail. Nonsense.

Oh yeah, forgot to add. It also takes forever (and I'm the guy who likes Game of Thrones and Mansions of Madness)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
Argh.

Seriously, these "traitor games" can't seem to get it right. 

1 - BSG - 30 minutes of psychology and deceit and treachery in a 180 minute game, overbloated with mechanics and details and stuff and nothing moves at any pace but glacial. 
2 - Resistance at least last only 30 minutes, but lacks narrative and dramaturgy 
3 - Panic Station - does a whole lot of story in 60 minutes, has tension, the whole narrative is player driven. BUT half finished product with thematic holes the size of Jupiter, an identity crisis and crashes as easily as Windows Vista when it came out. 
4 - Note to self - have to try Dead of Winter, but not in a rush...

So back to BSG. I dunno. It just drags. Supposedly it all makes sense if one watched the show, which I didn't. It's better if players know one another and create a good shared atmosphere, but, too much "thematic elements" (literally, each has a card and a counter and a page in the rulebook), too much overhead. If one wants to create the kind of atmosphere this advertises then lower overhead please. A bloated hogzilla.

RATING: 10
This has to be one of the most entertaining and downright HILARIOUS group games I have played to date. The chatter between players and random baseless accusations of being a cylon are epic. It doesn't matter if your friends throw you out the airlock and say you were a cylon... you will still love this game.

Update: I've played this game several more times since my review and it holds. The game is a fantastic group game if only for the chatter that it creates. I cannot say enough good things about this one.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A cooperative game with the added intrigue of traitors (cylons) in the mix. The possibility of alliances shifting halfway through the game keeps the suspicion alive. The actual game play is rather superficial - the real fun is had while trying to figure out who is a cylon and who is a human. I think the actual on board game play in Shadows Over Camelot (another cooperative game with a traitor) is superior, while Battlestar Galactica has the edge in interaction. 

In Shadows, an early traitor reveal removes a lot of the suspense from the game. Then you just play through to the end - not everyone will find what is left meaningful enough to keep their interest. This problem is avoided in Battlestar because the mid-game possibility of an additional traitor being added keeps the suspicions going, avoiding the possibility of playing for a substantial duration with all loyalties known. Having said that, both games are fun and choosing between the two probably comes down to preference for theme - knights of the round table vs. science fiction.

UPDATE: I can't remember how long our SOC games took, but BSG has taken around 4 hours or so every time. That's just too long.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
[1 play] We had a very enjoyable 6 player learning game. This is the best themed semi-cooperative game I've tried so far. The mechanics of the game work well to immerse the players in the experience - much more so than the "forming poker hands" which occurs in Shadows Over Camelot. The "traitor" mechanism is also much improved in my opinion - although I will say that I would recommend 5 players over 6 - to speed up the game just a bit and to eliminate the sympathizer card, which seems to reduce the fun for one player in the second half of the game.

Overall very pleased and looking forward to more of this one - something I could never say wholeheartedly about Shadows or Red November.

Most recent play 1-2-09 with Michael, Donovan, Andy, Joel, and Brian Rowe.

RATING: 9.25
#14 on my Top 100 Games of All Time (2017)
#11 on my Top 100 Games of All Time (2016)
#7 on my Top 100 Games of All Time (2015)

SO SAY WE ALL!! Frak yes, BSG! I get pumped up just thinking about this game. It's that awesome. I will say that you do need to play with a good group though- probably people you know well. I have had a couple lackluster experiences that I mainly attribute to the group dynamic. I would love to find a regular local game group just to play this game a lot. I like it more than the Resistance because I find the game mechanics to be intriguing. The theme interests me as well due to being a fan of the show. Yes, it's certainly a longer social deduction game, but it's longer because it's EPIC! So much potential for amazing stories and moments of glory and horror when it comes to this game. I LOVE IT.

Acquired: August 2012 - GenCon
(I have actually bought and sold this game like 3 times at this point for various reasons...)

Social Deduction
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
FFG wraps Werewolf in a BSG shell...and it works. Players are members of the BSG and have to use skill sets (and attendant cards) in order to deal with crises that come their way.

Add in the fear and paranoia of possible cyclons on the ship...that's when things start to get hairy. The mechanics are nothing new but are quite faithful to the original show. The way players commit face down cards to deal with problem cards is clever: and something other similar games should have done.

Only gripe is the long playtime. There should be a time limit on discussions to speed things up. But otherwise, fun fun fun!

RATING: 6
Played tens of times.

Nice co-op game with traitors (essentially a team game where loyalties are not known at the start).  The sleeper mechanic annoys me, it makes me feel as though I'm playing the first half on autopilot.  The arrangement of the crisis deck can inject a bit too much luck into the game, our group does a "Pandemic-like" shuffle to even out the luck.

Like any team game, it can be annoying if your teammates do things badly (eg. the human who does stupid things and doesn't justify them, or your cylon partner who tries too hard to keep cover and doesn't hurt humans enough).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2

Very little to be engaged with while in the down time and there is a lot of down time when you add the Expansions.  I feel there are better games to play as a coop opportunity that do not suck the life out of a game night or take up the whole game night. If I am to invest the time this game takes to play would rather play a deeper more strategic game like Eclipse, Dominate Species or Twilight Imperium.  This goes for all Battlestar expansions as well don't feel any really breath new life into the game just take more of mine.

RATING: 9
Exceptional, and great fun to teach. Battlestar, moreso than The Resistance, is an excellent "gateway" cooperative game- whereas The Resistance never really gets any deeper than the Bluff, Battlestar features pretty much the same Bluff along with a very well-designed co-op engine rich with theme and thus serves as not only a great introduction to hobby board games, but also as an excellent co-op strategy game.

MAJOR UPDATE: tried it with 5p at a gaming weekend. Easily one of the best gaming sessions I have had, ever. Started at breakfast and played till 5:30pm and I stayed in the Brig for most of the game, after claiming President to go with my Admiral and declaring Martial Law. There were tears, there was laughter, tension, passion and so much metagame it literally leaked into all other games we played that day. Fantastic experience. 
Still it has become even more obvious that the game relies on a good gaming group.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
[i]One of the Best and Most Memorable Gaming Experiences Around. Some Ambiguous Communication Restrictions and Uneven Modular Expansion Elements are the Only Mars on this Near Perfect Game System[/i]

[b]Best 5 Player Game Award[/b]

Playing as a Cylon is the most fun I've ever had. Some people criticize this game for putting too much game and  complexity around what should be a simple goal of "find the traitor", but that's actually what I liked about this game compared to the simpler traitor games -- it's more game and less activity.

[b]3 player[/b]: Pretty horrible. Only one Cylon, and skill checks are way too easy to pass because you draw so many cards. Won't play.

[b]4 player:[/b] Better than 3 player, but not as interesting as it can be because there's still only one Cylon. potentially loses a huge amount of intrigue when that one Cylon is revealed. I'd pass.

[b]5 player:[/b] Best player count. Two Cylons and 3 Humans is the perfect balance, without having to use weird bandaids like Sympathizer or adjusted resource dials

[b]6 player:[/b]Pretty good, because there's two Cylons. Balance isn't as good as 5 player. 6 player is better if you want to use Cylon Leaders

[b]7 player:[/b] This feels a little crowded, but still one of the best games ever made so I'll take it. Better than 5 player if you want to use Cylon Leader.

(5 Design + 5 Enjoyment)

[hr]IMO base game becomes sort of routine after you are experienced. It's just too predictable. It's easy to determine the makeup of someone's hand, what they added to skill checks, what cards you're like to draw if you dig the Quorom, etc. All this leaves little room for truly creative or surprising play amongst experts.

The Crisis cards also often end up with the same "bad" or "good" choices from game to game (including whether to tank them or try to pass), etc.

Luckily the expansions save it from having any sort of limit whatsoever on replayability. With the sheer variety the expansions add (3 of them now!), every game and situation is unique, so there are new creative approaches to backstabbing the humans in every game.

All three expansions add a CHUNK of value, in their own way. Though they each have their share of flaws, their scope is large enough that it's just not a problem -- the game even allows you to leave out the bits you don't like. I highly recommend the expansions.

[hr]After playing Secret Hitler, I have cooled off on this a bit as it is no longer the best traitor game I've played. Still great experience with all of the expansions, but I'd probably only rate the base gmae like an "8" now. With ALL expansions it's still a top 10 game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
Battlestar Galactica is one of my favorite games. It's another example of gameplay matching the theme perfectly. I had not seen the show the first time I played, but it was still a great experience. The game can run pretty long and that is primarily what keeps it off the table. There are a few expansions, but only a handful of the modules are worth using. I still enjoy this game and will play it whenever, but there are shorter games that deliver an experience that is just as good.

RATING: 10
This is the only game that I've ever played for 6 hours and then shouted, "Let's play again!" (We didn't--but I would have been up for it.)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Nothing new.  No big surprises.  You have a number of different timers manage.  You have to do damage control with abstract colors to manage abstract results.  If you get to zero on any of the timers you lose.  

Repeat. 

Repeat.

Repeat.

For a long time.

So why do I give this an eight?  Well, I like the show and it captures the best parts of the show perfectly (With none of the really, really awful bits).  There is a high level of tension throughout. They got the characters and events spot on.  There is a real feeling of paranoia, and there is some anxiety that comes in during the second phase when you could switch sides.  The push for the jump is exciting as tension builds.  Ultimately, the game is fun, and that counts for quite a bit in my book.

I really only have one significant complaint about the game.  I think the "sympathizer card" is a real bone. If you are a Cylon you get all the choices and all the fun.  If you get the sympathizer card and turned into a Cylon you get shuttled away immediately.  So no having fun bluffing it.  No special Cylon power. No extreme event card.  

Then to make things even less exciting for this player they are limited to only a few Cylon options one often being clearly worse than the others.  So you flip event cards and chose the card that is clearly worse.  This player is more or less effectively eliminated from the game.  It seems to me that they should get some kind of gimme.

RATING: 7.5
Although I usually love co-operative games, this one has such a nasty hidden traitor mechanic to it that it almost offsets the fun of working towards a common goal. Not a reflection on the game's design, just how I like to play. The game does an excellent job of capturing the feeling of hopelessness of the Galactica as it runs from the enemy... the "good" players are constantly losing all the time, just trying to stave off the inevitable. Since in my game session I was not a Cylon agent, I missed any moment of euphoria and felt really worn out by the end (we lost by the way). Maybe that makes for a great theme, but for me it doesn't always make for a fun evening. I think it would go a long way if a few positive events were interspersed with the negatives, just to keep you going. I updated my score recently after having played with the Pegasus Expansion.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
This is my favourite boardgame. With a traitor mechanism that fosters mistrust and suspicion amongst players, some of which are trying to work together, this game is wonderful in its semi-cooperative nature and the tension in creates in the fight not just against the game but also those trying to destroy you from within. That it well replicates the TV series is an added bonus.

Despite a sense of continuing despair and doom as resources ever dwindle, the game is never over as the humans persevere to snatch victory and the cylons look for the final blow. Human wins are always close and cheered, cylon wins never produce disgust at the game time wasted but with anticipation about how to next defeat the toasters.

Despite the numerous things that can be done in a turn and the various rules that govern the various aspects of the game, they are individually actually not too complex and with repeated plays, can be relatively straightforwardly learnt. 

Obviously with my obsessive stats that I keep, I adore this game!

All stats include expansions
Overall wins: 36/74 (47%)
As human: 22/53 (42%)
As cylon: 13/20 (65%)
As cylon leader: 1/1 (100%)
20 cylons in 73 games (27%) [not including games as cylon leader]
Last played as  Laura Roslin (CL Simon O'Neill)

RATING: 9
Love this one.  It's a 'find the traitor' game but with so much going on you have to always weigh how much trouble it would be, and if it would be worth it to finding them.. just very exciting, always tense fun. =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Yet another cooperative game, with a really cool theme. For me, though, (first) game play doesn't hold up -- too long, and too many times where you have nothing useful to do. After one play, I prefer Shadows Over Camelot. However, I suspect this is better with more players (except for game length).

Update: after the second play, it was still just OK -- sold off!

There are some really cool mechanisms here:
- 2 loyalty card distributions. Thematically this is very cool. In actual play, though, it didn't add much to the game: it was obvious which player was the cylon.
- several actions available to the revealed traitor
- interesting skill checks (with cards from players and destiny deck). Sounds great, but didn't seem to add much to our game.

On the other hand:
- too long
- several times players were wandering around the ship with few/no useful actions
- too long
- KNOWING there are cylons is less interesting than suspecting. You usually will know the exact number, too (unless one player is dealt more than one cylon card, of course).


=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
If you're into Battlestar Galactica, BUY THIS GAME. If you love games with hidden traitors where the trainer can really get into people's heads and screw with the game plans, BUY THIS GAME. Wild accusations will be flying left and right.

The only down side is that it's a long game & the length really increases per player due to the additional table talk. If there was any way to capture this in a 2 hour experience, it would be my #1 game of all time (and no, Dark Moon doesn't even come close).

This game, along with Kingdom Death Monster, has given me truly "epic" games with highs and lows that have been remembered long after. Not many games can do that, and certainly most Euros don't -- they typically generate post-game discussions and while fun, there's nothing memorable about them.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This is a longer game but the hidden traitor mechanic goes over incredibly well in my gaming group. This is asked for almost every game night.

RATING: 6.5
No real emotional investment here as I've never seen the show.  Still, it's fun to accuse people of being a psylon (sp?), and the gameplay is pretty fun.  Also, because everyone else I've played it with seems to be really, really into the show, it adds to the fun just to see them enjoying themselves!

Somehow, ending up as Admiral President Starbuck and firing a nuke at the Homestar (er, Basestar) while piloting a Viper was very, very cool.

Update 09/02/2011:  Not sure why I neglected updating this.  Watched the show in its entirety in late '09.  Fun enough game, made infinitely more engaging and enjoyable through knowledge of the show.  Both are flawed beasts, but fun regardless.  One of the better co-ops I've played.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
Pros: Interactive, even when it's not your turn.

Accusations flying across the table most of the game.

Cons:  The cylons seemingly have little motivation to not play along nicely until the second set of cards are dealt, making the first half of the game less interesting.

Game length-pretty long for a game where one of the main objectives is trying to determine who the traitors are.  Other games distill this mechanic to a much shorter game time.  If the first half was more engaging, this wouldn't be as much of an issue, but most of the decisions aren't that difficult.

Theme-more of a personal quirk here, but I'm not much of a sci-fi fan and have never watched the show, so the goal and the story behind the characters doesn't mean much to me.  I can see where it would be hugely entertaining if you're a fan.

Cooperative nature-another personal quirk, as most coop games fall flat for me (I do like Terra quite a bit though).  I don't like having to run my decisions by others for approval.  Hell, I have to do that enough in real life! One thing I like about board gaming is the outcome is largely dependent upon my own decisions and strategies and not second-guessed by others.

After sitting in for most of another game, I agree with my initial impression that sci-fi fans will love it.  Others will be mixed depending upon how much game they really think is present behind all the chrome and how much they enjoy longer cooperative games.  Personally, the game fails to capture my imagination and it's WAY too long for the small amount of interesting game play.

RATING: 4

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I really like this game.  I'm usually either hot or cold when it comes to hidden role games.  For me hidden role games at their purest are awful but I tend to like them when there is another layer of gameplay added.  To that end I really dislike basic Werewolf and The Resistance but don't mind Bang! and now really like Battlestar Galactica.

First of all, probably the best implementation of theme I've ever seen for a board game, and all done without sacrificing gameplay.  I love the show and love how the character cards and their bonuses/penalties reflect the characters from the show.  Even their starting positions, the crisis cards, and that you can't deploy Vipers from one side of Galactica all pull from the show while still working really well for gameplay.

It is an intense and fun coop experience with constant tension since your resources are constantly diminishing as you get closer to your goal and gives you that feeling of treading water with shore just in sight on the horizon.  I love that you can switch sides half-way through the game, some people think this is a crappy mechanic but I think it is original and a lot of fun to all of a sudden have to start trying to sabotage these people you spent an hour trying to get home and, again, it really fits the show's theme.

Finally, the whole game is really well balanced for a game that has so much going on.  And of course the one thing nobody can ever fault FFG on is their production values.  The game is gorgeous and the bits are all solid.

RATING: 7
Board: 3-6 Players

RATING: 5.5
Good but over-hyped (and overrated) in my opinion. The cylon factor is the great part, brilliant tie-in with the show, and the rising suspicions of who the secret cylon is make the game. The rest unfortunately falls a bit flat. Seems the most fun is to be had when actually being a cylon otherwise there is next to zero strategy in the game play, several rounds people had nothing to do when no ships attack, so turn after turn one waits for the crisis and tries to pass it. The game flow is really not that great. Not all that complex, but comes with tough decision making once in a while, if that is your thing. A bit too long, too,  for what it is but some seem to like that a lot. I wish I would have been a cylon!  
Played with 5, seemed it works with more but I was under the impression that more would make it even more tedious, more waiting time with nothing to do.

RATING: N/A
Regalo para fans Battlestar Galactica
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
A classic thematic intrigue game, Battlestar Galactica matches the theme and plot of the first season of the the modern television show perfectly.  The bluff mechanics and intrigue of the hidden cylon player(s) are extremely fun if handled by an attentive group of players.  The character's special skills are appropriately derived from the show.  The crisis cards are familiar plot devices from the show.  In addition to working as the game's engine, their flavor also greatly enhances the rather basic gameplay.  Hand management, crisis cards that require a choice, and deciding when to reveal when dealt a "You are a cylon" card are the main planning and strategy elements of the game.

This game can be brutal and difficult to win as the human players.  Especially if all of the "You are a cylon" cards are dealt before the sleeper agent phase (the midpoint) of the game.  Also, certain combinations of character types can make it very difficult to win as humans.

I enjoy this game the most with 6 players.  It did not play as well with 3 - 4.  It is currently our gaming group's favorite game if we have 6 players.  I only dock this game a point because it does not hit the table when our group has 4 or 5 players.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Never before have I ssen my game group argue and backstab to this degree.  This gem brougth out the best in us.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Has any game ever captured a theme so well? This is perhaps the greatest licensed game ever made - you definitely feel as if you are living out some of the most tense moments from the show.

However, it isn't all good news. Unfortunately, this game comes with more rules than you can fly a raider through, and much of the game goes slooooooowly as a result. Once the board inevitably fills up with Raiders and Basestars, the game tends to grind to a halt.

In short, if I'm playing with a bunch of BSG fans who will dig the theme, or I'm playing with people who love *mostly* co-operative board games, then this is worth it. However, I can't really recommend it otherwise.

RATING: 4
I finally got a chance to play this one. Glad I did, but not my cup of tea. It's a lot about the mental games that are played in the group. I didn't find it incredibly interesting especially for the amount of time it took to play it (3 1/2 hours I think).

I don't doubt that it's a good game if you are into that kind of social deduction thing. I'm just finding I'm more Euro in my game preferences.

The game does do a very good job of capturing the show, but I didn't really like that element of the show either (anyone could be a Cylon, no one is safe). I preferred it when the Final Five (Five?) were revealed and you knew who you could trust and move on from there.

So, my rating might be a little low, but I just don't really want to play this game again.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I love hidden faction social interaction games. Even though I have enjoyed all of my plays of this one and would gladly play again, I know it will not be soon. The length of the game (3 hours with limited instruction) means that it will deter almost everyone from a casual game night. This one is meant for one of those weekend games for a few select friends who decide on what big game to play ahead of time.
In that regard this one fits the bill perfectly.
You don't have to be a fan of the TV series to appreciate the game but it definitely helps with the immersion.
If you're looking for a similar theme and game type that you can fit in under 2 hours, I would suggest Dark Moon.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Battlestar takes the semi-cooperative, "There's a traitor (or two) among us" mystique of Shadows over Camelot and fixes many of the problems with its medieval predecessor. By making the [-]Progression of Evil[/-] Crisis step often a group task, it eliminates the lengthy downtime that can come with games of 5 or more players. By giving Cylons their own section of the board with various powers, it eliminates the often-boring "Add a siege engine, steal a card" revealed-traitor step of SoC. Instead of accusations, people are throwing each other into and out of the Brig left and right, and stripping each other of their titles. The Brig itself is a bit like the Captured! card from Shadows over Camelot: Merlin's Company but without the possibility of throwing a player out of the game for an hour or so by allowing them limited interaction and their own attempts to leave. Making most of the important information on the board (rather than what's in people's hands) makes table-talking much less tempting and necessary-feeling than SoC and keeps people from being mindlessly stuck on the same quest for several turns. Finally, Executive Orders make accomplishing things more possible even when there's five people between you and your next turn. (As an aside, I appreciate that I, someone who has never seen the show, could enjoy this game as much as those who did. Sure, the quotes and flavor text were lost on me, but the game itself was still incredibly fun; I didn't feel left out by my lack of familiarity with the source material at all.)

The game isn't without its flaws. First and foremost, it could've used a few more weeks in playtesting and editing. The rulebook makes finding certain rules a chore, especially since it has one of the most useless indices I've encountered. Some post-publication FAQs REALLY should have been caught before the game came out (how did NO ONE notice the Executive Order loop?). Fighting [-]siege engines[/-] raiders is a bit boring compared to other things you could be doing, and you get sort of stuck out in space--it's not worth spending an entire turn coming back to the ship to do something else. Also, since everything in space disappears whenever you jump and pilots get shunted back into the hangar, it can often feel, as a pilot, like you were just about to blow up some serious Cylon butt when you get teleported back into the ship. And again. And again. So being a pilot's a bit thankless. But overall the flaws are few, and the game is addictive and really well-done. My rating's currently a 9 for it--tied with SoC--but I can see that increasing as I see if I feel the same after more plays.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
Does a magnificent job of creating tension and paranoia among all the players. 

By the time you enter into the second phase of the game, you'll hardly trust anyone. Every nuance that is out of character and every suspect decision that you may be forced into making, targets you as a Cylon.

After all there is no real way of telling until they reveal themselves by which time it may well be too late.

As players get more experienced with this game, I can envisage the pressure cranking up unbearably. 

I wager that someone will totally lose it, during a game of BSG at some stage in the future. I just hope that it's not me.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.75
Fun game. Although we didn't get to finish, I enjoyed what we played.

I was Baltar and was a Human (and made tons of mental strategies to expose the Cylon) until we started the first turn and I realized I was suppost to get another Loyalty card. It turns out that other card made me a Cylon, so I had to re-think everything.

I played very conservatively, only messing up a few skill challenges that would have given other people a chance to look at my Loyalty cards. Because I was the President, I used this as an excuse to leave the main ship and draw tons of Quorum cards. We had 2 Pilots and the Support repairer in the game, so I knew destroying BSG would be too difficult.

My plan was to find out who the other Cylon was and join forces with them secretly to destroy the Morale of BSG, unfortuantly I got the other Cylon card at the half mark... which we then called game because it was getting late.

Best "co-operative" game I've played so far, beating out Pandemic, Last Night, and Shadows Over Camelot by a lot.

Hopefully I will get a chance to play again (and as a Cylon again... I love being evil)!

UPDATE: Played again and I was Baltar and a Cylon again. We (the Cylons) managed to win and lose. We won because the players messed up their turn order, but then when we went back and replayed it in the correct turn order we lost by a single action. Very close and very tense!

RATING: 7
I'm quickly becoming an absolute fanboy of this game.  There is always something interesting to be doing in every person's turn, and your decisions usually involve very difficult trade-offs.  I look forward to playing this one day where I'm not teaching a new player.

Official solitaire variant is too easy, 2-player was not good the one time we tried.

4- and 6-player games seem truly unbalanced.  If the humans are all in the blue at the halfway-point, cylons seem undefeatable.  And I hate the prospect of intentionally getting one resource in the red to counteract this.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Seems like an incredibly well thought out game in terms of keeping with the theme/plot/feel of the show. First game seemed way too long (5 hrs) so keen to try again with better understanding of the rules/tactics, and with a timer in place for the crisis events.

The real clincher is the Cylon/traitor aspect, which is made even stronger by the possibility of being 'switched on' at the halfway point. This puts it above a game like Pandemic, because even if it turns out that there aren't any Cylons in your midst, the possibility that you might be competing against a real person and not just 'the board' makes it much more fun. Also, it creates a level of compulsory secrecy which means that you actually get to make real decisions on your turn, rather than ending up following one bossy player who knows how to beat the game.
