=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Brilliant game. Though the theme will offset some non-gamers, it is actually as good as The Resistance (which came later and was probably inspired by this game).

But where The Resistance is just a 'clean design' that takes only the core mechanic of 'cooperative traitor', BS incorporates a very thematic 'Arkham Horror'-esque theme with that.

Only reason that the rating for this game is not the solid '9' I give to The Resistance is the fact that piloting seems quite underpowered and almost worthless, due to the fact that jumping is a MUCH better way to get rid of every troublesome fleet around you.

However, maybe we played it wrong. Time will tell as this will definitely get a replay.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
We had four players, and not quite enough time to finish the game, so I might have to bump up the ranking after a few more plays.

With four players, the game was alright, and the crises had a good rhythm to them. However, in my particular play group the Cylon didn't do anything especially obvious. He was admiral and getting us to the destination slowly with maximum fuel losses, which was fantastic Cylon behavior ... it just meant that no one ever got very suspicious which is what makes the game so interesting.

The next play had the full compliment of five players and went much better. Things were hectic enough before the sleeper phase that we were nervous and scrambling for control even though we all happened to be human. Once the sleeper phase hit, three Cylons emerged (Boomer and Baltar were in play), two of them not in the least subtle--the president and the admiral. One of them revealed near the end of the game passing the presidency to the unrevealed (but painfully obvious) Cylon admiral. It was rather beautiful. I had a wonderful little plan for how to salt the wound a little more before outing myself as a Cylon as well leaving the three two humans to contend with a mad robotic Military President. Unfortunately we had to cut the game short.

I love the rhythm of the game, and I suspect it gets even more interesting when someone starts the game as a Cylon. I think the crisis deck is mostly good, but it doesn't quite keep the pressure up when the fleet isn't around. Our poor pilots turn useless every time we jump and the pressure rockets right down. There are awkward stretches where nothing happens in space and the crises aren't quite up to creating tension all by themselves.

All in all, a great game. Looking forward to more. I think this is also the first Fantasy Flight game I've played that stays within the time limit printed on the box. ;)

RATING: 8
Great game only it can get a bit long in the tooth when you find yourself waiting it out for the base star to arrive.  It is a brilliant game for 'who's the cylon' tension, but the hang up lies in not having a good flow for battle.  It could be fixed by maybe having more cards with a base star or more frequent 'attack' cards? who knows.  Best bit though is trying to figure out the cylon...lots of action man eye movement sussing each other out.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

The only bad things I can say about the game is that the game lasts a little longer than it should and with the imbalance at four and six players, it's in the Human's best interests to do poorly in the first half so that they keep the advantage in numbers. =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Battlestar Galactica has strong theme and great artwork, I love the show, and it matches the show perfectly both from a theme and gameplay standpoint.  However, the game suffers from a few obnoxious problems.  

The first is that the game can draw out for an extremely long time, what is worse is that you can frequently feel like you are doing very little each turn, and in some cases, you can even be put into the brig where you essentially can't do anything.

I have also felt like the Cylons typically lose, and when a player reveals themselves as a Cylon there doesn't seem to be much they can participate in or do except for one big power when it becomes their turn, so the game becomes even more boring for them.

All in all, I absolutely love the idea, theme, art, and gameplay.  Described in person it sounds incredible, but when you actually play it it is a bit painful and by hour 3 you will be looking at the clock wanting it to end.  

I will not refuse to play this game, but I definitely have to be in the right mindset.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

still new, in box.

RATING: N/A
Comprado en labsk a serton

Nº jugadores: 3-6    Ideal: 6
Duración: 180-210 min

Primer contacto con el juego. Varias consultas al reglamento, explicación a los jugadores con todo lo que conlleva. Partida larga, en la que no estoy seguro de haber jugado bien todas las reglas, estoy seguro que una segunda partida sera mucho más dinámica y placentera.

Es un juego con potencial, pero para empezar a exprimirlo, me temo que hay que jugarlo unas 3 partidas con el mismo grupo para sacarle el jugo y disfrutarlo en condiciones.

La segunda partida fue mucho más fluida, disfrutable y divertida. A pesar de ello metimos la zarpa en algunos detalles que convirtieron el juego en algo imposible para los humanos.... a la tercera ira la vencida! :D

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This is a really, really good game.

The semi-collaborative set-up - where you appear to be working together, but some may be covertly or overtly working against you - brings in a great social element. As a fan of the show, it sure is fun to hop in a Viper and start zapping Cylon. Plus nothing beats that thrill of revealing as a Cylon at just the worst possible time!

BSG is divisive. My SO normally loves game and even liked the show, but she hates the game and refuses to play. Also, players with greatly disparate levels of expertise can wreck the game (like if the only new players or the only one who's played it before ends up as the sole Cylon).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
The face down cards plays plus the destiny deck make the game. It makes it easier to mess with the outcomes while pretending to be on everyone's side compared to a game like Shadows over Camelot. In Shadows it seems that mostly the way to play in secret as the traitor is to be a dead weight for the rest of the team. As soon as you tip your hand you can draw an accusation that comes out of turn.

In Battlestar you can poison the pot with bad cards and blame other people. You can tip your hand but not actually declare that you are Cylon and not have to give up the advantages of playing as a human. Other players have to take actions on their turn to stop you from being a threat and there's a turn order that you can exploit while doing so. So, it certainly makes it easier to play the traitor. But, it seemed that our game had a few easy jumps and the humans still lost, so I'm curious how easy it will be to win as the humans. Only time will tell.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
My first and original love affair with board games. Since I found I prefer euro games over thematic ones, but the theme on this one (BSG is one of my top 3 shows ever) give it a big plus. 

The base game alone is pretty much perfect, but I can't play it any more, due to the fact that there are 10 skill cards in the whole game, and I'm used to so much more.

The trick is: add the least amount possible from the expansions to get a great game.

Note: I have about 25+ more games of this I've played with this before boardgaming overtook my life, hence they are unlogged. I also have about 10 more games of this played on VASSAL. So really my playcount is in the forties, not the single digits.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Ebay.

Internal Dialogue for every game:

Before role assignment: "I want to be the cylon."
After role assignment: "I think everyone is a cylon but me...I hate cylons"
Remember there are more role assignments: "Maybe the cylon card is still out there after all, I want to be the cylon."
After 2nd role assignment: "I hate cylons."

There are a lot of games based on TV shows and Movies. Some are good games, some are neat because they remind you of the show. However BSG is a great game that actually captures the feeling of the series.

The mystery of who, if anyone, is sabotaging missions. The constant barrage of enemies attacking. Do we have the fuel to make it? Do we have the food/morale/population to make it? When do I make my move as the cylon?

Awesome.

I wish I could get it to the table more.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Loved the show, love the game.

RATING: 9
The first two games were really good, tension was high regarding both the anonymous cylon and whether or not the Galactica was going to reach Kobol. Really nice, one of the very best co-op -games with Space Alert and Pandemic. 

UPDATE: I'm having sooo much fun while playing this that I'm considering updating the rating to "10".

UPDATE: Ok, it's a 10. Played with 6 players and the game played just as good. We, people, we're so near to win but the cylons took it. The loss came with a bad dice roll but it tells a lot about the quality of the game when bad dice rolls don't bother me that much. This game is about the experience and interaction with other players, not so much about winning or losing. One of the very best games I've played.

UPDATE: Played it with Exodus expansion. Can't say I was completely taken by the new features. Cylon fleet adds a decent amount of tension to the proceedings but also takes away from leisure time which have been used to accuse others and play powerplay.Not bad by any means but I think Pegasus might be enough for me.

RATING: 8.5
It has a great sci-fi setting, a foreboding atmosphere, well-differentiated characters that are true to the show, a cohesive narrative, and, refreshingly for an FFG game, it's a fairly simple design that's easy to learn and teach.

I've liked Konieczka's previous designs that I've played, but often with some reservations.  He absolutely nailed this one out of the park.  An instant favourite.

The expansions, unfortunately over-complicate the game, so I now feel less comfortable taking it off the shelf.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5

Here it makes perfect sense. In some copycat games this mechanic also features and makes the game better, however it doesn't make thematic sense. Yeah, The Phantom League, I'm looking at you.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Hands down the best traitor game--beating Shadows Over Camelot (which it takes several aspects from) by no small margin.  The only thing that SoC has over BSG is the playing time.  However, and this is a huge however, the experience is head and shoulders better with BSG.  It can run a bit long, but this will mainly be due to a tremendous amount of interaction--a ton of game above the board.  This sacrifice is small when you factor in what you are doing in the game, and what playing it entails.  A rich experience all around, and one that places most of the emphasis on human (player) aspects and not on mechanical aspects.

RATING: 8

RATING: 8
Holy crap, I cannot say enough about this game.  First off, let's just get it out of the way... this is a long game.  You WILL be playing this for 3 hours, maybe even 4 if there's a lot of analysis paralysis at the table, or maybe only 2 hours if the humans are epicly terrible.  But I digress... This is one of my favorite games simply because of the player interaction.  Also, the theme is awesome and this game is pretty spot on with the show, and the expansions seem to only add cool (though likely unnecessary) stuff to the game.  I've only ever played 5-6 players, and it's always been awesome.

RATING: 9
From BGG Secret Santa 2012!

:star: implements the TV show theme excellently (and that show is one of the most awesome I've ever seen!)
:star: works with 5 players (though needs Daybreak for quality 6-player)
:star: traitor games are awesome
:star: the skill check mechanism is great here
:star: as is typical for FFG, high production quality
:star: the crisis cards are appropriately named and do a great job of sending the human fleet in a spiral of despair and failure

:nostar: not too easy to teach new people
:nostar: the pilot(-s) won't have a good time if all CACs are clumped together on the bottom of the deck
:nostar: the expansions don't mix particularly well

RATING: 10
3.1
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4.5
First Impression:

A very immersive game that trully delivers the experience. A most enjoyfull journey, at least initially. 
A good narrator significantly adds to the experience.

I seems to drag too long though. There are surprisingly few things to do each round, and the best option is usually obvious. You get to play your turn 2-3 times per hour, and despite the player interaction and the casual votings, that makes for a poor performance for what is essentially a deduction game with a great theme.

In short, bsg is a game of player interaction, deduction style, where the story of bs galactica unfolds, similar to what happened in the series. However, it clearly misses the sweetspot.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
This is my favorite board game of all time. It's the granddaddy of epic semi-cooperative board games. Some of my greatest experiences in gaming have been from this game. The only reasons I give it 9 instead of 10 are the length, the rules complexity, and the awkwardness of getting the "communication rules" right.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
It seems like a souped up better version of bang.  Trying to hide your desire to be destructive to the good team, without trying so hard you give it away.  This doesn't match my gaming tastes in the least, but this game doesn't transcend styles.  If this is your type of game, you will enjoy it, but if it is not.... well skip it.  The theme also does absolutely nothing for me as well.  Really, this game never really had a chance for me as all of its strengths are wasted on me.  Sometimes you just gotta play the other guys games.

There is probably 1 hour of decisions stretched out over the playing time.  Distilling the accusing and suspicion over 1 hour would be an amazing game design feat, I hope somebody accomplishes, but this design does not.

This rating assumes me being the admiral or president.  If one of those two roles are occupied by another player, this is probably a point lower.

RATING: 9
UPDATE: My rating of this game has slowly climbed from 5, to 6, to 7, and just now to 8.  I like it more with each play.  I also like it a lot more now that I've started watching the television show, so I understand the theme and characters.  This actually prompted me to start a thread and poll on this topic: http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/400654.  The paranoia and suspicion in this game is really excellent.  The game is still too long, but it's always memorable and enjoyable.  I'm looking forward to the expansion later this year. ----- Original Comment: I liked the paranoia that this game inspired in everyone with accusations flying about who was a traitor and people being jailed for acting too suspicious.  However, the game overstayed its welcome for me, lasting a few hours.  I also know nothing about the story and have never seen the show, so the characters and setting don't interest me.  Lastly, you really need a poker face to be able to play this, so if you're like me and everyone instantly knows whether you're a werewolf or a villager, then this game may not be for you.

Received as gift: July 20, 2009

RATING: 6
This game has some amazing mechanics that throw the room into a thrall of paranoia. What you are doing is very simple and would be boring if everyone wasn't at each others throats.

On that note, BSG is repetitive and tends to play longer than I have patience for most of the time (unless the cylons win before the final part of the game). It gets to the point where I don't really care who wins near the end because I just want the monotony to be over. It's not that the actual time is too long for the game to run, but it just gets incredibly repetitive after an hour or so.

RATING: 7.5
I like this game much more in my first dozen games.

Now, I don't know. I had one particularly bad game (however I know the responsible for this isn't the game, but one of the players), and some that, after the second jump I could see if the humans or the cylons have a fighting chance to win or if the game is already decided one way or another. Which isn't the coolest thing.

So, the rating that was a 8.5, dropped to 7.5.

****

Edit: I will still maintain the 7.5 rating, but after playing more times without expansions, a say this:

The base game is a 8.

The game with expansions: 7, or lower.

*****

Anyway, BSG was responsible for some amazing moments that got talked about to this day. Recently, it entered in a sort of "freeze" zone, as there are so much new stuff, and we played BSG sooooo much, that we mostly have a feel that we already gave the game its fair share. Still, when we have exactly 5 people to play, we are always thinking that we could be playing BSG. After 2010 I played [thing=41114][/thing] and [thing=128882][/thing], and both fell terrible flat with me. More than flat, actually, as I actively despise them. I still got the chills when I see someone saying the Resistance games take everything good of BSG and put it in a 30 minute game. No, they didn't. They lack the depth, the struggle, the stakes, the true feel of hopelessness and achievement either side can have.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3.5
Got as a gift. As expected, very poorly written, unindexed rulebook and very cluttered game. Lot's of things that could be done better, excessive use of cards (designer solution to problem that does not really exist). Figures are useless in the game, but also rubbish quality. Eons of downtime between player turns. Frequent deck reshuffling and incredibly repetitive game turns. 

Game is way too long for what it is (4h+ (Note: this is a timescale one can play Hannibal, ASL, Wilderness War, Successors and many other very rewarding games to conclusion and even have some spare time left)).

This game needs complete rule rewriting - or lacking that, comprehensive incorporated errata.
--
Too many games where resources run dry before anyone can do anything about it even without Cylon help (eg. discard X cards to prevent resource Y loss and player could not even theoretically have the necessary cards available). Happened way too many times now. Meh.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
The 32-page rulebook is scary at first, but after a few plays this game really shines as a wonderfully tense experience. It's best played with a group that already knows the game, and once you have that you have an intense experience with tough challenges, serious doubt, and tons of fun. Not for everyone, but awesome with the right group.

At first it seemed really biased toward the Cylons, but after dozens of plays it's closer to even with a slight leaning toward the Cylons. A fun fun challenge!

Unfortunately, there are certainly downsides. There can be significant downtime, especially with Allies from Exodus involved. There is no small amount of luck. It seems the humans have a very difficult time winning if two Cylons happen to be dealt from the start, and that's a purely random event. These keep it from going higher than an 8/10 for me.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
The central theme Battlestar Galactica of the Cylon players attempting to remain hidden to disrupt the humans efforts to stay alive and uncover the traitors makes the style of play a refreshing change from the resource management type of game.  Post game discussions are fascinating to find out from which point the cylon players were actually Cylons.  Were they Cylon from the begining or only half way through.  I've seen games where one cylon throws the other in the brig because he thought that player was a human.

Even not being a watcher of the show, I enjoyed it for a co-op sort of affair, but I can't see this being something I'd play one a week to week, or even month to month basis.

RATING: 6.5
11/14/10, Increasing rating after a 3rd play. I really enjoy this one. 

Based on 1 4 player game. Sympathizer went to cylon side. 

I found the early game with unrevealed cylons to be very fun and exciting.

The cylon player revealed shortly after the sympathizer came out and the second half of the game quickly became two humans versus 2 cylon players. I thought this second part of the game dragged a bit. I was human, but it seemed like being a revealed cylon was a pretty boring role.

BSG gets a special mention for outstanding integration of theme into mechanics. Almost all elements of theme get worked seamlessly into gameplay to create an immersive game experience. 

Finally, while long for a Euro, this is short for a FFG. Our game, with 1 new player, came in at 3 hours.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Battlestar Galactica: The Board Game is an exciting game of mistrust, intrigue, and the struggle for survival. Based on the epic and widely-acclaimed Sci Fi Channel series, Battlestar Galactica: The Board Game puts players in the role of one of ten of their favorite characters from the show. Each playable character has their own abilities and weaknesses, and must all work together in order for humanity to have any hope of survival. However, one or more players in every game secretly side with the Cylons. Players must attempt to expose the traitor while fuel shortages, food contaminations, and political unrest threatens to tear the fleet apart.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I adopted the rating system of James Fehrmeister, his username is fehrmeister. You can find an explanation of each criterion on http://www.boardgamegeek.com/geeklist/25077/11-attributes-i-research-on-games-i-want-to-try-an
James, thank you for your idea. 

RULES COMPLEXITY: :star::star::star::star::star:
there are many errata and many situations where it is not that clear how to proceed
STRATEGIC DEPTH: :star::star::star::star::star:
LUCK FACTOR: :star::star::halfstar::nostar::nostar:
NEGOTIATION FACTOR: :star::star::star::star::star: 
AMOUNT OF DOWNTIME: :star::star::nostar::nostar::nostar:
this depends a lot on how much one is communicating with the other players, discussing what would be the move which is in the best interest of the whole team; as this is a cooperative game I am very much into that; because of that I gave it just two stars which means I do not feel that much bored during another player's turn; sometimes other players, when it is their turn, do not like others to suggest anything; if this happens I am always wondering: is he/she maybe a Cylon? :)
FIDDLINESS: :star::star::star::star::star:
REPLAYABILITY: :star::star::star::star::star:
COMPONENT QUALITY: :star::star::star::star::halfstar:
PLAYER INTERACTION: :star::star::star::star::star:
TAKE THAT CONFLICT: :star::star::star::star::star:
MEANINGFUL THEME INTEGRATION: :star::star::star::star::star:

I simply adore this game! Particularly the paraonia issue, finding out who is a human and who is a Cylon. I love the theme, the choice to play different characters of the TV series, the cooperative part of the game and the tactical issues that one needs to take into consideration. 

SO SAY WE ALL! :)

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Simply epic with the right company.

Update April 2014: After about 6-7 more plays, each and every one undecided to the very last few turns, EPIC moments/paranoia (the brig gets used a lot after the sleeper phase),... This is just my favorite game, adding in the expansions soon for (even) more mayhem.

Update 2015: Still one of the greatest. Must say, with owning all the expansions, the most balanced version of the game is still the base game in itself. The expansions add some good things, and alternative endings, but the most balanced, tense gameplay tends to come from the base game alone.

Bluffing and observing skills are crucial in this game.

RATING: 9.5
This is a great example of a game that has transcended the simple genre categories of Ameritrash and Euro gaming.  The integration of theme is amazing, evoking the kind of panic and paranoia you see in the show beautifully, but the design is clean and streamlined, offering meaningful decisions every turn.  You will need a group that can handle the intensity of traitor mechanic, but if you have that kind of group this is about as good as gaming gets.

RATING: 8
Great game just dripping with theme. A very simple game maybe even simpler then Shadows over Camelot. It's the tense atmosphere the game creates that makes this game a solid 9/10. 

Just like the TV series that inspired the game paranoia runs rampant as everyone suspects everyone else of being a Cylon. It's a hard game to beat and the challenge keeps me returning.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.3
A truly different ameritrash. Seems to favor one side (Cylons) at first but as the players learn the game balances out. What makes it different is the team mechanics and there is even a great tweak of a possibility of switching from one team to the other during the game. Downside is the usual ameritrash randomness for example allowing almost certain winning combinations for cylons through lot. Those into new Galactica keep telling me that it is oozing with theme (I liked the personal goals that were introduced in some extension) but haven't bothered with the series so can't really tell. Still for anyone looking for a nice dramatic ameritrash that does something different (or for anyone looking a Galactica themed game) this could be an excellent pick.

RATING: 8
Sci fi themed boardgame.

Great game, especially with larger groups of players.  It's relatively quick to learn and has a lot of variety, and requires a lot of tough decisions.  The game also easily adapts to a co-op version (playable with any number of players upto six) with automated cylons.

Many of our games feel very close and victory is often not certain untill the very end.

RATING: 9
One of the most requested games in my collection.

Not only does it capture the feel of the TV series spectacularly, it is one of the most fun, frustrating, nail-biting, anger rising games my group plays.

If you are into team, bluffing, back-stabbing games, this is one to get.

It is a true team game, but for much of the time, you are never really sure which players are on which team.

RATING: 7.5

Lesson learned-  don't play cooperative role-playing space themed games with my dad (hard core republican conservative) and my brother (can't imagine him imagining he was someone else fighting evil.)

RATING: 6
I own this but don't recommend it, though some folks love it and praise it highly. Here's why I have problems with it: it takes forever (the game can last hours) and there's a lot to learn to start playing. There are two many shorter 'fixed' Werewolf-like games out there for me to play this long one. In this genre, I prefer One Night Ultimate Werewolf, Resistance/Avalon, Coup, or Are You the Traitor? to this game, and I don't feel trapped into a long boring game I don't want to quit out of respect of teammates. I actually plan to trade my copy to someone with something more interesting.

RATING: 6.5
I love how much this game invokes the spirit and feel of the show.  The actions you take on your turn always feel a bit dull to me, it's usually just grabbing a card or rolling a die.  Everything in the game feels punishing.  I really enjoy the central mechanism of choosing to use cards for their actions or to succeed goals.  Love traitor mechanisms.  In the end though... I dunno, the game just drags a bit.  Player turns feel too long.  If you're not a Cylon, there's that co-op feel of just getting repeatedly slapped down.   Still enjoy it, but not as much as I wish I did.

Really just the length of the game, and the drag of waiting for your turn knock this down quite a bit.  I wish that turns could go quicker and not lose that epic feeling of the game.  As it is, I'm always hesitant to play.

UPDATE: I'm found this less enjoyable the second time. The game is bland as a cooperative game, and the traitor element is only as good as the people playing the traitors.

RATING: 3
Rating after one play: but why so bad?
The game offers some few good aspects: like discovering that you are a traitor midway in the game. That said, why do I rate it bad?

Because it takes really long, is not streamlined at all and very repetitive. Pretending to have so much action by all those cards: but wait... 2 different cards of every color. Some action spaces have nearly no use at all while others are tremendous important.

You may end up losing the game as novices without knowing where you did lose it. Maybe you've lost it 1-2 hours before you realise i and just have to play so long to just realise you could gibr up.
Main element of the game: jumoing. Jumoing gets you away from the cylon ships while gets you nearer vicrots. Influence to jumping: few.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
I tell everyone that I do not like cooperative games, but with one major exception: Battlestar Galactica.  In this game, every player needs to think for themselves, and determine who has which motives.  The voting for outcomes (done on 85% of all event cards) is a really simple but great mechanic.  When the votes are tallied, you can see the colors of the cards that were thrown in as negative votes.  With deductive reasoning, you can often figure out who the cylons are from this information, and this is really the best part of the game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
A coop game with traitors mechanics. It is one of the best game-theme combinations I have seen in games. Full of situations where you need to deal with a crisis while trying to find the traitors and deal them. One of the best for me in it's genre, can be quite stressful sometimes but a very rewarding experience.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I wasn't impressed. The game was far to long for what it offered. There was too much downtime. The interesting mechanic: the cooperation and possible traitor, can be gotten in Shadows over Camelot with less hassle.

Edit: I've really come around regarding this game. If you have just one person who knows the rules down pat, then the game can move along pretty quickly. It provides a much deeper experience than Shadows and is more thematic. Giving a big ratings bump from 5 to 7.

RATING: 9
Not a fan of the show, haven't seen a single episode, but this one game is probably my gaming groups favorite way to spend an afternoon.

The mechanics are simple, and it is repeptitive, but if you can get into the game and the hidden traitor roles, it is a blast. People who say it lasts too long are just not playing it right. Yes, that is an elitest statement that won't apply to everyone, but this is a game to be experienced - not played.

One of the top five games to come out in the last five years - no contest.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
One of the richest thematic experiences ever, though I am suffering severe burnout as I pass the 10 play mark.  I knew nothing about the series when I played this the first time, but was enamored of it anyway.  Now that I've  seen the show, I see that this game does an excellent job reflecting the paranoia of the first two seasons.

I did fear that this would be a rehash of [gameid=15062], but it manages to keep the accusation and double-talk while eliminating some of the problems.  It is easier to secretly sabotage in BSG without giving away who you are, a glaring weakness in Shadows after a few plays.  It does have one weakness, which is that the tenseness can sometimes drop too low if the Crisis deck spits out an odd mixture of cards.  The game is better when there's ships around the board to keep plenty of juicy decisions.  Play with the battle board from the [url=http://boardgamegeek.com/boardgameexpansion/85905/battlestar-galactica-exodus-expansion]Exodus expansion[/url] for best results.

RATING: 7
Il gioco prende parecchio se si è fan della serie: la meccanica per cui chi prima è umano nella seconda parte della partita può essere Cylon potrebbe stonare in un gioco se non che qui si sposa benissimo con il tema del film. quindi c'è sempre cautela all'inizio da parte di tutti a non fare troppo bene.
La alea è ridotta, certo le carte sono pescate casualmente (e si può considerare la variante di mettere 1 carta flotta cylon ogni 10 crisi se non si vogliono sorprese) ma in questo modo si assapora il timing delle puntate, alcune frenetiche altre molto politiche a parlare. e in ogni caso il gioco si basa su questo mazzo di eventi di crisi, lo dice il nome stesso ogni carta è un ostacolo da affrontare non ci sono carte buone quindi + che un difetto l'alea qui è parte del gioco per dare origine a partite sempre diverse. Non lo trovo ripetitivo causa anche il gruppo che cambia ogni volta.
La lunghezza è giusta per dare spazio a tutte le varie sfaccettature di venire fuori, consiglio di dare il ruolo di Presidente al giocatore + esperto in quanto le carte Quorum sono molto difficili da gestire per i neofiti.

RATING: 7

Amikor éppen nem űrcsatázol, akkor javítod a  hajót, különböző kríziseket oldasz meg, majd egyszercsak rádfogja valaki, hogy áruló vagy és már be is csapták mögötted a börtönajtót... aztán a játék felénél újabb hűségkártyát kapsz, kiderül, hogy alvó ügynök vagy, és azt kívánod, bárcsak tényleg szabotáltad volna a munkát. Fantasztikus játék, de csak komoly érdeklődőknek! Vigyázat... 3-4 óra is benne lehet, ha sok a trash-talk! :)

RATING: 6
It shouldn't be fun. Every turn is like having an executive team meeting at work,with all the attendant stress and egos and alpha male posturing.
But it is fun.Maybe because i am a fan of the show. I think its genius that there are no good decisions to be made in the game,that every act every character makes screams 'Cylon!' to the rest of the group. The game really is an exercise in social interaction,and providing your group has the mental accuity to survive the paranoid backbiting and distrust inherent in the system(it is all a game,after all)then this is probably the best traitor-in-our-midst game out there,bar none.

RATING: 9
На самом деле в нее можно играть и вдвоем. Одному не пробовал.

Тема имеет для меня большое значение, а Галактика мне многим понравилась. Но и помимо темы, механика тоже не подводит.

Может конечно не понравиться что идут постоянные голосования - почти каждый ход, но с другой стороны в отличии от Камелота, намного сильнее ощущается, что испытания проходятся совместно.

----

Я понемногу смотрю что лежит в дополнении Пегас и кажется понимаю в чем недостаток Галактики.

Игра без дополнения - это только отрезок до Кобола. Игра с дополнением - это только от встречи с Пегасом до спасения с Каприки. Нет способа сыграть так, чтобы встретить Пегаса в пути. Не говоря о том, чтобы пролететь всю дорогу до самой Земли, на которой Пегас и Каприка лишь возможная альтернатива.

Игра построена так, что люди все время теряют, теряют и теряют. Вопрос лишь в том, сумеют ли они растянуть ресурсы до конца пути. Если же сравнивать с фильмом, то например воду и тилиум можно было потерять почти полностью, а затем полностью их восполнить. В игре же тенденция только к потерям, лишь изредка можно найти какую-то мелочь.

Получается что с атмосфера фильма передана лишь примерно наполовину (хотя это тоже приличное достижение). Также есть ряд неточностей, например: Галактика может атаковать только базовые корабли, Шэрон играет как пилот вайпера, а не раптора, у Розлин не просто видения - она может выбирать чему не произойти.

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Even though I can't imagine playing BSG with no expansions any longer (they just add so much content and interaction!), and the base game seems too easy now (it definitely wasn't at first though, but my group really mastered it, and we played a LOT).. it still is probably the best board game I ever encountered for a few simple reasons:
- Little to no downtime: even if it's other player's turn, people talk about strategies, use skills, participate in events etc., everyone's engaged pretty much all the time.
- Lots of interaction: you play as a group, but everyone has their own skills, special abilities and places where they shine. So everyone thinks not only about themselves, but also about how others can contribute.
- Traitor mechanic done right: you deal with a general Cylon threat, but also with a traitor among you. It's a gameplay AND narrative mechanic (people discussing character's actions, trying to find who's secretly trolling etc.)
- Every game is different. We've played probably more than 100 games, and almost all the time many hilarious things happened we never thought were possible.

The game takes a lot of time (sometimes even around 7 hours), but is completely worth it. It's both strategic and narrative, and engaging all the time.

One negative is perhaps that it's most appealing to people who watched the show. However the TV series are really good (even if we're not die hard fans), and we introduced the game to people who've never watched it, and they still enjoy the gameplay a lot (but I imagine it would be hard to get into the game if no one in your group has ever seen the series).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
There is a lot to like here. Very tense game. My main complaint is that combat is fiddly. Moving plastic ships around and sticking damage tokens etc starts getting tiresome. Other than that, this is a pretty solid game.

RATING: N/A
After the Cylon attack on the Colonies, the battered remnants of the human race are on the run, constantly searching for the next signpost on the road to Earth. They face the threat of Cylon attack from without, and treachery and crisis from within. Humanity must work together if they are to have any hope of survival…but how can they, when any of them may, in fact, be a Cylon agent?
\13\\13\
Battlestar Galactica: The Board Game is an exciting game of mistrust, intrigue, and the struggle for survival. Based on the epic and widely-acclaimed new Sci Fi Channel series, Battlestar Galactica: The Board Game puts players in the role of one of ten of their favorite characters from the show. Each playable character has their own abilities and weaknesses, and must all work together in order for humanity to have any hope of survival. However, one or more players in every game secretly side with the Cylons. Players must attempt to expose the traitor while fuel shortages, food contaminations, and political unrest threatens to tear the fleet apart.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
This game, as shipped, is broken. Some of the expansions alleviate this to some extent, but this hunk of krufty game mechanics just isn't fun enough to justify spending more money on top of the initial buy-in.

Some problems:

- Awful communication rules. If I start saying “I can help a WHOLE LOT” every time I’m going to give a 5 as a card, is that cheating? Answer: who the fuck knows.

- Terrible player scaling. For one thing, Battlestar Galactica's "sympathetic cylon" for odd numbers of players is ughhhh. The basic idea was that if humans were far ahead at the midway point, the sympathetic cylon was a real cylon, but if the humans were doing poorly, the sympathetic cylon was on the human side. This was pretty horrible, because whichever side got the sympathetic cylon probably won. So cylons suddenly wanted humans to do well for the first half, while humans actively tried to sabotage themselves. It was weird bizarro land play that went completely against the goals of the game. Also with too few players the witchhunt dynamics sort of fall apart and don't make for a compelling game. I think the game is most playable with exactly 6 players, and pretty awful for every other player count.

- Game length. I don't understand why a game of this depth deserves 6 hours of my time for one playthrough.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A brilliant game design that captures all of the intensity and paranoia of the first two seasons of Battlestar Galactica. Something memorable happens almost every time we play it, but unlike a lot of diplomacy games this one manages not to feel mean. You expect a cylon to turn on you or for your character to be falsely imprisoned at some point, so no one tends to take it personally when it happens. The character roles are well done, both in reflecting the actual character on the show and in influencing decisions that add to the air of distrust. Just an amazing game.

I have only one caveat. I get the feeling that if the game is played too often with the same people, a lot of the suspense will break down. When people start to learn the tendencies of the other players and begin experiencing the same debates over and over, the game's fun factor will probably start to drop off. Limit your plays to every other month or so and you will be able to enjoy one of the best gaming experiences out there.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
TBog

RATING: 6
This is still the best game I've played of its type - I love the tension, the bluffing, the wild accusations, and especially that there's something to do (unlike stuff like Werewolf or The Resistance). It can sometimes run longer than it is interesting, and the random bits can totally screw over people or teams in some games, but the biggest problem I've had lately is finding the nihilism in the game's atmosphere to be oppressive. The theme is really dark, especially if you read the flavor text on the crisis cards, and that really puts a damper on the fun for me at this point in my life.

[microbadge=9814] [i]PBF moderator:[/i] 1

[b]PBF hall of fame moments[b]
- [url=https://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/1669249/bsg-v142-election-gaius-baltar]V142[/url], Pristine above & beyond all around masterpiece of a game
- [url=https://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/1703880/bsg-v145-here-we-go-again]V145[/url], Pristine above & beyond all around masterpiece of a game
- [url=https://www.boardgamegeek.com/article/25868911#25868911]One of the best very tense situation...[/url]

Above, are the situations I live to play in in a BSG game. Nothing but the best memorable moments that I'll remember forever

[b] Some highlights:[/b]
- 200th game played (completed) on 08-11-16 on the BGG forums... [url=https://boardgamegeek.com/thread/1542676/bsg-v136a-cylon-bucket-lists/page/1](V136A)[/url]
A very interesting variant where all players had cylon motives to complete and were winning according to the motives only

- I played my [b][u]100th game[/u][/b] (taking into account that i currently play 10 pbf games) on 09-16-12 at the GmG event: Fall-loha in Burlington Vermont USA, a crushing win for the cylon in a one sided game. I was cylon from the start and just sat and watched the humans destroying themselves to put the finishing touch at the end

- Was once shot at +29 with the Admiral's quarter / Cain's ability on the very first turn without even having played a turn or having the chance to make a move, do something... talk about trusting friends :) (I was a cylon though! But really did nothing as it was on the first player turn and i was second!!!)

- Once played Cally who ended up being Admiral, President & CAG at the same time!

- Most BSG games played in a year: 61 (2012)

- Most play by forum [url=http://boardgamegeek.com/wiki/page/BSG_PBF](PBF)[/url] BSG games played at the same time: 13

- [url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/775178/bsg-v25-character-flaw/page/1]BSG-PBF: V25[/url] was the most brutal game i ever played... I have never seen a game going so one sided at a point that it became very boring in the end. 100% flawless, ultra perfect game for the cylon side after sleeper phase.

- All in! -Carlo (June 23rd 2012 / 1st meeting of the Variant regulars on Vassal)

RATING: 8
The varied characters and ability cards make it possible for everyone to have an important role in defending against the robotic Cylon traitor hiding among the crew - or giving the Cylon an extra edge in ending the Galactica's voyage.

RATING: 8

Exactly what I would write for Game of Thrones and TI3; FFG sticking hard to the 80/20 rule, which makes sense for a company with "staff designers" and a tight production schedule.
-----------
Update: Sure enough, Pegasus on the horizon. And that's cool, but I feel milked.  Moo.
-----------
I like it, but it has some rough edges. It should be shorter and denser. Too much time is lost in uninteresting things. There's plenty of mechanical clutter: why not add another subsystem or two to give more interesting options during Cylon downtime (when no basestar is present)?  My gut feel is that an expansion is already basically done, so some stuff was pared from this, and it shows.

Still, loads to like here if you go for the whole premise, and I do.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Battlestar Galactica is a ton of fun and I love it to death, but it's not without a few flaws that keep me from placing it in the pantheon just yet. 

First, it's a bit too long.  I know the ATers out there poo poo knocks on game length, but I don't think anyone can claim that being a revealed Cylon for three hours is fun.  Even as a human, some players seem to think it's a bit too long for what it is.  The bottom line is that this game would hit the table every game night if it came in at 90 minutes.  Unfortunately, it's twice that.

Second, some games just aren't as exciting as others.  When the Cylon fleet is bearing down on Galactica, this game is absolutely as fun as gaming gets.  Everybody has something to do and every move feels vitally important.  Two or three jumps in a row with no Cylons?  Not so much.

All that said, I love this game and would play it any time.  Also, since it's from FFG we can expect some expansions.  They are probably unlikely to address the time issue, but I'm almost positive they'll address the lulls-in-action issue, which should make it even more awesome.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: N/A
WARG
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Part of a bulk online order!

Excellent theme - much better fit than Shadows,  although suffers a bit from the standard fiddly extra mechanics from FFG.  I didn't really consider most locations,  what with flying around outside Galactica (now feels quite inefficient).  

Luck factor seems very high - you're juggling a whole bunch of resources,  and they're being depleted completely at random.  You have a lot of choices,  but most of the time there are pretty obvious things to do - mostly tactical optimizations.  You go through stretches where nothing's going on,  and stretches when there are enemies everywhere.  There's no real strategic planning since you can't guess what the next crisis will be.  Maybe if you could see the next 5 crises you could plan or somesuch,  but then you're in AP/coop driver land...

Main problem is that there aren't that many interesting decisions vs the time it takes - you are pretty much spinning your wheels waiting for the jump drive to spin up to go.  The rest of the game is trying to figure out who the Cylon is/are - once that's figured out,  it's both great - you can make slightly better plans - but bad because it devolves a bit into a pretty random puzzle.  It would almost be more interesting to have Cylons become "robot controlled" players,  and have the player throw his original loyalty cards into the remaining pool and draw a new loyalty card and character card.  Of course,  maybe Cylon reveals would happen every jump rather than voluntarily or would be forced by the brig or somesuch...

Ah yes,  rolling dice to destroy things.  Definitely not a fan.  More random busywork.

Regardless,  my feeling is there's a (very good) 60 minute game trapped in a 3 hour shell here :) The scifi (and BSG) fanboy in me would probably enjoy the current game anyways,  but it's far from a perfect design in my eyes.  It's better than Shadows but solves none of that game's problems.

The bits are very nice.  Solid quality cardboard.  Skill cards are a bit small (the minicard size),  crisis cards are normal sized.

A bit mixed bag in my mind - I like the theme more the Shadows,  but coming off Space Alert it might be potentially a good chunk too long. Then again, this seems to have a working traitors mechanic,  although whether the actions equate to more than spinning wheels in samey-ness will have to be resolved...

Mixed reviews so far - some people say the theme is spot-on and the action is good,  whereas others have reservations about long playtime and lack of interesting things to do (being stuck in the brig,  initial Cylons are the only threat...)

RATING: 7
Not a bad game at all, but no one did any streamlining job on this one. It feels like FFG just kept piling up rules upon rules until they thought it was close enough to the actual series to be considered finished.

I really dislike the little exception here and there in the rules that add nothing to the gameplay but make the game more "realistic" as far as the show is concerned. (The Agathon player not being allowed to play during the first turn because, in the series, Agathon starts out stranded on Caprica? Give me a break.)

In the end the game is long and fiddly, with a lot of downtime for everyone involved (*especially* a revealed Cylon). So while it can still be an enjoyable experience with the right crowd, I wouldn't play this one more than a couple times a year.

RATING: 9.5
This game is so much fun to play.

The journey through space to reach human salvation is very fun with everyone in the group helping each other to make decisions, contribute to skill checks, keeping resources high, and surviving the cyclon attacks.

I got to play as a cyclon and won my game as one, the victory is so tasty as destiny was essentially giving me the final chance to strike the humans and end them and the game. The face of shock when everyone thought I was a human is so great.

Highly recommend this game if you enjoy coop games with a traitor element involved. 
The flaws with the base game is bad crisis card shuffle which can cause a very horrible start for the group as I experienced in the first game where we were just bombarded by constant cyclon attacks. The other unfortunate part of the game is Battlestar galactica takes a long time to play, and my group's 2nd attempt after the first took around 3 hours. We couldn't get another game in.

But I still very much loved playing this game and would play it again.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
F.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5.5
The positives:

The game now clocks in at 2.5 hours.  That's a good thing.  I'm also impressed with the mechanics of the traitor system, and the brig shenanigans can be fun.

The negatives:

Player actions seem to be relatively obvious. Moreover, the default action seems to be "Executive Order" if you have the card available.

Being tossed into the brig can be a game-killing event for the victimized players.

Finally, compared to other co-ops, the one thing that BSG lacks - accusations aside - is in-depth discussion.  There are three reasons for this:

1. Any player can perform any action (due to unlimited mobility in the ship), and so there is rarely a pressing need for the group to discuss whether actions A and B needed to be accomplished by turn x - since the actions can be performed at any time by nearly any player.

2. Players have no idea what the impending crisis will be on a given turn (crises are randomly drawn), so players can't collectively plan ahead in terms of using/holding skill cards.

3. The skill cards available to each player are a matter of public knowledge.  Consequently, it is fairly obvious whether particular players can pitch in to avert a crisis.  The net result is that not much talk is needed to figure out who can help and who can't.

All of this leads me to believe that the crisis aspect of the game could have used some additional fine-tuning.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Much better than expected. The cylon (traitor) players have more to do than in Shadows over Camelot. Several different actions are available each turn so you can play your own character. The theme is good enough.

RATING: 10
[color=red]Secret [-]Santa[/-] [i]Cylon[/i] 2008 gift[/color] (thank you!)

Frakkin' fantastic game in just about every possible way.  I'm not even going to bother describing it because if you don't already know what this game is about you owe it to yourself to go find out.  Do it.  DO IT NOW!

There are very few games where I will automatically buy every expansion that comes out, but this is one of them.  Daybreak is likely to be the last, and I have it, so the game is now complete.

Shame I so rarely ever get to actually PLAY it, but when it actually hits the table it's pure awesome.

RATING: 6.28
That game has been poured into theme and is a must-have for any new-BSG fan. The quality of the components is high, on par with FFG's best productions. However more miniatures come with the extensions, which makes the whole game a bit nicer to look at.
Game mechanics are on the easy side as the essence of the game lies within the interaction between players in order to find the cylon. That makes solo play a lot frustrating since there is not much chrome to enjoy.
I also guess that hardcore fans of the series must have a blast roleplaying their character.

RATING: 7
This is a fun semi-cooperative game.  It builds well, and somewhat deceptively.  This is the 1st game I have ever played with a "traitor" aspect (not counting red november because that is very different)  I really enjoyed the acusations and the paranoia having a potential traitor instilled. =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Didn't like this game.  I think it could be good, but there were a few things that really bothered me. First and foremost, I feel like the decks could use a bit of variety.  There were cards worth 2, 3, 4+ points in a skill check ... but they all had exactly the same effect. I found that rather repetitive. The in-ship combat was ok, using just a single die to resolve, but if you were on the wrong side of the Galactica, it took too many turns to get in position to do anything.  I'm hoping that was an overlooked rule (was taught at game night without reading the rules myself), but the repetitiveness of the cards turned me away from this one.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
*
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
{ P - 2 3 4 5 [6] [7] }

In Arkham Horror, the investigators are fighting an uphill (possibly unwinnable) battle if the mythos deck is too hostile, and the same concept applies to BSG, except here the deck's degree of brutality directly benefits one of the teams. The flagship example of this was a game I played where the beginning was perfect - no discernable Cylon, morale in red - and then the second half completely went to shreds as nearly every new draw deposited enemy cruisers around the Galactica and two power outages forestalled the humans from jumping away from them. Amusingly, the Cylon from round one was dealt the second Cylon card and gave it to me after the humans were already seeing the writing on the wall, arbitrarily handing me a share of the victory when it was technically unnecessary.

Another problem is that the Cylons have little wiggle room, especially in the first half; considering the game state, there's always an optimum play that a given player should perform, and if he doesn't it's logical to conclude he's the Cylon. Skill checks that matter are usually Senate Hearing Committee'd, and it's not particularly difficult to deduce a Cylon throwing negative cards on skill checks by remembering who contributed and who didn't and which destiny deck cards have already passed. I've never played as Cylon before but it seems the only real way to hinder the humans is lucksack into Senate Committees and Execute Orders, then hold them the entire game.

Characters are typically boring as well; other than the flavor and special ability they're just card drawing machines, and you can expect to perform one function the entire game, usually three hours. (My second game I played Execute Orders on people well over 50% of my turns, and President typically does the same thing with Quorum cards.)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Played it once, which isn't nearly enough for a game like this. For me it's difficult to find players who like to play this game. So that's the main problem. The impression i got so far is good. It has very interesting elements and if everyone enjoys playing it, is willing to take their role seriously, i'm sure this game could be epic. But the "battlefield" around the ship didn't really got to me and looked a bit messy in mechanics, but maybe we did some things wrong. The, "oh, there they come, we have to jump", then jump and start all over and repeating business of paying the cards to prevent disasters from happening seems a bit repetitive to me. But again, i should play it more to really understand all the details and game mechanics for what it really is. 

I wonder if this game should take so long though ... but that's only an issue if it's not so fun to play.

RATING: 10
Wow, This game is so much more than the rules. =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
Not very good.  It's just not.  If you get dealt the cylon card you'll be bored silly, as you'll either be in jail and doing nothing, or revealed and doing little to nothing, with no real decisions or strategy to plan.

Furthermore, revealing as a cylon is a sure win for the cylons, so it doesnt make sense to not reveal.  Then you sit in the corner with nothing much to do, and the human players fight a game they will never win, making repetitive decisions that have little meaning.

All this takes 4 to 5 hours! Ugg.

The only drama is to drag out the who is the cylon by not revealing, and that's nearly impossible to accomplish.  The human players quickly break the rules in dropping hints that are nearly out and out cheating in telling thier loyalty, so unless you're a professional actor, the whole thing just doesnt work.  And when the traitor dynamic breaks apart, the game is left with nothing redeeming.

Really, skip it.

RATING: 7
(Trade Interest: medium) haven't really reached a full conclusion on this one yet.  it's kind of fun to be guessing who the cylon is.  assusation fly, and the slightest hitch in play of cards can send you down the wrong path.  it's pretty difficult to win, especially if you get a bad run of cards.  Fuel seems to be one you NEVER want to waste, since it is required for almost every single jump card.

on further plays, i think the game lasts too long, and doesn't hold interest, and not sure if anyone would be devoted enough to get good enough to make the game shorter.  too bad.  i really like the theme.

RATING: N/A
7 after 1 play.

Numerous fiddly rules, presumably to recreate various features of the TV show, though the game is essentially about betrayal and spies. Other semi-cooperative games probably recreate the main mechanic well without so many fiddly bits. The sympathiser mechanic is well-designed as it acts as a balancer between the humans and cylon factions.

Having said the above, I can understand why it is well-liked by fans of the TV show or science fiction.

太空堡垒卡拉狄加，巨无聊
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
The only game I have that's been a hit with virtually everyone I've ever presented it to, except for one stick in the mud who thought it took too long, BSG is a cooperative game with a twist...one or more players are secretly working against everyone else, which gives this a "poker" factor involving the human element that makes every game unique depending on who's playing. It perfectly captures the concept of the show as well, especially the tension of wondering when the cylons are going to suddenly "jump" in from out of nowwhere to attack the fleet. Seriously, can't stress it enough...out of the the twenty or so people who've I've taught the game to, and these aren't "game" people for the most part, nearly ALL of them won't stop talking about the game for days afterward. A must buy.

RATING: 10
Fantastic game, if you're a fan of Battlestar Galactica the TV show, then you'll love this for sure! It perfectly captures the feel of the show, both in the paranoia, and how you're desperately trying to keep one step ahead of the Cylons. Very good game, and hidden traitor games is something I enjoy overall.

I'm also quite happy about the game being deep, and involved enough to be fun mechanically, so it's not just living purely on its theme. The constant player interaction is top notch. You are constantly involved, and interested in every aspect of the game. I don't even understand the people who complain about this game's downtime?! This is one of my all-time favorites.

RATING: 6.5
Thematic and wonderfully produced.  Although Battlestar Galactica introduced some interesting mechanics into its gameplay, ultimately the experience was far too long for what it is.

Obviously the most recognized aspect of BSG is the traitor and the sleeper agent phase, where former teammates could become the cylon everyone have been working to fight off.  To distribute the loyalty cards a second time midway through the game is a brilliant way to shake things up.  Furthermore, I really do like how skill checks are performed.  It allows for subtle sabotage without giving away one's identity, which is often a critique against Shadows Over Camelot.

Unfortunately, there is just way too much downtime, and as much as I love playing with the full complement in a co-op game, every single turn seem to take forever to complete.  Add to that the lack of variety in skill cards; the numerous die rolls involved when activating raiders, especially if you are besieged by too many; as well as how long it takes to resolve each crisis, the game just drags after the initial newness wears off.  With that said, I don't see myself playing this very often.  Good effort, but not destined to be a favorite or a classic.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
One of my favorite games.  Just really enjoy the co-op with traitor element in this one.  I also really enjoyed the show so the theme is really good for me.  I play a lot of Play By Forum but I do not record those on here.  I've played at least 10 PBF games by now.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
The king of traitor games. No other game does traitoring as well as BSG. The base game is almost flawless out of the box. The Pegasus expansion adds even more options for dealing with cylons (and for cylons to do dirt). The other expansions don't add that much. For the best experience use the Defcon variant to keep Cylon attacks from coming too often or too seldom. The only thing that keeps this from being a masterpiece is that it takes a little tweaking to balance the Crisis deck and Super Crisis Cards.

Once uncovered as a Cylon your decision making drastically goes down to a scripted choice.  I do not like Battlestar for its theme, or because of hidden bad guys, but because it simply takes too long and its not something I want to play again.

RATING: 5
2009-05-11: [b][bgcolor=#ff66cc] 4.5 [/bgcolor][/b] It think the game implements the show really well, but the downtime is a killer.  That, and even when we had three basestars and wads of raiders threatening a throng of civilians, I didn't really feel any tension:  The FTL was pretty much ready to go, and we popped out from under them.  It emulated the show beautifully, except I was not nervous whatsoever.  I blame this on myself, though:  I think I've lost the emotional investment in collaborative games.  Fortunately, excellent company makes up for my lack of engagement by the game, so I can be talked into it by sufficiently charming people....

I really appreciated the card mechanism to allow subversive play.  It was reminiscent of [gameid=8671] (another mostly-collaborative game) combined with the undercover cop variant for [gameid=19237], in that the group contributes cards to overcome a crisis ([gameid=8671]), with the temptation to hold on to cards for personal gain ([gameid=8671] again), but the subversion happens in a probably secretive way, such that the moles can keep tunneling.... ([gameid=19237])  The excellent thing that [gameid=37111] adds is a pair of fate cards, allowing cylons to gamble and undermine the effort with a chance of not even letting anyone know there is any subversion whatsoever.  Countering that is the ability to force card play to be face-up for a crisis.

Again, as I said about [gameid=30549], I think anybody with any affinity for collaborative games, but (in this case) who can slot up to four hours of playtime will love this game.  If you enjoyed the show, you will probably enjoy the game that much more.

2010-12-29: [b][bgcolor=#cc99ff] 5 [/bgcolor][/b] As you slog through this, it gets a bit more tolerable, and can get a little engrossing.  Still not my cup of tea, but I [b]can[/b] be convinced, when I have nothing better to do for four hours.  Yes, sure, once everyone's played it many times, you can squirt it out in two hours.  While that's a much more acceptable timeframe, I hope I never get enough experience for that.  ;)

RATING: 9
The base game is really cool, and so faithful to the show that it can even increase enjoyment of the show, as well as the other way around. 

The hidden traitor mechanic as well as the constant crises make for a tense game most of the time. Even when the humans are doing amazing and no resources in the red when you get to sleeper phase, the game can turn on a dime and victory is never assured.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
The desperate struggle of the last remnants of humankind against the overwhelming Cylon attacks - and their own, inner demons - feels just as breathtaking as in the television series. On its best with players who have watched through the whole show. Every victory for humankind is hard-earned indeed, and always tight. Very rewarding for the Cylons, too. Playing out all the suspicions and paranoia regarding Cylon infiltrators is essential - without it, the game would be underwhelming. The question is not if you're too paranoid - it's if you're paranoid *enough*. After all, even the cat in the house *could* be a Cylon infiltrator!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Besides creating the atmosphere of the series alive, this is the best game of 2008 and probably one of the best games I've played.

RATING: 6
PROS: Great game. Thematically accurate to TV series and still tactically sound. Very interactive, minimal down-time as you are constantly watching each others moves and listening for clues that suggest the truth of player loyalties, Very easy to learn for anyone who wants to learn it (usually mastered within 3-4 game rounds). Very much non-stop action. 

CONS: Needs minimum 3 players, NOT recommended for heavily competitive players or bullies (i.e.: people who enjoy making their colleges suffer)

RATING: 8.5
Wow, the tension in this game is high and it just increases with each turn. As soon as the first mission fails, name calling and paranoia starts to spread over the table.

The end of the game will either be the bad guys winning or the good guys winning by an incredibly small margin. 

Aside from a small problem of occasional Analysis Paralysis, the game is really enjoyable. You'll see the time fly with this one.

RATING: 5
After 1 Play: Just isn't my type of game.  Some people really get into the story, but if you're looking for interesting mechanics and decisions, I'd suggest you look elsewhere.  From my experience, luck is far more of a factor in determining the outcome than either skillful play or correctly identifying the cylons.  In my one and only game, there was only one cylon in the beginning, but as he was a new player he didn't really know how to subvert the humans without revealing himself.  The humans were doing nearly perfect when I became the other cylon halfway through.  Still, one well timed betrayal and a couple crippling cards in a row turned that great start into defeat.

RATING: 5
This is one of those games, I wish I would like - but somehow I can´t. It is not a bad game and it really feels like reliving the tv-show, which in itself might be enough for some people to love this game, but... BUT it doesn´t get me hooked at all. And I think there are quite some reasons - the 3 major ones for me:
1.) It doesn´t really feel necessary to uncover the Z, since the damage potential seems almost higher when acting openly against the humans. 
2.) I often have the feeling of being played by the game instead of playing/deciding myself, since the combination of upcomming crysis on the one hand and my special role/power often leave just one good course of action.
3.) Lack of a climax. Jumping for the last and final time is not much different from the very first jump - or the third or fourth for that matter. For me, it lacks the sense of achievemet or final showdown.

RATING: 8
Played once, a long time ago. The game's great fun, but I can see the enjoyment of it depending heavily on the group. So, with a group of heavy thinkers who care only about mechanics, subtract a point. Scratch that, take two or three. In a group laden with roleplay and a focus on atmosphere, add a point.

The group I played with was in the middle of the two extremes, and the game played very well, with lots of paranoia going on - which is lovely.

Edit: Played some more. Would be up for a game of this almost anytime, but my initial thoughts held true.

RATING: 7
Some interesting mechanics, and fun to get into the roles; as always the unknown betrayer element builds some nice tension. However, the pacing of the events can be really uneven, and in the case of Cylon ship attacks things always seem to reset with the jump just at it's getting interesting. In the best case scenario that is; often nothing really builds up at all, and the event cards get a little lack-luster after a while. Biggest flaw, however, is the length of the game, needs to be an hour shorter at least.

UPDATE: The Cylon fleet expansion seems to go a long way towards fixing the pacing issues of the fleet cards in the original deck. Played with other expansions but none feel as essential, although if you like the game most are worth trying out; just don't play with everything together. Still too long, unless one side plays poorly or gets incredibly unlucky.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
Back in the day, I played this game quite a bit and it may have even been my favorite. There was nothing like it that blended a thematic strategy game with traitor mechanics (at least that I'd played). Nowadays, this has gotten shelved for Dead of Winter since it's not as finicky about player counts and nobody cares about the show/theme anymore. Personally, I preferred the fact that we *knew* there were traitors somewhere once we passed the halfway point, which pushed us to point fingers at each other over every action, every twitch, every smile. In Dead of Winter, we look around the table anxiously, but it feels like a coop game first with a phenomenal traitor element smuggled in. Battlestar Galactica puts the traitor element in the front of everyone's mind, with some co-op mechanics involving blowing up frakkin' cylons and firing up the FTL to back it up.

Anyway yes this game is exceptional... with exactly 5 players. The expansions do improve upon the awful, non-thematic cylon sympathizer role, but it's meant to be played with 5 players.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Demoed, purchased and played at Gencon.  It's the best game of the con in my opinion.  Just drips flavor. 

After 10 plays, the rating dipped a bit as each game feels a bit samey.  Still good, I just am not being pulled back to it as much as I thought I would.

UPDATE:  Still dropping in rating.  I find I am having less fun each time it hits the table.  It's overlong for what it is.

RATING: 10
Kiemelkedően jó paranoia játék. Remek taktikai lehetőségek vannak benne. Bár hosszú, de minden perce izgalmas és pörgős. Nincs két egyforma menet, mindig vannak meglepetések. Bár kell hozzá egy jó csapat, és az összes kiegészítő, hogy igazán megmutassa az erejét. Sértődősöknek nem ajánlom.
